#↩

For Cally, Edie, and Kate

With love and gratitude

#↩

For every complex problem, there is a solution that is simple, neat, and wrong.

对于每一个复杂的问题，都存在一个简单、简洁但却错误的解决方案。

—JOURNALIST AND ESSAYIST H. L. MENCKEN

——记者兼散文家H·L·门肯

#↩

[ 1 ] Embracing Chaos

[ 1 ] 拥抱混乱

As manager of a private investment firm, Jay Sheldon bought a small cable television company in the Midwest some years ago. He didn’t know much about the industry, but the $8 million price seemed right, and the purchase would let him test the water. Jay and his partners quickly got the business into the black. A year later, they wanted to expand by acquiring nearby systems. After running the numbers, they figured that they could pay $11 million, maybe $12 million tops, to buy a second cable company in a neighboring city.

作为一家私人投资公司的经理，杰伊·谢尔顿几年前收购了中西部一家小型有线电视公司。他对这个行业了解不多，但800万美元的价格在他看来很合适，而且这次收购也能让他试水。杰伊和他的合伙人很快就让公司扭亏为盈。一年后，他们想通过收购附近的公司来扩张业务。经过一番计算，他们认为收购邻近城市的第二家有线电视公司最多需要1100万美元，也许最多1200万美元。

Jay began an extended series of talks with its owner, but after two months of back-and-forth, it became obvious that the parties were far apart on price. “Listen,” the other owner said. “I didn’t post a For Sale sign. You came to me. You’d have to dump fifteen million in cash right on my desk to tempt me. And I’d probably kick myself if I took it.”

杰伊开始与房主进行一系列长时间的谈判，但经过两个月的反复磋商，双方在价格上显然存在巨大分歧。“听着，”对方房主说，“我没挂出‘出售’的牌子。是你主动来找我的。你得直接把一千五百万美元现金扔到我桌子上才能打动我。就算我收下了，我可能也会后悔。”

Sheldon understood that this wasn’t a bluff, but he also felt the demand was unrealistic. By conventional logic, the parties were deadlocked. If a seller’s bottom line is three million higher than the buyer’s absolute top dollar, you can’t have a deal.

谢尔顿明白这不是虚张声势，但他同时也觉得这个要求不切实际。按照常理，双方陷入了僵局。如果卖方的底价比买方的最高出价高出三百万美元，那交易就不可能达成。

Or can you?

或者你能做到吗？

“Let me ask one last question,” Sheldon said before getting up to leave. “If you think your system is worth fifteen million, how about ours?”

“让我问最后一个问题，”谢尔顿起身离开前说道，“如果你认为你的系统价值一千五百万美元，那我们的系统呢？”

“Oh, yours is a bit smaller,” was the answer. “I’d say fourteen or so.”

“哦，你的要小一些，”对方回答说，“我估计大概十四个左右。”

Sheldon turned the deal upside down. He adroitly became the seller instead of a buyer . In a little more than a year, he flipped his own system for almost twice what his firm had paid for it (and much of that had been leveraged). He was still bullish on cable, but when he encountered this particular owner, who was rabid about the industry, Sheldon had the agility to transform an apparent impasse into a lucrative sale.

谢尔顿彻底扭转了局面。他巧妙地从买家变成了卖家。一年多一点的时间里，他以几乎是公司当初购买价格两倍的价格（而且其中大部分还是杠杆融资）转手卖掉了自己的系统。他仍然看好有线电视行业，但当他遇到这位对这个行业狂热的老板时，谢尔顿凭借敏捷的思维，将看似僵局的交易转化为了一笔利润丰厚的买卖。

His solution was clever. More important, though, was his nimble mind-set. In the impediment to his hoped-for acquisition, Sheldon spotted the seed of another deal that would serve him even better. When he let go of his initial plan, the insight arrived in a flash.

他的解决方案很巧妙。但更重要的是他敏捷的思维。在收购计划受阻的过程中，谢尔顿看到了另一笔交易的契机，这笔交易对他更有利。当他放弃最初的计划时，灵感瞬间涌现。

Sheldon’s agility is the mark of a master negotiator. Yes, preparation is important, but negotiation is a two-way street. We can’t script the process. Whoever sits across the table from us may be just as smart, determined, and fallible as we are. We can’t dictate their agendas, attitudes, or actions any more than we’d let them dominate us. Adaptability is imperative in negotiation from start to finish. Opportunities will pop up. So will obstacles. Power ebbs and flows. Talks that crawl along can race forward or veer off in another direction. Even our own objectives may evolve. We have to make the best of whatever unfolds.

谢尔顿的敏捷身手正是谈判高手的标志。没错，准备工作固然重要，但谈判是双向的。我们无法预先设定谈判流程。坐在我们对面的人可能和我们一样聪明、坚定，也可能犯错。我们既不能左右他们的议程、态度或行动，也不能让他们支配我们。从始至终，适应能力在谈判中都至关重要。机遇会不断涌现，障碍也会随之而来。权力此消彼长。进展缓慢的谈判可能突然加速，也可能偏离方向。甚至我们自身的目标也可能发生变化。我们必须尽力应对一切可能发生的情况。

Negotiators like Sheldon are great improvisers. When things aren’t going well, they’ll float a clever proposal, crack a joke, or even challenge the other side. If need be, they’ll also make major changes in strategy. What’s odd, though, is that there isn’t much about improvising in standard negotiation books. That’s true both for the hardball manuals on dominating the other side and for the “win-win” texts that preach joint problem solving. In spite of their obvious differences, both approaches start with the same static premise that you have your given interests and I have mine. The win-win message is that by laying your cards on the table, you can expand the pie by making mutually beneficial trades. The hardball line tells you to chest your cards (and maybe slip a couple up your sleeve).

像谢尔顿这样的谈判者都是即兴发挥的高手。当谈判进展不顺利时，他们会提出巧妙的提议，开个玩笑，甚至挑战对方。如有必要，他们还会对策略做出重大调整。然而，奇怪的是，标准的谈判书籍中很少提及即兴发挥。无论是教你如何压制对方的强硬谈判手册，还是提倡共同解决问题的“双赢”理论，都存在这个问题。尽管两者之间存在明显的差异，但两种方法都基于同一个静态前提：你有你的利益，我有我的利益。“双赢”理论认为，通过公开自己的底牌，你可以做出互惠互利的交易，从而扩大利益蛋糕。而强硬谈判的论调则告诉你把底牌藏在胸前（或许还可以偷偷藏几张）。

But there’s much more to negotiation than bluffing and trading. The challenge lies in the fact that preferences, options, and relationships are typically in flux. Theorists may have sidestepped this reality, but top negotiators understand this very well.

但谈判远不止虚张声势和讨价还价。真正的挑战在于，偏好、选择和关系通常都在不断变化。理论家们或许回避了这一现实，但顶尖谈判者对此却了如指掌。

I’ve seen this in my own research and also thanks to the work of colleagues at the Program on Negotiation (a cross-disciplinary consortium of negotiation experts at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Tufts University). In a ten-year project led by Jim Sebenius, we’ve analyzed the work of great negotiators in a wide range of fields. They’ve included diplomats such as George Mitchell, who mediated peace in Northern Ireland; investment banker Bruce Wasserstein; and the visionary artists Christo and Jeanne-Claude.

我在自己的研究中发现了这一点，这也要感谢谈判项目（一个由哈佛大学、麻省理工学院和塔夫茨大学的谈判专家组成的跨学科联盟）的同事们的工作。在吉姆·塞贝纽斯领导的一项为期十年的项目中，我们分析了各个领域杰出谈判者的工作。其中包括调解北爱尔兰和平的外交官乔治·米切尔；投资银行家布鲁斯·沃瑟斯坦；以及富有远见的艺术家克里斯托和珍妮-克劳德。

The contexts in which these virtuosos negotiated differed. Their personalities ran the gamut as well. Some had a certain gravitas, while others were warm and entertaining—even funny. Yet in our workshops with them, they all emphasized the dynamic nature of negotiation and the importance of agility. The late ambassador Richard Holbrooke, who forged the accord ending the bloodshed in the Balkans, described negotiation as being more like jazz than science. “It’s an improvisation on a theme,” he said. “You know where you want to go, but you don’t know how to get there. It’s not linear.”

这些谈判大师所处的谈判环境各不相同，他们的个性也千差万别。有些人沉稳内敛，有些人则热情风趣，甚至幽默风趣。然而，在我们与他们共同举办的研讨会上，他们都强调了谈判的动态性和灵活性的重要性。已故大使理查德·霍尔布鲁克促成了结束巴尔干地区流血冲突的协议，他将谈判比作爵士乐而非科学。“它就像围绕一个主题的即兴演奏，”他说，“你知道你想去哪里，但你不知道该如何到达那里。它并非线性发展。”

UN special envoy Lakhdar Brahimi, having mediated in some of the world’s most violent and unpredictable trouble spots, used a nautical metaphor to express the same idea. Negotiators must always “navigate by sight,” he cautioned. No matter how diligently we prepare, we’re bound to encounter surprises, pleasant and otherwise, that warrant course corrections.

联合国特使拉克达尔·卜拉希米曾在世界上一些最暴力、最难以预测的冲突地区进行调解，他用航海的比喻表达了同样的观点。他告诫说，谈判者必须始终“凭眼见为准”。无论我们准备得多么充分，都难免会遇到意想不到的情况，无论是令人愉快的还是令人不快的，都需要我们及时调整方向。

Donald Dell, the sports agent-marketer, made his mark by hammering out huge contracts for basketball players Patrick Ewing and Moses Malone and earning millions in endorsement deals for tennis stars Arthur Ashe and Jimmy Connors. He’s orchestrated bidding wars between rival television networks for broadcasting rights to events like the French Open.

体育经纪人兼营销专家唐纳德·戴尔（Donald Dell）凭借为篮球运动员帕特里克·尤因（Patrick Ewing）和摩西·马龙（Moses Malone）敲定巨额合同，以及为网球明星阿瑟·阿什（Arthur Ashe）和吉米·康纳斯（Jimmy Connors）赚取数百万美元的代言费而声名鹊起。他还曾策划各大电视台之间为争夺法国网球公开赛等赛事的转播权而展开竞标。

Dell has also done very well negotiating on his own behalf. In 1998 he sold his sports management firm ProServ to an entertainment company for what he describes as “the proverbial offer I couldn’t refuse.” A few years later, after buying much of it back for twenty cents on the dollar, he then resold his interest to Lagadère Unlimited, where he is group president in charge of TV deals, events, and tennis.

戴尔在谈判方面也做得非常出色。1998年，他将自己的体育管理公司ProServ出售给一家娱乐公司，他称之为“无法拒绝的天价”。几年后，他又以原价的五分之一的价格购回了大部分股份，随后将剩余股份转售给了拉加代尔集团（Lagadère Unlimited）。目前，他担任该集团总裁，负责电视转播、赛事和网球业务。

For all his success, though, Dell is quick to say that things often don’t go according to plan. “I can’t tell you how many times I arrived prepared for a negotiation, only to have someone or something come up that upset or changed the deal I thought I was doing. The only way to protect yourself one hundred percent against this situation is to assume there is something you don’t know. This advice will not only keep your mind up to speed with the deal and force you to consider other parties’ motivations, but it will also keep your ego in check.”

尽管戴尔取得了诸多成功，但他总是坦言，事情往往不会按计划进行。“我数不清有多少次，我做好了充分的谈判准备，结果却因为某些人或事而感到沮丧，或者改变了我原先以为达成的交易。要想百分之百避免这种情况，唯一的办法就是假设存在你不知道的事情。这条建议不仅能让你始终掌握交易的最新进展，迫使你考虑对方的动机，还能让你保持谦逊。”

LEARNING, ADAPTING, AND INFLUENCING

学习、适应和影响

Lesser known but highly talented deal makers make the same point. Tom Green is a remarkable negotiator who has worked in both the private and public sectors. Tom was a key figure in the sale of a storied baseball franchise and helped restructure a failing health maintenance organization (HMO) that many thought was headed for bankruptcy.

一些名气不大但才华横溢的交易撮合者也持相同观点。汤姆·格林是一位杰出的谈判专家，曾在私营部门和公共部门都工作过。他曾是出售一支历史悠久的棒球特许经营权的关键人物，并帮助重组了一家濒临破产的健康维护组织（HMO）。

Tom also served on the public interest team that resolved massive litigation against the tobacco industry. Until that time, Big Tobacco had never lost a case or paid a dime to settle health claims out of court. When Mississippi, Massachusetts, and a few other states filed suit to recover Medicaid costs for smoking-related illnesses, their effort seemed quixotic. Yet one by one, Green and his colleagues enlisted forty other states to join the effort. That momentum brought the tobacco companies to the bargaining table. In 1998 the industry bowed to more stringent regulation and agreed to pay $350 billion in damages.

汤姆还曾参与公共利益团队，该团队成功解决了针对烟草行业的巨额诉讼。在此之前，大型烟草公司从未败诉，也从未支付过一分钱用于庭外和解健康索赔。当密西西比州、马萨诸塞州和其他几个州提起诉讼，要求追回因吸烟相关疾病而产生的医疗补助费用时，他们的努力似乎徒劳无功。然而，格林和他的同事们逐一争取到了其他四十个州的加入。这股势头最终迫使烟草公司坐到了谈判桌前。1998年，烟草行业屈服于更严格的监管，并同意支付3500亿美元的赔偿金。

I wrote a case study about this meganegotiation for my MBA course. Tom visited the class the first time I taught it and listened as students analyzed the deft coalition building and old-fashioned horse trading that led to the unexpected outcome. Near the end of the discussion, I asked Tom for his own conclusions. After complimenting students on their observations, he added something that surprised them. The secret of his success, he said, has been “making chaos my friend in negotiation.”

我为我的MBA课程撰写了一份关于这场大型谈判的案例研究。汤姆在我第一次授课时来听课，他聆听了学生们分析如何巧妙地构建联盟，以及如何运用传统的谈判技巧最终促成了出人意料的结果。讨论接近尾声时，我请汤姆分享他自己的结论。在赞扬了学生们的观察之后，他补充了一些令他们惊讶的内容。他说，他成功的秘诀在于“在谈判中化混乱为友”。

When Tom speaks about embracing chaos, he’s not talking merely about cases involving scores of parties, thorny issues, and messy politics. Rather, he knows that all negotiations, large and small, are chaotic, since they take place in fluid and often unpredictable environments. But that’s not to say that negotiation is random. The process is propelled by how the parties interact. Understanding how seemingly small moves or gestures can change the course of negotiation can mean the difference between agreement and deadlock.

汤姆谈到拥抱混乱时，并非仅仅指涉及众多参与方、棘手问题和复杂政治的案例。他深知，所有谈判，无论大小，都带有混乱的成分，因为它们发生在瞬息万变、难以预测的环境中。但这并不意味着谈判是随机的。谈判过程是由各方的互动推动的。理解看似微小的举动或姿态如何改变谈判走向，往往决定着最终是达成协议还是陷入僵局。

Saying that negotiators like Tom are agile improvisers doesn’t mean that they make everything up as they go along. Far from it. They’re well prepared, but they don’t hobble themselves with rigid plans. They understand that effective negotiation demands rapid cycles of learning, adapting, and influencing.

说像汤姆这样的谈判者是灵活的即兴者，并不意味着他们完全凭感觉行事。恰恰相反。他们准备充分，但不会用僵化的计划束缚自己。他们明白，有效的谈判需要快速地学习、调整和施加影响。

Each of those italicized words is critical. Learning, adapting, and influencing take place in most negotiations, of course, but all too often only by happenstance. Instead, I’m talking about deliberate learning. It entails updating your expectations on three levels: (1) the scope of the issues under discussion, (2) the best means for resolving them, and (3) the nature of your relationship with counterparts. “Another way of saying it,” Ambassador Brahimi asserts, “is keep an open mind and be ready to change and adapt to the situation. Don’t ask reality to conform to your blueprint, but transform your blueprint to adapt to reality.”

这些斜体字中的每一个都至关重要。学习、适应和影响当然在大多数谈判中都会发生，但往往只是偶然发生的。我指的是有意识的学习。这需要在三个层面上更新你的预期：(1) 讨论问题的范围；(2) 解决这些问题的最佳途径；(3) 你与对方的关系性质。“换句话说，”布拉希米大使强调，“要保持开放的心态，随时准备改变和适应情况。不要要求现实符合你的蓝图，而是要调整你的蓝图以适应现实。”

The learning can’t be passive. It’s not like browsing in a store, checking stock prices, or reading a text. Latent information in those contexts is unchanging. A book has the same number of pages whether you skim it or read it word for word. But the fact is that much of what you must learn in negotiation can only come by interacting with the other party. Let’s say that you reveal your priorities to your counterparts, hoping to foster a cooperative exchange. If you’re right, you may proceed down a collaborative path. But if, instead, they interpret your disclosure as a sign of weakness, the negotiation could take a turn you wouldn’t have chosen.

学习不能是被动的。它不像逛商店、查看股票价格或阅读文本那样。在这些情境下，潜在信息是一成不变的。一本书无论你是略读还是逐字阅读，页数都一样。但事实是，谈判中你必须学习的大部分内容只能通过与对方互动才能获得。假设你向对方透露了自己的优先事项，希望促进合作交流。如果你的判断正确，你们或许能够朝着合作的方向发展。但如果对方将你的坦诚解读为软弱的表现，谈判的走向就可能出乎你的意料。

Or you make a proposal. It doesn’t work for them. They counter with something that’s not so hot from your point of view. But the two ideas together prompt both of you to come up with a third option that neither party would have conjured on its own. When the issue under discussion changes, you must adapt accordingly. It may be a slight adjustment, or, as it was with Jay Sheldon, it may be a major shift.

或者你提出一个方案，对方不接受。他们提出的方案在你看来也不尽如人意。但这两个想法结合起来，促使你们双方想出第三种选择，而这是任何一方单独都想不到的。当讨论的问题发生变化时，你必须做出相应的调整。这可能只是细微的调整，或者，就像杰伊·谢尔顿的情况一样，可能是一次重大的转变。

Likewise, you seek to influence those on the other side, to convince them of the value of what you’re offering. What they say in response—and how they say it—speaks to that particular point, but it is also feedback on how effectively you’re engaging your counterpart. Maybe your style suits them. If not, you’ll need to change your approach. Beyond the dollars and cents of a potential deal, you are negotiating how to negotiate.

同样，你也要努力影响对方，让他们相信你所提供产品或服务的价值。他们的回应——以及他们的回应方式——不仅体现了这一点，也反映了你与对方沟通的有效性。也许你的风格很适合他们。如果不是，你就需要改变策略。除了潜在交易的金额之外，你还在协商如何谈判。

SUCCESS AND FAILURE

成功与失败

Decades ago, in a low-rise section of Manhattan, the governing board of a church on a corner lot asked the Julien Studley real estate firm to conduct an appraisal. Board members hoped that they could fetch a price that would allow them to build elsewhere and have enough money left over to fund their social programs. The firm’s figure was far less than they needed, however, so the church paid the appraisal fee and abandoned its plan.

几十年前，在曼哈顿一处低层街区，一家教堂的理事会委托朱利安·斯图德利房地产公司对一块街角地块进行估价。理事会成员希望估价后，教堂可以在别处重建，并且还能剩下足够的资金来支持他们的社会项目。然而，该公司给出的估价远低于他们的预期，因此教堂支付了估价费，放弃了原先的计划。

The young broker handling the matter had another idea, though. What if he could somehow acquire all the parcels on the block? The whole assembly would be worth far more than its component parts. But there were lots of challenges. For starters, his firm didn’t have the resources to buy all the properties, nor did it have a deep-pocketed buyer lined up. And there was the risk that its acquisitions would invite competitors and potential holdouts.

负责此事的年轻经纪人却另有打算。如果他能设法收购这片街区的所有地块呢？整体价值将远远超过各部分价值的总和。但这其中困难重重。首先，他的公司没有足够的资金购买所有房产，也没有找到财力雄厚的买家。此外，收购还可能招致竞争对手和潜在的反对者。

It took time, but the broker and his firm pulled it off. Parcel by parcel, they met the different needs of various owners. They paid the moving expenses of some elderly tenants in one case. In another, they kept a restaurant open so that its employees would have work until construction began. They even worked out a condo arrangement in which the church could rebuild on its current land. But the firm also got tough with potential competitors. If you ever happen to be in Midtown, just look up, and you can see the result: the gleaming Citibank tower with its sharply angled top. The story of how it came to be offers powerful lessons about adaptive, improvisational negotiation.

虽然耗时良久，但经纪人和他的公司最终成功了。他们逐块地满足了不同业主的各种需求。例如，他们为一位年迈的租户支付了搬迁费用；又如，他们让一家餐厅继续营业，确保员工在施工开始前有工作可做；他们甚至还达成了一项公寓协议，让教堂得以在现有土地上重建。但这家公司也对潜在的竞争对手采取了强硬态度。如果你有机会去曼哈顿中城，抬头看看，就能看到最终的成果：闪闪发光的花旗银行大厦，其顶部棱角分明。这座大厦的建造过程为我们提供了关于灵活应变、即兴谈判的宝贵经验。

Other cases don’t end as well. The board of a co-op apartment building enacted a rule requiring everyone to install and pay for child safety bars in the windows. One particular owner refused to pay, insisting that the board pick up the cost: in that case, $902. The board, made up of his neighbors in the building, felt compelled to uphold its legal authority and filed suit, hoping the owner would relent. Instead, he retained his own attorney, and the parties were off to the litigation races.

其他一些案例的结局则不那么美好。某合作公寓楼的业主委员会制定了一项规定，要求所有住户在窗户上安装并支付儿童安全防护栏的费用。其中一位业主拒绝支付，坚持要求业主委员会承担这笔费用：902美元。业主委员会由他的邻居组成，他们认为有必要维护自身的合法权益，于是提起诉讼，希望这位业主能够让步。然而，他并没有就此罢休，而是聘请了自己的律师，双方就此展开了一场旷日持久的诉讼。

The co-op board won before the trial judge, lost on appeal, and then got the original judgment reinstated by a still higher court. This battle dragged out almost five years. By that time, their combined legal bills had ballooned to more than $80,000—almost one hundred times the amount originally at stake.

合作公寓委员会在初审法官面前胜诉，上诉失败，之后又通过更高一级法院的诉讼恢复了原判。这场官司持续了近五年。到那时，他们的诉讼费用总额已超过8万美元——几乎是最初争议金额的100倍。

They weren’t finished, either. The objecting owner gave up trying to overturn the judgment, but the parties turned to fighting over whether he had to reimburse the board for its legal costs. When they were finally done, they had broken through the $100,000 barrier.

事情还没完。提出异议的业主放弃了推翻判决的努力，但双方转而争论他是否需要赔偿董事会的诉讼费用。最终，这场官司的金额突破了10万美元大关。

From the start, each side assumed that the other would come to its senses and abandon the fight. Instead, they both dug themselves ever deeper and kept on shoveling. Nobody planned on investing so much time, money, and emotion in a lose-lose proposition, yet that’s the outcome they got.

从一开始，双方都以为对方会幡然醒悟，放弃争斗。然而，他们却越陷越深，纠缠不休。谁也没想到会在一场注定失败的博弈中投入如此多的时间、金钱和情感，但最终的结果却恰恰如此。

The apartment owner himself finally learned his lesson. “I’m a man converted,” he said afterward. “Anything you can possibly do to avoid a lawsuit, do it.” The lawyer for the co-op’s board wasn’t chastened, though. “I think the expenditures here were appropriate and were pretty much kept to a minimum,” he said. He claimed that his clients “had an idea of what was going on” throughout the case. “There were no surprises.” His attitude betrays a fatalistic commitment to a strategy even when there’s mounting evidence that it’s not working.

公寓业主本人最终也吸取了教训。“我彻底改变了看法，”他事后说道，“任何能避免诉讼的事情，都一定要去做。” 然而，合作公寓委员会的律师却毫无悔意。“我认为这里的支出是合理的，而且已经控制在最低限度了，”他说道。他声称他的客户在整个案件过程中“都清楚发生了什么”。“一切都在预料之中。” 即使越来越多的证据表明这种策略行不通，他的态度仍然流露出一种宿命论式的执着。

Maybe the owner could have “donated” $902 for some other common use without having to back down on the legal principle. Or another resident, caught in the cross fire, might have made the case go away by anonymously sending the board $902 in cash to cover the cost of the window bars—a bargain compared with being assessed for the mushrooming legal costs. The fiasco also might have been averted if just one board member had asked the right question when they filed suit: namely, What’s the worst thing that could happen here? An obvious answer would be that the owner would be just as obstinate as they were.

或许业主可以把这902美元“捐赠”用于其他公共用途，而无需在法律原则上妥协。或者，另一位被卷入这场纷争的居民，可以匿名向业主委员会汇款902美元现金，用于支付窗户护栏的费用，从而平息这场风波——与承担不断飙升的诉讼费用相比，这简直是小菜一碟。如果当时有一位业主委员会成员在提起诉讼时问对了问题，这场闹剧或许也能避免：那就是，最糟糕的情况会是什么？一个显而易见的答案是，业主会像他们一样固执己见。

Cookie-cutter strategies crumble in the turbulence of real-world negotiation. Persistence is often a virtue, but clinging to an obsolete plan is not. Jay Sheldon was intent on buying the nearby cable system. When it became clear that its owner wouldn’t budge on price, however, he didn’t try to beat him down further or cave on his own valuation of that business. Nor did he walk away. Instead, he adapted by crafting a superior plan B. But remember that it was Sheldon’s agility that made it all happen. His counterpart, sitting at the same table, looking at exactly the same facts, didn’t imagine being a buyer until Jay proposed it.

千篇一律的策略在现实世界谈判的动荡中不堪一击。坚持固然是美德，但死守过时的计划却并非如此。杰伊·谢尔顿一心想收购附近的有线电视系统。然而，当他意识到对方老板在价格上寸步不让时，他并没有试图进一步压低价格，也没有降低自己对这家公司的估值。他更没有就此放弃。相反，他迅速调整策略，制定了一个更优的备选方案。但请记住，正是谢尔顿的灵活应变才成就了这一切。他的对手坐在同一张桌子旁，面对着完全相同的事实，却从未想过自己会成为买家，直到杰伊提出收购方案。

WHAT’S MISSING IN THE CONVENTIONAL WISDOM

传统观念中缺失了什么？

The groundbreaking negotiation text Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In, by my colleagues Roger Fisher, Bill Ury, and Bruce Patton, was first published thirty years ago. Its timing couldn’t have been better. The book offered a constructive alternative to the then prevailing view that negotiation is inevitably a win-lose proposition, a game won by muscle and deception. Many people were weary with conflict, however, whether in protracted litigation, work stoppages, or in troubled areas of the world like the Middle East.

我的同事罗杰·费舍尔、比尔·尤里和布鲁斯·帕顿合著的开创性谈判著作《谈判力：如何在不妥协的情况下达成协议》于三十年前首次出版。它的出版时机可谓恰到好处。这本书为当时盛行的“谈判必然是一场零和博弈，靠蛮力和欺骗取胜”的观点提供了一种建设性的替代方案。然而，无论是旷日持久的诉讼、罢工，还是中东等动荡地区的冲突，许多人都已厌倦了各种矛盾。

The authors presented a five-point method, one relevant to any context, from renting an apartment to international diplomacy:

作者提出了一种五点方法，该方法适用于任何情境，从租房到国际外交都适用：

1. Focus on interests, not positions.

1. 关注兴趣，而不是立场。

2. Separate the people from the problem.

2. 将人与问题分开。

3. Invent options for mutual gain.

3. 创造互利共赢的选择。

4. Insist on objective criteria.

4. 坚持客观标准。

5. Develop your best alternative to a negotiated agreement, or BATNA (your walkaway if there is no deal).

5. 制定谈判协议的最佳替代方案，或 BATNA（如果无法达成协议，你的最终选择）。

This interest-based approach was widely embraced as win-win negotiation (although that term never appears in Getting to Yes ). At the core, it was an appeal to enlightened self-interest.

这种基于利益的谈判方法被广泛接受为双赢谈判（尽管“双赢”一词从未出现在《谈判力》一书中）。其核心在于诉诸明智的利己主义。

The book remains a strong rebuttal to old-fashioned hardball tactics. Rather than locking into fixed positions, negotiators should dig deeper and work from underlying interests. If you’re seeking a new job, don’t haggle over salary and risk getting the relationship off to a bad start. Instead, look for other benefits that might be more valuable than a few more dollars of straight pay. With a little inventiveness, you can transform many zero-sum problems into opportunities for mutual gain. And even tough bargainers with no concern about fairness should be tempted by the prospect of expanding the pie.

这本书依然是对老套强硬谈判策略的有力反驳。谈判者不应固守成规，而应深入挖掘，从根本利益出发。如果你正在寻找新工作，不要在薪资上斤斤计较，以免一开始就破坏双方关系。相反，你应该寻找其他可能比多挣几块钱更有价值的东西。只要稍加创意，你就能将许多零和博弈的问题转化为互利共赢的机会。即使是那些不讲公平的铁腕谈判者，也应该被“把蛋糕做大”的前景所吸引。

Readers were also reminded of the importance of relationships and reputation. Aggressive tactics may work in one-time, price-only transactions between strangers, but there are costs. Most people who’ve been strong-armed once don’t come back for another drubbing. Books such as Jim Camp’s Start with No: America’s Number One Negotiating Coach Explains Why Win-Win Is a Disastrous Strategy, and How You Can Beat It ignore the fact that in today’s highly networked world, what goes around often comes around. Nor do they explain what’s achieved if both parties stonewall and just wait for somebody to blink.

读者也被提醒人际关系和声誉的重要性。咄咄逼人的策略或许在陌生人之间一次性的、仅以价格为导向的交易中奏效，但代价是巨大的。大多数被胁迫过一次的人都不会再上当受骗。像吉姆·坎普的《从“不”开始：美国顶级谈判教练解释为什么“双赢”是一种灾难性的策略，以及你如何战胜它》这样的书籍忽略了一个事实：在当今高度网络化的世界里，善恶终有报。它们也没有解释，如果双方都采取僵持不下的策略，只是等待对方露出破绽，最终会得到什么。

Sometimes the bargaining table is tilted, of course. When that’s the case, Getting to Yes emphasizes the importance of improving one’s BATNA. It’s a matter of weighing offers on the table against the best you realistically can do if there’s no deal. Having a good fallback naturally strengthens your bargaining hand. If you’re holding lousy cards, then you may have to accept terms that you’re not wild about.

当然，谈判桌上的局势有时也会处于不利地位。在这种情况下，《谈判力》强调了完善自身最佳替代方案（BATNA）的重要性。这需要权衡现有报价与如果无法达成协议，你实际能做到的最佳方案。拥有一个可靠的备选方案自然会增强你的谈判筹码。如果你手握劣势，那么你可能不得不接受一些你并不十分满意的条款。

So two cheers for win-win negotiation. Books based on that model freed negotiators from the notion that “more for you means less for me.” They opened people’s minds to the problem-solving potential latent in many negotiations. A lot of good work on negotiation has been done since the publication of Getting to Yes . But the basic framework rests implicitly on static assumptions about interests, options, circumstances, and relationships, when these factors tend to be fluid and ambiguous. Just as military strategists acknowledge the fog of war, negotiators must confront the haze that obscures the territory that they explore.

所以，让我们为双赢谈判喝彩！基于这种模式的书籍使谈判者摆脱了“你得到的越多，我的损失就越少”的观念。它们启发人们认识到许多谈判中蕴藏的解决问题的潜力。自《谈判力》（Getting to Yes）出版以来，关于谈判的研究成果层出不穷。然而，其基本框架隐含地建立在关于利益、选择、环境和关系的静态假设之上，而这些因素往往是流动且模糊的。正如军事战略家承认战争迷雾的存在一样，谈判者也必须直面笼罩着他们探索领域的迷雾。

The standard model doesn’t capture the complexity of real-world negotiation any more than stuffed birds in a museum reveal the marvel of flight, or show us how those creatures dart and soar in the breeze. Instead of a snapshot, we need a moving picture that illuminates how the negotiation process evolves over time. That’s the aim of this book.

标准模型无法捕捉现实世界谈判的复杂性，就像博物馆里的鸟类标本无法展现飞行的奇妙，也无法向我们展示这些生物如何在微风中翱翔一样。我们需要的不是一张快照，而是一幅动态的画面，它能阐明谈判过程如何随时间演变。这正是本书的目标。

I’m not out on a limb saying that basic win-win theory whistles past thorny negotiation problems. Roger Fisher himself often began presentations by ripping his bestseller in two to demonstrate the need for fresh thinking. To see why, take a second look at two celebrated axioms on which the conventional model rests. One is “Focus on interests, not positions.” The other is “Develop your BATNA” (your walkaway option).

我并非妄言，基本的双赢理论对棘手的谈判问题视而不见。罗杰·费舍尔本人就经常在演讲开始时，将自己的畅销书撕成两半，以此来说明需要新的思维方式。要理解这一点，不妨重新审视一下传统模式所依赖的两条著名原则。一条是“关注利益，而非立场”。另一条是“制定你的最佳替代方案”（BATNA，即你的退路）。

First, regarding interests, the hard truth is that we often can’t know what our interests are until we’re really negotiating. The suggestion that we don’t know our own minds may seem strange, even insulting. But seasoned negotiators know this well. Bear with me.

首先，关于利益，残酷的现实是，我们往往只有在真正谈判时才能了解自己的利益所在。这种“我们不了解自己的想法”的说法或许听起来很奇怪，甚至有点侮辱人。但经验丰富的谈判者对此心知肚明。请听我慢慢道来。

Negotiation often leads us somewhere unexpected, sometimes happily so. Say that you’re trying to buy a particular house. After analyzing the market (and your bank account), you swear that the absolute maximum you’ll pay is $350,000, preferably much less. Yet several days later, you shell out $375,000 to close the deal. Does that mean you negotiated badly? Possibly, if you got fast-talked into overpaying. Then again, maybe not. Violating your initial limit could make sense if the property proved to be in better shape than you expected or you learned that similar homes in the area recently sold for much more. You paid more than you planned to, but maybe you still got a bargain.

谈判常常会把我们引向意想不到的方向，有时甚至是惊喜。假设你想买一套房子。在分析了市场行情（以及你的银行账户）之后，你信誓旦旦地说，你的最高预算是35万美元，最好是更低一些。然而几天后，你却支付了37.5万美元完成了交易。这是否意味着你的谈判策略失败了呢？如果你被花言巧语哄骗着支付了过高的价格，那或许是这样。但也不一定。如果房子比你预想的状况要好，或者你了解到附近类似的房子最近都卖了更高的价格，那么突破最初的预算限制也并非不可能。你最终支付的价格可能比计划的要高，但或许你仍然捡了个大便宜。

Interests are fluid, so we need to be flexible ourselves. But that complicates negotiation strategy and decision making. Stable goals give us discipline. They help us know when to say yes and when to walk away. If we dispense with objectives, we can rationalize any outcome. Surely that can’t be right. When Tom Green told my students about the importance of embracing the chaos of negotiation, he tacked on a critical corollary. It’s imperative, he said, “to stay on beam.”

利益瞬息万变，所以我们自身也需要灵活变通。但这会使谈判策略和决策变得复杂。稳定的目标能让我们保持自律，帮助我们判断何时该答应，何时该放弃。如果我们放弃目标，就能为任何结果找到合理的解释。这肯定不对。汤姆·格林在向我的学生讲述拥抱谈判混乱的重要性时，还补充了一个至关重要的推论。他说，关键在于“保持专注”。

Likewise, the BATNA concept is crisp in theory but messy in practice. It presumes that negotiations come down to a simple decision: deal or no deal. Were that true, whenever someone offers you something slightly better than your walkaway, you should take it. That could mean settling cheap when, with some creativity, you might grow the pie (or by persisting, get a larger slice of it). Then again, you don’t want to push so hard that you risk losing what you already have in hand. Knowing when to say yes can be tricky.

同样，BATNA（最佳替代方案）的概念理论上很清晰，但实践中却很混乱。它假定谈判最终归结为一个简单的决定：成交或不成交。如果真是这样，那么只要有人提出比你的底线略好的方案，你就应该接受。这可能意味着你本可以发挥创造力，把蛋糕做大（或者坚持不懈地争取更大的份额），却不得不做出妥协。当然，你也不想用力过猛，以至于失去已经拥有的东西。何时说“是”其实很难把握。

The standard BATNA model also isn’t helpful when you’re negotiating with no clear fallback. Just ask a business school graduate interviewing for jobs with no other offer in hand. When she’s negotiating with one company, her BATNA is the uncertain prospect of landing a position elsewhere. How should she figure her walkaway when she has no immediate options? Few books address this common problem. This one does.

当你在没有明确退路的情况下进行谈判时，标准的最佳替代方案（BATNA）模型也无济于事。不妨问问那些正在面试但没有其他offer的商学院毕业生。当她只与一家公司谈判时，她的最佳替代方案就是找到其他工作的不确定前景。当她没有其他选择时，她该如何确定自己的底线？很少有书会探讨这个常见问题。而这本书做到了。

The elusiveness of interests and messiness of BATNAs collide when you have to juggle multiple negotiations. That’s what happens when you comparison shop for a car at several dealerships. You may know generally what kind of vehicle you’d like, but you still want a great price. When you’re negotiating with one salesperson, your fallback is often the uncertain prospect of how well you might do with another.

当你需要同时处理多方谈判时，利益的复杂性和最佳替代方案（BATNA）的混乱局面就会相互碰撞。当你同时在几家经销商处比价购买汽车时，这种情况就会发生。你可能大致知道自己想要什么样的车，但你仍然希望价格优惠。当你与一位销售人员谈判时，你往往会因为不确定能否与其他销售人员达成协议而退缩。

My colleague (call her Carol Griffin) and her husband, Don, faced this problem when they were looking for their first house. Carol is a brilliant decision theorist, so her preparation was off the charts. She researched the local market and compared school systems. She even test drove different commuting routes. Then she plugged all the data into a spreadsheet and weighted the factors so that they could rank different properties.

我的同事（姑且称她为卡罗尔·格里芬）和她的丈夫唐在寻找第一套房子时就遇到了这个问题。卡罗尔是一位杰出的决策理论专家，所以她的准备工作做得非常充分。她研究了当地市场，比较了各个学校的教育体系，甚至还亲自试驾了不同的通勤路线。然后，她把所有数据都输入到一个电子表格中，并对各项因素进行加权，以便对不同的房产进行排名。

Looking back now, however, Carol admits that she and Don didn’t know what they wanted until they toured various properties and began to negotiate. One house was priced right but needed a lot of work. Another had smaller rooms but also a gorgeous yard. Still others that had looked good online somehow had less appeal in person.

然而，卡罗尔现在回想起来承认，她和唐在参观各种房产并开始谈判之前，并不清楚自己想要什么。一套房子价格合适，但需要大量翻修。另一套房子房间较小，但院子很漂亮。还有一些房子，虽然在网上看起来不错，但实地看却没那么吸引人。

Some factors that they cared about—heating costs and the proximity to schools—were easy to compute, but how they actually felt about different places was not. With their apartment lease about to expire, they faced hard BATNA choices. For the house they loved , should they keep bargaining to knock down the price to an affordable number? Or should they settle for a less expensive place that they liked all right before some other buyer snapped up that one? (We won’t even think about how much harder this would have been if Carol and Don didn’t see eye to eye themselves.)

他们关心的一些因素——比如取暖费和离学校的远近——很容易计算，但他们对不同地方的真实感受却难以捉摸。公寓租约即将到期，他们面临着艰难的“最佳替代方案”（BATNA）选择。对于他们心仪的房子，他们应该继续讨价还价，把价格降到可以承受的范围内吗？还是应该在其他买家抢走之前，选择一套他们也喜欢但价格更低的房子？（我们甚至不敢想象，如果卡罗尔和唐自己意见不一致，情况会变得多么棘手。）

How we resolve such dilemmas isn’t put to the test until we have to decide between a given bird near at hand versus the chance of snaring a more enticing one deeper in the bush. It’s not simply how much better the latter might be objectively. We also have to reckon the odds of winning it—and taste how we’ll feel if we end up losing out on both deals.

只有当我们不得不在近在咫尺的鸟儿和灌木丛深处更诱人的猎物之间做出选择时，我们解决这类两难困境的能力才会真正经受考验。这不仅仅关乎后者客观上可能有多好，我们还必须权衡成功的概率——并体会如果两边都错失良机，我们会作何感想。

Savvy real estate brokers understand that, like the Griffins, many clients don’t really know what they want. University of Virginia psychologist Tim Wilson describes how his own agent listens politely when prospective buyers list their priorities, but then blithely ignores them and shows them many different properties. “On the initial visits, the agent pays close attention to her clients’ emotional reactions as they walk through the houses, trying to deduce what they are really looking for.” According to Wilson, brokers have a saying: “Buyers lie.” It’s not deliberate. People just don’t know their own minds. “One reason my real estate agent is so successful is that she is quite skilled at inferring what her clients want and often knows their preferences better than the clients themselves do.”

精明的房地产经纪人明白，像格里芬一家一样，很多客户其实并不清楚自己想要什么。弗吉尼亚大学心理学家蒂姆·威尔逊描述了他自己的经纪人是如何在潜在买家列出他们的优先事项时礼貌地倾听，然后却漫不经心地忽略这些，带他们看了很多不同的房产。“在最初的几次看房中，经纪人会密切关注客户在参观房屋时的情绪反应，试图推断他们真正想要的是什么。”威尔逊说，经纪人之间有一句俗语：“买家会撒谎。”这并非出于故意，而是人们自己也不清楚自己想要什么。“我的房地产经纪人如此成功的原因之一，就是她非常擅长推断客户的需求，而且往往比客户自己更了解他们的喜好。”

Carol and Don played it safe by working out a deal for the less expensive place. Sometimes, though, they get wistful driving past their dream house, four blocks away. They wonder if they could have haggled a lower price by being more assertive. But because of the inherent uncertainty of negotiation, they can never know for sure.

卡罗尔和唐为了稳妥起见，选择了价格较低的那套房子。不过，有时候开车经过四个街区外的梦想之家时，他们还是会感到惆怅。他们会想，如果当初更坚持己见，是不是就能砍价得更低一些。但由于谈判本身就充满不确定性，他们永远也无法确定。

That kind of second-guessing does little good. Instead, you’re better off critiquing how you negotiated. On this score, the Griffins did well. Carol’s meticulous preparation could only reflect attributes that were easy to quantify. It couldn’t capture how they felt about particular houses until they took their tours. Still, it served as a valuable template against which they could check their judgments. Before scratching a house that they had rated high, it forced them to ask what it was that they didn’t like and how much that mattered. They shifted their priorities but in a disciplined manner.

这种事后诸葛亮式的猜测没什么用。相反，你最好反思一下自己的谈判方式。在这方面，格里芬夫妇做得很好。卡罗尔一丝不苟的准备工作只能反映出那些容易量化的特质。在实地看房之前，它无法捕捉到他们对特定房屋的真实感受。尽管如此，它仍然为他们提供了一个宝贵的模板，可以用来检验他们的判断。在放弃一套他们评价很高的房子之前，它迫使他们思考自己不喜欢什么，以及这些不喜欢之处对他们有多重要。他们调整了优先顺序，但方式很自律。

The Griffins learned and adapted along the way. Some owners they negotiated with seemed to be testing the market on the chance that somebody would make an offer they couldn’t refuse. Others were in more of a hurry to sell, which gave the Griffins more leverage than they anticipated. In the end, the people who sold their home to the Griffins understood they were careful shoppers and gave them a price that was too good to pass up.

格里芬夫妇一路摸索学习，不断调整策略。他们遇到的一些房主似乎在试探市场，希望能找到一个无法拒绝的报价。而另一些房主则急于出手，这反而给了格里芬夫妇比预期更大的谈判筹码。最终，那些把房子卖给格里芬夫妇的房主们明白他们是精明的买家，于是给出了一个他们无法拒绝的优惠价格。

DYNAMIC NEGOTIATION

动态谈判

This book explains how to become a more agile and effective negotiator. It’s not a matter of being somewhat prepared and a little flexible. If you try that, you’ll fall between the cracks. Instead, managing uncertainty should be the cornerstone of your negotiation strategy . Part 1 lays out a dynamic model for analyzing and conducting negotiations. Part 2 is about mind-set and the techniques for learning, adapting, and influencing on the fly. Part 3 situates these concepts in each phase of negotiation, from openings, through critical moments, to closing. Part 4, “Mastery,” knits together creativity, ongoing learning, and ethics.

本书阐述了如何成为一名更灵活高效的谈判者。这并非仅仅是做好一些准备、保持一点灵活性就能实现的。如果这样做，你就会陷入困境。相反，应对不确定性应该是你谈判策略的基石。第一部分构建了一个动态的谈判分析和实施模型。第二部分着重讲解心态以及如何快速学习、适应和施加影响的技巧。第三部分将这些概念应用于谈判的各个阶段，从开场白、关键时刻到最终成交。第四部分“精通”则将创造力、持续学习和职业道德融会贯通。

Specifically, the first part—“A Sense of Direction”—deals with the role of ambiguity, change, and luck inherent in any negotiation. Understanding the nature of the environment is step one in developing adaptive strategy for traversing it. But simply acknowledging uncertainty is not enough. Master negotiators bake it into their strategy and turn it to their advantage.

具体来说，第一部分——“方向感”——探讨了谈判中固有的模糊性、变化和运气因素的作用。了解环境的本质是制定适应性策略的第一步。但仅仅承认不确定性是不够的。谈判高手会将不确定性融入他们的策略，并将其转化为优势。

The upcoming chapter, “A Map of the Pyrenees,” digs deeper into the underlying challenges of unpredictability introduced here. It poses three key questions you should address before negotiating. The chapter after that, “Prospecting,” offers preparation tools for setting goals, weighing trade-offs, assessing the upside, and determining when to walk away. While chapters 2 and 3 focus on what you are seeking (your substantive goals), chapter 4, “Plan B,” is about strategy and process—the how —of searching for agreement. It spells out nine strategic principles for venturing forward.

即将推出的章节“比利牛斯山脉地图”将深入探讨此处提出的不可预测性所带来的潜在挑战。它提出了谈判前您应该解决的三个关键问题。紧随其后的章节“寻找潜在客户”提供了设定目标、权衡利弊、评估潜在收益以及决定何时放弃的准备工具。第二章和第三章侧重于您所寻求的（您的实质性目标），而第四章“备选方案”则着重于寻求达成协议的策略和流程——即如何实现。它详细阐述了九项推进谈判的战略原则。

The second part of the book—“Improvising”—zeroes in on micro-interactions on a tactical level. Being nimble is about both mind-set and technique. This section begins with a chapter entitled “Presence of Mind.” To perform at your best, you must be prepared to negotiate both mentally and emotionally. That requires a paradoxical ability to be both calm and alert, patient and proactive, creative yet fully grounded.

本书第二部分——“即兴发挥”——着重探讨战术层面的微互动。灵活应变既关乎心态，也关乎技巧。本部分以题为“临场应变”的章节开篇。要想发挥最佳水平，你必须做好充分的心理和情绪准备。这需要一种看似矛盾的能力：既要保持冷静和警觉，又要保持耐心和积极主动，既要富有创造力，又要脚踏实地。

Other chapters in this second section dig into improvisational principles and techniques. In the chapter “The Swing of Things,” you’ll see how jazz musicians, even complete strangers, create new music on the spot. They know when to solo and when to harmonize. They even dare to make mistakes. Then, as counterpoint, in “Situational Awareness,” you’ll see how concepts from the battlefield, chess, and competitive sports apply not only to hardball settlement of lawsuits and labor disputes but also to collaborative transactions.

第二部分的其他章节深入探讨了即兴演奏的原则和技巧。在“即兴创作”一章中，你会看到爵士乐手，即使是完全陌生的人，也能现场创作出新的音乐。他们知道何时独奏，何时和声。他们甚至敢于犯错。与之形成对比的是，在“情境意识”一章中，你会看到战场、国际象棋和竞技体育中的一些概念，不仅适用于诉讼和劳资纠纷的硬性解决，也适用于合作交易。

The third part of the book—“Managing the Process”—applies these practices to the flow of negotiation. The “Openings” chapter compares transcripts of two pairs of veteran negotiators dealing with the same problem. One pair slips into taking potshots at each other. The other, instinctively following the rules of jazz and improv, just as quickly gets into sync.

本书第三部分——“流程管理”——将这些方法应用于谈判流程。“开场白”一章对比了两对经验丰富的谈判者处理同一问题的对话记录。其中一对谈判者开始互相攻击，而另一对则本能地遵循爵士乐和即兴表演的规则，迅速达成共识。

Then the “Critical Moments” chapter examines tipping points in negotiations: junctures where you have to make decisions that are hard to unwind. Making an offer that you can’t take back is one example. Dealing with threats or outbursts is another. A chapter on “Closing” wraps up this section. If someone makes you an attractive proposal, when should you take it and when should you press for more?

接下来，“关键时刻”一章探讨了谈判中的转折点：你必须做出难以逆转的决定的关键时刻。例如，提出一个无法撤回的报价。应对威胁或情绪爆发也是一个例子。本部分以“成交”一章作结。如果有人向你提出了一个很有吸引力的方案，你应该何时接受，何时又应该争取更多？

The last portion of the book—“Mastery”—illuminates the attributes that separate capable negotiators from the stars. One is creativity, as you’ll see in the chapter “Silk Purses.” People such as Jay Sheldon (the investor who salvaged his cable deal) have the knack for finding agreement where others might see only deadlock. Mastery also entails an intriguing mix of confidence and humility. In the chapter “Wicked Learning,” you’ll discover that the best negotiators learn the right lessons from their experience. They aren’t intoxicated by prior success.

本书最后一部分——“精通”——阐述了优秀谈判者与顶尖谈判者之间的区别。其中之一是创造力，正如您将在“妙计”一章中看到的那样。像杰伊·谢尔顿（那位挽救了有线电视交易的投资人）这样的人，总能在别人眼中看似僵局的地方找到共识。精通还包含一种巧妙的自信与谦逊的结合。在“经验教训”一章中，您会发现，最优秀的谈判者会从经验中汲取正确的教训。他们不会被过去的成功冲昏头脑。

The book’s concluding chapter, “Fair Enough,” examines ethical issues inherent in all negotiations. The most difficult choices aren’t about right and wrong; rather, they require reconciling competing values and obligations. Then the appendix presents twenty-five reasons to embrace chaos in negotiation, a thematic listing of the key principles and methods of the learn-adapt-and-influence approach. This list is a quick refresher for crafting strategy.

本书最后一章“公平起见”探讨了所有谈判中固有的伦理问题。最艰难的选择并非关乎对错，而是需要调和相互冲突的价值观和义务。附录列出了在谈判中拥抱混乱的二十五个理由，并按主题列出了“学习-适应-影响”方法的关键原则和方法。这份清单可以帮助读者快速回顾制定策略所需的要点。

I’m confident that a thoughtful reading of this book will make you a better negotiator, whether you’re a relative novice or have lots of experience under your belt. The advice here is built on the best practices of top negotiators. It offers a fresh and practical slant on negotiation, one that may push you to rethink your own habits and assumptions. I hope that’s liberating.

我相信，无论你是谈判新手还是经验丰富的谈判高手，认真阅读本书都能让你成为更优秀的谈判者。本书的建议建立在顶尖谈判者的最佳实践之上，它为谈判提供了一个新颖而实用的视角，或许会促使你重新审视自己的习惯和假设。我希望这能让你有所启发。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Anticipate that goals, interests, and walkaway alternatives might evolve in ways that are to your advantage or detriment.

■ 要预料到目标、兴趣和备选方案可能会朝着对你有利或不利的方向发展。

■ Understand that negotiation is an interactive process. Your actions and statements may influence your counterparts in ways that you did not expect or intend.

■ 要明白谈判是一个互动过程。你的言行可能会以你意想不到的方式影响对方。

■ Maximize your negotiation effectiveness by crafting a robust strategy.

■ 通过制定强有力的策略，最大限度地提高您的谈判效率。

■ Be prepared to improvise.

■做好随机应变的准备。

#↩

PART ONE

第一部分

A Sense of Direction

方向感

You’d be surprised how many people don’t actually know what they want with the kind of precision that a negotiation demands. Then you have to think of the two thousand ways to get where you want to go: what the trades might be, what the arguments might be, what the moves might be on the other side. And you watch carefully, and listen carefully, talk less, and remain persistent.

你会惊讶地发现，很多人其实并不像谈判中要求的那样，清楚自己想要什么。这时，你必须设想出两千种达成目标的途径：可能的交易、可能出现的争论、对方可能采取的行动。你需要仔细观察、认真倾听，少说多做，并保持坚持不懈。

—AMBASSADOR CHARLENE BARSHEFSKY

——大使查琳·巴尔谢夫斯基

#↩

[ 2 ] A Map of the Pyrenees

[ 2 ] 比利牛斯山脉地图

Many years ago, a military patrol was caught by a fierce blizzard in the Swiss Alps. The soldiers were lost and frightened, but one of them found a map tucked in his pocket. After consulting it, the men built a shelter, planned their route, and then waited out the storm. When the weather cleared three days later, they made their way back to the base camp.

多年前，一支军事巡逻队在瑞士阿尔卑斯山遭遇了一场猛烈的暴风雪。士兵们迷失了方向，惊恐万分，但其中一人在口袋里找到了一张地图。他们查看地图后，搭建了一个简易的避难所，规划了路线，然后等待暴风雪过去。三天后，天气放晴，他们返回了营地。

Their commanding officer, relieved that his men had survived the ordeal, asked how they made their way out. A young soldier produced the life-saving map, and the officer studied it carefully. He was shocked to see that it was a map of the Pyrenees Mountains that border Spain and France, not the Alps.

他们的指挥官松了口气，得知部下都幸存了下来，便询问他们是如何脱险的。一名年轻士兵拿出了那张救命的地图，军官仔细查看。他震惊地发现，这张地图描绘的是西班牙和法国交界处的比利牛斯山脉，而不是阿尔卑斯山脉。

This story, attributed to Hungarian biochemist and Nobel laureate Albert Szent-Gyorgi, dates back to the 1930s. It is often cited in serious research on organizational learning and is widely regarded as true.

这个故事据说是匈牙利生物化学家、诺贝尔奖得主阿尔伯特·圣捷尔吉在20世纪30年代讲述的。它经常被组织学习方面的严肃研究引用，并被广泛认为是真实的。

Whether or not the tale is apocryphal, how could the wrong map save climbers lost in the Alps? There are three explanations, and they are as relevant for negotiators as for anyone caught in the wilderness.

无论这个故事是真是假，一张错误的地图怎么可能拯救迷失在阿尔卑斯山的登山者呢？对此有三种解释，而且这些解释对于谈判者和任何身处荒野的人都同样适用。

First, the map rekindled the soldiers’ confidence. It released them from the paralysis of indecision and impelled them to take action. The men didn’t bicker or wander aimlessly. Instead, they shielded themselves against the storm and waited for the best time to make a move.

首先，地图重燃了士兵们的信心。它让他们摆脱了犹豫不决的困境，促使他们采取行动。士兵们没有争吵，也没有漫无目的地游荡。相反，他们严阵以待，抵御风暴，等待最佳时机发起进攻。

Second, the map provided impetus. Heading exactly the right way proved less important than simply getting moving. That isn’t always prudent, of course. If we’re lost and sit tight, others may come to our rescue. In negotiation, by contrast, we have to rely on our own wits and initiative to get where we want to go. A bias for action almost always beats being passive.

其次，地图起到了推动作用。事实证明，走对方向远不如行动本身重要。当然，这并非总是明智之举。如果我们迷路了却原地不动，或许有人会来救我们。相比之下，在谈判中，我们必须依靠自己的智慧和主动性才能达成目标。积极主动几乎总是胜过消极被动。

Most important, the map sharpened the soldiers’ awareness. It gave them a template from which they could work. Once they were under way, portions of the map may have conformed to specific areas the soldiers encountered. Mountains have common characteristics, after all: steep headwalls, brooks, and more gentle inclines. But peaks are also distinctive in other respects. When the drawing no longer fit the scene, the men had to reconsider their position and find some other part of the map that seemed more plausible.

最重要的是，地图提高了士兵们的警觉性。它为他们提供了一个可以参考的模板。一旦行军开始，地图上的某些部分可能与士兵们遇到的特定区域相吻合。毕竟，山脉有一些共同的特征：陡峭的山壁、溪流和较为平缓的坡度。但山峰在其他方面也各具特色。当地图上的描述不再与实际情况相符时，士兵们就必须重新评估他们的立场，并在地图上找到其他更合理的参考区域。

That constant vigilance enabled them to improve their mental model of the actual world they were traversing. This ongoing reorientation required keen attention to their surroundings. Their survival depended on a willingness to abandon earlier assumptions and accept new realities.

这种持续的警惕使他们能够不断完善对所处真实世界的认知模型。这种持续的重新定位需要他们密切关注周围环境。他们的生存取决于他们是否愿意放弃先前的假设并接受新的现实。

Confidence, impetus, and vigilance: summon that trio, and you have hardy companions when stakes are high and outcomes in doubt, whether traversing mountains or negotiating agreements.

自信、干劲和警惕：召集这三者，当风险高、结果不确定时，无论是翻山越岭还是谈判协议，你都将拥有坚实的伙伴。

The soldiers’ map was wrong, but not that wrong. A map of the Sahara or of Lake Erie would have done the soldiers no good. To be useful, the map had to correspond roughly to reality. If it weren’t plausible, the men wouldn’t have had confidence in themselves. And it had to be appropriate to the context, or it wouldn’t have provided initial direction. But it also had to be the right scale. A fine-grained map probably would have left them worse off. Overwhelmed with topographical details, they could have argued in circles about where to start rather than focus on where they needed to go.

士兵们的地图虽然错了，但错得离谱。撒哈拉沙漠或伊利湖的地图对士兵们毫无用处。一张有用的地图必须大致符合实际情况。如果地图不合情理，士兵们就无法建立信心。地图还必须与实际情况相符，否则就无法提供初步的指引。此外，地图的比例尺也必须合适。一张过于精细的地图反而可能让他们更加迷茫。如果地图上充斥着大量的地形细节，他们可能会陷入无休止的争论，纠结于从哪里开始，而不是专注于前进的方向。

You can’t pull a printed map from your pocket, of course, when you’re formulating a negotiating strategy. You have to draft one yourself. Even when you’re on familiar ground and prior experience suggests a particular path, guard yourself against a been-there, done-that mind-set. The terrain may have changed since your last time around. Traditional cartographers used sextants, surveyors’ transits, and altimeters to mark out territory. As Ambassador Brahimi says, negotiators must constantly use their eyes. Specifically, you need a realistic sense of three features of the landscape.

当然，制定谈判策略时，你不可能从口袋里掏出一张打印好的地图。你必须自己绘制一张。即使你身处熟悉的领域，以往的经验也指引你走上某条特定的道路，也要警惕那种“过来人”的思维模式。地形可能与你上次来时已经发生了变化。传统的制图师使用六分仪、经纬仪和高度计来标示地域。正如布拉希米大使所说，谈判者必须时刻保持警觉。具体来说，你需要对地形的三个特征有清晰的认识。

The first is a clearheaded view of where you think you are at present—that is, a reckoning of your needs, priorities, and trade-offs—as well as your fallback options if the negotiation becomes stalemated. The second is an estimate of your counterpart’s circumstances so that you can gauge what might prove acceptable. (We’ll get into this in depth in the next chapter.) A third element of mapping negotiation entails cataloging key factors that you don’t know at the outset, so that you’re alert for surprises as the process unfolds. Asking yourself these three questions will help you prepare strategy:

首先，你需要清晰地了解自己目前的处境——也就是评估自身的需求、优先事项和权衡取舍——以及谈判陷入僵局时的备选方案。其次，你需要评估对方的处境，以便判断哪些条件可能被接受。（我们将在下一章深入探讨这一点。）谈判策略规划的第三个要素是记录你在谈判初期未知的关键因素，以便在谈判过程中保持警惕，应对可能出现的意外情况。问自己以下三个问题将有助于你制定策略：

1. Should I negotiate?

1. 我应该谈判吗？

2. Is now the time?

2. 现在是时候了吗？

3. Do I hedge or go all in?

3. 我应该采取对冲策略还是全力投入？

These questions encourage you to grapple with the uncertainty of negotiation and take it into account in mapping a robust plan.

这些问题旨在引导你正视谈判中的不确定性，并在制定稳健的计划时将其考虑在内。

SHOULD I NEGOTIATE?

我应该谈判吗？

Herb Cohen recounts stories about haggling with salesmen in his popular book You Can Negotiate Anything. He admits that getting a special discount on a refrigerator can take multiple trips to the store and hours of chatter, but he relishes the process. For him, the sticker price is just a starting point.

赫伯·科恩在他畅销书《任何事都能谈判》中讲述了与销售员讨价还价的故事。他坦言，为了买到一台冰箱，争取到特别折扣可能需要多次往返商店，耗费数小时的谈判时间，但他乐在其中。对他来说，标价仅仅是个起点。

Cohen is right. Lots of things are negotiable. As he advises, you don’t get if you don’t ask. But asking can be risky, as Arvind Gupta learned to his regret. He was close friends with an older couple who lived in a beachfront mansion with sweeping views of the ocean. Somehow, for twenty years, they had never been billed for property taxes, nor had they ever paid them.

科恩说得对。很多事情都是可以商量的。正如他所建议的，你不问就什么也得不到。但问也可能有风险，阿文德·古普塔就为此后悔不已。他与一对住在海滨豪宅里的老夫妇是挚友，那豪宅视野开阔，可以饱览壮丽海景。不知何故，二十年来，他们从未收到过房产税账单，也从未缴纳过。

When a notice from the city arrived, it was for a staggering amount. The couple had already been thinking about downsizing, and the bill pushed them to make that decision. They were childless, so they approached Arvind, whom they loved, and offered to sell him the property for $2.5 million.

当市政部门寄来账单时，金额之巨令人咋舌。这对夫妇原本就打算换小房子，这张账单更是促使他们下定决心。由于膝下无子，他们便找到自己深爱的丈夫阿文德，提出以250万美元的价格将房产卖给他。

Arvind realized that this was a bargain price, but it was beyond his means. So he approached another friend whom he calls “Wealthy Bill,” a nickname that is also a shorthand measure of the latter’s fortune. Bill recognized the investment opportunity and was glad to be a silent partner in the purchase. But Bill said they should counter with an offer of $2.25 million. If the sellers insisted on full price, he noted, they could always pay it if necessary. Arvind was hesitant, however. The asking price was already well below market.

阿文德意识到这价格很划算，但超出了他的承受范围。于是他去找了另一位朋友，他称这位朋友为“富豪比尔”，这个绰号也暗示了比尔的财富。比尔看出了其中的投资机会，并乐于成为此次收购的幕后合伙人。但比尔建议他们还价225万美元。他指出，如果卖家坚持要全价，他们也可以在必要时支付。然而，阿文德犹豫了。要价已经远低于市场价了。

“Nonsense,” said Bill. “There’s always room to bargain.” Arvind reluctantly made the counteroffer, since it was mostly Bill’s money that was at stake.

“胡说，”比尔说，“总有讨价还价的余地。” 阿尔文德很不情愿地提出了还价，毕竟牵涉到的主要是比尔的钱。

You probably know where this story is going. Arvind’s friends expressed their hurt and anger when he tried to haggle: “We treated you like a son, and this is how you thank us?” The owners withdrew their offer, found a real estate broker, and, less than a year later, sold their property for $11 million.

你大概已经猜到故事的走向了。当阿文德试图讨价还价时，他的朋友们表达了他们的伤心和愤怒：“我们把你当儿子一样对待，你就是这样回报我们的？” 房主撤回了报价，找了一位房地产经纪人，不到一年后，就以1100万美元的价格卖掉了房子。

Whoops!

哎呀！

Arvind is philosophical about the experience. He’s not rich, but he’s professionally successful and comfortable financially. He is also exhibit A for the principle that the only way to know just how close to the edge of the cliff you can go safely is to take one more step beyond that.

阿文德对这段经历持一种超然的态度。他并不富有，但事业有成，经济状况也相当不错。他也是“只有走得更远，才能知道自己究竟能安全地走到悬崖边多远”这一原则的最佳例证。

Compare Arvind’s blunder with Liz and Tony Weiler’s story. For twenty years, they rented a summer cottage in Salt Harbor, a charming coastal community in Massachusetts. From their back porch, they could watch their children playing on the private beach below. They befriended the elderly owner who lived next door. She encouraged them to plant raspberry and blueberry bushes. In return, Liz made fruit pies for her landlady.

将阿文德的失误与莉兹和托尼·韦勒的故事进行比较。二十年来，他们在马萨诸塞州迷人的海滨小镇盐港租了一栋避暑别墅。从后廊，他们可以俯瞰孩子们在下面的私人海滩上玩耍。他们与住在隔壁的老房主成了朋友。老房主鼓励他们种植覆盆子和蓝莓。作为回报，莉兹会为老房主做水果派。

From time to time, they inquired discreetly whether she might be willing to sell the property, but the owner herself had three grown children, one of whom had expressed interest in the house. The Weilers knew that they’d be able to return to the cottage every summer so long as their neighbor was still alive, but they despaired of what would happen when she died. And she was now ninety-four.

他们时不时会偷偷打听她是否愿意出售这处房产，但房主自己有三个成年子女，其中一个已经表示对房子感兴趣。韦勒一家知道，只要邻居还健在，他们每年夏天都能回到这间小屋，但他们对她去世后会发生什么感到绝望。而她现在已经九十四岁了。

Then one August morning, the owner’s eldest son appeared at their door. Without coming in, he announced that he had talked to his mother and his siblings. The family was ready to sell. “Three hundred and thirty thousand dollars,” he said. “Take it or leave it. Let us know before Labor Day.” Then he left.

八月的一个清晨，房主的长子出现在家门口。他没有进门，只是宣布他已经和母亲及兄弟姐妹谈过了，家里准备卖房。“三十三万美元，”他说，“买也好，不买也罢。劳动节前告诉我们。”说完，他就离开了。

The Weilers were in a swirl. At long last, the cottage could be theirs. But what about the price? Given the market, $330,000 wasn’t outlandish, and they could afford it, but it was no bargain, either. Then again, there was nothing else in that range that they could love nearly as much. Nevertheless, Liz bristled at the take-it-or-leave-it remark. Why not make a counteroffer?

韦勒一家陷入了迷茫。他们终于可以拥有这栋小屋了。可是价格呢？考虑到市场行情，33万美元不算离谱，他们也负担得起，但绝对算不上便宜。话又说回来，在这个价位上，他们也找不到其他像这栋小屋一样让他们如此心动的房子了。尽管如此，莉兹还是对那种“要么接受要么放弃”的态度感到恼火。为什么不还价呢？

Whenever somebody makes you a proposal, either at the outset or deep into a negotiation, you must reckon the plusses and minuses of bargaining further. In the Weilers’ case, the upside of countering could be saving some money. Knocking 10 percent or more off the price could be a long shot, but even saving half that amount might seem worthwhile.

无论何时有人向你提出方案，无论是在谈判初期还是深入谈判阶段，你都必须权衡进一步讨价还价的利弊。就韦勒夫妇而言，还价的好处可能是省钱。虽然砍价10%甚至更多可能希望渺茫，但即使只省下一半的钱也值得考虑。

What about the downside, though? Would there be any harm in asking? The owner might lower the demand a bit or insist that the price is the price. But it had taken the family years to agree to sell. Their consensus might be fragile. If the Weilers countered, any one of the siblings might regard that as an excuse to retract the offer.

但缺点是什么呢？问问又有什么坏处呢？房主可能会稍微降低要价，或者坚持价格就是最终价格。但这家人花了多年时间才同意出售，他们的共识可能并不牢固。如果韦勒一家还价，任何一个兄弟姐妹都可能以此为借口撤回报价。

Sitting on the porch of their rented cottage, the Weilers weighed the pros and cons of negotiating. Nothing ventured, they thought, nothing gained. But they also imagined a corollary: nothing ventured, nothing lost.

韦勒夫妇坐在租来的小屋门廊上，权衡着谈判的利弊。他们心想，不入虎穴，焉得虎子。但他们也想到一个推论：不入虎穴，焉得虎子。

The fog of negotiation—its inherent uncertainty—makes it hard to know how much room there is to negotiate or if there’s any room at all. Odds are that the Weilers could have counteroffered without exploding the deal, but for them, the pivotal question was whether the upside of saving $15,000 or $20,000 would be worth taking even a small chance of losing a house they’d come to cherish.

谈判的迷雾——其固有的不确定性——使得人们难以判断谈判空间的大小，甚至根本无从谈起。韦勒夫妇或许可以提出还价而不至于破坏交易，但对他们而言，关键问题在于，节省1.5万或2万美元的收益是否值得冒失去这栋他们无比珍视的房子的风险。

The conventional negotiation theory that we covered in the prior chapter doesn’t address the problem of when to say yes. It just tells you to weigh whatever you’re offered against your no-deal alternative—that is, your best course of action if you can’t reach agreement. Viewed this way, for Arvind or for the Weilers, it’s a matter of comparing two paths on a simple decision tree.

我们在上一章讨论的传统谈判理论并没有解决何时应该说“是”的问题。它只是告诉你，要权衡对方提出的条件和不达成协议的替代方案——也就是如果你无法达成协议，你的最佳行动方案。从这个角度来看，对阿文德或韦勒一家来说，这就像是比较决策树上的两条路径。

The implication is that a buyer should say yes whenever offered a better deal than he or she can get elsewhere. Real-world negotiation is more interesting, however. A more accurate strategic map would include the separate paths for saying yes to an acceptable deal or walking away, plus a third alternative, pushing for even more attractive terms.

这暗示着，只要报价比其他地方更优惠，买家就应该接受。然而，现实谈判远比这复杂得多。更准确的策略图谱应该包含三种路径：接受可接受的报价、放弃交易，以及第三种选择——争取更优厚的条件。

The size and likelihood of what you might gain from continuing to negotiate have to be weighed against the downside of losing the deal. Holding on to a bird in the hand requires a sensitive touch firm enough to prevent it from flying away but not so forceful as to squeeze the life out of it. Context matters. How much risk you’re willing to run depends on your temperament, as well as your resources and alternatives. The time to stop negotiating is when the risk of pressing further outweighs possible gains.

继续谈判可能获得的收益及其可能性，必须与失去交易的风险进行权衡。就像抓住一只鸟需要轻柔的触碰，既要足够坚定以防止它飞走，又不能用力过猛而扼杀它的生命。具体情况至关重要。你愿意承担多大的风险取决于你的性格、资源和备选方案。当继续谈判的风险超过潜在收益时，就应该停止谈判。

IS NOW THE TIME?

现在是时候了吗？

Many years ago, just as my uncle Al’s family was starting out on a summer vacation, their car broke down. Black smoke poured out from under the hood. The engine had thrown a rod.

很多年前，就在我叔叔阿尔一家开始暑假旅行的时候，他们的车抛锚了。引擎盖下冒出滚滚黑烟。发动机连杆断了。

The timing was bad, and the location was worse. The breakdown occurred right in front of a car dealership. According to family lore, a salesman who witnessed the whole episode strode out of the showroom toward them, rubbing his hands, his face beaming.

时机不对，地点更糟。车子抛锚的地方就在一家汽车经销店门口。据家人回忆，一位目睹了整个过程的销售员搓着手，笑容满面地从展厅里朝他们走来。

The story had a happy ending, sort of. My late uncle bought a new station wagon on the spot. He got the suitcases from the smoldering heap and loaded them into the new car, and the family had a fine vacation. Of course, Uncle Al paid dearly. And, as it happened, the car was a Ford Edsel, a short-lived model that automotive buffs remember as one of the great lemons in Detroit’s history.

故事的结局算是圆满吧。我已故的叔叔当场买了一辆新的旅行车。他从那辆冒着烟的废车里搬出行李箱，装进新车，一家人度过了一个愉快的假期。当然，阿尔叔叔为此付出了惨痛的代价。而且，碰巧的是，那辆车是福特埃德塞尔，一款昙花一现的车型，汽车爱好者们至今仍记得它是底特律历史上最臭名昭著的“柠檬车”之一。

Uncle Al went on to have a remarkable career in business, buying small companies and helping them grow and prosper. He was always a superb negotiator. But on that distant July day, he was in the wrong place at the wrong time. He had to have another car, and the salesman knew it.

阿尔叔叔后来在商界取得了非凡的成就，他收购小公司，帮助它们发展壮大。他一直是一位出色的谈判者。但在遥远的七月某一天，他却在错误的时间出现在了错误的地点。他急需一辆车，而销售员也明白这一点。

You’re better off, of course, when you can schedule negotiations to your advantage. The time to buy a car is when you don’t urgently need one. It’s even better if the dealer is under pressure to get cars off the lot, near the end of a promotional period. If selling one more vehicle puts the dealer over his or her quota, you’ll get a great price. The only downside of coming in late is that other shoppers may have picked over the inventory, but you can always come back at the end of the next month.

当然，如果能安排对自身有利的谈判时间，那就更好了。买车的最佳时机是当你并不急需用车的时候。如果经销商在促销期末期急于清仓，那就更划算了。如果多卖一辆车就能让经销商超额完成销售目标，你就能拿到非常优惠的价格。晚些到店的唯一缺点是其他顾客可能已经挑选过车辆了，但你总可以等到下个月底再来。

Whether time is on your side depends on the stability of your BATNA: your walkaway alternative. Will your nonagreement options get better or worse in the future? Sometimes that’s an easy call. If you’re trying to sell a ski condo in May, it may be worth waiting till the first frost gets people thinking again about winter sports. But waiting, of course, means swallowing operating costs and condo fees in the interim and risking that the market for vacation properties will soften. Timing also depends on whether the other parties expect their own alternatives will wax or wane. If both sides feel that time is on their side, everyone may be in for a long haul.

时间是否站在你这边，取决于你的最佳替代方案（BATNA）的稳定性：你的“脱身之计”。你的非协议选项未来会变得更好还是更糟？有时这很容易判断。如果你打算在五月份出售一套滑雪公寓，那么等到初霜降临，人们重新开始关注冬季运动时，或许值得一试。当然，等待意味着你要承担这段时间的运营成本和公寓管理费，并且还要承担度假房产市场疲软的风险。时机的选择还取决于其他各方对自身替代方案的预期是增强还是减弱。如果双方都认为时间站在自己这边，那么这场谈判可能将会旷日持久。

When Harvard economist Richard Zeckhauser was still a student, he designed a simple game that demonstrated the potential impact of time pressure in negotiation. Pairs of subjects had to divide some money, but were given different rules. If two people couldn’t agree on the split, no one would get anything. With one group, most came to agreement, many splitting the money fifty-fifty, though often only after extended haggling.

哈佛经济学家理查德·泽克豪瑟还在求学时，就设计了一个简单的游戏，用来演示时间压力对谈判的潜在影响。游戏中，参与者两两一组，需要分配一笔钱，但规则不同。如果两人无法就分配方案达成一致，则谁也得不到任何东西。其中一组参与者最终大多达成了协议，许多人甚至五五分成，尽管这往往是在经过长时间的讨价还价之后才实现的。

Richard then gave another set of paired subjects—call them group B—the same amount to divide, but he told them that the prize would shrink with every tick of the clock. Because time literally was money, these people reached agreement quickly, almost always splitting the prize equally.

随后，理查德又给另一组受试者（我们称之为B组）同样数额的奖金，但他告诉他们，奖金会随着时间一分一秒地减少。由于时间就是金钱，这些人很快就达成了协议，几乎总是平分奖金。

With group C, Richard added a devilish twist. Again there was a tax that grew bigger with time, but here he specified that only one side—not the other—would pay most of the entire penalty. As you might guess, the people who were more heavily taxed usually got a smaller share. The surprise was that un taxed parties often did poorly too.

在C组中，理查德又加了个阴险的圈套。同样，税额会随着时间推移而增加，但他这次明确规定，只有一方——而不是另一方——会承担大部分的罚款。不出所料，税负更重的人通常得到的份额更少。令人惊讶的是，那些未被征税的人往往也损失惨重。

These subjects typically overplayed their hand. Believing that time was on their side, they expected their counterparts to buckle because of the ever-mounting tax. Instead, many people in that weaker position held out, biting their own nose to spite those who were pressuring them. By the time they reached agreement, the pie had shrunk significantly, resulting in less for both sides.

这些被谈判者通常都过于乐观。他们认为时间站在自己这边，就指望对方会因为不断上涨的税负而屈服。然而，许多处于弱势地位的人却坚持抵抗，为了对抗施压者而忍气吞声。等到他们最终达成协议时，蛋糕已经大幅缩小，双方都损失惨重。

People fall into the same kind of trap in real-world negotiations. In business transactions, each side may be hesitant to make a concession to close a deal, fearful that they will look weak. Likewise, litigants pour money into lawsuits, never expecting to try their case, on the assumption that they can wait out the other side. It takes only one stubborn party to create a stalemate. If both sides are committed to outlasting the other, the costs can be colossal.

人们在现实谈判中也常常陷入类似的陷阱。在商业交易中，双方都可能因为害怕显得软弱而犹豫不决，不愿做出让步以达成交易。同样，诉讼当事人投入大量资金，却从未指望真正开庭审理，而是想当然地认为可以拖延时间，最终达成协议。然而，只要一方固执己见，就可能造成僵局。如果双方都执意要拖延时间，最终的代价可能不堪设想。

The National Hockey League and the NHL Players Association ended a protracted dispute early in 2013, but only after each side suffered enormous losses due to cancellation of half the regular season. During the lockout, league commissioner Gary Bettman stated that the teams were losing between $18 and $20 million daily; in turn, the players lost between $8 and $10 million in salary every day. Even as the deadline for reaching agreement loomed larger and larger, each side assumed that the other was bound to “come to its senses” and compromise.

国家冰球联盟（NHL）和NHL球员协会在2013年初结束了一场旷日持久的劳资纠纷，但双方都因常规赛半数取消而遭受了巨大损失。在停摆期间，联盟主席加里·贝特曼表示，各球队每天损失1800万至2000万美元；球员们每天的薪水损失也高达800万至1000万美元。尽管达成协议的最后期限越来越近，但双方都认为对方最终会“幡然醒悟”并做出妥协。

From the players’ point of view, it seemed unreasonable for the owners to sacrifice ticket sales and television income while carrying huge debt on their facilities. The owners, in turn, couldn’t see how players would risk losing a full year of income in their short careers. Each group thought that time favored it.

从球员的角度来看，老板们背负着巨额债务，却牺牲门票收入和电视转播收入，这似乎很不合理。而老板们也无法理解球员们为何愿意在短暂的职业生涯中冒失去一整年收入的风险。双方都认为时间会站在他们这边。

In many ways, this was a lose-lose negotiation. Both sides would have been substantially better off if at the outset they had somehow managed to reach the same terms that they finally agreed upon. The lost ticket, concession, and media revenue is gone for good; so are the paychecks that the players would have received if there had been no stoppage. The outcome seems all the more irrational given that both sides had been down this road before: Half a season was squandered in 1994–95, while a lockout in 2004–05 caused the cancellation of the entire NHL season.

从很多方面来看，这是一场双输的谈判。如果双方一开始就能达成最终达成的协议，对彼此的处境都会好得多。门票、特许经营权和媒体收入的损失已成定局；球员们原本应得的薪水也同样损失殆尽。考虑到双方此前都曾经历过类似的困境，这样的结果显得更加不合情理：1994-95赛季，半个赛季被白白浪费；而2004-05赛季的停摆则导致整个NHL赛季取消。

Prolonging a negotiation makes sense only if there’s solid reason to believe that you will be in a better position tomorrow than you are today. That can be the case if the added time enables you to gain leverage by improving your fallback position or winning key allies. Having more time also may allow you to be better prepared (though that’s true for your counterparts, too). But conditions can also worsen. Stringing along customers may prompt them to look for better terms from your competitors. For instance, if you hold out for a better price on a new home, mortgage rates may rise.

只有当你确信明天你的处境会比今天更有利时，延长谈判才有意义。例如，如果延长谈判时间能让你通过改善后备方案或赢得关键盟友来获得筹码，那么延长谈判时间就可能带来这种优势。更多的时间也可能让你做好更充分的准备（当然，你的对手也是如此）。但情况也可能恶化。拖延谈判可能会促使客户向你的竞争对手寻求更优惠的条件。例如，如果你坚持要求更低的价格购买新房，抵押贷款利率可能会上升。

Getting ready for an important negotiation can take time as well, but you won’t be omniscient. Certain things about your counterparts—their priorities, temperament, and trustworthiness—may be learned best by negotiating in earnest. It’s time to negotiate when you can learn more by being at the table than being absorbed in private preparation.

准备一场重要的谈判也需要时间，但你不可能无所不知。关于谈判对手的某些信息——他们的优先事项、性格和可信度——或许只有通过认真谈判才能更好地了解。当你在谈判桌上获得的收获比沉浸于私下准备中更多时，就应该开始谈判了。

DO I GO ALL IN?

我该孤注一掷吗？

A few years ago, Iberia Airlines approached Boeing and asked it to propose a new midrange plane. The aircraft industry had been in a deep slump since 2001, and Iberia was one of the few carriers making money at that time. The prospect of new business for Boeing seemed a godsend to the company. Nevertheless, it was hesitant to make a proposal.

几年前，伊比利亚航空公司找到波音公司，请其设计一款新型中程飞机。自2001年以来，航空业一直处于低迷状态，而伊比利亚航空是当时少数几家盈利的航空公司之一。对于波音公司而言，这笔新业务的前景似乎是天赐良机。然而，波音公司却迟迟不愿提出方案。

In the past, Iberia had always favored Airbus, a European consortium. It was likely that the Spanish airline just wanted to use Boeing as a stalking horse to wrangle better terms from its longtime supplier. For Boeing, the cost of bidding for the Iberia contract—and losing—would be substantial. Beyond managerial time and millions of dollars in design work and financial expenses, there were important reputational factors. Being runner-up in a two-horse race would confirm the gloomy assessments of market analysts and further weaken Boeing’s hand in negotiating with other potential customers. It would also cause morale problems within the company. But any real chance of securing the Iberia contract would require Boeing to court the airline aggressively and make a bold bid. Halfway measures would not work.

过去，伊比利亚航空一直更倾向于欧洲财团空客。这家西班牙航空公司很可能只是想利用波音作为幌子，从其长期供应商那里争取更有利的条款。对波音而言，竞标伊比利亚航空的合同——以及最终落败——的代价将是巨大的。除了耗费管理时间、数百万美元的设计工作和财务支出外，还有重要的声誉因素。在两强争霸中屈居第二，不仅印证了市场分析师的悲观预测，也进一步削弱了波音在与其他潜在客户谈判时的筹码，还会打击公司内部士气。但要想真正拿下伊比利亚航空的合同，波音必须积极争取该航空公司，并提出大胆的报价。折中方案行不通。

Initially, Boeing decided not to bid. The odds of winning were just too small, and the costs of losing were correspondingly high. Iberia, however, didn’t want to have to deal with Airbus as its sole source, so it went to great lengths to convince Boeing that the American company had a real shot at the contract. Boeing ultimately relented and invested heavily in a proposal, but Iberia chose Airbus—after the latter was compelled to make significant price concessions to match Boeing’s terms.

最初，波音公司决定不参与竞标。中标的概率实在太小，而失败的代价却相应很高。然而，伊比利亚航空不想只与空客公司合作，因此竭尽全力说服波音公司，这家美国公司确实有机会赢得这份合同。波音公司最终让步，投入巨资制定了一份方案，但伊比利亚航空最终选择了空客——前提是空客公司被迫做出重大的价格让步，以符合波音公司的条件。

Coming up empty-handed in this negotiation was worse for Boeing than never trying at all. Having to go all in with its proposal—and doing so publicly—compounded its problems. In hindsight, there was remorse that the company didn’t stick with its original decision and stay out of the competition.

对波音公司而言，这次谈判的失败比从未尝试还要糟糕。被迫全力以赴地提出方案——而且还要公开进行——更是雪上加霜。事后看来，公司后悔当初没有坚持最初的决定，置身事外。

Sometimes, though, you’ve got to dump all your chips on the table in order to be seen as a serious player. Those chips may be your time, money, or status—or all three. When you can hedge your bets or play one possible deal off another, that’s fine, but sometimes you’ve got to put your negotiation eggs in one basket and then manage that basket very carefully.

但有时候，为了被视为认真的谈判者，你必须孤注一掷。这些筹码可能是你的时间、金钱或地位——或者三者兼而有之。如果你能分散风险或利用一项潜在交易来抵消另一项潜在交易的影响，那当然没问题，但有时候你必须把谈判的希望寄托在一个项目上，然后小心翼翼地管理好这个项目。

Nobel laureate Tom Schelling’s classic The Strategy of Conflict analyzed situations where locking oneself in amplifies leverage. For an illustration, he described the hot-rodders’ game of chicken, in which two souped-up cars speed toward each other head-on. The first driver to swerve loses face. Schelling speculated about what would happen if one of the drivers yanked his steering wheel off the steering column and conspicuously tossed it out the window. Then he’d really be all in, committed to tearing straight ahead heedless of the consequences. The other driver would have to veer away to avoid disaster.

诺贝尔经济学奖得主汤姆·谢林在其经典著作《冲突的策略》中分析了“自我封闭”如何增强自身优势的情境。他举例说明了改装车爱好者之间的“胆小鬼游戏”：两辆改装车迎头相撞，谁先转向谁就丢脸。谢林设想，如果其中一位车手猛地把方向盘从转向柱上扯下来，然后明目张胆地扔出窗外，会发生什么？这样一来，他就真的孤注一掷，不顾一切后果地直奔前方。另一位车手为了避免灾难，就不得不转向避让。

Schelling wrote his essay at the height of the Cold War, so many of his examples have a hard edge, but his insights also apply to business today. Fox Television’s prominence is due to an all-in move it made in the 1990s, when it bid aggressively for National Football League broadcasting rights. Even though audience ratings were sagging, the upstart network offered almost twice what CBS had been paying for the prime Sunday-afternoon time slot.

谢林撰写这篇文章时正值冷战高峰期，因此他举的许多例子都带有鲜明的时代烙印，但他的洞见对当今商业依然适用。福克斯电视台的崛起归功于其在20世纪90年代的一次孤注一掷的举动：当时它积极竞标美国国家橄榄球联盟（NFL）的转播权。尽管收视率下滑，这家新兴电视台仍开出了几乎是哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）在周日下午黄金时段支付价格两倍的报价。

The preemptive strategy worked. CBS didn’t even try to match the bid. With one aggressive move Fox not only won NFL rights but also elbowed a place for itself at the table with the three established networks. It might have been able to acquire the football contract more cheaply, but by making a blow-out offer, Fox ended the competition then and there.

先发制人的策略奏效了。CBS甚至都没尝试匹配报价。福克斯凭借一次强势的举动，不仅赢得了NFL的转播权，还跻身三大老牌电视网的行列。它或许能以更低的价格拿下这份橄榄球合同，但福克斯通过抛出天价报价，彻底终结了竞争。

Many negotiations don’t require all-in moves. Putting a toe in the water can be all that’s required. That’s how Sandy Ritchie bought a beautiful property off the Maine coast. Sandy already owned a two-acre island nearby, a low-lying pile of granite with sparse vegetation. But it had a camp, and when the tide was right and the wind was calm, he could row over and enjoy being master of his little kingdom. On the way to his place, Sandy would pass Bold Island, just east of the fishing town of Stonington. It’s a picture-postcard scene with a spruce forest running up above the shoreline. There’s even a dock for boats and a comfortable house up among the trees.

许多谈判并不需要孤注一掷。试探一下就足够了。桑迪·里奇就是这样在缅因州海岸附近买下了一处美丽的房产。桑迪在附近已经拥有一座两英亩的小岛，那是一座地势低洼、植被稀疏的花岗岩小岛。岛上有一个营地，当潮水合适、风平浪静时，他可以划船过去，享受掌控自己小王国的乐趣。去他家的路上，桑迪会经过博尔德岛，它位于渔镇斯托宁顿以东。那里风景如画，云杉林沿着海岸线向上延伸。岛上甚至还有一个码头，树林深处还有一栋舒适的房子。

Sandy discovered that a widow in upstate New York owned the property. He wrote her a letter, introduced himself, and asked her to let him know if she were ever interested in selling. He heard nothing back in return, but the inquiry had cost him only a few minutes of his time.

桑迪发现这处房产的所有者是纽约州北部的一位寡妇。他给她写了一封信，做了自我介绍，并请她如果将来有意出售房产可以联系他。他没有收到任何回复，但这次询问只花费了他几分钟的时间。

He wrote again the following year. This time he described his family’s love for the ocean and what his young children had been doing in school. Again, no answer. For the next six years, he composed his annual letter, reiterating his interest in the island and updating the owner on family news. Never did he get a reply.

第二年他又写了一封信。这次他描述了全家对大海的热爱，以及孩子们在学校的近况。依然杳无音信。接下来的六年里，他每年都写信，重申自己对这座岛屿的喜爱，并向岛主汇报家里的近况。但他始终没有收到任何回复。

Finally, he sent a note saying that he hoped he hadn’t been a nuisance. He would call, he said, and if she wished him to stop, he would respect her wishes. When he called a few days later, a nurse answered and told him that the woman couldn’t come to the phone but that she would like him to keep writing.

最后，他写了张便条，说希望自己没有打扰到她。他说他会打电话，如果她希望他停止，他会尊重她的意愿。几天后他打电话过去，接电话的是一位护士，护士告诉他，那位女士不方便接电话，但希望他继续写信。

Several months later, Sandy received a letter from the owner saying that she was now ready to sell. She wanted him to make an offer. Sandy calculated the most he could afford and sent a proposal, explaining his circumstances. This time the woman phoned him to say that she would accept his figure. Sandy was ecstatic. But then the next day, he got a second call, this time from the woman’s lawyer, saying that the deal was off because his bid was far less than the appraised value.

几个月后，桑迪收到房主的来信，说她准备出售房产，希望他出价。桑迪计算出自己能负担的最高价格，并提交了一份报价，解释了自己的情况。这次，房主打电话告诉他，她接受他的报价。桑迪欣喜若狂。但第二天，他又接到了第二个电话，这次是房主的律师打来的，说交易取消了，因为他的出价远低于评估价。

Sandy wrote back to the owner that he understood the circumstances, but his offer was the best he could do given his family obligations. Two days later, the woman overruled her lawyer. Sandy now owns Bold Island. All it took to negotiate purchasing one of the jewels of the Maine coast was ten postage stamps—and a decade’s worth of patience.

桑迪回信给岛主，表示理解她的处境，但考虑到家庭责任，这已是他能给出的最好报价。两天后，那位女士推翻了律师的决定。桑迪现在拥有了博尔德岛。而促成这笔缅因州海岸明珠的交易，仅仅用了十张邮票——以及十年的耐心。

BEST-CASE AND WORST-CASE ANALYSIS

最佳情况和最坏情况分析

Answering the three core questions (Should you negotiate? Is now the time? Do you go all in?) requires projecting yourself into the future. Doing a “ pre mortem” is powerful protection against wishful thinking. It’s a strategic planning technique advocated by decision scientist Gary Klein in his book Intuition at Work: Why Developing Your Gut Instincts Will Make You Better at What You Do (it has since been retitled The Power of Intuition ).

回答这三个核心问题（你应该谈判吗？现在是时机吗？你应该全力以赴吗？）需要你对未来进行预测。进行“事前验尸”（premortem）是防止一厢情愿想法的有效方法。这是一种战略规划技巧，决策科学家加里·克莱因在他的著作《工作中的直觉：为什么培养你的直觉会让你在工作中表现更出色》（后更名为《直觉的力量》）中提出了这一观点。

Klein’s research shows that in critiquing any plan, it’s not enough to ask, “Can we foresee any problems with this approach?” Such a question will surface some concerns, but often it’s a skimpy list. It’s easy to be smitten with your own logic. Having mapped backward from point Z—your goal—to your starting point, A, you may persuade yourself that there is but one true way that things can go. Klein has found that slightly rephrasing the question conjures up a richer picture of what could unfold. Specifically, test your strategy by asking this:

克莱因的研究表明，在评估任何计划时，仅仅问“我们能预见到这种方法会有什么问题吗？”是不够的。这样的问题会引出一些担忧，但通常列出的问题清单非常简略。人们很容易被自己的逻辑所迷惑。从目标点 Z 反向推算到起点 A，你可能会说服自己事情只有一种正确的发展方向。克莱因发现，稍微改变一下问题的措辞，就能描绘出一幅更丰富的图景，展现可能出现的各种情况。具体来说，你可以通过问自己以下问题来检验你的策略：

• Premortem Part 1: Flash forward. Imagine that the negotiation is under way. Now imagine there’s been a major setback. What is it?

• 事前分析（第一部分）：设想一下谈判正在进行中。现在想象一下，谈判出现了重大挫折。是什么挫折呢？

That subtle shift in framing will animate your vision. Your focus will shift from whether something bad might happen to assuming that trouble will occur . You needn’t be paranoid. Put aside being hit by a meteor just as you’re about to sign the deal. But consider things that are unlikely yet still could happen.

这种微妙的视角转变会让你的视野更加生动。你的关注点会从“是否可能发生坏事”转移到“假设麻烦一定会发生”。你无需杞人忧天。先别去想在你即将签署合同时被陨石砸中这种事。但要考虑那些可能性很小但仍然可能发生的事情。

Perhaps, for example, there’s a small chance that the market will shift in the other party’s favor or that after making an agreement, you learn belatedly that you could have gotten better terms elsewhere. If you think about such scenarios, you may realize that they’re more probable than you’d like to admit. A seemingly simple transaction with a supplier could drag out longer than expected, for instance. If that happens, meeting commitments to your own customers could be difficult. You’d be in a weak position unless you lined up a fallback in advance.

例如，市场形势或许有很小的概率会向对方有利的方向转变，或者达成协议后，你才发现其实在其他地方可以获得更优惠的条件。仔细想想这些情况，你可能会意识到它们发生的概率比你想象的要高得多。比如，与供应商之间看似简单的交易，可能会比预期拖延更久。如果这种情况发生，你就很难履行对客户的承诺。除非你事先做好备选方案，否则你将处于不利地位。

The point of the premortem exercise isn’t to identify each and every way a deal might go wrong. That’s neither possible nor necessary. Rather, it’s meant to foster an attitude of watchfulness, so you’ll be quicker to see that the process is going awry. If you’re alert, you may be able to get back on track. If not, you’ll have a plan B.

事前分析的目的并非在于找出交易中可能出错的每一个环节。这既不可能也没必要。它的目的是培养一种警惕的态度，让你能更快地发现流程中的偏差。如果你保持警觉，或许还能及时纠正错误。即便失败，你也有备选方案。

In planning ahead, it’s just as important to be open to good news, of course. Thus, you should couple Klein’s premortem with an optimistic test:

当然，在制定计划时，保持开放的心态接受好消息同样重要。因此，你应该将克莱因的“事前验尸”与乐观测试结合起来：

• Premortem Part 2: Flash forward again. This time imagine that there’s been some sort of pleasant surprise. What is it?

• 事前分析第二部分：再次快进到未来。这次想象一下，发生了一些令人惊喜的事情。那会是什么呢？

You needn’t fantasize that you’re going to win the MacArthur “Genius Grant” for negotiation. Rather, limit your analysis to the outer bounds of reality. Think of something positive that has a 10 percent chance of occurring. If you’re buying new equipment or supplies, maybe your vendor has an unexpected overstock, for example. If so, you might get a better price or faster delivery than in the past.

你无需幻想自己能凭借谈判技巧赢得麦克阿瑟“天才奖”。相反，你应该将分析范围限定在现实的合理范围内。想想那些发生概率为10%的积极因素。例如，如果你要购买新设备或耗材，供应商可能正好有意料之外的库存过剩。如果是这样，你或许能获得比以往更优惠的价格或更快的交货速度。

Optimistic scenarios will raise your sights. Studies show that negotiators who set lofty goals get better deals. By aiming high, they don’t give away as much of the bargaining range when there’s ample room to negotiate. Instead of contenting themselves with outcomes they can live with, these negotiators focus instead on how much the other party might be prepared to grant. In addition, imagining upside scenarios prepare you to recognize opportunities and find creative solutions.

乐观的设想能让你放眼未来。研究表明，设定远大目标的谈判者往往能达成更好的交易。目标高远意味着，在谈判空间充足的情况下，他们不会轻易放弃太多谈判筹码。这些谈判者不会满足于自己能够接受的结果，而是专注于对方可能做出的让步。此外，设想有利的局面能帮助你发现机遇，找到创造性的解决方案。

Research also shows that positive and negative expectations about negotiation can be self-fulfilling. In a recent experiment on psychological priming, Adam Galinksy and his colleagues gave some subjects five minutes to write a pep talk for themselves. They were told to list the outcomes they desired and the behaviors they would use to achieve, or promote, them. The subjects in a second group were instructed to list mistakes that they might make and what they could do to prevent those errors.

研究还表明，人们对谈判的积极和消极预期都可能产生自我实现的效应。在最近一项关于心理启动效应的实验中，亚当·加林斯基和他的同事让一些受试者用五分钟时间写一段自我激励的文字。他们被要求列出自己期望的结果以及实现或促进这些结果的行为。另一组受试者则被要求列出自己可能犯的错误以及可以采取哪些措施来避免这些错误。

As you’d expect, the optimistic “promoters” made bolder demands than did the more cautious “preventers.” While the former concentrated on what they could accomplish, the latter thought about how they could fail. But there was an added bonus: when promotion-primed negotiators were matched up against one another, they created far more value than did pairs of prevention-primed people.
