Those in the latter group tended to accept anything that met their minimum needs, while the promoters pushed harder for their real priorities instead of just compromising. As a result, they were more likely to spot mutually beneficial trades.

正如你所预料的，乐观的“推动者”提出的要求比谨慎的“阻止者”更为大胆。前者专注于他们能够达成的目标，而后者则考虑他们可能失败的方式。但还有一个额外的好处：当两两一组的“推动者”谈判时，他们创造的价值远高于两两一组的“阻止者”。后者往往接受任何能够满足他们最低需求的条件，而“推动者”则会更加努力地争取他们真正优先考虑的事项，而不是仅仅做出妥协。因此，他们更有可能发现互惠互利的交易。

CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM

谨慎乐观

Thinking hard about both the upside and the downside simultaneously requires a healthy schizophrenia. Optimism can generate value and put you in a better position to get a goodly share of it. But being unrealistic is doubly dangerous. Dreaming that a customer will give you the sun, the moon, and the stars for whatever you’re offering could leave you empty-handed if he or she can find a more reasonably priced provider. Ungrounded optimism can also blind you to obstacles that may pop up. The realist will be quicker to recognize that things haven’t gone as hoped and to improvise accordingly.

同时认真思考利弊需要一种健康的“精神分裂症”。乐观可以创造价值，让你更有机会从中获益。但不切实际则危险得多。幻想客户会为你提供的产品或服务付出天价，如果他们能找到价格更合理的供应商，你最终可能一无所获。不切实际的乐观也会让你对可能出现的障碍视而不见。务实的人会更快地意识到事情并未如预期发展，并做出相应的调整。

The snowbound soldiers in the Alps drew confidence from their map. It renewed their hopes and gave them direction. Fortunately, they didn’t fall into the trap of “bending the map.” They didn’t twist reality to fit their preconceptions. Instead, as with strategy for negotiation, they used it as a tool for ongoing learning, adaptation, and ultimate survival.

被困在阿尔卑斯山雪中的士兵们从地图中汲取信心。地图重燃了他们的希望，并指引了方向。幸运的是，他们没有落入“曲解地图”的陷阱。他们没有为了迎合自己的成见而扭曲现实。相反，他们像运用谈判策略一样，将地图作为持续学习、适应和最终生存的工具。

In complex cases, formal analytic tools can help formulate and test different scenarios. In a lawsuit settlement, for example, decision tree software can gauge risk at different stages of litigation. Similarly, elaborate financial models can reveal alternative ways of structuring deals in the face of turbulent markets. For most cases, though, thinking out loud and back-of-envelope assessments are sufficient.

在复杂案例中，正式的分析工具可以帮助构建和测试不同的方案。例如，在诉讼和解中，决策树软件可以评估诉讼不同阶段的风险。同样，复杂的财务模型可以揭示在动荡的市场环境下构建交易的替代方法。但对于大多数情况而言，口头思考和粗略评估就足够了。

Let’s go back to Arvind Gupta’s case, where he blew a bargain purchase of beachfront property. He didn’t have to be clairvoyant to foresee the chance he was taking. Merely asking himself this question—“Something has gone disastrously wrong; what is it?”—would have highlighted the risk of counteroffering. Granted, Arvind was in a bind because he was playing with his silent partner’s money. At the latter’s suggestion, he drew up a purchase-and-sale agreement, thick with legalese, with the lowball counteroffer buried down near the bottom of the document. When the owners came to that provision, they were shocked. Arvind sheepishly tried to explain, but it was too late, and the deal was dead.

让我们回到阿文德·古普塔的案例，他错失了一笔划算的海滨房产交易。他无需预知未来也能预见到自己正在冒的风险。只要问问自己——“出了大问题，到底是什么问题？”——就能意识到还价的风险。诚然，阿文德当时处境艰难，因为他动用的是合伙人的钱。在合伙人的建议下，他起草了一份充斥着法律术语的买卖协议，并将低价还价条款藏在了协议的末尾。当业主看到这一条款时，他们大吃一惊。阿文德尴尬地试图解释，但为时已晚，交易已经告吹。

If he had thought more imaginatively about the risk of rejection, instead of just crossing his fingers, he could have managed the downside. Suppose, for example, he had begun his conversation with the owners by assuring them that he would buy the property. With that settled, he could have sought their help in solving his problem with his coinvestor. Could they come down just a bit, he might have asked, so he wouldn’t jeopardize his financing? Perhaps the owners would have said no, but it’s hard to believe they would have been insulted. It’s even possible that they might have offered the seller financing themselves. Even if they didn’t budge, it wouldn’t have been hard for Arvind to go back to Wealthy Bill, who already had okayed the asking price.

如果他当初能更理性地考虑被拒绝的风险，而不是仅仅祈祷好运，或许就能更好地应对不利局面。例如，假设他一开始就向房主保证自己会买下这处房产。既然这一点已经确定，他就可以寻求房主的帮助，解决他和另一位投资人之间的问题。他或许会问他们能否稍微降价，以免影响他的融资。房主或许会拒绝，但很难相信他们会因此感到被冒犯。他们甚至有可能主动提出为卖方提供融资。即便房主不肯让步，Arvind 也完全可以去找已经同意要价的“富豪比尔”。

And what of Liz and Tony Weiler, our other buyers, who said yes to an apparent ultimatum but still brood over whether they overpaid? They recognized the risk of countering and concluded that the upside of saving a little money wasn’t worth the chance of jeopardizing a fragile agreement. There were alternatives beyond the take-it-or-leave-it options stated by the owner’s son. They might have used the “principled approach” advocated in Getting to Yes by asking, “How did you arrive at your price?” The idea is to shift the conversation away from hard dollars and focus instead on fairness criteria (comparable sales, for example). If the parties can agree on an appropriate standard, then it may be easier for them to arrive at a workable price.

那么，另一位买家莉兹和托尼·韦勒夫妇呢？他们虽然答应了看似最后通牒的报价，但内心仍在纠结是否出价过高。他们意识到还价的风险，最终认为省下一点钱的收益并不值得冒着破坏脆弱协议的风险。除了房主儿子提出的“要么接受要么放弃”的选项之外，还有其他选择。他们或许可以采用《谈判力》一书中提倡的“原则性方法”，比如询问“你们是如何确定这个价格的？”。这样做的目的是将讨论的焦点从具体的金额转移到公平性标准上（例如，参考可比房屋的销售情况）。如果双方能够就一个合适的标准达成一致，那么就更容易找到一个双方都能接受的价格。

That tactic might be worth trying in other instances, though I’m skeptical about using it in a case where getting the seller to negotiate was a long and ticklish process. With little to gain and much to lose by prolonging the negotiation, it was best simply to say yes. The Weilers got the house that they wanted, after all. As with any successful deal, it came with the nagging question of whether they could have done a little better. That kind of doubt is better, though, than the regret that Arvind lives with.

在其他情况下，这种策略或许值得一试，但我对在与卖家谈判过程漫长而棘手的情况下使用这种方法持怀疑态度。延长谈判收益甚微，损失却很大，所以最好的办法就是直接答应。毕竟，韦勒夫妇最终还是买到了心仪的房子。任何成功的交易都会伴随着一个挥之不去的疑问：他们是否可以做得更好？不过，这种疑虑总比阿文德日后一直活在悔恨之中要好得多。

You need the optimism and self-confidence that you’ll be able to seize opportunity when things break your way. But you have to accept that in negotiation your fate is never solely in your hands. Some of what happens in a given case will be either unpredictable or beyond your control. Negotiation strategy must allow for that reality.

你需要保持乐观和自信，相信自己能够在机遇来临时牢牢把握住它。但你必须明白，在谈判中，你的命运并非完全掌握在自己手中。某些事情的发生往往是无法预料的，或者超出你的控制范围。谈判策略必须考虑到这一现实。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Choose whether to negotiate further or simply say yes to an acceptable offer.

■ 选择是继续谈判还是直接接受可接受的报价。

■ Time negotiations to your advantage, if possible.

■ 尽可能把握谈判时机，争取对自己有利。

■ Decide whether to hedge or go all in.

■ 决定是采取对冲策略还是全力投入。

■ Weigh best- and worst-case scenarios as you formulate strategy.

■ 在制定策略时，要权衡最佳情况和最坏情况。

■ Balance optimism and caution.

■ 保持乐观和谨慎的平衡。

#↩

[ 3 ] Prospecting

[ 3 ] 勘探

Several years ago, colleagues and I organized a negotiation workshop for general managers in the National Hockey League. They earn their living by hammering out big contracts with their players—or, more specifically, with their agents. Deals for superstars add up to millions of dollars and can lock in a team for up to a decade or more. The NHL imposes an overall salary cap on teams, so signing the right players at the right prices is critical to success on the ice.

几年前，我和同事们为国家冰球联盟（NHL）的总经理们组织了一场谈判研讨会。他们的工作就是与球员——更准确地说，是与球员经纪人——敲定巨额合同。超级球星的合同金额高达数百万美元，足以让球队锁定十年甚至更久。NHL对各队实行工资帽限制，因此，以合适的价格签下合适的球员对于球队在冰上取得成功至关重要。

To illustrate the importance of preparation, we split the participants into two groups and put them in separate rooms. We asked people in one group to be in their familiar role of general manager. We had the others be agents. Then we gave everyone the statistics and r é sum é of an unsigned player, with only his name disguised. Although the participants didn’t know it, everyone got the same information.

为了说明准备工作的重要性，我们将参与者分成两组，分别安排在不同的房间里。我们要求其中一组扮演他们熟悉的总经理角色，另一组则扮演经纪人。然后，我们给每组参与者提供一位未签约球员的统计数据和简历，只隐去了球员的姓名。尽管参与者并不知情，但每个人都获得了相同的信息。

We asked everyone three questions about how he’d negotiate this contract, whichever side they happened to be on. We wanted to know their planned first offer (or demand, in the case of agent) and their absolute walkaway. Then we asked what they thought the other party’s walkaway would be.

我们问了每个人三个关于如何谈判这份合同的问题，无论他们站在哪一方。我们想知道他们计划的首次报价（如果是经纪人，则是他们的要价）以及他们的底线。然后我们问他们认为对方的底线会是多少。

When we paired up people to negotiate, the most that teams were prepared to pay was almost always less than the minimum that the agent was willing to accept. In more than 90 percent of the matches, there was no room for agreement. Many participants were hundreds of thousands of dollars apart. And here’s the kicker: this gap was precisely what these guys expected! Almost all of them had predicted a stalemate. They went into negotiations knowing that their best offer wouldn’t be enough to satisfy the other side.

当我们安排双方进行谈判时，球队愿意支付的最高价格几乎总是低于经纪人愿意接受的最低价。超过90%的谈判中，双方根本没有达成协议的余地。许多参与者之间的报价差距高达数十万美元。更令人惊讶的是：这种差距正是他们预料之中的！几乎所有人都预料到谈判会陷入僵局。他们一开始就知道，即使自己给出最高报价，也无法让对方满意。

That’s not to say they thought the case was nonnegotiable. Not so. They knew from experience that players and teams work things out. But for most of these GMs, negotiation is about getting the other side to cave in. Maybe it shouldn’t be surprising that those in the hard-hitting world of pro hockey view negotiation as a contest of wills. But that’s also how many other people picture the process, whether they’re buying a car, selling a home, or even working out a salary for a new job.

这并非意味着他们认为此事毫无谈判余地。并非如此。他们从经验中得知，球员和球队最终都能解决问题。但对大多数总经理而言，谈判的本质在于让对方让步。或许，职业冰球这个竞争激烈的世界里，人们将谈判视为意志力的较量并不令人意外。但事实上，许多人对谈判过程的理解也与此类似，无论是买车、卖房，甚至是协商新工作的薪资。

This zero-sum model positions an irresistible force on one side (the player) and an immovable object (team management) on the other, with each pushing hard until somebody budges. Seeing negotiation this way makes it a win-lose proposition.

这种零和博弈模式将谈判双方视为不可抗拒的力量（球员）和不可撼动的对象（球队管理层），双方都竭尽全力，直到一方让步为止。这样看待谈判，就将其变成了一场零和博弈。

The one-dimensional model fails to reflect the real-world complexity of negotiation. Because it considers only price, it fosters a “fixed pie” attitude, as my colleague Max Bazerman calls it. When people believe that there is only a given amount to be divided, the long knives come out. And even if you recognize the potential of value-generating trades, the one-dimensional framework is no help in weighing one package of proposals against another.

这种一维模型无法反映现实世界谈判的复杂性。因为它只考虑价格，所以会滋生一种“蛋糕是固定的”心态，正如我的同事马克斯·巴泽曼所说。当人们认为只有一定数量的利益可以分配时，就会出现恶性竞争。即使你认识到存在创造价值的交易，这种一维框架也无法帮助你权衡不同的方案。

Take the case of my friend Jack when he was car shopping a few years ago. He likes Volvos, but only the sporty coupes and fancy sedans. On a visit to the dealer, however, he spotted a jet-black, souped-up wagon with a 300-plus horsepower engine, a six-speed gearbox, and high-tech wheels.

以我朋友杰克几年前买车时的经历为例。他喜欢沃尔沃，但只喜欢运动型轿跑车和豪华轿车。然而，在一次去经销商那里时，他却发现了一辆漆黑的改装旅行车，配备了300多马力的发动机、六速变速箱和高科技轮毂。

Although Jack usually buys brand new, he asked the salesman why this particular vehicle already had five thousand miles on it. “Oh, it was too much car for the guy who bought it.” That comment was the clincher for my type-A friend, though the salesman didn’t know that. Privately, Jack loved the car, but he also loves a bargain, so he was doing his best to mask his craving.

虽然杰克通常都买新车，但他还是问销售员为什么这辆车已经跑了五千英里。“哦，对买家来说，这车太大了。”这句话彻底打动了我这位A型性格的朋友，尽管销售员并不知道这一点。杰克私下里很喜欢这辆车，但他又喜欢捡便宜，所以他竭力掩饰自己的欲望。

Jack knew there would be a deal. Even then that much was certain. But he couldn’t know how far he could knock down the sticker price. Nor could he know how long this little dance would take or where they’d end up.

杰克知道肯定能达成交易。这一点他非常确定。但他无法预知价格能降到什么程度。他也无法预料这场拉锯战会持续多久，最终结果又会如何。

The situation was hazier for the salesman, who was trying to assess this stranger who had ambled into the showroom. Was Jack a prospect or just a tire kicker killing time? Either way, what would be the best way to pitch him? Should he push on price or just be happy to move an offbeat vehicle off the lot? Jack dresses well. Maybe the salesman sniffed a thick wallet. Then again, Jack’s self-confidence is unmistakable, so he also could look like a tough bargainer. Good salespeople have intuitions about customers, but that’s not the same as hard-and-fast knowledge.

对于销售员来说，情况就比较复杂了。他正努力判断这个漫步走进展厅的陌生人究竟是潜在客户，还是只是个闲逛的顾客？无论如何，该如何向他推销呢？是应该在价格上多下功夫，还是只想尽快把这辆不太常见的车卖出去？杰克衣着考究。或许销售员已经嗅到了他鼓鼓囊囊的钱包。但话说回来，杰克的自信显而易见，所以他也可能看起来像个难缠的买家。优秀的销售员对顾客有直觉，但这和确凿的了解是两回事。

Underneath all the posturing and bantering, Jack and the smooth-talking salesman were negotiating seriously. Each was trying to scope out the bargaining range. Jack had to see this car himself, hear why it was being sold, and revise his antiwagon bias. In turn, the salesman was sizing up my friend’s interest (and his budget). Walking into the showroom, Jack would have bet dollars to donuts against even looking at a station wagon. That same afternoon, after a lot of haggling, he happily drove one home—and at a good number, too.

在所有虚张声势和玩笑话的背后，杰克和那位能说会道的销售员其实是在认真谈判。双方都在试探价格的底线。杰克必须亲眼看看这辆车，听听它被卖掉的原因，并修正他对旅行车的偏见。而销售员则在评估我朋友的兴趣（以及他的预算）。走进展厅时，杰克肯定打赌自己连看一眼旅行车都不会。然而，就在当天下午，经过一番讨价还价，他兴高采烈地把一辆旅行车开回了家——而且价格也相当不错。

But even in this simple transaction, price wasn’t the only issue Jack had to resolve. Should he accept the dealer’s offer on his trade-in or go through the hassle of a private sale? He decided on the latter. Did he want to finance the purchase? Jack had planned to pay cash, but Volvo was subsidizing a 1 percent rate. That was too good to pass up. He also got an extended warranty at cost. The terms were worked out in back-and-forth discussion. Some of the options that the salesman proposed weren’t worth the money, Jack felt, but others were. In the end, price was still an important factor, but other items proved to have value too.

但即便在这笔简单的交易中，价格也不是杰克唯一需要考虑的问题。他应该接受经销商的旧车置换报价，还是费劲地进行私人交易？他最终选择了后者。他是否想要贷款购车？杰克原本打算全款支付，但沃尔沃提供了1%的利率补贴。这实在太划算了，不容错过。他还以成本价购买了延保服务。双方来回协商，最终敲定了条款。杰克觉得销售员提出的一些选项并不值得花钱，但也有一些物有所值。最终，价格仍然是一个重要因素，但其他一些项目也同样具有价值。

The familiar win-lose bargaining-range notion ignores the trading and tweaking that take place even in everyday transactions like Jack’s. This chapter presents an alternative, more realistic model for conceptualizing the area of potential agreement, as well as a tool for developing appropriate strategy. Used together, these models can serve as a negotiator’s map of the Pyrenees.

传统的赢输博弈概念忽略了即使在像杰克这样的日常交易中也存在的讨价还价和调整。本章提出了一种更贴近现实的替代模型，用于概念化潜在的协议范围，并提供一个制定合适策略的工具。结合使用这些模型，它们可以作为谈判者探索比利牛斯山脉的地图。

CONSTRUCTING A DEAL TRIANGLE

构建交易三角

We’ll start with the deal triangle shown below. It’s bounded on one side by your own baseline—that is, outcomes that you prefer marginally over making no deal at all. The second side is the other party’s baseline, or the corresponding set of potential deals that it finds acceptable, though just barely. The third line is made up of real-world constraints that limit the parties’ ability to be creative. These might be resource shortages, deadlines, or company policies that can’t be violated.

我们先来看下图所示的交易三角。它的一边是你自己的底线——也就是你勉强能接受的、比完全不达成交易更可接受的结果。另一边是对方的底线，也就是对方勉强能接受的潜在交易方案。第三边则是由现实中的各种限制因素构成，这些因素限制了双方的创造性。例如资源短缺、截止日期，或者不能违反的公司政策。

The triangle formed by these three boundaries represents the territory of workable outcomes from everyone’s point of view. Any proposal beyond that is a deal breaker, since it’s out of bounds for at least one of the parties.

由这三条边界构成的三角形代表了各方都能接受的可行方案范围。任何超出这个范围的提议都会导致交易失败，因为它至少对其中一方来说是越界的。

This triangle image allows parties to move into a broader area of workable deals, not just back and forth along a taut line. Where there’s some room for agreement, parties will still differ about which particular outcome they prefer, of course. And when there is no deal space starting out (as with the hockey GMs), agreement may be reached by finding creative solutions rather than through concessions.

这种三角形图能帮助各方在更广泛的可行交易范围内进行博弈，而不是仅仅沿着一条紧绷的线来回拉锯。当然，即使存在一些达成共识的空间，各方对于最终结果的偏好仍然会存在分歧。而当一开始就没有达成交易的余地时（例如冰球总经理们的情况），或许可以通过寻找创造性的解决方案而非做出让步来达成协议。

If you conclude there’s little room for agreement, you should be satisfied with outcomes that are an improvement over the status quo, even if only just a bit. By contrast, if you sense that the area between the parties’ respective baselines could expand, then strive to create (and claim) more value. To succeed, you need to know which one of these two situations you’re in. If you don’t have a clue whether there’s only a little room or a lot, you’re simply tossing darts blindfolded. It’s hard to hit a bull’s-eye if you can’t see the target.

如果你认为双方几乎没有达成共识的余地，那么即使只是略微改善现状，你也应该感到满意。相反，如果你觉得双方的底线之间还有扩大的空间，那么就应该努力创造（并争取）更多价值。要想成功，你需要知道自己处于哪种情况。如果你完全不清楚双方的合作空间是小还是大，那就好比蒙着眼睛扔飞镖。如果看不到靶心，就很难击中靶心。

Explaining the deal triangle concept is easy. Getting an accurate fix on real-world possibilities is more challenging. The deal triangle isn’t rigid. It can flex, grow, or vanish as conditions change in negotiation. Even so, keeping that picture in mind will help you chart your progress as you test assumptions and update your expectations.

解释交易三角的概念很容易，但要准确把握现实世界中的可能性却更具挑战性。交易三角并非一成不变，它会随着谈判条件的变化而灵活调整、扩展甚至消失。即便如此，牢记这一概念仍有助于你在检验假设和更新预期时，更好地把握谈判进展。

SETTING YOUR BASELINE

设定你的基准线

The term bottom line rankles sophisticated negotiators, and with good reason if that’s taken to mean a rigid position. Why handcuff yourself by assuming that there’s only one way to satisfy your interests? What you discover as you negotiate may justify either upping your demands or softening them. On the other hand, you need a disciplined way of knowing when to say yes and when to say no. You need to draw a line somewhere, but define it broadly. Rather than putting a single stake in the ground, prepare by identifying a set of different outcomes that would be acceptable—though only barely. Together those marginal deals constitute your baseline, or the border that separates your saying yes from your saying no. Drawing the baseline involves three simple steps:

“底线”这个词会让老练的谈判者感到不快，如果将其理解为僵化的立场，这种不快也情有可原。为什么要把自己束缚住，认为只有一种方法可以满足你的利益呢？谈判过程中的发现可能会让你有理由提高或降低你的要求。另一方面，你需要有条不紊地知道何时该说“是”，何时该说“不”。你需要划定一条界限，但要宽泛一些。与其设定一个固定的目标，不如事先确定一系列勉强可以接受的结果。这些勉强可以接受的交易共同构成了你的基准线，也就是区分“是”和“不”的分界线。划定基准线包含三个简单的步骤：

1. Establish a benchmark deal.

1. 建立基准交易。

2. Identify equivalent packages.

2. 找出等效包装。

3. Anticipate likely change.

3. 预测可能的变化。

The first step—establish a benchmark deal—is Negotiation 101. From the first chapter, recall the classic BATNA concept (the best alternative to a negotiated agreement). A particular offer is tempting only if it at least matches your fallback option, all other things being equal. The better your BATNA, the pickier you can be. Correspondingly, if your nonagreement alternative is poor, you may have to take less than you hope for and feel you deserve.

第一步——确定基准交易——是谈判入门课。回顾第一章的经典概念“最佳替代方案”（BATNA）。在其他条件相同的情况下，只有当某个报价至少与你的备选方案相当时，它才具有吸引力。你的BATNA越好，你就可以越挑剔。相应地，如果你的备选方案很差，你可能不得不接受低于你期望和应得的条件。

When going into every negotiation, identify—provisionally—a point on the scales where you’d have a hard time deciding between accepting or rejecting a firm and final proposal from the other side. It’s a way of testing your resolve. It also gives you a standard for evaluating alternative deals.

在每次谈判前，先初步确定一个临界点，在这个临界点上，如果对方提出最终方案，你会很难决定是接受还是拒绝。这既能检验你的决心，也能为你评估其他方案提供一个标准。

Step two is to identify equivalent packages—better in some respects, worse in others—that on balance would be worth the same to you as your benchmark. Here’s an analogy: let’s say that you won a bag of groceries in a supermarket drawing. Everything in the bag may have some value to you, but some items you like, while others, such as fresh raspberries, you love . How many cans of soup would you give up to get another pint of berries? One? Two? Three? Maybe ten? I’m not talking about swaps that would improve the overall value of the mix. Rather, imagine a different assortment that would be worth exactly the same to you as the bag you won initially.

第二步是找到与你的基准组合价值相当的替代方案——有些方面更好，有些方面更差——但总体而言，这些方案对你的价值与你的基准组合相同。举个例子：假设你在超市抽奖中赢得了一袋杂货。袋子里的每样东西对你来说可能都有价值，但有些东西你喜欢，而另一些，比如新鲜的覆盆子，你则非常喜欢。为了再得到一品脱覆盆子，你愿意放弃多少罐汤？一罐？两罐？三罐？或许十罐？我说的不是那些能提升整体价值的交换。而是想象另一种组合，它对你的价值与你最初赢得的那袋杂货完全相同。

Any offer that you receive in negotiation will likewise be a mixed bag of provisions: some that you gain from the other party, and other items that you must grant in return. So identify at least two other such bundles that are of equivalent net value. Remember that the task here is to find deals that put you on the knife edge between accepting and rejecting the proposal.

任何谈判中收到的报价都必然是各种条款的混合体：有些是你从对方那里获得的，有些则是你必须做出的回报。因此，至少要找到另外两个价值相当的类似方案。记住，关键在于找到那些让你在接受和拒绝之间摇摆不定的交易。

Going through this preparation exercise forces you to weigh trade-offs. Thinking them through ahead of time is a whole lot better than making snap decisions in the midst of a negotiation. Mulling over your preferences also opens up your thinking the same way that warming up before a match makes a tennis player limber and focused. Research suggests that negotiators who prepare by toying with alternative solutions generate still more ideas when they negotiate with other parties.

进行这样的准备练习能迫使你权衡利弊。提前思考远比在谈判过程中仓促做决定要好得多。仔细斟酌你的偏好也能像赛前热身让网球运动员更加灵活专注一样，打开你的思路。研究表明，那些事先考虑过各种替代方案的谈判者，在与其他各方谈判时，往往能产生更多想法。

Karen Lacey was reasonably happy in her job but was being wooed by QXData, a top-tier company that she liked a lot. She hoped that it would offer her a handsome compensation package, but she wanted to determine her baseline: the lower boundary of acceptability. Using round numbers, she figured that she might have trouble turning down a $100,000 salary and a standard benefits package. But on the other hand, she had some hesitations about the risks of changing jobs. She decided that an offer of $100,000 was her benchmark deal.

凯伦·莱西对目前的工作还算满意，但她非常欣赏的一家顶尖公司QXData正极力向她抛出橄榄枝。她希望QXData能提供一份优厚的薪酬方案，但她也想先确定自己的底线：也就是能够接受的最低标准。粗略估计，如果年薪10万美元加上标准的福利待遇，她应该很难拒绝。但另一方面，她也对跳槽的风险有所顾虑。最终，她决定将10万美元的年薪作为自己的基准。

With that in mind, Karen thought next about trade-offs, using a yellow pad to note different deals that would be minimally acceptable. She asked herself, for instance, what she would require to make up for a hypothetical 10 percent lower salary. In itself, anything less than $100,000 would drop her into no-deal territory, but adding perks such as stock options, a nice company car, and a lot more vacation time might make up the difference. Getting some equity could offset living on a somewhat smaller income. Then to test her preferences further, she considered what benefits she’d be willing to surrender for a higher paycheck. Having to buy health insurance with after-tax dollars would mean that she’d need a bump of $25,000 in salary to end up with something equal to her benchmark deal.

考虑到这一点，凯伦接下来开始权衡利弊，她用一张黄色便笺纸记下了各种勉强可以接受的条件。例如，她问自己，如果薪水假设降低10%，她需要什么来弥补？如果年薪低于10万美元，她就无法接受这份工作，但如果加上股票期权、公司配车和更多假期等福利，或许可以弥补收入上的差距。获得一些股权可以弥补收入略低带来的影响。为了进一步检验自己的偏好，她考虑了为了更高的薪水，她愿意放弃哪些福利。如果必须用税后收入购买医疗保险，那就意味着她需要增加2.5万美元的薪水才能达到她设定的基准水平。

She hoped to do better than any of these bundles, of course, but she understood the need to lay out the boundary between yes and no. That meant deliberately confronting herself with hard choices. If one of her hypothetical deals looked better than the others, she trimmed it down a bit. If another was trumped by the rest, she sweetened it. After tweaking these packages, she now had three points that constituted her baseline, the first side of the deal triangle.

她当然希望自己能做得比这些方案都好，但她也明白必须划清界限，做出选择。这意味着她要刻意面对艰难的抉择。如果某个假设方案看起来比其他方案更好，她就会稍微调整一下。如果另一个方案被其他方案压制，她就会增加一些优惠。经过一番调整，她最终确定了三个关键点，作为她的基准，也就是交易三角的第一条边。

Thinking imaginatively about your baseline is important whether the negotiation affects your career (as it would for Karen) or is a simpler transaction. If you’re shopping for a car, for example, you’d take test drives, read Consumer Reports , and research pricing online. But having chosen what make and model vehicle you want, figure the top dollar you’d pay. (Once again you’re just drawing a walkaway line, not setting any goals just yet.) But don’t stop there. Next, conjure some equivalent deals. How deep a price discount would it take for you to be tempted by a demo with ten thousand miles on it? Or go in the other direction: How much more would you pay if the dealer included a premium sound system?

无论谈判是否会影响你的职业生涯（就像凯伦的情况一样），或者只是一笔简单的交易，发挥想象力设定你的底线都至关重要。例如，如果你要买车，你会试驾、阅读《消费者报告》并在网上查询价格。但是，在选定你想要的车型之后，先估算一下你能接受的最高价格。（再次强调，你只是划定了一个底线，暂时不要设定任何目标。）但不要就此止步。接下来，设想一些类似的交易。一辆行驶了1万英里的试驾车，需要多大的折扣才能让你心动？或者反过来想：如果经销商加装一套高级音响系统，你愿意多付多少钱？

Such assessments should be sketched in pencil, subject to change depending on what you learn while you’re negotiating. When Karen sits down to close the deal with her new employer, her enthusiasm for the job may grow. Together they may think of other items that she values (a discretionary budget, for example). As new issues and alternatives arise, her initial trade-off analysis will give her a solid foundation from which to work.

这类评估应该先用铅笔勾勒出来，并根据谈判过程中了解到的情况随时调整。当凯伦与新雇主坐下来敲定合同时，她对这份工作的热情可能会更高。他们可能会一起想到她重视的其他方面（例如，可自由支配的预算）。随着新问题和新方案的出现，她最初的权衡分析将为她后续的工作奠定坚实的基础。

This leads to the last step in establishing a baseline: anticipating change. The analysis so far has been premised on what you know today and how you currently rank your priorities. But you’ll probably learn some important things in the course of negotiation. (It would be odd if you don’t, in fact.) Circumstances may change as well.

这就引出了建立基准的最后一步：预测变化。到目前为止的分析都是基于你目前掌握的信息以及你当前的优先级排序。但在谈判过程中，你很可能会了解到一些重要的事情。（事实上，如果你没有了解到任何重要的事情，那才奇怪呢。）情况也可能会发生变化。

Let’s use Karen’s example; specifically, the three packages she identified to trace out her baseline. She imagined what might happen that would raise her minimum requirements. What if in the midst of negotiating with the new company, her current employer gave her a promotion—and the pay increase that would go with it? That would improve her BATNA significantly, in respect to both money and status. QXData would then have to offer more than the $100,000 that initially would have been tempting.

我们以凯伦的例子为例；具体来说，就是她为了确定基准线而确定的三个方案。她设想了哪些情况会提高她的最低要求。如果在与新公司谈判的过程中，她现在的雇主给她升职加薪呢？这将显著改善她的最佳替代方案（BATNA），无论从金钱还是地位方面来看都是如此。这样一来，QXData就不得不提供比最初诱人的10万美元更高的报价了。

But she also considered what situational changes might justify accepting less than her original baseline. She had just bought a new home and had her old condo under agreement. But if that latter deal didn’t close, she’d be stuck owning two properties in a weak real estate market. If Karen had to cover two mortgages, straight salary could look better than stock options. She might readjust her trade-offs accordingly.

但她也考虑过，哪些情况的变化可能让她接受低于最初预期的条件。她刚买了一套新房，之前的公寓也已经达成交易。但如果后者交易失败，在房地产市场疲软的情况下，她将不得不同时拥有两套房产。如果凯伦需要偿还两份房贷，那么固定工资可能比股票期权更有吸引力。她或许会据此调整自己的权衡取舍。

When Karen took into account how her baseline could change, it looked more like a brushstroke on a watercolor painting than a clear-cut line on a blueprint. She was all right with that ambiguity. It reminded her that her success negotiating with QXData would be influenced not just by her skill but also by external factors. Moreover, she knew that her baseline was merely one boundary of the deal space, not a measure of success. If she did only a little better than her walkaway, she probably wouldn’t make a great deal. Instead, she understood her baseline as simply the lowest rung on a ladder of potentially ascending value.

当凯伦考虑到她的底线可能会发生变化时，它看起来更像是水彩画上的一笔，而不是蓝图上清晰的线条。她并不介意这种模糊性。这提醒她，与QXData谈判的成功不仅取决于她的技巧，还取决于外部因素。此外，她明白她的底线仅仅是交易范围的一个边界，而不是衡量成功的标准。如果她最终的报价只比她的底线略高一些，她可能也谈不上达成一笔大交易。相反，她把底线理解为潜在价值阶梯上的最低一级。

ESTIMATING THEIR BASELINE

估算他们的基线

The amount of room for agreement depends on how your interests dovetail with those of your counterpart, but estimating a counterpart’s baseline can be difficult. One reason is strategic. People on the other side may be wary about disclosing how far they’d be willing to compromise, concerned that if you knew their limit, you’d push them right up to it. If you ask flat out, they’re likely to bluff or be evasive. (Or they might turn the same question back on you.)

双方达成共识的空间取决于彼此利益的契合程度，但评估对方的底线并非易事。原因之一是策略性的。对方可能不愿透露自己愿意妥协的程度，担心一旦被你摸清底线，就会逼他们突破底线。如果你直接问，他们很可能会虚张声势或闪烁其词。（或者他们也可能反过来问你同样的问题。）

You must look for clues elsewhere. If you’re house shopping, online services such as Zillow can give you an overall sense of the market. They can’t, however, tell you whether a given owner is in a hurry to sell or is holding out for top dollar. Judgments often have to be made case by case. If Karen thinks about the negotiation from her prospective boss’s perspective, she should be able to anticipate some of his concerns. Agreeing to a high salary might be hard for him if it would disrupt existing pay scales. If that turns out to be a problem, a performance bonus might be a solution.

你必须从其他方面寻找线索。如果你正在寻找房子，像 Zillow 这样的在线服务可以让你对市场有一个大致的了解。但是，它们无法告诉你某个房主是急于出售还是想要高价。很多时候，判断需要具体情况具体分析。如果凯伦能从她未来老板的角度思考谈判，她应该能够预料到他的一些顾虑。如果高薪会打破现有的薪酬体系，那么他可能很难接受。如果这确实是个问题，绩效奖金或许是一个解决办法。

Thinking about what other parties should value is always a risk, however, as they may see things differently. It’s even harder if they’ve done a poor job reckoning their own baseline. Test your thinking with disinterested friends who may suggest other perspectives. Doing so may leave you less sure about your counterpart’s priorities, but that’s preferable to false confidence. Someone like Karen, negotiating a new job, can tap her network. Maybe a friend knows someone else who once worked at QXData and is familiar with its compensation policy.

然而，揣测对方的价值观始终存在风险，因为他们可能持有不同的看法。如果他们连自己的底线都搞不清楚，那就更难了。不妨找些不相关的、能提供不同视角的朋友来检验你的想法。这样做或许会让你对对方的优先事项产生一些疑虑，但这总比盲目自信要好。像凯伦这样正在洽谈新工作的女士，可以利用自己的人脉。也许她的朋友认识曾在QXData工作过、熟悉其薪酬政策的人。

After doing her homework, Karen’s estimate of the other side’s baseline may look less like her own brushstroke and more like a cloud of question marks. So be it. It’s a signal not to treat assumptions as facts. Floating different packages will give her a feel for where her counterpart has flexibility. There may be no harm in aiming high, but if salary proves a stumbling block, she’ll have already come up with an answer.

经过一番功课，凯伦对对方底线的评估可能不再像她自己描绘的那样清晰，而更像是一团问号。没关系。这表明她不能把假设当成事实。提出不同的方案能让她了解对方在哪些方面有回旋余地。提出高价或许无妨，但如果薪资最终成为障碍，她也已经想好了应对之策。

Anticipating the concerns of the other party also provides a basis for influencing its thinking—and shifting its baseline in your favor. Someone looking to buy your house might have calculated how much of a mortgage she can afford. You might persuade her to bump up her offer by explaining how special energy-saving features will reduce operating costs. Or in litigation, revealing key documents may convince the other party to reassess its chances of winning in court.

预判对方的顾虑，也能为影响其思维方式——并使其基准线向你有利的方向转变——奠定基础。例如，有意购买你房产的人可能已经计算过自己能负担多少房贷。你可以通过解释房屋的节能特性如何降低运营成本，说服她提高出价。或者，在诉讼中，披露关键文件或许能促使对方重新评估胜诉的几率。

Mis learning is inevitable. Another car example makes the point. I was at a dealership waiting for an oil change. Alex, a genial salesman with a salt-and-pepper beard, asked, “Got a minute? I’ll tell you a story on myself.”

错误学习是不可避免的。另一个关于汽车的例子可以说明这一点。当时我在一家汽车经销店等着换机油。一位名叫亚历克斯的和蔼可亲的销售员，留着灰白相间的胡子，问道：“有空吗？我给你讲个我自己的故事。”

He pointed out a woman, probably in her early twenties, who was just dropping off her brand-new car for its initial service. She was wearing jeans and a tattered sweatshirt. Alex explained that she and her husband had come in two months earlier and asked about the highest-end model that the dealership sold. They wanted the sunroof, the heated leather seats, almost all fancy options, but not a turbocharged engine.

他指着一位大概二十出头的女士，她正把新车送来做首次保养。她穿着牛仔裤和一件破旧的运动衫。亚历克斯解释说，她和丈夫两个月前来咨询过这家经销店最高端的车型。他们想要天窗、加热真皮座椅，几乎所有的高级配置都要，但不要涡轮增压发动机。

Alex didn’t have such a vehicle in stock, and from what he saw, there was no way this young couple could afford it. In idle chatter, he’d learned that the husband worked on the shipping dock of a wholesale fruit distributor where the wife was a file clerk. Nevertheless, Alex ordered the car, figuring that he could sell it to someone else if this couple couldn’t get financing.

亚历克斯店里没有这种车，而且从他观察来看，这对年轻夫妇肯定买不起。闲聊中，他得知丈夫在一家水果批发商的装卸码头工作，妻子则在那里做档案管理员。尽管如此，亚历克斯还是订了这辆车，心想如果这对夫妇贷不到款，他还可以把车卖给别人。

Sure enough, when he phoned them after the car came in, they seemed evasive. Could you hold it for another week? they asked. Alex half expected never to see them again. But they did appear as promised—and with a cashier’s check for the full amount. The couple apologized for the delay and said that they were sorry for not being straightforward with him earlier. “We just won eight million dollars in the lottery,” they said, “and our lawyer told us to be careful with that information.”

果然，车子送来后，他打电话过去，对方却闪烁其词。“能再留一周吗？”他们问。亚历克斯心想，这下恐怕再也见不到他们了。但他们果然如约出现——还带来了一张全额的银行本票。这对夫妇为耽搁道歉，并表示很抱歉之前没有坦诚相告。“我们刚中了八百万美元的彩票，”他们说，“律师叮嘱我们小心处理这件事。”

Alex couldn’t help himself. “Why didn’t you buy the turbo?” he blurted.

亚历克斯忍不住脱口而出：“你为什么不买涡轮增压版？”

“We don’t want to kill ourselves,” the wife answered sensibly. She and her husband wanted a plush-looking ride, but with a fortune in hand, they planned to drive as cautiously as their grandparents.

“我们不想送命，”妻子理智地回答道。她和丈夫想要一辆看起来很豪华的车，但他们手头有一大笔钱，所以打算像他们的祖父母那样谨慎驾驶。

It’s easy to misread other people, especially at the bargaining table, where they’re likely to be careful about revealing too much. Depending on our personalities and dispositions, we may hope for the best from them or fear the worst. Being observant about how a counterpart’s baseline may have shifted in the course of negotiation is crucial.

我们很容易误读他人，尤其是在谈判桌上，因为对方往往会谨慎地避免透露太多信息。根据我们自身的性格和倾向，我们可能会对他们抱有最好的期望，也可能担心最坏的情况。因此，密切观察对方在谈判过程中立场可能发生的变化至关重要。

IDENTIFYING EXTERNAL CONSTRAINTS

识别外部约束

Real-world factors beyond either party’s control form the third boundary of the triangle. A family may be looking to build a new home. They solicit a bid from a well-regarded contractor and are ready to sign a contract when world timber prices shoot up. What then?

超出双方控制范围的现实因素构成了三角关系的第三个边界。例如，一个家庭可能正打算建造新房。他们向一家信誉良好的承包商询价，并准备签订合同，这时世界木材价格却飙升。接下来该怎么办？

The buyers will either have to stretch their budget and pay more than they expected, or shrink their plans and live in a smaller house. The builder, in turn, will have to recalculate his bid, figuring out what portion of the added cost he can pass on and how much he will have to eat. The family may end up with less house and the builder may get less profit because economic conditions narrowed the deal space. Of course, if lumber prices dropped, room for agreement would expand, leaving one or both parties better off.

买家要么得提高预算，支付超出预期的价格，要么就得缩减计划，住进更小的房子。反过来，建筑商也得重新计算报价，琢磨着增加的成本中哪些可以转嫁给客户，哪些自己要承担。由于经济形势收紧，交易空间缩小，最终买家可能只能买到更小的房子，建筑商的利润也可能减少。当然，如果木材价格下跌，双方的谈判空间就会扩大，让其中一方或双方都从中受益。

Some constraints are economic. Others can be based in law. (Two competing businesses might wish to keep their prices high but be legally barred from price fixing.) The ticking clock can be a limit as well. When my friend Jack bought his souped-up Volvo, the 1 percent financing improved the deal, but it was available (supposedly) for only two more days. Company policy and procedures can be constraints as well.

有些限制因素是经济方面的，有些则源于法律。（例如，两家竞争企业可能都想维持高价，但却被法律禁止进行价格操纵。）时间限制也是一个制约因素。我的朋友杰克买那辆改装过的沃尔沃时，1%的融资利率让交易更加划算，但据说只剩下两天时间了。公司政策和流程也可能构成限制。

Formal analysts would quibble about diagramming the deal space in this way. They’d argue that the “external constraints” line can be ignored if each party folds such factors into its respective preferences. A key element would be lost, however. Sometimes the deal space can be expanded by addressing external constraints. Let’s say that Duncan owns a ten-acre parcel zoned currently for single-family homes on large lots. It’s worth about $750,000. A developer would pay twice that, however, if condos were allowed. In that instance, the parties would have a shared interest in lobbying local officials for a rezoning.

正式的分析师可能会对这种交易空间图解方式提出异议。他们认为，如果各方都将外部限制因素纳入各自的偏好考量，那么“外部限制”这条线就可以忽略不计。然而，这样做会遗漏一个关键要素。有时，通过解决外部限制，交易空间反而可以扩大。假设邓肯拥有一块十英亩的土地，目前规划用途是建造大型独栋住宅。这块地价值约75万美元。但如果允许建造公寓，开发商愿意出价两倍的价格。在这种情况下，各方就有了共同的利益，那就是游说地方官员重新规划土地用途。

Thus, all three sides of the deal triangle are fuzzy. Throughout the process, each side will be trying to fathom the other’s baseline to see how hard it can push its own agenda. In time the resolve of one or both parties may wane. They may engage in less posturing or discover creative ways of breaking the impasse. When that happens, the size and nature of the deal space may change.

因此，交易三角的三方都存在模糊性。在整个过程中，每一方都会试图揣摩对方的底线，以评估自身利益的推进力度。随着时间的推移，一方或双方的决心可能会减弱。他们或许会减少虚张声势，或者找到打破僵局的创新方法。当这种情况发生时，交易空间的大小和性质都可能发生变化。

THE VALUE LADDER

价值阶梯

By definition, all the outcomes within the triangle are feasible for the relevant parties, though they will rate them differently. Your own baseline is merely a floor. Outcomes above it are better for you; some may be much better. You also should set a stretch goal, something to reach for so that you don’t settle too cheaply. It’s not necessarily something that you’d put out as a take-it-or-leave-it offer, otherwise you could end up empty-handed.

根据定义，三角模型中的所有结果对相关各方来说都是可行的，尽管他们对结果的评估会有所不同。你的基准线只是一个最低限度。高于基准线的结果对你更有利；有些结果可能好得多。你也应该设定一个挑战目标，一个努力的方向，这样你就不会轻易妥协。这并非一个可以随意拒绝的选项，否则你最终可能会一无所获。

Establishing a stretch goal calls for best-case-scenario thinking. Specifically, imagine an outstanding result, one that might have only a 10 percent chance of materializing. That’s an arbitrary figure, of course. It represents a possibility that you shouldn’t dismiss, but that wouldn’t leave you surprised or disappointed if it doesn’t come to pass.

设定远大目标需要我们设想最佳情况。具体来说，想象一个卓越的结果，即使它实现的概率只有10%。当然，这只是一个大概的数字。它代表了一种你不应该排除的可能性，但即便最终没有实现，你也不会感到意外或失望。

Goal setting involves guesswork, of course. Much depends on the needs and perceptions of your particular counterpart. Start with the baseline you estimated for them. Then, because you need to stretch, go a bit beyond that by imagining what conditions or beliefs would convince the other party to be even more generous than that. From those potential deals, pick as a target whatever bundle serves you best. Call this intentional wishful thinking. Have high hopes but also ponder what conditions would have to exist to make them come true. If you’re dealing with a vendor, for example, consider the possibility that the company is hungry for your business because it just lost a big order with another customer.

目标设定当然少不了猜测。很大程度上取决于对方的需求和看法。首先，从你预估的基准开始。然后，为了增加一些可能性，不妨在此基础上再进一步，设想一下哪些条件或信念能够说服对方更加慷慨。从这些潜在的交易中，选择最符合你利益的组合作为目标。你可以称之为“有意识的美好愿望”。抱有很高的期望，但也要思考需要哪些条件才能实现这些期望。例如，如果你正在与供应商打交道，可以考虑这样一种可能性：该公司可能因为刚刚失去另一家客户的大订单而急于争取你的业务。

Updating your deal triangle, you locate that best-case scenario well above your baseline—and probably outside the deal triangle, though not much, from the other side’s point of view. (point B , below). In turn, the people with whom you’re negotiating may hope to talk you into accepting their dream deal A . It’s high above their baseline, but a bit below yours. If the other party’s aspirations are unrealistic, you will have a lot of work to do.

更新你的交易三角模型后，你会发现最佳方案远高于你的基准线——而且从对方的角度来看，它可能超出交易三角模型的范围，但差距不大（见下文B点）。反过来，与你谈判的人可能希望说服你接受他们的理想方案A。这个方案远高于他们的基准线，但略低于你的基准线。如果对方的期望不切实际，你将面临很多工作要做。

As Karen thought about her job negotiation, she felt that getting $125,000 salary plus stock options and other perks would be a long shot but not out of the question. If that’s what QXData offered, she’d jump at it, but she was leery about proposing such a package herself. In addition to negotiating her compensation, Karen realized that she was also establishing her relationship with her prospective boss and colleagues. She didn’t want to come on too strong.

凯伦在考虑工作谈判时，觉得争取到12.5万美元的年薪外加股票期权和其他福利虽然希望渺茫，但并非完全不可能。如果QXData真的提供这样的待遇，她肯定会欣然接受，但她自己却不敢提出这样的条件。除了谈判薪酬之外，凯伦也意识到自己是在和未来的老板及同事建立关系。她不想表现得过于强势。

If you’re lucky, you may end up with more than you ever imagined. Jack Binion, a celebrated Las Vegas casino operator, tells of an old Mississippi family that owned some prime farmland that another developer was trying to buy. In planning their strategy, one of them said, “Let’s ask five million for this property.” Others in the family worried that the high number could turn off the developer, but they agreed to give it a try.

如果你足够幸运，最终得到的可能远超你的想象。拉斯维加斯著名赌场经营者杰克·比尼恩讲述了一个密西西比州老家族的故事。这个家族拥有一块黄金地段的农田，另一位开发商正试图收购。在制定策略时，家族中的一位成员提议：“我们开价五百万美元吧。”家族中的其他人担心这个高价会吓跑开发商，但他们还是同意试一试。

Fortunately for them, the buyer started first. “We’ve thought this over,” he said, “and our bottom line is twenty million.” After the siblings caught their breath, they said they’d have to confer privately. When they returned, they were able to bump the final figure up to $25 million.

幸运的是，买家先开了口。“我们已经考虑过了，”他说，“我们的底价是两千万美元。” 兄妹俩喘了口气后，表示需要私下商量一下。等他们回来后，最终成交价定在了两千五百万美元。

In most cases, of course, you’ll settle someplace between the pinnacle of your highest hopes and your baseline. You can think of intermediate levels of satisfaction as rungs on your value ladder, or gradients on a wilderness map that mark increasing altitude as you approach the summit. The more you’ve considered different ways to tweak a deal, the more nimble and creative you’ll be in the thick of negotiation. And keeping those rungs in mind as various proposals are floated lets you judge whether you’re making progress or sliding back.

当然，大多数情况下，你的最终目标会介于你最高的期望和你的底线之间。你可以把这些中间的满意度水平想象成价值阶梯上的台阶，或者荒野地图上的渐变区域，它们标志着你接近顶峰时海拔的不断升高。你考虑过的调整方案越多，在谈判的关键时刻你就会越灵活、越有创造力。在各种方案被提出时，牢记这些阶梯，就能帮助你判断自己是在取得进展还是在倒退。

From a purely strategic viewpoint, it would be ideal if you alone could see the deal space, and your counterpart could not. You’d then be able to compel an outcome that would optimize the deal’s value for you and give those on the other side just enough to gain their assent. That’s your target position (near point B ) in the upper right-hand corner. Of course, if they had perfect vision and you didn’t, they’d push for a result in the upper left (near point A ) that maximizes their welfare but doesn’t do much for you.

纯粹从战略角度来看，最理想的情况是只有你能看到交易空间，而你的交易对手却看不到。这样你就能促成一个对你而言价值最大化的结果，同时又能给对方留下足够的利益以达成一致。这就是你的目标位置（靠近右上角的B点）。当然，如果对方视野开阔而你却看不到，他们就会力求达成左上角（靠近A点）的结果，这个结果能最大程度地提升他们的利益，但对你却没什么好处。

Information is power. Whichever negotiator has a clearer sense of what’s feasible has the advantage. That’s why people are cautious about disclosing their true needs and priorities. If nobody reveals his interests, nobody gets exploited. Then again, if there are no disclosures, no deals get made. This is the classic creating-claiming dilemma inherent in all negotiations. Out of necessity, negotiators must exchange information. Where relationships are strong and trust is high, this may come easily. In arm’s-length transactions, it can be arduous.

信息就是力量。谈判者中，谁对可行性的认知更清晰，谁就占据优势。正因如此，人们才谨慎地披露自己的真实需求和优先事项。如果没人透露自己的利益，就不会有人被利用。反之，如果没有信息披露，交易也就无法达成。这就是所有谈判中固有的经典“创造-索取”困境。出于必要，谈判者必须交换信息。在关系牢固、信任度高的情况下，这可能很容易实现。但在非直接交易中，这可能非常困难。

Even if both parties were forthright and the deal triangle was transparent, there still could be jostling over where the deal should end up. Splitting it down the middle might be a practical solution in some cases, but in other situations, one or both parties may believe that they deserve the major share. One way or another, they should not settle near point C , where their respective baselines intersect. Such an outcome would work for both of them, but just barely. It would squander the potential value of deals higher up in the triangle, well above each side’s baseline.

即使双方坦诚相待，交易三角关系也清晰透明，最终的交易结果仍可能存在争议。在某些情况下，平分或许是一个切实可行的方案，但在其他情况下，一方或双方都可能认为自己理应获得最大份额。无论如何，他们都不应将最终结果定在双方底线交点附近的C点。这样的结果对双方都有利，但仅仅是勉强可行。它会浪费交易三角关系中更高位置的潜在价值，而这些位置远高于双方各自的底线。

In real-world negotiation, of course, you won’t be able to lay out the deal triangle with the precision of a land surveyor. But having in mind the image of what you’d like to see, were it only possible, will help you orient yourself. It reminds you what information you’re looking for and organizes what you learn along the way. Seeing the deal space as an area that potentially can be expanded provides a richer and more realistic view of the process.

当然，在现实谈判中，你不可能像土地测量员那样精确地描绘出交易三角图。但是，如果能想象出你理想中的交易三角图，就能帮助你明确方向。它能提醒你正在寻找哪些信息，并整理你一路了解到的信息。将交易空间视为一个可以扩展的区域，能让你对整个过程有更丰富、更现实的认识。

THE PROSPECT MATRIX

前景矩阵

Our preparation so far has focused on the substance of deals: your interests, options, and trade-offs, as well as those of your counterparts, as best you can gauge them. Now it’s time to zoom out and see how that analysis shapes negotiation strategy more broadly. The first step is determining where on a scale you’d peg the chances of reaching agreement: are they high, low, or somewhere in between?

我们目前的准备工作主要集中在交易的实质内容上：你和对方的利益、选择和权衡取舍，尽可能地评估它们。现在是时候跳出固有思维，看看这种分析如何更广泛地影响谈判策略了。第一步是确定你认为达成协议的可能性有多大：高、低，还是介于两者之间？

If you’re like most people, you may waver before marking a particular spot. That’s fine. Such hesitation is another reminder to be modest when making assumptions. You may prefer to sketch a broader band of probabilities instead of committing to a hard number. As for Karen, she knew that the company’s recruiters wanted her on board—they had reached out to her, after all. But she wasn’t certain they could put together a compensation package that would justify a move. So, not to jinx herself, she put the odds of making a deal at 75 percent.

如果你和大多数人一样，在确定具体位置之前可能会犹豫不决。这很正常。这种犹豫提醒我们在做假设时要保持谦逊。你或许更倾向于先勾勒出一个更宽泛的可能性范围，而不是确定一个确切的数字。至于凯伦，她知道公司的招聘人员希望她加入——毕竟他们主动联系过她。但她不确定公司能否提供一份足以让她跳槽的薪酬方案。所以，为了避免给自己带来厄运，她把达成协议的可能性设定为75%。

In making an estimate for an upcoming negotiation, ask why you’re optimistic (or why you’re not). Does your guess reflect your personality, or is this case particularly promising (or daunting)? What specific facts or assumptions inform your estimate—and what more would you like to know to confirm or revise it? If you’ve dealt with this counterpart before or handled similar situations, for example, you may have confidence in your expectations. That’s fine, but can you imagine a reason why your hand could be stronger (or weaker) this time than it was in the past?

在对即将到来的谈判进行评估时，问问自己为什么乐观（或不乐观）。你的估计反映了你的性格吗？还是因为这次谈判本身就特别有希望（或令人畏惧）？你的评估基于哪些具体事实或假设？你还想了解哪些信息来验证或修正你的评估？例如，如果你之前与对方有过交锋或处理过类似情况，你可能对自己的预期很有信心。这当然没问题，但你能想象出这次你的优势（或劣势）可能比以往更强（或更弱）的原因吗？

Even after reflection, it may be hard to tell if there will be lots of room for agreement or only a little. You should have a good sense of your own alternatives but find it hard to gauge how badly your counterpart needs to make a deal with you. If you know only your own floor, but not their ceiling, you can’t predict whether you’ll be squeezed or have room to reach high. Don’t wish away uncertainty. Instead, factor it into your plan. The less certain you are about the odds of reaching agreement, the more provisional your strategy must be.

即使经过深思熟虑，也很难判断双方达成协议的空间究竟有多大，还是只有一线希望。你应该对自己的选择方案有清晰的认识，但却很难判断对方究竟有多迫切地想要与你达成协议。如果你只知道自己的底线，却不知道对方的底线，就无法预测自己是会受到挤压还是有很大的发挥空间。不要试图回避不确定性，而应该将其纳入你的计划。你对达成协议的可能性越没有把握，你的策略就越需要灵活变通。

You’ve now reckoned one dimension of your prospects. Call this the latitude of possibility. The next step is estimating the potential upside of a deal—the longitude, if you will. Ask yourself whether this particular deal will yield a lot or only a little, compared with your fallback plan, given the effort needed to pull it off.

现在你已经评估了前景的一个维度，不妨称之为可能性范围。下一步是估算交易的潜在收益——也就是可能性的经度。问问自己，考虑到完成这笔交易所需的努力，与你的备选方案相比，这笔交易的收益是高还是低。

To locate where you are on a scale, think back to your deal triangle, specifically the baseline you estimated for your counterpart. If you’re offering something he values highly—and he has the resources to pay for it—you may have a lot to gain. We’re talking best-case scenarios here, not necessarily the most likely outcome.

要确定你目前所处的位置，回想一下你的交易三角模型，特别是你为对方设定的基准价格。如果你提供的东西他非常看重——而且他也有能力支付——你可能会获益匪浅。我们这里讨论的是最佳情况，而不是最可能的结果。

In Karen’s case, she was of two minds. On the one hand, she didn’t expect QXData to pay her significantly more than she was already getting. Her current employer might match any offer. In dollars-and-cents terms, the upside of agreement seemed modest, at least in the short term. But emotionally, that didn’t feel right at all to Karen. She liked the people at QXData and felt the company was poised for a great future. She wanted to be part of it. Going through this exercise helped her remember what mattered most to her. She drew a bold circle around Large .

凯伦内心十分矛盾。一方面，她并不指望QXData会给她比现在高很多的薪水。她现在的雇主很可能会匹配任何报价。从金钱角度来看，至少在短期内，这份协议带来的好处似乎并不大。但从情感上来说，凯伦却觉得很不自在。她喜欢QXData的同事，也觉得公司前途光明。她想成为其中的一份子。这个过程帮助她重新思考了什么对她来说最重要。她用一个粗圆圈圈出了“大”这个选项。

When you’re weighing your own negotiation prospects, construct a simple matrix by combining the latitude of the probability with the longitude of potential gain.

当你权衡自己的谈判前景时，将概率的纬度与潜在收益的经度结合起来，构建一个简单的矩阵。

In the upper right-hand cell are the grade- A deals. Think of this area as standing for abundance , if you like. It represents negotiations where both the odds of agreement and the expected payoff are high. If your assessment of an upcoming negotiation lands you here, congratulations.

右上角的单元格代表的是A级交易。你可以把这个区域想象成富足的象征。它代表着达成协议的几率和预期收益都很高的谈判。如果你对即将进行的谈判的评估结果恰好落在这个区域，恭喜你！

If you have competition, however, you may have to sweeten your offer to win agreement. Doing so would net you less and thus put you in the lower right-hand cell, grade B , which we’ll call bonus . Again, the chance of agreement is high and the outcome is better than your fallback, but the upside is lower. You won’t get rich on any one such transaction, but string together a bunch of them, and you’ll do well in the long run.

然而，如果遇到竞争，你可能不得不提高报价才能赢得协议。这样做会减少你的收益，因此你会被归入右下角的B级，我们称之为“额外收益”。同样，达成协议的概率很高，结果也比你的备选方案要好，但收益上限较低。你不可能靠一次这样的交易就一夜暴富，但如果能把这些交易串联起来，从长远来看，你就能获得不错的收益。

The left-hand column represents relative long shots. If the potential payoff is large enough, you’re in the grade C — chancy —area. Rolling the dice may be worth the gamble, so you shouldn’t necessarily avoid such negotiations. But make sure you’re realistic about the possible upside. You don’t want to chase rainbows.

左侧一栏代表的是相对风险较高的选择。如果潜在回报足够大，那就属于C级——风险较高——的范畴。冒险一试或许值得，所以你不必完全回避这类谈判。但务必对可能获得的收益保持务实的态度。不要抱有不切实际的幻想。

You rarely want to be down in category D : dead-end territory. Here there’s little to gain and not much chance of getting even that. There are exceptions, though. Sometimes you’re obliged to make a good-faith attempt at agreement even though you can already see that none is likely.

你很少想落入D类：死胡同。在这里，你几乎得不到任何好处，甚至连这点好处都很难获得。当然，也有例外。有时，即使你明知达成协议的可能性微乎其微，你也必须尽力尝试。

Negotiations don’t magically fall into these neat little boxes, of course, but the exercise is essential when crafting a game plan. Each category calls for a different strategy. Once in a while, you may find yourself in the grade- A area. Good for you. But you should revisit your assessment of the upside. Maybe you’re overestimating how much your counterpart needs you. Or maybe you didn’t set your own baseline high enough. Rethink your BATNA. Your walkaway may be better than you expected. Others may be eager to do a deal with you.

当然，谈判不会凭空变成这些简单的类别，但这种模拟是制定谈判策略的关键。每个类别都需要不同的策略。偶尔，你可能会发现自己处于最佳状态，这当然是好事。但你应该重新评估谈判的潜在收益。也许你高估了对方对你的需求程度，或者你设定的底线不够高。重新思考你的最佳替代方案（BATNA）。你的最终选择可能比你预期的更好，其他人或许也渴望与你达成交易。

If you’re in B territory or on the boundaries between the four cells, think twice about how hungry you should be for this particular deal. It may well be worth pursuing, but you don’t necessarily want to go all in. You also should be prepared to walk away if things don’t pan out.

如果你处于B类区域或四个区域交界处，请仔细考虑你对这笔交易的渴望程度。它或许值得追求，但你未必需要孤注一掷。如果事情进展不顺利，你也应该做好放弃的准备。

I once did some work for a midsized company with a CEO who said cheerfully, “In twenty-five years, we’ve never failed to reach agreement.” Because we were in a meeting with his other senior managers, I nodded my head and smiled. Later, when we were alone, I told him that his unblemished record was an odd thing to be proud of. I quoted the old saying, “If you never miss a flight, you’re spending a lot of time at the airport.”

我曾经为一家中型公司工作，那里的CEO兴高采烈地说：“二十五年来，我们从未在达成协议方面失败过。” 因为当时我们正在和其他高管开会，我点头微笑。后来，我们单独相处时，我告诉他，他那从未失手的记录其实没什么值得骄傲的。我引用了一句老话：“如果你从不错过航班，那你肯定在机场待了很长时间。”

The same principle applies in negotiation. “If you always come to agreement,” I said, “there are only two explanations, and neither of them is good. Either you’re being overly cautious and only going after sure things, or sometimes you’re saying yes when you should be walking away.” There are flights you just can’t afford to miss, I added, and deals that must be made, but don’t agree simply for the sake of agreement.

同样的道理也适用于谈判。“如果你总是达成协议，”我说，“只有两种解释，而且这两种解释都不好。要么你过于谨慎，只追求稳赚不赔的事；要么你有时明明应该放弃，却还是答应了。”我补充道，有些航班你绝对不能错过，有些交易你必须达成，但不要为了达成协议而达成协议。

You need to keep that in mind especially if you’re in the areas C or D . If the odds of reaching agreement aren’t good and the payoff is low, put serious effort into improving your fallback. If you’re negotiating on behalf of a client or organization, make sure that the expectations are realistic. You don’t want to be second-guessed if you come back empty-handed. And if you’re operating on your own, guard yourself by setting up a trip wire. If you’re exploring a joint venture, for example, and three months have passed without any apparent progress, ask yourself what reason there is to believe that conditions will be more favorable going forward. If you trudge on, you may miss other, more promising opportunities.

尤其是在C或D领域，这一点更需要牢记。如果达成协议的可能性不大，收益又低，那就应该认真考虑如何改进你的备选方案。如果你代表客户或机构进行谈判，务必确保预期合理。你肯定不想空手而归后被人质疑。如果你是独自行动，那就设置一些陷阱来保护自己。例如，如果你正在探索合资企业，三个月过去了却没有任何进展，那就问问自己，有什么理由相信未来的条件会更好？如果继续拖延下去，你可能会错过其他更有前景的机会。

When Karen looked at her matrix, she had mixed emotions about finding herself in the abundance box. It was partly superstition, she knew. She didn’t want to get her hopes up too high. But it also surfaced a conflict she was feeling. Part of her didn’t want to jeopardize a great job by asking too much in the way of compensation. But Karen also didn’t want to undersell herself. This inner conflict wasn’t pleasant, but she realized that it was better to work through these feelings now than wrestle with them as she was negotiating.

当凯伦查看她的矩阵时，发现自己落在了“富足”方框里，心情十分复杂。她知道这其中一部分是迷信，她不想抱有过高的期望。但这同时也暴露了她内心的矛盾。一方面，她不想因为索要过高的薪酬而毁掉这份好工作；另一方面，她也不想低估自己的价值。这种内心的冲突并不愉快，但她意识到，与其在谈判时与这些情绪纠缠不清，不如现在就理清它们。

Drawing a deal triangle and constructing a prospect matrix had bolstered her confidence. There were still question marks, many that she could resolve only in the course of negotiating, but she knew that she was in a good position. Moreover, she had thought about her baseline, her trade-offs, and different ways of structuring an agreement. Karen had even set a stretch goal. She had done her homework. Whichever way negotiation unfolded, she was well prepared to learn, adapt, and influence.

绘制交易三角图和构建前景矩阵增强了她的信心。尽管仍有一些疑问，其中许多只能在谈判过程中解决，但她知道自己处于有利地位。此外，她已经考虑过自己的底线、权衡取舍以及不同的协议结构。凯伦甚至设定了一个挑战性目标。她做足了功课。无论谈判如何进行，她都做好了充分的准备，能够学习、适应并施加影响。

THINKING BIG

胸怀大志

People with ambitious goals don’t take their own baseline as a starting point. Instead, they focus on what they think they can persuade their counterparts to accept. They think big, make bold demands, and compromise slowly. Sometimes they succeed, but they run a greater risk of stalemate. They tend to overestimate their power and underestimate other parties’ resolve.

雄心勃勃的人不会以自身底线为出发点。相反，他们会专注于如何说服对方接受某些条件。他们胸怀大志，提出大胆的要求，并且谨慎地做出妥协。有时他们能够成功，但陷入僵局的风险也更大。他们往往高估自己的实力，低估对方的决心。

Swarthmore College psychologist Barry Schwartz calls such people “maximizers.” They press hard and worry about their decisions. By contrast, “satisficers” tend to be okay with whatever they get. In a study of recent college graduates, Barry and two colleagues found that maximizers landed jobs that paid 20 percent more than satisficers got, but (and it’s a big drawback) they were less happy with their deals! The satisficers were content with doing a bit better than their next best offer, while the maximizers bemoaned not accomplishing their lofty goals.

斯沃斯莫尔学院心理学家巴里·施瓦茨将这类人称为“追求完美者”。他们会全力以赴，并且对自己的决定忧心忡忡。相比之下，“满足者”则往往对现状感到满意。巴里和他的两位同事对应届大学毕业生进行了一项研究，发现追求完美者找到的工作薪水比满足者高出20%，但（这是一个很大的缺点）他们对自己的工作却不太满意！满足者满足于比次优选择略好一些，而追求完美者则抱怨自己未能实现远大的目标。

It would be great if we could switch these traits on and off. During the actual negotiation, we could tap the maximizer side of our brain to expand the deal space. A maximizer wouldn’t take “company policy” as a firm constraint. Unlike a satisficer, she’d try to craft a new policy or figure out a way around the old one. Yet it’s hard to turn off that kind of restless thinking even when the deal is done. In its worst form, it generates self-doubt and insecurity. When we’re done, we’d be better off accepting whatever we’ve achieved and moving on to the next deal.

如果我们能随时开启或关闭这些特质，那就太好了。在实际谈判中，我们可以调动大脑中“最大化者”的那一面，来扩大交易空间。“最大化者”不会把“公司政策”视为绝对的限制。与“满意者”不同，她会尝试制定新的政策，或者找到绕过旧政策的方法。然而，即使交易达成，也很难停止这种不安的思考。在最糟糕的情况下，它会滋生自我怀疑和不安全感。当我们完成一项交易后，最好是接受已经取得的成果，然后着手进行下一项交易。

Consider Hollywood producer Jerry Weintraub, who seems to embody both these traits. In his book When I Stop Talking, You’ll Know I’m Dead: Useful Stories from a Persuasive Man , he tells how as a young promoter with no resources or reputation, he audaciously pursued Elvis Presley as a client—and eventually signed him. (We’ll see how later, in the chapter on closing.) But in addition to recounting his successes, Weintraub also speaks about failures without regret. When his protégé John Denver fired him abruptly, the singer-actor asked, “Don’t you want to know why?” Weintraub answered, “Why should I care?” He doesn’t look back. He’s always moving forward.

好莱坞制片人杰瑞·温特劳布似乎完美地诠释了这两种特质。在他的著作《当我停止说话，你就知道我死了：一个说服力强的人的实用故事》中，他讲述了自己年轻时作为一名既无资源又无名望的经纪人，如何大胆地追求猫王埃尔维斯·普雷斯利，并最终成功签约。（我们将在后面的“成交”章节中详细探讨。）除了讲述自己的成功经历，温特劳布也坦然面对失败，毫无悔意。当他的得意门生约翰·丹佛突然解雇他时，这位歌手兼演员问道：“你不想知道为什么吗？”温特劳布回答说：“我为什么要关心？”他从不回头看，总是向前看。

In 1998 he decided to produce a remake of the 1960 movie Ocean’s Eleven , which had starred Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and the rest of the fabled Rat Pack. It’s challenging enough to sign a single major star. Nowadays, lining up an all-star cast for relatively short money would seem next to impossible. But Weintraub succeeded, first by landing Matt Damon and director Steven Soderbergh. With them cast, it was easier to reel in George Clooney, Julia Roberts, Brad Pitt, Don Cheadle, Andy Garcia, and other big names. (When he sent the script to Roberts, he attached a $20 bill with a note saying, “We know you get twenty for a movie, but you have to work for a little less on this one.”) The new version was among the top five earners worldwide in 2002.

1998年，他决定翻拍1960年的电影《十一罗汉》，该片由弗兰克·辛纳屈、迪恩·马丁以及其他传奇的“鼠帮”成员主演。要知道，签下一位一线明星就已经够难了。如今，想用相对较少的预算召集到全明星阵容几乎是不可能的。但温特劳布做到了，他首先签下了马特·达蒙和导演史蒂文·索德伯格。有了他们，再去争取乔治·克鲁尼、朱莉娅·罗伯茨、布拉德·皮特、唐·钱德尔、安迪·加西亚和其他大牌明星就容易多了。（当他把剧本寄给罗伯茨时，他附上了一张20美元的钞票，并附言道：“我们知道你拍一部电影能挣20美元，但这次你得少拿点钱。”）新版《十一罗汉》在2002年跻身全球票房前五。

Several years later, Weintraub wanted to do a sequel, Ocean’s Twelve , but the chance of getting all the actors back seemed remote. (We never saw Richard Dreyfuss in Jaws 2 or Jodie Foster in the follow-up to The Silence of the Lambs .) The Ocean actors all had commitments to other pictures, and some might not have shared Weintraub’s enthusiasm for a repeat. Nevertheless, he called Clooney, Roberts, Pitt—the whole gang—and shamelessly told each one that all the others were on board. Nobody wanted to be the spoiler, so everyone signed up again. Bryan Lourd, managing partner of Creative Artists Agency, which represented many of them, knew that Weintraub was blowing smoke, but says, “Eventually we just folded.”

几年后，温特劳布想拍续集《十二罗汉》，但要让所有演员回归似乎希望渺茫。（我们没能在《大白鲨2》里看到理查德·德莱弗斯，也没能在《沉默的羔羊》的续集中看到朱迪·福斯特。）《十二罗汉》的演员们都已签约其他影片，而且有些人可能并不像温特劳布那样热衷于续集。尽管如此，他还是给克鲁尼、罗伯茨、皮特——所有演员——都打了电话，厚颜无耻地告诉他们，其他人都同意了。谁也不想当“剧透者”，所以大家都再次签约了。他们中的许多人的经纪公司——创新艺人经纪公司（CAA）的执行合伙人布莱恩·卢尔德知道温特劳布是在吹牛，但他还是说：“最终我们还是妥协了。”

On the surface, it may seem that this is a story about how Weintraub improved his odds of making the sequel by stretching the truth. There’s more to it than that. It’s a positive example of high aspirations being self-fulfilling. Weintraub’s persistence and blithe denial of practicalities led him to tackle a project that no one else dared to touch. His optimism proved irresistible to the actors, all of whom had become good friends. As proof of that, they demurred again when he pulled the same stunt three years later for Ocean’s Thirteen .

表面上看，这似乎是一个关于温特劳布如何通过夸大事实来提高拍摄续集几率的故事。但事实远不止于此。这是一个远大抱负最终实现的正面例子。温特劳布的坚持不懈和对现实的漠视，使他敢于接手一个无人敢碰的项目。他的乐观精神对演员们来说极具吸引力，他们都成了他的好朋友。三年后，当他再次故技重施拍摄《十三罗汉》时，演员们却都婉拒了，这便是最好的证明。

The Ocean’s trilogy grossed over $1 billion. Back in the late nineties, when Weintraub floated the idea of the first movie, it’s doubtful that even he foresaw the huge payoff. He’s smart, funny, and has built a great network of relationships. But success like this can’t be scripted, and Weintraub didn’t try to. Instead, he took a step at a time—though they were bold steps, to be sure.

《十一罗汉》三部曲票房超过10亿美元。早在90年代末，当温特劳布提出拍摄第一部电影的想法时，恐怕连他自己也未必预料到会取得如此巨大的成功。他聪明风趣，人脉广泛。但这样的成功并非剧本可循，温特劳布也从未试图去规划。相反，他一步一个脚印地走——当然，每一步都可谓大胆。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Don’t limit your vision by relying on the one-dimensional “bargaining range” model of negotiation.

■ 不要局限于一维的“谈判范围”模式，从而限制你的视野。

■ Instead, build a deal triangle that opens up the potential area of workable agreements.

■ 相反，构建一个交易三角，从而开拓出达成可行协议的潜在领域。

■ Weigh your trade-offs, and then establish a baseline of different deals that could satisfy your interests.

■ 权衡利弊，然后确定能够满足你利益的不同交易的基准。

■ Estimate your counterpart’s baseline, but keep in mind that assessing his or her interests is difficult.

■ 估算对方的底线，但请记住，评估对方的兴趣是困难的。

■ Set a stretch goal, so that you don’t settle too cheaply.

■ 设定一个更高的目标，这样你就不会在价格上妥协。

#↩

[ 4 ] Plan B

[ 4 ] B计划

The Citibank Center, as it’s still familiarly known, is an iconic feature of New York’s skyline. It may seem as if the fifty-nine-story tower, with its sharply angled peak, has stood in Midtown Manhattan forever. Up into the 1970s, however, the block that fronts Lexington Avenue between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets was sleepy and timeworn. It was home to low-rise residential and commercial buildings, an old Gothic church, and other properties owned by various organizations, trusts, and individuals. How those separate parcels were acquired and assembled is recounted in an entertaining 1974 New York magazine article, “How They Assembled the Most Expensive Block in New York’s History,” by Peter Hellman, as well as in Holdouts! , a book by Andrew Alpern and Seymour Durst. The tale still serves as a master class in formulating and implementing negotiation strategy.

花旗中心，人们至今仍熟知的名字，是纽约天际线上的标志性建筑。这座59层高的摩天大楼，拥有棱角分明的尖顶，仿佛永远屹立在曼哈顿中城。然而，直到20世纪70年代，位于莱克星顿大道53街和54街之间的这片街区还显得沉寂而破败。这里曾是低矮的住宅和商业建筑、一座古老的哥特式教堂以及其他一些由不同机构、信托和个人拥有的房产的所在地。彼得·赫尔曼在1974年发表于《纽约》杂志的一篇妙趣横生的文章《他们是如何打造纽约历史上最昂贵的街区的》中，以及安德鲁·阿尔珀恩和西摩·杜斯特合著的《坚守者！》一书中，都详细讲述了这些零散地块是如何被收购和整合的。这个故事至今仍是制定和实施谈判策略的经典案例。

I’ll tell the story in detail, so let me flag key themes at the outset. For starters, you’ll hear echoes of concepts we explored in prior chapters, such as coping with uncertainty, creating value, and mapping the way to our objectives. You’ll also see how those elements, taken together, compel a dynamic approach to negotiation, one that makes learning, adapting, and influencing paramount.

我会详细讲述这个故事，所以首先让我指出几个关键主题。首先，你会听到一些我们在前几章探讨过的概念的回响，例如应对不确定性、创造价值以及规划实现目标的路径。你还会看到，这些要素如何共同促成一种动态的谈判方法，这种方法将学习、适应和影响置于首位。

Deliberate learning was a priority for the New York Realtors who acquired the properties for Citi. It enabled them to adapt to changing circumstances and to persuade reluctant owners to sell. Sometimes the land assemblers extended an olive branch. Other times they brandished big sticks. In still other cases, they reached agreement not because of specific terms they offered but, rather, due to patient relationship building. Each acquisition was an end it itself—getting all the properties was essential—but every transaction also helped the assemblers recalibrate as they moved forward.

对于为花旗集团收购房产的纽约房地产经纪人来说，刻意学习至关重要。这使他们能够适应不断变化的环境，并说服不愿出售的业主。有时，土地收购者会伸出橄榄枝；有时，他们会采取强硬手段。还有一些情况下，他们达成协议并非因为提出了具体的条款，而是因为耐心建立关系。每一次收购本身都是一个目标——获得所有房产至关重要——但每一次交易也帮助收购者在前进的过程中不断调整策略。

The project was audacious, certainly falling in the low-odds, high-payoff category in our prospects matrix. The assemblers recognized that reality. Throughout the process, they took steps to minimize their risk and improve the potential upside. Even so, the negotiations took several years to complete—and they involved scores of parties and millions of dollars. Few of us engage in deals of such magnitude or complexity, but small-scale everyday transactions require the same kind of flexible, creative, multilevel approach.

这个项目雄心勃勃，在我们评估的项目矩阵中，它无疑属于低风险高回报的范畴。项目发起人深知这一点。在整个过程中，他们采取措施尽可能降低风险，并提高潜在收益。即便如此，谈判仍然耗时数年才完成——而且涉及数十个参与方和数百万美元的资金。我们当中很少有人会参与如此规模或复杂程度的交易，但日常的小规模交易也需要同样灵活、创新、多层次的方法。

To make the moral of this story crystal clear, I’ll lay out strategic precepts that apply to negotiations across the board. You may have already grasped some of these lessons from your own experience. Here are nine key principles that you will see in action:

为了让这个故事的寓意更加清晰明了，我将阐述一些适用于所有谈判场合的战略原则。你或许已经从自身的经验中领悟到其中一些道理。以下是九项关键原则，你将在实践中看到它们的应用：

1. Set a Provisional Goal. A general sense of direction is essential, but narrow objectives can make negotiation an all-or-nothing proposition.

1. 设定一个暂定目标。大致的方向感固然重要，但目标过于狭隘会让谈判变成一场非此即彼的博弈。

2. Have a Plan B. An obstacle to agreement may harbor seeds for a different deal, perhaps even better than first expected.

2. 要有备选方案。达成协议的障碍可能蕴藏着达成另一项协议的契机，甚至可能比最初预期的还要好。

3. Envision the End Game. Reason backward from your goal to discover plausible paths for getting there.

3. 设想最终目标。从目标出发，反向推导，找到实现目标的可行路径。

4. Make Learning a Priority. Use early tests and probes to illuminate the negotiation landscape.

4. 将学习放在首位。利用早期测试和探索来了解谈判格局。

5. Adapt When You Have To . Accept the reality that other parties won’t always do what you want or anticipate.

5. 必要时要适应。接受现实，其他人不一定会按照你想要或预期的方式行事。

6. Think Like a Competitor. Stress test your strategy by seeing how others could exploit it.

6. 像竞争对手一样思考。通过观察其他人可能如何利用你的策略来检验你的策略是否有效。

7. Be Multilingual. Bring along both carrots and sticks.

7. 要精通多种语言。奖励和惩罚都要兼备。

8. Guard Your Exit Option. As in poker, know when to hold ’em and know when to fold ’em; when to walk away and when to run.

8. 守护好你的退路。就像打扑克一样，要知道什么时候该坚持，什么时候该弃牌；什么时候该离开，什么时候该逃跑。

9. Always Be Closing. From start to finish, each step should be aimed at getting closer to agreement.

9. 时刻以达成协议为目标。从始至终，每一步都应该以达成协议为目标。

This set of principles isn’t a lockstep checklist. Rather, each element is a gear, lever, or spring in the machinery of dynamic strategy. In particular cases, some parts may prove more vital than others, but all must link smoothly.

这套原则并非一套死板的清单。相反，每个要素都是动态战略机制中的一个齿轮、杠杆或弹簧。在特定情况下，某些部分可能比其他部分更为关键，但所有部分必须顺畅衔接。

1. Set a Provisional Goal. Don Schnabel, a young broker with the real estate firm of Julien J. Studley, had been hired by St. Peter’s Lutheran Church to appraise what its fifteen-thousand-square-foot plot might fetch in what was then a hot real estate market. Famous as the “jazz church,” St. Peter’s had been the venue for jazz legend Louis Armstrong’s funeral in 1971, but it was strapped for cash and squeezed for space. Its board hoped that a profitable sale would help expand its social services. Schnabel scrutinized all the properties on the block to generate his estimate. The figure he calculated proved disappointing, however, so the church’s board decided not to sell.

1. 设定暂定目标。唐·施纳贝尔是朱利安·J·斯图德利房地产公司的一位年轻经纪人，他受圣彼得路德教会委托，评估该教会一万五千平方英尺的地皮在当时火热的房地产市场中能卖多少钱。圣彼得教会素有“爵士乐教堂”之称，1971年爵士乐传奇人物路易斯·阿姆斯特朗的葬礼就在这里举行。然而，教会当时资金短缺，空间也捉襟见肘。教会理事会希望通过出售这块地皮来扩大其社会服务。施纳贝尔仔细考察了该地块上的所有房产，以得出他的估价。然而，他计算出的数字却令人失望，因此教会理事会决定不出售。

2. Have a Plan B. That would have been the end of it, but Schnabel’s research convinced him that even if there couldn’t be a satisfactory sale of the church property in its own right, a deal might be fashioned by acquiring all the Lexington Avenue parcels, along with others fronting the cross streets. One unified piece of property would have much more value than the sum of its separate parts. It would be a win-win- win solution: the current owners would get a premium over market value; a major corporation could erect a landmark building; and, oh yes, whoever brokered the deal would make handsome commissions.

2. 准备备选方案。事情原本可能就此结束，但施纳贝尔的研究让他相信，即使教堂地产本身无法顺利出售，也可以通过收购莱克星顿大道上的所有地块，以及沿街的其他地块来达成交易。这样一来，整体地产的价值将远高于各部分价值的总和。这将是一个三赢的方案：现有业主可以获得高于市场价的溢价；一家大型企业可以建造一座地标性建筑；当然，促成这笔交易的人也能获得丰厚的佣金。

Success, however, would depend on Schnabel reaching agreement not just once but almost twenty times with that many different owners. In figuring his baseline for each property, he’d pay a little sweetener, if necessary, over its stand-alone value, but he had to stay within a reasonable budget for the whole project. He knew the real estate market generally. To get the best price each time, however, he’d have to uncover the unique needs, attitudes, and expectations of every owner to gauge his or her particular baseline. All told, it was an all-or-nothing proposition. Getting a yes from most of them wouldn’t be enough. And if things didn’t work out, the downside would be unloading properties for which he had overpaid. Shutting down the project midway could be expensive.

然而，成功与否取决于施纳贝尔能否与近二十位不同的业主达成协议，而且不止一次。在确定每处房产的基准价格时，如有必要，他会在房产的独立价值基础上略作溢价，但整个项目的总成本必须控制在合理的预算范围内。他对房地产市场有着大致的了解。然而，为了每次都能获得最佳价格，他必须深入了解每位业主的独特需求、态度和期望，从而评估他们各自的基准价格。总而言之，这是一项成败在此一举的计划。仅仅获得大多数业主的同意是不够的。如果项目失败，不利之处在于他不得不出售那些他已经高价买入的房产。中途终止项目可能会造成巨大的损失。

3. Envision the End Game. The only thing that Schnabel had was this high-risk, high-reward vision. His firm didn’t own any of the parcels, nor did it have the resources to acquire them. To solve that problem, he had to imagine who might be the ultimate purchaser if he could pull off each separate acquisition. In strategic terms, this kind of thinking is called backward mapping. It’s a matter of starting analysis with the final objective and then reasoning back, step-by-step, to uncover paths for getting there.

3. 设想最终目标。施纳贝尔唯一拥有的就是这个高风险、高回报的愿景。他的公司既不拥有任何地块，也没有足够的资源去收购它们。为了解决这个问题，他必须设想，如果他能够成功完成每一项收购，最终的买家会是谁。从战略角度来看，这种思维方式被称为逆向映射。它指的是从最终目标出发进行分析，然后逐步回溯，最终找到实现目标的路径。

Schnabel identified a likely prospect right across the street: First National City Bank, as it was then called. The bank was outgrowing its present offices and looked with envy at the spectacular headquarters of its downtown rival, Chase Manhattan Bank. Schnabel approached First National City Bank cold. After months of internal meetings, the bank gave its go-ahead.

施纳贝尔在街对面就发现了一个潜在的收购目标：当时的“第一国民城市银行”。这家银行的现有办公场所已经无法满足业务增长的需求，并且对位于市中心的竞争对手——大通曼哈顿银行——那座气派非凡的总部大楼羡慕不已。施纳贝尔直接与第一国民城市银行接洽。经过数月的内部磋商，银行最终同意了收购。

Proceeding discreetly was essential, however. If the various neighborhood owners learned about a deep-pocket buyer, they would hold out for top dollar. Competitors could swoop in too. Schnabel set up a straw holding company, Lexman Realty. He was listed as vice president, and his boss as president, but the identity of the sole stockholder—the bank—was not public record.

然而，低调行事至关重要。如果附近各家业主得知有财力雄厚的买家，他们肯定会索要最高价。竞争对手也可能趁虚而入。施纳贝尔设立了一家空壳控股公司——莱克斯曼地产公司。他本人被列为副总裁，他的老板被列为总裁，但唯一股东——银行——的身份并未公开。

4. Make Learning a Priority. Having conceived his grand strategy, Schnabel had to go back to square one and choose which owner to approach first. The physical map of Manhattan is precise, but the map of possible deals on a single city block is complex. To get his bearings, Schnabel had to start moving, just like our snowbound soldiers in the Alps. It wasn’t a matter of proceeding methodically from one property to its immediate neighbor. Instead, he needed to find vantage points that would give him a realistic sense of possibilities.

4. 将学习放在首位。制定好宏伟战略后，施纳贝尔不得不从头开始，选择首先接触哪位业主。曼哈顿的地图虽然精确，但单个街区内所有潜在交易的分布却错综复杂。为了掌握方向，施纳贝尔必须行动起来，就像被困在阿尔卑斯山的士兵一样。他不能按部就班地从一处房产挨家挨户地拜访，而是需要找到合适的视角，以便对各种可能性有一个更现实的认识。

Schnabel decided to hold off on the Lexington Avenue parcels, as important as they were. They would be the most expensive, and if he were to make a move there—right across from the bank—other real estate people might sense what he was attempting. It seemed safer and cheaper to begin around the corner on Fifty-third Street.

尽管莱克星顿大道上的地块非常重要，但施纳贝尔决定暂缓收购。这些地块价格最高，而且如果他贸然出手——就在银行对面——其他房地产商可能会察觉到他的意图。相比之下，从附近的第五十三街开始似乎更安全也更划算。

For his initial probe, Schnabel chose a four-story building that housed a gourmet restaurant on the first floor. He negotiated a buy-out of the operator’s lease but then was shocked to learn that the landlord had just contracted to sell the property to one Manny Duell, a man described in the Alpern and Durst book as a “sometimes developer and professional holdout.” Somehow Duell had gotten wind of the project and claimed to have contracts to buy the abutting buildings as well.

施纳贝尔最初的调查选择了一栋四层楼的建筑，一楼是一家高级餐厅。他与餐厅经营者协商买断了租约，但随后震惊地得知，房东刚刚与曼尼·杜埃尔签订了合同，准备将这处房产出售给杜埃尔。阿尔珀恩和杜斯特在书中将杜埃尔描述为“有时是开发商，有时是职业守房者”。不知何故，杜埃尔得知了这个项目，并声称自己也签有购买相邻建筑的合同。

5. Adapt When You Have To. Having an early competitor on the block threatened to derail Schnabel’s entire plan, but the bank encouraged him to see if it could buy out Duell. After some bargaining, they arrived at an acceptable price for the three properties—a result that made Duell millions of dollars of profit on contracts that he had held for only a few months at most.

5. 必要时要灵活变通。竞争对手的出现一度威胁到施纳贝尔的整个计划，但银行鼓励他尝试收购杜埃尔的房产。经过一番讨价还价，双方最终就三处房产的价格达成一致——这一结果让杜埃尔从他最多只持有几个月的合同中获利数百万美元。

Settling on the price wasn’t the hardest part, however. As Schnabel slid the check over to Duell, he added, “Manny, just one thing. If you want me to take over these contracts, I need to know you are going to stay off the block from this point on. I don’t want you popping up on the other side with more contracts. I want this to be good-bye, Manny.”

然而，敲定价格并不是最难的部分。施纳贝尔把支票递给杜埃尔时，补充道：“曼尼，还有一件事。如果你想让我接手这些合同，我需要知道你从现在开始不会再出现在交易市场上。我不想看到你带着更多合同再次出现。曼尼，我希望这是最后一次了。”

Duell promised to disappear, but Schnabel persisted, saying that he didn’t want to see Manny’s partner, cousins, or anyone else fronting for him. Duell swore once more that he’d stay out of the way.

杜埃尔答应消失，但施纳贝尔坚持说，他不想再见到曼尼的合伙人、表兄弟或其他任何人替他撑腰。杜埃尔再次发誓他会置身事外。

“I believe you, Manny,” replied Schnabel. “As a token of your good faith, I’m sure you won’t mind signing over to me a three-hundred-thousand-dollar mortgage on one of the buildings you own. Maybe that nice one at 530 Sixth Avenue. We’ll put it in escrow. If you stay off the block for eighteen months, it reverts to you.”

“我相信你，曼尼，”施纳贝尔回答说。“为了表示你的诚意，我相信你不会介意把你名下的一栋楼的三十万美元抵押贷款转让给我吧。也许是第六大道530号那栋不错的楼。我们会把它存入第三方托管账户。如果你在十八个月内不进行任何交易，这笔钱就归还给你了。”

According to Hellman’s account, Duell ranted that he would never do such a thing, but all the while, he couldn’t take his eyes off the big check with all the zeros and his name on it. Schnabel waited until the seller calmed down and yielded to his demand for security.

据赫尔曼描述，杜埃尔咆哮着说他绝不会做这种事，但他的目光却始终无法从那张印着他名字、数字全是零的大支票上移开。施纳贝尔一直等到卖方冷静下来，同意了他的担保要求。

Schnabel worked on multiple levels. He was pushing forward with his grand plan of assembling the block. But he was also hammering out deals with individual owners, adapting to circumstances as they became apparent. Closing the first purchase was more work than he had anticipated, though it was better to discover potential obstacles early. He also inoculated himself against further incursions, at least by Duell. The experience underscored the importance of moving quickly before others learned of his plans.

施纳贝尔的工作涉及多个层面。他一方面推进着收购这片街区的宏伟计划，另一方面也在与各个业主敲定交易，并根据实际情况灵活调整策略。完成第一笔收购比他预想的要费力得多，不过及早发现潜在障碍总归是件好事。这也让他免受了杜埃尔的进一步干扰。这次经历让他意识到，在其他人知晓他的计划之前迅速行动至关重要。

In subsequent cases, money wasn’t always the obstacle. Schnabel’s next move, for example, was acquiring a Hungarian restaurant on Lexington Avenue. He guessed that the owner, Eva Trefner, might be seeking to retire after having operated the place for twenty years. He was right, but she was also concerned about what would happen to her loyal staff. Schnabel promised to keep the place open for at least another year, so that sale went through smoothly.

在后来的案例中，资金并非总是障碍。例如，施纳贝尔的下一步是收购莱克星顿大道上的一家匈牙利餐厅。他猜测餐厅老板伊娃·特雷夫纳在经营了二十年后可能想要退休。他的猜测没错，但特雷夫纳也担心她忠实的员工们的未来。施纳贝尔承诺至少再让餐厅营业一年，因此这笔交易顺利完成。

6. Think Like a Competitor. It was important that Schnabel not overpay in any of these transactions. He owed it to his client to be prudent with its money. There were also strategic considerations. The more properties he acquired, the more costly it would be to be stymied by holdouts. There was the risk he could reach a point where he’d have to pay big premiums to acquire the last few pieces of the puzzle.

6. 像竞争对手一样思考。施纳贝尔在任何交易中都不能支付过高的价格，这一点至关重要。他有责任谨慎使用客户的资金。此外，还有战略方面的考量。他收购的房产越多，一旦被那些不愿收购的对手阻挠，损失就越大。他有可能最终不得不支付高额溢价才能拿下最后几块地。

Schnabel also had to worry about the downside of possible competition. Secrecy was one line of defense. In addition, he sequenced his acquisitions, hopping around the block like a Monopoly player bent on controlling key portions of the game board. Schnabel thus turned his attention to Fifty-fourth Street, where he started acquiring brownstones. He also approached the pastor of St. Peter’s—his original client—and floated the possibility that its property would be worth much more as part of a package than as a stand-alone.

施纳贝尔还不得不担心潜在竞争带来的负面影响。保密是他的一道防线。此外，他精心安排收购顺序，像大富翁玩家一样在街区里四处游走，力图控制棋盘上的关键区域。于是，施纳贝尔将目光转向了第五十四街，开始收购那里的褐石建筑。他还联系了圣彼得教堂的牧师——他最初的客户——并提出，教堂的房产如果打包出售，价值会比单独出售高得多。

The church was intrigued by the financial benefits but was concerned, as Hellman recounts it, that “no horrors be perpetrated on residential tenants who were forced off the block.” Schnabel pledged that this wouldn’t happen, and worked out an elaborate condominium arrangement that would allow the church to rebuild a bigger structure on the same corner, largely outside the footprint of the office tower.

教会对经济利益很感兴趣，但正如赫尔曼所述，他们担心“被迫搬离街区的居民会遭受不测”。施纳贝尔承诺不会发生这种情况，并制定了一项复杂的产权分割方案，允许教会在同一街角重建一座更大的建筑，该建筑基本位于办公楼的占地面积之外。

7. Be Multilingual. Dealings with some other owners differed from the hard-nosed bargaining with Manny Duell. Schnabel kept his word with the church, of course. And his colleague Charles McArthur arranged moving plans for two elderly sisters, Julia and Alyce Belora, providing them with first-class tickets to their new home in California. It’s another example of how the more-for-me, less-for-you view of negotiation doesn’t capture the richness of many real-life situations. Some sellers put a high value on Schnabel’s courtesy and integrity in ways that were independent of price.

7. 精通多种语言。与其他一些业主的交易方式与和曼尼·杜埃尔（Manny Duell）的强硬谈判截然不同。当然，施纳贝尔信守了对教会的承诺。他的同事查尔斯·麦克阿瑟（Charles McArthur）为两位年迈的姐妹朱莉娅·贝洛拉（Julia Belora）和艾丽斯·贝洛拉（Alyce Belora）安排了搬家事宜，并为她们提供了前往加州新家的头等舱机票。这再次说明，那种“我多给，你少给”的谈判观无法捕捉到许多真实情况的丰富内涵。一些卖家非常看重施纳贝尔的礼貌和诚信，而这些价值与价格无关。

Timing was a key factor in other cases. Schnabel’s colleague Charles McArthur met a reclusive bachelor who insisted that he would never sell. This wasn’t Manny Duell holding out for top dollar. There was no room for agreement at any price. Nevertheless, McArthur kept visiting and once brought slides of his recent European trip. Finally, after two years of quiet courtship, McArthur felt it was time to press the issue.

在其他一些案例中，时机也至关重要。施纳贝尔的同事查尔斯·麦克阿瑟遇到了一位隐居的单身汉，他坚称自己永远不会出售房产。这可不是曼尼·杜埃尔那种不肯卖高价的情况。双方根本没有讨价还价的余地。尽管如此，麦克阿瑟还是坚持拜访，甚至还带去了他最近欧洲之旅的幻灯片。最终，经过两年的默默努力，麦克阿瑟觉得是时候采取行动了。

“We’ll draw up a contract,” he told the owner. “The line for purchase price will be blank. We’ll say yes or no. If we say no, Tom, I promise you’ll never be bothered again.” The owner then wrote down $850,000 on the form. The bank—which was funding the acquisitions—gave its approval, and the owner bought himself a handsome brownstone farther downtown.
