“我们会拟定一份合同，”他告诉房主，“购买价格一栏留空。我们会说‘是’或‘否’。如果我们说‘否’，汤姆，我保证以后再也不会打扰你。”房主随后在表格上写下了85万美元。为此次收购提供资金的银行批准了合同，房主便在市中心更远的地方买下了一栋漂亮的褐石建筑。

Think about how this worked both at the outset and then again at the end. For months and months, McArthur held off, recognizing that it was not yet time to negotiate. And when the time seemed ripe, he moved delicately. He didn’t make an offer, nor did he ask for a demand, but in handing over the contract, he signaled that the time to do business had come. Leaving the purchase price open was a sign of the respect and trust that had grown between the two men. McArthur sensed that Tom would reciprocate this gesture. (By contrast, neither he nor Schnabel would have ever given Manny that kind of control.)

想想这件事从开始到结束是如何运作的。几个月来，麦克阿瑟一直按兵不动，因为他知道谈判的时机尚未成熟。而当时机似乎成熟时，他采取了巧妙的行动。他既没有提出报价，也没有要求对方提出条件，而是递交了合同，这本身就表明了交易的时机已到。不谈收购价格，体现了两人之间日益增长的尊重和信任。麦克阿瑟感觉到汤姆也会以同样的态度回应。（相比之下，他和施纳贝尔都绝不会把这种控制权交给曼尼。）

Other pieces fell into place, some because of creativity and patience on the brokers’ part, others due to haggling. Sometimes it was both. According to Hellman’s account, the big prize on Fifty-fourth Street was the Medical Chambers building, owned by forty doctors. Most were in high tax brackets and unlikely to be tempted by cash. Schnabel proposed a swap for a better building. The doctors fired their board for even considering it.

其他环节也相继敲定，有些是经纪人的创造力和耐心促成的，有些则是讨价还价的结果。有时两者兼而有之。据赫尔曼所述，第五十四街的“宝地”是医疗商会大楼，由四十位医生所有。他们大多属于高收入群体，不太可能被现金诱惑。施纳贝尔提议用一栋更好的大楼交换。医生们竟然因为考虑这个提议而解散了董事会。

Their new board rebuffed a $4 million offer and even rejected having a new building constructed to their specifications. Once again there was no apparent room for agreement. This time Studley solved the problem not by relationship building but through creativity. The Medical Chambers was a stock company. It could merge with the bank and thus give the doctors shares in Citi. They wouldn’t pay taxes until they chose to sell—and then it would be at the lower capital gains rate. Out of nowhere, enormous room for agreement suddenly blossomed.

他们的新董事会拒绝了400万美元的收购要约，甚至拒绝按照他们的要求建造新大楼。双方再次陷入僵局，毫无达成共识的余地。这一次，斯塔德利解决问题的方法并非建立人脉关系，而是发挥创造力。医疗商会是一家股份制公司，它可以与银行合并，从而使医生们获得花旗银行的股份。在他们选择出售股份之前，无需缴纳任何税款——而且届时将按较低的资本利得税率征税。就这样，双方突然之间找到了巨大的合作空间。

8. Guard Your Exit Option. In hindsight, stories such as the Citibank acquisition suggest a certain inevitability, as if each step inexorably led to the next. But Schnabel and his colleagues might have been just as savvy and resourceful yet still have failed due to factors beyond their control. In an alternative universe, Manny Duell might have refused to stay off the block. Had that happened, Schnabel’s firm would have faced a tough choice: Should it quit the project that it had just started or engage in a race to tie up other properties? With deeper pockets and perhaps more skill, it might be able to secure enough parcels to prevent Duell or anyone else from controlling the block. On the other hand, holdouts like him could demand exorbitant prices for their remaining properties.

8. 保留退出选择权。事后看来，像花旗银行收购案这样的案例似乎预示着某种必然性，仿佛每一步都不可避免地导向下一步。但即便施纳贝尔和他的同事们同样精明能干，也可能因为一些无法掌控的因素而失败。在另一个平行宇宙中，曼尼·杜埃尔或许会拒绝退出。如果真是如此，施纳贝尔的公司将面临艰难抉择：是放弃刚刚启动的项目，还是投入到争夺其他地块的竞争中？凭借更雄厚的资金和或许更强的实力，他们或许能够获得足够的地块，阻止杜埃尔或其他任何人控制整个地块。另一方面，像杜埃尔这样的“死守者”可能会为剩余的地块索要天价。

Just walking away might have been easier. All that the brokers had put into the venture was their own time—and the money the bank had spent to buy out the tenant’s lease. If his firm had stepped out, maybe Duell would have stepped in. Everything could have turned out very differently, not because of anything our protagonists did but because of seemingly minor parties. It’s impossible to plan for every zig and zag that a negotiation might take. Depending on your luck, maybe you’ll run into your own version of Manny Duell, or maybe you won’t. Practical strategy must give you multiple options along the way.

或许直接退出会更容易些。经纪人在这个项目上投入的只有自己的时间，以及银行用来买断租户租约的资金。如果他的公司退出，杜尔或许就会接手。一切可能朝着截然不同的方向发展，并非因为我们的主人公做了什么，而是因为一些看似无关紧要的第三方。谈判中可能出现的每一个曲折都无法预料。运气好的话，你或许会遇到属于你的曼尼·杜尔，或许不会。务实的策略必须让你在谈判过程中拥有多种选择。

Schnabel chose to make his first probe on Fifty-third Street, where properties were cheaper. He protected himself from being blocked by holdouts elsewhere by not getting in too deep. He guarded the option of reselling the early acquisitions to people who might be interested in them as stand-alones or who were more optimistic about pulling together the whole block.

施纳贝尔选择首先在第五十三街进行考察，因为那里的房产价格较低。为了避免被其他地方的守势户阻挠，他没有一开始就投入太多资金。他保留了将早期收购的房产转售给那些可能对独立房产感兴趣或更有信心收购整个街区的人的选择权。

Backward mapping can take you only so far, however. It’s a powerful way of envisioning one possible route to your destination, but it can’t reveal all the potential detours along the way. As a result, you need to keep a sharp eye out for exit options and half-a-loaf solutions that may be better than none. That’s true whether you’re competing against other buyers in a marketplace or searching for a path to a fruitful partnership. In deal making and dispute resolution, discretion sometimes trumps valor.

然而，反向规划只能帮你到此为止。它能有效地帮你设想一条通往目的地的可能路线，但却无法揭示沿途所有潜在的弯路。因此，你需要时刻留意各种退出方案和权宜之计，即便它们可能只是权宜之计。无论你是在市场上与其他买家竞争，还是在寻求建立富有成效的合作关系，这一点都适用。在交易和纠纷解决中，谨慎有时比强硬更重要。

9. Always Be Closing. Seasoned climbers say that the summit isn’t the only place on the mountain. Sometimes in negotiation you have to backtrack. Schnabel’s toughest negotiation came at the end. It required hard bargaining over a shoddy corner building owned by an estate that leased ground floor space to an optometrist and a liquor store. Schnabel agreed to pay the executrix a premium for the property, rationalizing that it was worth it to complete the entire deal. At the closing, though, she slyly informed him that she had recently extended the commercial leases by a full twelve years. According to Hellman, Schnabel was furious. “He was trapped; the assemblage was too far along now to stop, and the executrix knew it.”

9. 永远不要放弃。经验丰富的登山者常说，山顶并非山上唯一的终点。谈判有时也需要退一步。施纳贝尔最艰难的谈判就发生在最后阶段。他需要就一栋破旧的街角建筑进行激烈的讨价还价，这栋建筑的所有者将底层出租给了验光师和酒铺。施纳贝尔同意支付遗嘱执行人一笔溢价，他认为为了完成整个交易，这样做是值得的。然而，在交易结束时，遗嘱执行人却狡猾地告诉他，她最近已将商业租赁合同延长了整整十二年。据赫尔曼说，施纳贝尔当时非常愤怒。“他进退两难；谈判已经进行到无法挽回的地步，而遗嘱执行人也心知肚明。”

She had sold the valuable lease rights, reaping additional money for the heirs of the estate. The buyer was Sam Salerno. He would regularly stroll the sidewalk, glance over to the existing bank headquarters, and then watch, Hellman says, “as, one by one, the wrecker ball took down the buildings on the block. He did not look like a man in a hurry to sell out his lease.”

她卖掉了那份价值不菲的租赁权，为遗产继承人赚取了额外的收入。买家是萨姆·萨勒诺。赫尔曼说，他经常沿着人行道散步，瞥一眼现有的银行总部，然后看着“拆迁队一栋接一栋地拆除街区上的建筑物。他看起来并不像一个急于出售租赁权的人。”

Schnabel and his client were all in at this point, and Salerno knew it, but the bank acted as if it were in no rush to buy. It seemed prepared to build around him, if need be. And so, in full view of the public, the bank and this streetwise operator played out a game of chicken. The bank knew that Salerno didn’t have any other viable buyer. He was all in too. Eventually somebody blinked, and the bank bought out the lease rights for $385,000.

此时施纳贝尔和他的客户已经全力以赴，萨勒诺也心知肚明，但银行却装作并不急于收购。如有必要，银行似乎准备围绕他进行重建。于是，在众目睽睽之下，银行和这位精明的商界人士展开了一场胆量博弈。银行知道萨勒诺没有其他合适的买家。萨勒诺也已全力以赴。最终，有人妥协了，银行以38.5万美元的价格买下了租赁权。

Where this transaction fit into the whole sequence of acquisitions was critical. By the time Salerno appeared, the bank controlled enough properties that it could proceed without him, if necessary, even though that wouldn’t be ideal. Secrecy was no longer a factor. Indeed, the fact that Salerno knew the bank had a fallback made it less likely that it would have to use it.

这笔交易在整个收购计划中的位置至关重要。萨勒诺出现时，银行已经控制了足够多的资产，即使没有他，必要时也能继续推进收购，尽管这并非理想之选。保密不再是问题。事实上，萨勒诺知道银行有后备方案，这反而降低了银行动用该方案的可能性。

Schnabel’s shrewd sequencing also took into account the value of early probing and learning. His initial deals weren’t just ends in themselves. They helped him garner information and resources that would set up a successful end game. Along the way, he was ever mindful of possible exits and alternatives if things didn’t go as hoped.

施纳贝尔精明的策略也考虑到了早期试探和学习的价值。他最初的交易并非仅仅是为了达成目的，而是为了收集信息和资源，为最终的成功奠定基础。在此过程中，他始终牢记着如果事态发展不如预期，可能的退出方案和替代方案。

Thinking through the possible upside and downside of a negotiation takes something of a split personality. It’s as if you’re building a yacht to cruise the world while also stocking a life raft with provisions. You need optimism, even daring, to undertake negotiations that others might pass up as fruitless, yet at the same time, you must accept the reality that achieving success is never fully within your control.

权衡谈判的利弊需要一种双重性格。这就像你既要建造一艘环游世界的游艇，又要准备一艘救生筏。你需要乐观，甚至大胆，才能进行那些别人可能认为毫无意义的谈判；但与此同时，你也必须接受这样一个现实：成功永远无法完全由你掌控。

Assembling the Citibank block proved a big success for the bank and the Studley firm that negotiated all the acquisitions. It took five years of hard work, some luck, and $40 million. At the time, it was the highest-priced land purchase in New York City history. Clearing the site and erecting the tower took years as well. Almost a decade passed between the day that Schnabel first ambled around the block and when the new Citibank Center opened in 1977.

组装花旗银行大楼对花旗银行和负责所有收购谈判的斯图德利公司来说都是一次巨大的成功。这耗费了五年时间，也需要一些运气，以及4000万美元。在当时，这是纽约市历史上价格最高的土地收购。清理场地和建造大楼也花费了数年时间。从施纳贝尔第一次在这片街区漫步到1977年新的花旗银行中心落成，几乎过去了十年。

Don Schnabel’s negotiating skill got the ball rolling. Charles McArthur and other colleagues in the Studley firm played big roles in executing the project. Together they had the imagination to see that the obstacle to one deal—a simple, stand-alone sale of St. Peter’s Church—bore the seeds of a much more profitable set of transactions. If the value of the church’s property was insufficient in itself, the answer was to couple it with many others. Quite literally, they generated economies of scale.

唐·施纳贝尔的谈判技巧让一切步入正轨。查尔斯·麦克阿瑟和斯图德利律师事务所的其他同事在项目执行中发挥了重要作用。他们富有远见地发现，看似阻碍交易的单一因素——圣彼得教堂的独立出售——却孕育着一系列利润更为丰厚的交易。如果教堂房产本身的价值不足以带来收益，那么解决办法就是将其与其他众多房产结合起来。他们确实实现了规模经济。

THE COST OF INFLEXIBILITY

缺乏灵活性的代价

The Citibank story is exhibit A in the case for adaptive negotiation strategy. The nine underlying principles I’ve covered don’t guarantee success, but they move the odds in the right direction. You can see that by looking at what can happen when the precepts are ignored. Just as that new tower was opening, another developer was attempting a land assembly in Atlantic City, New Jersey, a hundred miles to the south as the gull flies. Unlike Studley, however, Richard Bloom let everyone know what he was doing from the start.

花旗银行的案例是适应性谈判策略的最佳例证。我提到的九项基本原则并不能保证成功，但它们能大大提高成功的几率。看看忽视这些原则的后果就知道了。就在那座新大楼落成之际，另一位开发商正在新泽西州的大西洋城进行土地收购，那里距离花旗银行总部直线距离约一百英里。然而，与斯塔德利不同的是，理查德·布鲁姆从一开始就让所有人知道他的计划。

New Jersey had passed legislation authorizing casinos. Atlantic City, an old resort town that had seen better days, was poised to take off. Bloom wanted to put together the last potentially valuable oceanfront block. It was comprised of seventy-two private houses, plus a few storefronts and businesses near the boardwalk itself. Rather than trying to acquire the residential properties secretly, one by one, he boldly sought to get them in one fell swoop.

新泽西州通过了授权赌场的法案。昔日辉煌不再的大西洋城，这座老牌度假小镇，正蓄势待发，准备重振雄风。布鲁姆想要收购最后一块极具潜力的海滨地块。这块地由七十二栋私人住宅组成，外加木板路附近的一些店面和商铺。他没有选择秘密地逐一收购这些住宅，而是大胆地试图一次性全部拿下。

Bloom announced to the whole neighborhood that he would pay $100,000 per house—two or three times the typical stand-alone value. But there was a catch: each deal would be contingent on everyone else agreeing to sell. He hoped this offer would turn the holdout problem on its head. Any owner who thought about trying to haggle for more would be pressured by neighbors fearful of losing their windfall. “It’s like having fourteen salesmen on the block at all times,” said Bloom.

布鲁姆向整个社区宣布，他愿意为每栋房子支付10万美元——是普通独立房屋价格的两到三倍。但有个条件：每笔交易都必须以其他所有住户都同意出售为前提。他希望这个提议能彻底解决业主不愿出售的问题。任何想要讨价还价的业主都会受到邻居们的压力，因为他们害怕失去这笔意外之财。“这就像街区里随时都有十四个推销员在招揽生意一样，”布鲁姆说道。

At first blush, his strategy looked clever. People liked its transparency. Yes, Bloom would get rich—he was upfront about that—but so would they. And everybody would be treated the same, whether or not they had just given their place a fresh coat of paint. It was only the land that mattered. After all, every structure would soon be torn down, be it shabby or spotless.

乍一看，他的策略似乎很聪明。人们喜欢它的透明性。没错，布鲁姆会发财——他对此毫不掩饰——但他们也会。而且每个人都会受到同样的对待，无论他们的房子是否刚刚粉刷一新。真正重要的只有土地。毕竟，所有建筑很快都会被拆除，无论它破旧不堪还是崭新如初。

This open approach had risks, of course. To protect himself from other developers who might jump in with sweeter offers, Bloom imposed a strict deadline. Either he’d get a quick yes from everyone, or he’d walk away. He also wasn’t worried about the neighbors trying to do the assembly themselves. They didn’t have an organization, and relationships among them weren’t universally good. “If they had tried to do that,” he said later, “they’d still be trying to pick a chairman.”

当然，这种开放的做法也存在风险。为了防止其他开发商提出更诱人的条件，布鲁姆设定了一个严格的最后期限。要么他能迅速得到所有人的同意，要么他就放弃。他也不担心邻居们会自行组织会议。他们没有组织，而且彼此之间的关系也并非都很好。“如果他们真那样做了，”他后来说道，“他们现在可能还在选主席呢。”

As it happened, his problem lay elsewhere. Bloom had many takers, but there also were several owners who weren’t keen to move. For some of them, $100,000 wasn’t going to change their way of life. Others had principal homes elsewhere. They didn’t feel the peer pressure to sell—or weren’t bothered by it. Bloom succeeded in getting more than 90 percent of the owners to sign up, but this wasn’t a game of horseshoes. Coming close wasn’t good enough.

结果，他的问题出在别处。布鲁姆确实吸引了不少买家，但也有一些业主并不愿意搬家。对他们中的一些人来说，10万美元并不会改变他们的生活方式。还有一些人在别处有主要住所，他们感受不到出售房产的同侪压力——或者说，他们根本不在乎。布鲁姆最终成功说服了超过90%的业主签约，但这可不是掷马蹄铁那么简单。仅仅接近成功是不够的。

In the end, the simplicity of his strategy was both a strength and a weakness. By making a one-size-fits-all offer, Bloom couldn’t adapt to the needs and demands of particular owners. The kind of value-creating solutions we saw with the Citibank example (such as the tax deal with the doctors and pampering the elderly sisters) were not available. He tried to salvage the project, saying that he was willing to pay more for certain houses, but appeasing holdouts risked unsettling deals he had already made.

最终，他策略的简单性既是优势也是劣势。由于采用了一刀切的方案，布鲁姆无法根据特定业主的需求进行调整。我们在花旗银行案例中看到的那些创造价值的解决方案（例如与医生达成的税收协议以及对年迈姐妹的悉心照料）都无法实现。他试图挽救这个项目，表示愿意为某些房屋支付更高的价格，但安抚那些不愿妥协的业主可能会破坏他已经达成的交易。

Nevertheless, Bloom did some things right. He had a clear goal and a plausible plan for achieving it. Perhaps it was a long shot, but if it had come through, his payoff would have been big. On the prospect matrix, it was in the chancy box, but there was minimal downside. Bloom anticipated possible competition and shielded himself from it. His downfall was his plan’s rigidity. Once he set it in motion, he learned little about various owners’ priorities. Moreover, he could bargain only in the language of cash. To his credit, though, he gave himself a cheap out. All he lost was his time and effort.

尽管如此，布鲁姆也做对了一些事情。他目标明确，并制定了切实可行的计划来实现目标。这或许是一次孤注一掷的机会，但如果成功，回报将非常丰厚。从前景评估的角度来看，这属于高风险项目，但风险极小。布鲁姆预料到了潜在的竞争，并采取了相应的措施来规避风险。他的失败在于计划的僵化。一旦计划启动，他就很难了解各个老板的优先事项。此外，他只能用金钱来谈判。不过，值得称赞的是，他给自己留了一条低成本的退路。他损失的仅仅是时间和精力。

The Walt Disney Company should have made the same decision far sooner when it was pushing a new $650 million theme park thirty-five miles west of Washington, DC. It was the 1990s, and the company was flush with success. Disneyland in California was spectacularly profitable, and Disney World in Florida was even more so. Disney’s only regret was that it hadn’t acquired even more adjoining land in its earlier projects, given the local development booms they had launched.

华特迪士尼公司本应更早做出同样的决定。当时，该公司正大力推进一项耗资6.5亿美元的新主题公园项目，选址在华盛顿特区以西35英里处。那是上世纪90年代，公司正处于事业的巅峰时期。加州迪士尼乐园盈利颇丰，佛罗里达州迪士尼世界更是利润丰厚。迪士尼唯一的遗憾是，鉴于其早期项目带动了当地的开发热潮，当时没有收购更多相邻土地。

Its new park was to have a historical theme and be called Disney’s America. Through secret negotiations (much like those for Citibank), it had already acquired the three thousand acres it needed. The company had also quietly lined up support from local, state, and federal officials. Having tied up the land and corralled most of the politicians, Disney went public with its plans in 1993. The problem was that its chosen site was four miles from the Manassas National Battlefield Park, where the Civil War Battles of Bull Run took place. The tract also abutted a dozen notable towns, as well as more than two dozen lesser-known battlefields and historic districts. Not surprisingly, preservationists and environmentalists voiced concern about increased traffic and other adverse impacts on local communities.

迪士尼计划建造一座以历史为主题的新公园，名为“迪士尼美国”。通过秘密谈判（与收购花旗银行的谈判如出一辙），该公司已悄然获得了所需的3000英亩土地。此外，该公司还悄悄地争取到了地方、州和联邦官员的支持。在拿下土地并拉拢了大部分政界人士后，迪士尼于1993年公开了其计划。问题在于，其选址距离马纳萨斯国家战场公园仅4英里，而马纳萨斯国家战场公园正是南北战争时期布尔河战役的发生地。这片土地还毗邻十几个著名城镇，以及二十多个鲜为人知的战场和历史街区。不出所料，文物保护人士和环保人士对交通拥堵加剧以及对当地社区的其他不利影响表示担忧。

Disney countered with a massive public relations campaign that further mobilized opposition. Proponents praised the park for combining education and entertainment, citing a Lewis and Clark white-water raft ride and a Depression-era country fair. One Disney spokesman sparked a firestorm by heralding a planned ride that would “make you feel what it was like to be a slave or what it was to like to escape through the Underground Railroad.”

迪士尼随即发起了一场声势浩大的公关活动，反而进一步激起了反对者的情绪。支持者称赞该公园寓教于乐，并列举了路易斯与克拉克探险漂流项目和大萧条时期的乡村集市等项目。一位迪士尼发言人宣称，一项计划中的游乐设施将“让你体验奴隶的苦难，或者感受通过地下铁路逃亡的滋味”，此言一出，立即引发轩然大波。

Historians such as David McCullough and Shelby Foote condemned the project. Disney countered that those people were merely fronting for rich members of the Washington establishment who didn’t want their country estates invaded by common tourists. CEO Michael Eisner sabotaged his own efforts repeatedly with comments such as this: “Over the years, I’ve visited my son at Georgetown University, and I learned that he and most of his fellow students . . . have never been to a Civil War battlefield . . . I attended many history classes in my life . . . and I didn’t learn anything.”

戴维·麦卡洛和谢尔比·富特等历史学家谴责了这个项目。迪士尼则反驳说，这些人只不过是华盛顿权贵阶层的代言人，他们不希望自己的乡间庄园被普通游客侵占。首席执行官迈克尔·艾斯纳屡次发表自毁前程的言论，例如：“这些年来，我去乔治城大学探望儿子，发现他和他的大多数同学……从未去过南北战争战场……我这辈子上过很多历史课……却什么也没学到。”

Eisner’s arrogant stance made great copy for fund-raising appeals by preservationist groups. Editorialists across the country quoted his remark that “the First Amendment gives you the right to be plastic.” All its prior secret dealings didn’t help, either. Politicians who had gotten on the Disney’s America bandwagon earlier looked for ways to gingerly slip off it.

艾斯纳傲慢的态度为文物保护团体的筹款呼吁提供了绝佳素材。全国各地的社论都引用了他那句“宪法第一修正案赋予你成为塑料人的权利”。此前迪士尼的种种秘密交易也无济于事。那些早先搭上“迪士尼美国”这趟顺风车的政客们，都在想方设法小心翼翼地退出这场运动。

Even within the company, top people began to think it was time to kill the project. Regulatory fights were costing the company money. More important, the controversy was distracting management and tarnishing the Disney reputation. Eisner was resolute, however, telling reporters, “If people think we will back off, they are mistaken.” He said that the opposition “just makes me more excited about the project.” Eventually even he had to capitulate. Eisner had fallen into the trap of believing that past is prologue. Sticking with an approach that had succeeded in Anaheim and Orlando, he was blind to the reality that this was a different time and place. He was slow to learn and still slower to adapt.

即使在公司内部，高层也开始认为应该终止这个项目。监管方面的斗争让公司损失惨重。更重要的是，这场争议分散了管理层的注意力，损害了迪士尼的声誉。然而，艾斯纳却态度坚决，他对记者说：“如果人们认为我们会放弃，那就大错特错了。” 他说，反对的声音“只会让我对这个项目更加兴奋”。最终，连他也不得不妥协。艾斯纳陷入了“过去可以重演”的误区。他固守着在阿纳海姆和奥兰多取得成功的策略，却对时代和环境的差异视而不见。他学习迟钝，适应能力更是差强人意。

AGILITY

敏捷

It’s easy to render that verdict after the fact, of course. The fair test of strategy isn’t whether it succeeds or fails in a particular case. Luck can tilt the outcome one way or another. But sound strategy should anticipate a fan of possibilities. Negotiators need to be open to latent opportunities (as was Schnabel in New York) as well as to pitfalls of the kind that doomed Disney in Virginia.

当然，事后下结论很容易。衡量战略的公平标准并非在于它在特定案例中的成败。运气可能会左右结果。但合理的战略应该预见各种可能性。谈判者需要对潜在的机遇保持开放态度（就像施纳贝尔在纽约所做的那样），同时也要警惕那些导致迪士尼在弗吉尼亚州惨败的陷阱。

We can only speculate what would have happened if its team had used Gary Klein’s premortem technique early in the planning process. Just driving around northern Virginia with the thought in mind that something will go badly might have made the Disney people realize that this time they weren’t in the orange groves of Florida or California. If they had foreseen possible opposition, they might have addressed it by revising the design or finding a less controversial site—or perhaps by junking the plan before it sparked so much costly controversy.

我们只能猜测，如果迪士尼团队在规划初期就运用加里·克莱因的“事前验尸”技巧，结果会如何。仅仅是在弗吉尼亚北部开车兜风，心里想着可能会出问题，或许就能让迪士尼的人意识到，这次他们不是身处佛罗里达或加利福尼亚的橘子园。如果他们预见到可能会遇到反对意见，或许可以通过修改设计或寻找争议较小的地点来应对——或者干脆在引发如此代价高昂的争议之前就放弃这个计划。

Being an agile learner takes a special mind-set. On the one hand, you need a measure of commitment and a sense of direction. You negotiate to achieve certain ends, after all, not just to solve an intellectual puzzle. But on the other hand, you need a constant willingness to reevaluate your prospects and priorities. You have to be willing to walk away when your hopes don’t square with reality.

成为一名敏捷学习者需要一种特殊的思维模式。一方面，你需要一定的投入和方向感。毕竟，你是为了达成特定目标而进行协商，而不仅仅是为了解决一个智力难题。但另一方面，你需要不断地重新评估你的前景和优先事项。当你的期望与现实不符时，你必须有勇气放弃。

It’s easy to fall in love with your plans. The more effort you put into making them, the more seductive they become. But your counterparts may be unreasonable. They may have a better offer. Their personal style may drive you nuts. Too bad. That’s how it is sometimes. Effective negotiators cope with uncertainty and chaos. Great ones thrive on it.

人们很容易爱上自己的计划。你投入越多心血，计划就越诱人。但你的对手可能不讲道理。他们可能提出更好的条件。他们的个人风格可能让你抓狂。没办法，有时候就是这样。高效的谈判者能够应对不确定性和混乱局面。而卓越的谈判者则能从中获益。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Don’t get trapped by prior success; past isn’t always prologue.

■ 不要被过去的成功所束缚；过去并不总是序章。

■ Tune your approach to fit the circumstances and the style of the person with whom you’re dealing.

■ 根据具体情况和对方的风格调整你的方法。

■ Remember that deal making isn’t just about dollars and cents; relationship building is essential.

■ 请记住，达成交易不仅仅是金钱交易；建立关系至关重要。

■ Make sure that your strategy aligns with clients and colleagues.

■ 确保你的策略与客户和同事的策略保持一致。

■ Give yourself wiggle room, or you may get stuck.

■ 给自己留有回旋余地，否则你可能会陷入困境。

#↩

PART 2

第二部分

Improvising

即兴发挥

Some situations are like playing chess while mountain climbing.

有些情况就像一边登山一边下棋。

—AMBASSADOR RICHARD HOLBROOKE

——理查德·霍尔布鲁克大使

#↩

[ 5 ] Presence of Mind

[ 5 ] 临场应变能力

Picture two ultracompetent people, both accomplished in their respective fields. One gets a huge rush out of negotiating. The other is paralyzed by the mere thought of it.

想象一下两个能力超群的人，他们在各自的领域都取得了卓越的成就。一个谈判时会感到无比兴奋，而另一个仅仅是想到谈判就会感到恐惧和无助。

First, there’s Donald Dell, the pioneering sports marketer and agent. Back when he was just starting out, Dell was in a tense negotiation with the maker of Head tennis rackets, endorsed by one of his star clients, Arthur Ashe. The company wanted to stop paying the 5 percent royalties on all sales. Dell and Ashe wanted to keep the payments flowing.

首先要提到的是体育营销先驱和经纪人唐纳德·戴尔。在他事业起步阶段，戴尔曾与他的明星客户之一阿瑟·阿什代言的Head网球拍制造商进行过一场紧张的谈判。该公司想要停止支付所有销售额5%的版税。而戴尔和阿什则希望继续支付这笔款项。

Dell was meeting with Head’s marketing team when the door flew open and the chairman stormed in. “Goddamn it!” he screamed. “This is outrageous. He’s making ten times what I’m making, and I’m chairman of this company.”

戴尔正在和海德的营销团队开会，突然门被猛地推开，董事长怒气冲冲地走了进来。“该死的！”他吼道，“这太离谱了。他的收入是我的十倍，而我可是这家公司的董事长！”

The room went silent. Would Dell cave in or blow up the deal by answering in kind? Everyone turned to see how he’d respond. After a brief pause, Dell tilted his head, smiled, and said, “But Pierre, Arthur has a much better serve than you do.”

房间里一片寂静。戴尔会妥协还是会以牙还牙，毁掉这笔交易？所有人都转头看向他，想看看他会作何反应。短暂的沉默后，戴尔歪了歪头，笑着说：“不过皮埃尔，亚瑟的发球比你好得多。”

The tension broke, and people laughed and got back to business. They tweaked the royalty schedule and preserved a business relationship that was beneficial for both sides. Dell was quick with a joke. Even more important, he was poised in the face of high emotion. And his own ease and good humor relaxed everyone else.

紧张的气氛消散了，人们笑着继续谈正事。他们调整了版税方案，维持了对双方都有利的商业关系。戴尔总能妙语连珠，更重要的是，他能在情绪高涨时保持镇定。他的轻松和幽默也让其他人放松下来。

Then there’s Chris Robbins, an emergency room physician in a big city hospital. Chris is exactly the kind of doctor I’d want if I were wheeled in on a stretcher: calm and focused amidst all the stress. But that’s true only in the ER. That composure falls apart when it comes to negotiating. Chris craved a spot in a highly selective clinical training program but was tied up in knots about even asking for the two-month leave it required. Such requests are unusual, and, given current staffing problems, there was a risk of appearing disloyal to the ER team. The answer could be no. The prospect of a confrontation was so intimidating that Chris never raised the issue.

还有克里斯·罗宾斯，他是大城市医院急诊室的一名医生。如果我被担架抬进来，克里斯正是我希望遇到的那种医生：在压力之下依然保持冷静和专注。但这仅限于急诊室。一旦涉及到谈判，他的沉着冷静就荡然无存了。克里斯渴望参加一个竞争激烈的临床培训项目，但却因为要请两个月的假而犹豫不决。这样的请求并不常见，而且考虑到目前的人员配备问题，这样做可能会被视为对急诊室团队不忠。答案很可能是“不”。面对冲突的前景如此令人畏惧，以至于克里斯最终没有提出这个问题。

People like Chris are phobic about negotiation. They’ll do anything to avoid pushing or being pushed. They’re neither competitive nor cooperative. In psychological terms, they’re avoiders. If they can satisfy their minimum needs, they’ll say yes just to cut short the stress of dealing with people who have different agendas and styles. It’s an expensive aversion.

像克里斯这样的人害怕谈判。他们会想尽一切办法避免主动或被动。他们既不具备竞争意识，也不善于合作。从心理学角度来说，他们是回避型人格。如果能满足他们的最低需求，他们就会轻易答应，只是为了尽快摆脱与那些有着不同目的和风格的人打交道的压力。这种回避行为代价高昂。

I remember a participant in an executive program who bristled at the thought of haggling with a car salesman. “I just pay the sticker price,” she announced. “I’ve got better things to do with my time than play some foolish game.” I asked if she realized what she was passing up. “Maybe you’re rolling in money,” I said. “But in just fifteen minutes, you might knock down the price by a couple of thousand dollars. If you were willing to play a little hardball, wouldn’t your favorite charity welcome that cash?” I saw a trace of panic in her eyes.

我记得一位参加高管培训项目的学员，一想到要和汽车销售员讨价还价就觉得很不爽。“我只付标价，”她说道，“我还有更重要的事要做，没空玩这种愚蠢的游戏。”我问她是否意识到自己错过了什么。“也许你腰缠万贯，”我说，“但只要花十五分钟，你就能砍掉几千美元。如果你愿意稍微强硬一点，你最喜欢的慈善机构难道不欢迎这笔钱吗？”我看到她眼中闪过一丝慌乱。

Most people fall somewhere between the extremes of loving negotiation and loathing it. They don’t relish tough encounters, but they don’t run from them, either. They see negotiation as an unavoidable part of business and personal life, an obstacle course they have to run to get work done. At a break in a recent negotiation workshop, I heard two participants trade horror stories about their own recent negotiations. One guy admitted that he had messed up a deal by losing his temper. “I was bending over backward with my customer, giving concession after concession. Nevertheless, he accused me of playing bait and switch and demanded even more. He sure knew how to hit my hot button.”

大多数人对谈判的态度介于热爱谈判和厌恶谈判之间。他们不乐于面对棘手的谈判，但也不会逃避。他们认为谈判是商业和个人生活中不可避免的一部分，是完成工作必须跨越的障碍。在最近一次谈判研讨会的休息时间，我听到两位学员分享了他们最近谈判中的惨痛经历。其中一位坦言，他因为一时冲动搞砸了一笔交易。“我竭尽全力讨好客户，不断做出让步。然而，他却指责我玩弄花招，还提出了更多要求。他真是太会戳我的痛处了。”

“You and I must be fire and ice,” laughed his colleague. “In my case, I just froze up. The minute we started, all the preparation I’d done, every number I’d run, everything just flew right out the window. And the more I realized that I was blowing it, the worse things got.”

“你我真是水火不容啊，”他的同事笑着说。“我当时完全懵了。比赛一开始，我之前做的所有准备，我演练过的所有数据，全都白费了。而且我越意识到自己搞砸了，情况就越糟糕。”

Most of us could tell similar stories about losing our footing in negotiation, at least once in a while. Slipups don’t have to involve fiery outbursts or going blank. Even a momentary lack of focus at a key point can spell trouble. Indeed, throwing other people off stride is the point of hardball ploys. Tom Wolfe’s novel A Man in Full describes a negotiation between a bank and a real estate developer who has fallen on hard times. (As research for the book, Wolfe sat in on such meetings.) These so-called work-out deals involve restructuring the financial terms of huge loans. In practice they’re often about lenders’ attempts to shake every last dime out of borrowers’ pockets before they fall into bankruptcy.

我们大多数人至少偶尔都会有在谈判中失算的经历。失误并不一定意味着情绪失控或大脑一片空白。即使在关键时刻一时走神，也可能酿成大祸。事实上，扰乱对方的节奏正是强硬策略的目的所在。汤姆·沃尔夫的小说《全能之人》就描写了一家银行与一位陷入困境的房地产开发商之间的谈判。（为了创作这本书，沃尔夫曾旁听过类似的谈判会议。）这些所谓的“债务重组”协议涉及对巨额贷款的财务条款进行调整。实际上，它们往往是贷款方在借款人破产前竭尽全力榨取其最后一分钱的手段。

In Wolfe’s account, this particular developer had been given royal treatment back when times were good, but now he finds himself summoned to a claustrophobic room. The Danish pastries on the sideboard are stale. The only available drink is warm orange juice served in flimsy plastic cups, the same size as for urine specimens. The developer knows the game being played, but as the bank forces him to hand over one asset after another—first one property, and then another, and finally his private plane—he starts to perspire. By the time the meeting is over, he’s a broken man with saddlebags of sweat under each arm.

在沃尔夫的描述中，这位开发商在风光无限时曾享受过帝王般的待遇，如今却被召进一间令人窒息的房间。餐具柜上的丹麦酥皮点心已经干硬。唯一能喝的饮料是装在薄薄的塑料杯里的温热橙汁，杯子大小跟尿样杯差不多。开发商明白银行的套路，但当银行逼他一件接一件地交出资产——先是一处房产，然后是另一处，最后连他的私人飞机也交了——他开始汗流浃背。会议结束时，他已精疲力竭，腋下汗涔涔的。

How should you cope with the hot and cold feelings that negotiation often provokes? You won’t find many answers in standard texts. Indeed, many negotiation books tiptoe around the topic of emotion. The classic Getting to Ye s earnestly advises “separating the people from the problem,” which some readers took to mean focusing one’s attention solely on substantive issues. But negotiation is about more than money or terms and conditions. The people you deal with want to feel respected as individuals. They want their ideas to be appreciated and their status acknowledged as well. Later in his career, Roger Fisher and psychologist Daniel Shapiro coauthored a sequel to Getting to Yes called Beyond Reason: Using Emotions as You Negotiate . Roger and Dan warn that if you ignore other parties’ core emotional concerns, you risk stalemate even if your offers ostensibly meet their tangible interests.

如何应对谈判中常常出现的忽冷忽热的情绪？你很难在标准教材中找到答案。事实上，许多谈判书籍都对情绪问题避而不谈。经典著作《谈判力》（Getting to Yes）郑重建议“将人与问题分开”，一些读者将其理解为只关注实质性问题。但谈判远不止金钱或条款。与你打交道的人希望感受到作为个体的尊重。他们希望自己的想法得到认可，自身地位得到承认。罗杰·费舍尔（Roger Fisher）在其职业生涯后期与心理学家丹尼尔·夏皮罗（Daniel Shapiro）合著了《谈判力》的续篇——《超越理性：谈判中的情绪运用》（Beyond Reason: Using Emotions as You Negotiate）。罗杰和丹警告说，如果你忽视对方的核心情感诉求，即使你的提议表面上满足了他们的实际利益，你也有可能陷入僵局。

That’s only part of the story, though. Your passions both reflect and influence your relationships with people. You may feel warmly toward one person, while someone else makes your blood boil. And then there are people like Chris, who get the chills just thinking about negotiation. Those responses can either help or hinder your search for agreement, depending on how you understand, channel, and learn from them.

但这只是故事的一部分。你的热情既反映也影响着你与他人的关系。你可能对某个人充满好感，而对另一个人却怒火中烧。还有像克里斯这样的人，一想到谈判就不寒而栗。这些反应可能会帮助你达成共识，也可能会阻碍你，这取决于你如何理解、引导和从中学习。

Feelings color perceptions and influence behavior. You can be up or down, tense or relaxed, depending on the day and the particular circumstances. Studies even show that seemingly irrelevant factors (whether it’s sunny or rainy, if the room in which you’re negotiating has been freshly cleaned, and whether you’re standing tall or hunched over) all can tilt your emotional outlook. And, of course, much depends on the mood of your particular counterparts.

情绪会影响感知和行为。你的情绪会随着当天的心情和具体情况而波动，时而高涨，时而低落，时而紧张，时而放松。研究甚至表明，一些看似无关的因素（比如晴天还是雨天，谈判的房间是否干净整洁，以及你是站姿端正还是弓着背）都会影响你的情绪状态。当然，对方的情绪也至关重要。

Having emotions is one thing. The problem is that when your emotions have you, they can derail the negotiation process instead of being useful signals that help you orient to the situation at hand. It’s a big mistake simply to let feelings wash over you. Instead, you should put them to creative use. According to an old adage, “We see things not as they are, but as we are.” Being upbeat and confident can’t guarantee success, of course, but it does help. The alternative—having low expectations—is often self-fulfilling. Worry about slipping up breeds caution and distrust. Anxiety may not doom you to failure, but it’s often a needless burden.

拥有情绪是一回事。问题在于，当情绪左右你时，它们会扰乱谈判进程，而不是成为帮助你把握当前形势的有效信号。任由情绪左右你的判断是一个巨大的错误。相反，你应该创造性地利用它们。正如一句古老的谚语所说：“我们看到的不是事物本身，而是我们自己。” 保持乐观和自信当然不能保证成功，但确实有所帮助。相反，低期望值往往会成为自我实现的预言。担心犯错会滋生谨慎和不信任。焦虑或许不会导致失败，但它常常是一种不必要的负担。

Even if you have Donald Dell’s poise, it’s important to understand how emotions impact your counterparts. It’s rarely in your interest to confirm their worst fears. Even debt collectors like those in Tom Wolfe’s novel have to sense how hard they can press without provoking an explosion or a walkout that leaves everyone worse off. In more collaborative negotiations, you need to know how to encourage others to be open to your arguments and ideas.

即使你拥有唐纳德·戴尔那样的沉着冷静，了解情绪如何影响对方也至关重要。证实对方最糟糕的担忧通常对你没有好处。即使是像汤姆·沃尔夫小说中那样的讨债人，也必须把握好施压的力度，以免引发冲突或对方愤然离席，最终导致双方都蒙受损失。在更注重合作的谈判中，你需要知道如何引导对方接受你的观点和想法。

Like Wolfe’s developer, you won’t always be in a strong position. Nor can you dictate whom you deal with or how they’ll treat you. External circumstances may be beyond your control as well. But you can manage your emotional responses to those challenges. Much of the pressure that people feel in negotiation is self-imposed. It is a self-defeating attitude, one that with practice you can discard.

就像沃尔夫的开发者一样，你不可能永远处于优势地位。你也无法决定与谁打交道，或者他们会如何对待你。外部环境也可能超出你的掌控。但你可以管理自己面对这些挑战时的情绪反应。人们在谈判中感受到的大部分压力都是自己施加的。这是一种自我挫败的态度，但通过练习你可以克服它。

MASTERING PARADOX

掌握悖论

People such as Donald Dell love high-wire negotiations. Like star athletes, they rise to the occasion, especially when the stakes are high and the competition intense. “I live for such moments,” Dell says of the Arthur Ashe–Head deal. Some of these remarkable people have PhDs or professional degrees. Others never finished high school. Many boast years of experience, but there are also gifted novices. These great negotiators share one common trait: keen presence of mind. That’s how people like George Mitchell and Lakhdar Brahimi can envision agreement in the midst of bitter conflict.

像唐纳德·戴尔这样的人热爱高风险的谈判。他们如同明星运动员一般，总能在关键时刻挺身而出，尤其是在竞争激烈、风险极高的情况下。“我为这样的时刻而活，”戴尔在谈到阿瑟·阿什与海德的谈判时说道。这些杰出人士中，有些人拥有博士学位或专业学位，有些人甚至高中都没毕业。许多人经验丰富，但也有一些天赋异禀的新手。这些伟大的谈判者都有一个共同的特质：敏锐的临场应变能力。正因如此，像乔治·米切尔和拉克达尔·布拉希米这样的人才能在激烈的冲突中找到达成协议的办法。

Their emotional balance is buttressed by tenacity and underlying optimism. They’re comfortable with ambiguity, uncertainty, and risk. Averell Harriman, a diplomat from an earlier era, was known as “the crocodile.” Once he sank his teeth into a problem, he wouldn’t let go. Bruce Wasserstein, the late New York investment banker, treated everything as a negotiation, not just business deals, but where to eat and whether to call if you might be late for a meeting. “This could be quite exhausting,” says Laurence Grafstein, who worked with Wasserstein for more than a decade. “After a while, you just began to cave. But then he wouldn’t allow you to capitulate, so the negotiation cycle would begin anew.” There are other negotiators whose deals don’t make the front page but who fit the same profile. Arnaud Karsenti, a young real estate developer and entrepreneur, says, “I love negotiation; the hairier, the better!”

他们的情绪平衡建立在坚韧和潜在的乐观之上。他们能够坦然面对模糊性、不确定性和风险。老一辈的外交官艾弗雷尔·哈里曼（Averell Harriman）以“鳄鱼”著称。一旦他盯上某个问题，就绝不松口。已故的纽约投资银行家布鲁斯·沃瑟斯坦（Bruce Wasserstein）把一切都当作谈判，不仅是商业交易，就连去哪儿吃饭、开会迟到要不要打电话这些事都要谈判。“这让人筋疲力尽，”与沃瑟斯坦共事十余年的劳伦斯·格拉夫斯坦（Laurence Grafstein）说道，“时间久了，你就会开始妥协。但他不会让你轻易认输，于是谈判又会重新开始。”还有一些谈判者，他们的交易虽然不为人知，但却符合同样的特质。年轻的房地产开发商兼企业家阿尔诺·卡尔森蒂（Arnaud Karsenti）说：“我热爱谈判；越棘手越好！”

In my consulting and research, I’ve met, worked with, and studied top negotiators in a wide variety of fields. I’ve been impressed with their mental makeup, their ability to balance what might seem to be opposing states of mind. I’ve come to see that to excel, negotiators must be simultaneously:

在我的咨询和研究工作中，我接触、合作并研究了各个领域的顶尖谈判专家。他们的思维方式以及平衡看似对立的心理状态的能力给我留下了深刻的印象。我逐渐认识到，要想在谈判中脱颖而出，谈判专家必须同时具备以下素质：

calm and alert,

冷静且警觉

patient and proactive, and

耐心、积极主动，而且

practical and creative.

务实且富有创意。

This balancing act isn’t a matter of switching from one to the other at different times during a negotiation. The key is being all of these things at once. Nor is it a matter of trade-offs. The goal isn’t being a little calm and somewhat alert. A closer look at each of these dualities shows how to reconcile them.

这种平衡并非在谈判过程中不同阶段交替使用不同的策略，关键在于同时具备所有这些特质。这也不是取舍的问题，目标也不是保持冷静和警觉。仔细审视这些二元性，就能找到调和它们的方法。

Take poise. It’s essential when negotiations get heated. It gives you the emotional wherewithal to defuse tense situations. But vigilance is just as important. It helps you spot early signs that the negotiation is not turning out as hoped.

保持冷静。这在谈判陷入僵局时至关重要。它能让你拥有化解紧张局势的心理素质。但保持警惕同样重要。它能帮助你及早发现谈判进展不如预期的迹象。

You likewise need a rich brew of patience and initiative. The former is a well-trumpeted virtue: good things come to those who wait, and haste makes waste. Those adages apply in negotiation. Building trust takes time. Rushing the process can backfire in cultures where what seems like small talk is an important social ritual. And making proposals prematurely, before laying the groundwork, can spur rejection.

同样，你需要兼具耐心和主动性。耐心是众所周知的美德：好事多磨，欲速则不达。这句格言在谈判中同样适用。建立信任需要时间。在某些文化中，看似闲聊实则重要的社交礼仪，操之过急可能会适得其反。在尚未做好充分准备的情况下就过早提出方案，很可能会遭到拒绝。

But initiative is a virtue too. The thesaurus likens it variously to a plan, inventiveness, and having the upper hand—all of which are decided advantages at the bargaining table. Only by probing do you learn how high up the value ladder you can climb, or when it’s time to switch to plan B. If you fail to take the lead, the other side will set the tune.

但主动性也是一种美德。词典将其比作计划、创造力和掌握主动权——所有这些都是谈判桌上的关键优势。只有通过深入探究，你才能了解自己能在价值阶梯上攀升到多高，或者何时该启用备选方案。如果你不主动出击，对方就会掌控局面。

Then there are the dual goals of practicality and creativity. Master negotiators are hardheaded realists. They realize when they’ve been stuck with a lemon—but they also know how to make lemonade. When parties are deadlocked over price, for example, a resourceful seller might provide financing to bridge the gap. Maybe forming a joint venture could create profit all around.

此外，谈判还需兼顾实用性和创造性。谈判高手都是头脑冷静的现实主义者。他们清楚自己是否遇到了棘手的问题，但也懂得如何化腐朽为神奇。例如，当双方在价格上陷入僵局时，精明的卖方可能会提供融资来弥补差额。或许成立合资企业也能实现双赢。

On the other hand, being grounded is a plus too. Practical recognition of the other side’s needs and constraints helps negotiators focus on workable solutions instead of flights of fancy. It signals when half a loaf is the most you’re going to get. Pragmatism also inoculates you against falling in love with a deal and paying more than the top dollar you set initially.

另一方面，脚踏实地也是一种优势。务实地认识到对方的需求和限制，有助于谈判者专注于可行的解决方案，而不是异想天开。它能让你明白，你最多只能得到半块面包。务实还能避免你对交易产生好感，最终支付超过你最初设定的最高价。

Ideally, you’d like to have all these virtues in full measure, but each pair seems a contradiction. How can you remain calm if you’re also on the lookout for danger? But embracing paradox isn’t some fanciful New Age notion. You often rely on other professionals to do exactly that. If someone in your family needs a coronary bypass operation, for example, you’d want a heart surgeon who’s both calm and alert. Likewise, you hope your children are blessed with teachers who are simultaneously patient and proactive. And if you’d been on board the crippled Apollo 13 moon mission, you’d have wanted the NASA mission control crew to be practical and creative to the max.

理想情况下，你当然希望自己能兼具所有这些美德，但每一种美德似乎都自相矛盾。如果你时刻警惕危险，又怎能保持冷静呢？然而，接受这种矛盾并非什么异想天开的新时代理念。你常常会依赖其他专业人士来做到这一点。例如，如果你的家人需要做冠状动脉搭桥手术，你会希望找到一位既冷静又警觉的心脏外科医生。同样，你也希望你的孩子能遇到既耐心又积极主动的老师。如果你曾参与过那次遭遇事故的阿波罗13号登月任务，你肯定希望NASA任务控制中心的工作人员能够做到既务实又富有创造力。

I’ve seen the same qualities in master negotiators. While each of these three dualities (calm-alert, patient-proactive, practical-creative) is important in its own right, they rest upon and express a deeper pairing of assurance and humility. Those attributes aren’t emotions. Rather, they represent a more fundamental way of seeing oneself in relation to others.

我在谈判高手身上也看到过同样的特质。虽然这三种特质（冷静警觉、耐心积极、务实创新）各自都很重要，但它们都建立在更深层次的自信与谦逊之上，并体现了这两种特质的结合。这些特质并非情绪，而是代表了一种更根本的看待自身与他人关系的方式。

The assurance part of the equation is confidence that you can handle the task at hand, given what’s reasonably possible. In turn, the humility element accepts that not everything is knowable or subject to your control. Mihaly Csikszentmilhalyi, author of the influential book Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience, says that the mark of strong individuals is an abiding confidence in having the personal resources to determine their own fate. “In that sense, one would call them self-assured, yet at the same time, their egos seem curiously absent; they are not self-centered.” He says that “their energy is typically not bent on dominating their environment as much as on finding a way to function within it harmoniously.” It requires recognition that “to succeed, one may have to play by a different set of rules from what one would prefer.”

等式中的“自信”指的是在合理可行的范围内，你对自己能够胜任当前任务的信心。而“谦逊”则意味着接受并非所有事物都可知或受你掌控。米哈里·契克森米哈赖（Mihaly Csikszentmilhalyi）在其颇具影响力的著作《心流：最优体验心理学》中指出，强者的标志是对自身拥有掌控命运所需资源的持久自信。“从这个意义上讲，我们可以称他们为自信，但与此同时，他们的自我意识似乎又异常淡薄；他们并不以自我为中心。”他表示，“他们的精力通常并非用于支配环境，而是用于寻找与环境和谐共处的方式。”这需要认识到，“要想成功，有时不得不遵循一套与自己偏好不同的规则。”

EMOTIONAL BAGGAGE

情感包袱

Several years ago, my colleagues Julianna Pillemer, Kim Leary, and I ran a study of people’s thoughts and emotions about negotiation. Julianna is trained in psychology, and Kim is a psychotherapist and psychoanalyst. We were curious: Why do some people love negotiating, while others loathe it?

几年前，我和我的同事朱莉安娜·皮勒默、金·利里进行了一项关于人们对谈判的看法和情绪的研究。朱莉安娜是心理学专业的，金是一位心理治疗师和精神分析师。我们当时很好奇：为什么有些人喜欢谈判，而有些人却厌恶谈判？

We were skeptical about whether simply polling subjects about their views would uncover their deep feelings about the process. Telling people to rate themselves is often problematic, and the wording of survey questions can skew results. (For instance, asking about self-confidence puts that idea in subjects’ heads.) We also doubted that simple numbers on a 10-point scale could capture the complexity of people’s psyches. To get a deeper understanding, we turned to the patented ZMET method developed by our colleague Gerry Zaltman, a sociologist. Drawing on interdisciplinary research from cognitive psychology and affective neuroscience, Gerry and his colleagues believe that people think primarily in images (usually visual), and certainly not in words alone. We dream in moving pictures, after all, not words or spreadsheets.

我们怀疑仅仅通过民意调查能否揭示受访者对整个过程的深层感受。让人们自我评价往往存在问题，而且调查问卷的措辞也可能导致结果出现偏差。（例如，询问自信心会给受访者灌输自信的观念。）我们也怀疑，简单的十分制评分能否捕捉到人们心理的复杂性。为了更深入地了解，我们采用了同事、社会学家格里·扎尔特曼（Gerry Zaltman）开发的专利方法ZMET。格里和他的同事们借鉴了认知心理学和情感神经科学的跨学科研究，认为人们主要以图像（通常是视觉图像）进行思考，而不仅仅是依靠文字。毕竟，我们的梦境是动态的画面，而不是文字或电子表格。

Their market research firm—Olson Zaltman Associates—studies the underlying structures that frame people’s thinking about a given topic. These deep structures are unconscious templates that shape how people process and react to information. They reveal themselves in the ordinary metaphors and descriptions that people use in everyday conversation. Someone who describes negotiation as a waltz, for instance, has a different view of the process than does another person who calls it “a scorpion’s mating dance.” By exploring such images, we were able to plumb the source of people’s complex feelings about negotiation.

他们的市场调研公司——奥尔森·扎尔特曼联合公司（Olson Zaltman Associates）——研究人们对特定话题的思考方式背后的深层结构。这些深层结构是无意识的模板，塑造着人们处理和回应信息的方式。它们体现在人们日常对话中使用的普通比喻和描述中。例如，将谈判比作华尔兹的人，与将其比作“蝎子求偶舞”的人，对谈判过程的看法截然不同。通过探索这些意象，我们得以深入探究人们对谈判复杂感受的根源。

The subjects in our study were primarily managers, both men and women, plus a few lawyers. All had fifteen or more years of real-world negotiation experience. We wanted to tap the emotional experience of veterans, not rookies.

我们研究的对象主要是管理人员，包括男性和女性，以及一些律师。所有参与者都拥有十五年或以上的实际谈判经验。我们希望了解的是经验丰富的谈判者，而不是新手的情感体验。

Two weeks before our interviews (which ran three to four hours each), we asked subjects to collect a half dozen images that they associated with some aspect of the negotiation process. They could clip pictures from magazines, make photocopies from books, or even draw their own sketches. When they arrived on campus, our trained interviewers asked the subjects how the images they had chosen expressed their thoughts and emotions. We wanted to know the source of those feelings, what triggered them, and how they influenced people’s behavior. When we were done, we had days of audiotape and reams of single-spaced transcripts. The pictures that the subjects gave us were the real gems in our trove of data.

在访谈开始前两周（每次访谈持续三到四个小时），我们请受访者收集六张与谈判过程相关图片。他们可以从杂志上剪下图片，从书中复印图片，甚至可以自己绘制草图。受访者到达校园后，我们训练有素的访谈员会询问他们选择的图片如何表达他们的想法和情感。我们想了解这些感受的来源、触发因素以及它们如何影响人们的行为。访谈结束后，我们收集了数天的录音和大量的单倍行距文字稿。受访者提供的图片才是我们收集到的宝贵数据。

I demonstrate a miniversion of the research method in my advanced negotiation course for MBA students. One year my first volunteer was a debonair, seemingly self-assured Frenchman named Thierry, who ultimately graduated near the top of his class. Thierry walked to the front of the room and plunked a photo of a tropical paradise on the overhead projector. “What does that have to do with negotiation?” I wondered.

我在为MBA学生开设的高级谈判课程中演示了这种研究方法的简化版。有一年，我的第一位志愿者是一位风度翩翩、看似自信满满的法国人，名叫蒂埃里，他最终以优异的成绩毕业。蒂埃里走到教室前面，把一张热带天堂的照片投射到投影仪上。“这跟谈判有什么关系呢？”我心想。

“Look at that island,” he explained. “There’s a lot that’s pleasant about negotiation. But look at those clouds: there could be a storm brewing. You always have to watch out.”

“看看那座岛，”他解释说。“谈判有很多令人愉快的地方。但看看那些云：暴风雨可能正在酝酿。你必须时刻保持警惕。”

His comment was spontaneous. We didn’t put the idea of turmoil into his head. We simply asked him in a neutral way to mull over his thoughts and feelings about negotiation. Despite his outward self-assurance, he harbored concern that tranquil encounters can become turbulent. Prior to coming to class, as he leafed through photos, he read that feeling into this seemingly benign scene.

他的评论是即兴的。我们并没有在他脑海中植入“动荡”的概念。我们只是以一种中立的方式请他思考一下自己对谈判的看法和感受。尽管他表面上很自信，但他内心深处却担心平静的会面可能会演变成动荡。在来上课之前，当他翻阅照片时，他从这幅看似平静的画面中读出了这种担忧。

The older, more experienced negotiators we studied did the same thing, time and time again, and in much greater depth. On the surface, their pictures had nothing to do with negotiation, but for the person who picked the image, it had an element or branch on which their preexisting feelings could perch. Their selections differed, but as with Thierry, they often would point first to something positive in the image and then counter their observation with a strong negative.

我们研究的那些年纪更大、经验更丰富的谈判者，反复地、甚至更深入地运用了同样的技巧。表面上看，他们选择的图片与谈判毫无关系，但对于选择图片的人来说，图片中包含着某种元素或线索，可以让他们找到自己既有感受的立足点。他们的选择各不相同，但和蒂埃里一样，他们通常会先指出图片中积极的一面，然后再用强烈的负面观点来反驳。

In spite of individual differences, the negotiators we interviewed had important commonalities:

尽管存在个体差异，但我们采访的谈判者们都具有重要的共同点：

• Everyone expressed mixed feelings about negotiation. Those who tended to enjoy the process also spoke about the risk of tripping up or being exploited. Similarly, those who described negotiation as largely an onerous process acknowledged potential silver linings.

• 每个人都对谈判表达了复杂的情感。那些乐于享受谈判过程的人也谈到了出错或被利用的风险。同样，那些认为谈判过程十分繁琐的人也承认其中可能存在一些积极的方面。

• Coping with those conflicting feelings is a challenge in itself. One of our subjects described it this way: “It is a balancing act between the relationship and the task. You want to maximize your opportunity and the relationship you have with that person.”

• 应对这些矛盾的情感本身就是一项挑战。我们的一位受访者这样描述道：“这就像是在人际关系和工作任务之间寻求平衡。你既想最大限度地利用机会，又想最大程度地维系与对方的关系。”

• In the same vein, the unpredictability of negotiation triggered anxiety, especially in respect to the behavior and attitudes of other parties. All our subjects were successful professionally, yet many worried about their own competence and vulnerability. “It’s not always clear,” said one senior manager, “who is the wizard behind the curtain and who is the charlatan.”

同样，谈判的不可预测性也引发了焦虑，尤其是在对方的行为和态度方面。所有受访者在职业上都取得了成功，但许多人仍然担心自己的能力和脆弱性。“有时候很难分辨，”一位高级经理说，“谁是幕后的高手，谁又是骗子。”

• Virtually everyone spoke of the gap between the ideal of win-win negotiation they wished for and what they regarded as the harsh realities of real-world hard bargaining. Even the optimists brought in pictures of alligators and other predators lying in wait.

几乎每个人都谈到了他们所期望的双赢谈判的理想状态与他们认为现实世界中艰难谈判的残酷现实之间的差距。就连乐观主义者也拿出了鳄鱼和其他捕食者潜伏在暗处的图片。

• Taken together, the swirl of feelings that negotiators experience, the unpredictability of the process, and the tension between aspirations and reality constitute a heavy cognitive and emotional load. Thus, it’s small wonder that negotiators find the process stressful.

• 总而言之，谈判者所经历的种种复杂情绪、谈判过程的不可预测性以及理想与现实之间的矛盾，共同构成了沉重的认知和情感负担。因此，谈判者感到压力巨大也就不足为奇了。

If you visit our project website, you’ll see a sample of images that the participants selected and hear some of their recorded descriptions of what the pictures symbolize. Again and again, you’ll find renderings of an isolated negotiator beset by risks and dangers on all sides. What you can’t view online, unfortunately, is what our subjects look like in person. They all appear confident and successful. Sitting across from them at the bargaining table, you’d have every reason to believe that you were up against self-possessed negotiators. What they expressed in their ZMET interviews, however, paints a different picture. Some things that particular individuals said were unique to them, but anxiety was commonly triggered by three overlapping concerns:

如果您访问我们的项目网站，您会看到参与者选择的一些图片样本，并听到他们对这些图片象征意义的描述。您会反复看到这样的画面：一位孤立无援的谈判者，四面楚歌，危机四伏。遗憾的是，您无法在线看到我们受访者的真实面貌。他们看起来都自信满满，似乎很成功。如果您与他们坐在谈判桌对面，您完全有理由相信自己面对的是一群沉着冷静的谈判者。然而，他们在ZMET访谈中表达的内容却描绘了一幅截然不同的景象。虽然每个人的某些说法都独一无二，但焦虑通常源于以下三个相互交织的担忧：

1. Uncertainty about what counterparts will accept, how best to engage them, and whether agreement is even possible. One person said, “Whenever you are going into any situation where you think you are uncertain, there tends to be anxiety.” Another subject spoke of the challenge of anticipating where your target (as he put it) is going to be. “It’s chess. It’s thinking multiple moves down the line and not attacking the person where they are or addressing just the issue at hand.”

1. 对对方的接受程度、如何最好地与他们沟通以及是否能够达成协议都存在不确定性。一位受访者说：“当你进入任何你感到不确定的情境时，往往会感到焦虑。”另一位受访者谈到了预测目标（正如他所说）的挑战。“这就像下棋。要考虑多步之后的策略，而不是攻击对方的原地踏步，或者仅仅关注眼前的问题。”

2. Worries about the quality of the relationship with counterparts, especially the risk that they might not be ethical, cooperative, or respectful. As one manager put it, “There is posturing in virtually all negotiations. I’m using it in the situation when you have people transparently miscast the facts.” Another person chose an image of people appearing to shake hands but actually holding guns. For him, it symbolized how relationships themselves can be counterfeit. “And so it appears to be an act of greeting and cordiality, but in reality it’s pointing a gun at somebody. So there’s a difference between the appearance and the reality.”

2. 对与对方关系质量的担忧，尤其是对方可能缺乏道德、合作或尊重。正如一位经理所说：“几乎所有谈判中都存在虚张声势。我用它来形容那些公然歪曲事实的人。” 另一个人则选择了一张看似握手实则持枪的图片。对他而言，这象征着人际关系本身也可能是虚假的。“表面上，这似乎是在打招呼、表示友好，但实际上却是在用枪指着别人。所以，表象和现实之间存在着巨大的差异。”

3. Performance anxiety, the fear of being outfoxed or appearing foolish. One person’s picture featured a city scene with tall buildings lining a street. He noted, “The street is abandoned, and all you see is the pavement. On the pavement is an unlittered pathway, and on either side of the pathway are many banana peels. This image [represents] that I am concerned when entering into negotiations about slipping up.” Another worried about self-defeating behavior: “Coming apart would mean losing my temper, losing control of the situation, being unable to think clearly about the options because of whatever the emotional situation is. I feel that if am going to come apart, then everything will come apart.” Still another described what he called “an image of somebody weighing their head on a scale to see whether they are worthy or not.” Then he added, “That kind of implied doubt wouldn’t help our negotiator.”

3. 表现焦虑，即害怕被人耍弄或显得愚蠢。一位参与者的描述是一幅城市景象，街道两旁林立着高楼大厦。他写道：“街道空无一人，只能看到人行道。人行道上有一条干净的小路，路两旁散落着许多香蕉皮。这幅图[代表]我在谈判中担心自己会犯错。”另一位参与者则担心自己会做出适得其反的行为：“崩溃意味着我会失去理智，失去对局面的控制，因为情绪波动而无法清晰地思考各种选择。我觉得如果我崩溃了，那么一切都会崩溃。”还有一位参与者描述了他所谓的“有人把自己的头放在天平上称重，看看自己是否配得上谈判”的画面。然后他补充道：“这种隐含的怀疑对我们的谈判者没有任何帮助。”

No wonder people approach negotiation warily, not knowing whom to trust or whether they’ll succeed. Caution has been bred into us, more strongly with some people than with others. One of our subjects admitted, “I hate confrontation. I don’t deal well with other people’s anger. I think anger blocks both creativity and understanding because real anger is just such a boiling emotion that it overtakes you. I think that is what is negative about it. It blocks further communication.”

难怪人们在谈判时总是小心翼翼，不知道该信任谁，也不知道谈判能否成功。谨慎似乎是与生俱来的本能，只是有些人比其他人更加强烈。我们的一位受访者坦言：“我讨厌冲突。我不擅长应对别人的愤怒。我认为愤怒会阻碍创造力和理解力，因为真正的愤怒是一种汹涌澎湃的情绪，它会彻底控制你。我认为这就是愤怒的负面影响所在。它会阻碍进一步的沟通。”

Posturing, deception, miscommunication, and confrontation are commonly feared perils of negotiation. Sometimes they’re real threats. Other times they are just in our imagination. And that’s true for us and for the people with whom we deal.

摆姿态、欺骗、沟通不畅和对抗是谈判中人们普遍担忧的风险。有时它们是真实存在的威胁，有时则仅仅存在于我们的想象中。这不仅适用于我们自己，也适用于与我们打交道的人。

DOUBLE STANDARDS

双重标准

Most people in our study saw others as predators in the negotiation jungle and themselves as prey. A few, however, identified with the aggressive side of human nature. One acknowledged the wolf within him. Another saw himself as a rifleman taking aim. But even those who visualized themselves fending off vicious creatures may have revealed more than they realized, projecting onto others their own negative attributes. Listen to how this person merges his impression of other people’s motivations with his own self-image:

我们研究中的大多数人将他人视为谈判丛林中的捕食者，而将自己视为猎物。然而，也有少数人认同人性中具有攻击性的一面。一位承认自己内心深处藏着一头狼。另一位则把自己想象成一名瞄准目标的步枪手。但即使是那些将自己想象成抵御凶猛野兽的人，也可能暴露出比他们意识到的更多东西，将自身的负面特质投射到他人身上。请听听这个人是如何将他对他人动机的印象与自身的自我认知融合在一起的：

“Sometimes you can be in negotiations, outfoxed by somebody perhaps not playing fairly. And I think that is a real difficult thing when it occurs. You can have a lack of honesty or you can see that. Sometimes people can play it a little bit unprofessionally; I think that is being outfoxed. I think being crafty and shrewd is playing your side intelligently.”

“有时候谈判中，你可能会被一些不讲道理的人耍得团团转。我觉得这种情况发生时真的很棘手。可能是对方缺乏诚信，也可能你能看出这一点。有时候人们的手段不够专业；我觉得这就是被耍了。我认为精明老练才是真正懂得如何巧妙地维护自身利益。”

Did you catch that mental shell game? When we’re “crafty and shrewd,” we’re just behaving intelligently. But when others do the same thing, they “lack honesty” and aren’t “playing fairly.” A double standard is a recipe for righteousness and retribution. When each negotiator sees his own tactics as clever and the other’s as evil, tensions escalate, confirming everyone’s worst fears.

你识破了这种心理上的障眼法吗？当我们说自己“狡猾精明”时，其实只是在展现智慧。但当别人做同样的事情时，他们就被说成“缺乏诚实”和“不公平”。双重标准只会滋生自以为是和报复。当每个谈判者都认为自己的策略高明，而对方的策略邪恶时，紧张局势就会升级，最终印证所有人最糟糕的预感。

Even a seemingly small action can trigger a downward spiral. A brusque greeting or an unexpected demand can spark a reaction that this negotiation won’t be as easy as hoped. Heart rates may go up a notch, stomach muscles may tighten, and before long, people may lose their composure. Serious negotiation is a physical act. It takes energy, concentration, and stamina. Internal doubts and discomfort are deadweights that can degrade your attention to the unfolding relationship with the other party.

即使是看似微小的举动也可能引发恶性循环。生硬的问候或出乎意料的要求都可能让人意识到谈判并非如预期般顺利。心跳可能会加快，胃部肌肉可能会紧绷，很快，人们就可能失去冷静。严肃的谈判是一项体力活动，需要精力、专注力和耐力。内心的疑虑和不安会成为阻碍，分散你对与对方关系发展的注意力。

It comes down to who you’d rather be: a well-centered negotiator or one who is anxious and distracted. Either type could start from the same place by extending an offer that he or she thinks is generous, but then be surprised when the other side rejects it. The person who’s well balanced will take that reaction in stride and focus on how to be more persuasive. By contrast, the anxious negotiator may start second-guessing himself and worrying about what to do if the deal falls through. With more composure, he could be better focused on making the deal work.

归根结底，这取决于你更愿意成为哪种类型的谈判者：沉着冷静的谈判者，还是焦虑不安、心神不宁的谈判者。这两种类型的人可能都从同一个起点出发，提出自己认为慷慨的报价，但当对方拒绝时，都会感到意外。沉着冷静的人会坦然接受这种反应，并专注于如何更有说服力地进行谈判。相比之下，焦虑的谈判者可能会开始自我怀疑，担心如果交易失败该怎么办。如果他能更加冷静，就能更好地专注于促成交易。

People who bring positive feelings to the table protect themselves against overreacting to slights and setbacks. They are patient and perceptive. The emotions stirred up by negotiation—anxiety and frustration, on the one hand; openness and assurance, on the other—aren’t static or transitory. Those feelings morph into trajectories that become the attitudes and inclinations that either facilitate or impede the process of reaching an agreement. Negotiators who can channel the ebb and flow of feelings have a substantial advantage over others who simply let themselves be rocked by them.

那些在谈判中保持积极心态的人，能够避免对轻视和挫折反应过度。他们耐心且洞察力敏锐。谈判中激起的情绪——一方面是焦虑和沮丧，另一方面是开放和自信——并非静止不变或转瞬即逝。这些情绪会演变成态度和倾向，从而影响最终达成协议的进程。能够驾驭情绪起伏的谈判者，比那些任由情绪左右的人拥有显著优势。

PEAK PERFORMANCE

巅峰表现

Negotiators can learn a lot about emotional balance and concentration from star athletes and other performers who must be at their best in high-pressure settings. Baseball players describe with awe those days when the pitch coming toward them looks as big as a beach ball. Football coaches praise coolheaded quarterbacks who can pick out an open receiver in the midst of an opposing blitz. And some ice hockey goalies claim that time slows down for them, so that they can casually block a puck flying at them at one hundred miles an hour.

谈判者可以从明星运动员和其他需要在高压环境下保持最佳状态的表演者身上学到很多关于情绪平衡和专注力的知识。棒球运动员会惊叹于那些感觉飞来的球像沙滩球一样大的日子。橄榄球教练会赞扬那些在对方猛攻中也能冷静找到空位接球手的四分卫。一些冰球守门员甚至声称时间对他们来说仿佛慢了下来，让他们能够轻松地挡住时速一百英里的冰球。

Sports psychologists such as Robert Nideffer link this state of “being in the zone” to the absence of mental distractions. Mihaly Csikszentmilhalyi describes the related concept of flow as total absorption. It’s a mental state where “people are so involved in an activity that nothing else seems to matter; the experience itself is so enjoyable that people will do it even at great cost, for the sheer sake of doing it.”

像罗伯特·尼德弗这样的运动心理学家将这种“进入状态”与消除精神干扰联系起来。米哈里·契克森米哈赖将与之相关的“心流”概念描述为完全沉浸。这是一种精神状态，在这种状态下，“人们如此投入于某项活动，以至于其他一切都显得无关紧要；体验本身如此令人愉悦，以至于人们即使付出巨大代价也会去做，仅仅是为了去做而已。”

It is easy to visualize a cellist, engrossed in his music, or a marathon runner, lungs bursting as she nears the finish line, as being in flow or in the zone. Even a design team, brainstorming ideas for a new product, might have moments when its members are all in sync, free of distractions.

我们很容易想象一位大提琴手全神贯注于音乐，或者一位马拉松运动员在冲向终点线时气喘吁吁，进入一种心流或专注的状态。即使是设计团队，在为新产品集思广益时，也可能出现所有成员步调一致、不受干扰的时刻。

But what of negotiation? Is it possible to imagine a negotiator as deeply absorbed as the cellist or as focused as the marathon runner? Negotiation is an interpersonal process. Keeping up with the exchange of arguments, propositions, and reactions prompts an internal dialogue that can jeopardize your focus on the moment. If you’re not self-aware, negotiation can be a hothouse for cultivating thoughts and feelings that subvert concentration.

那么谈判呢？我们能想象一个谈判者像大提琴手那样全神贯注，或者像马拉松运动员那样专注吗？谈判是一个人际互动的过程。跟上双方的论点、提议和反应，会引发内心的对话，从而分散你对当下的注意力。如果你缺乏自知之明，谈判就可能成为滋生干扰注意力的温床。

Athletes (and their fans) know about “choking.” Studies suggest that stress cramps working memory, the resource that experts draw upon to excel. In sports, it might be sparked by an external event, such as a spectator throwing something onto the playing field. But often the cause is internal, where a competitor’s mind gets tied up with negative thoughts. Pressure to perform in a win-or-lose moment may overwhelm an athlete’s senses and cause him or her to freeze. For a tennis player, it may be fear of making a bad shot. For the negotiator, it may be doubt about his ability to get a good deal or win the other person’s respect.

运动员（以及他们的粉丝）都深知“关键时刻掉链子”的滋味。研究表明，压力会削弱工作记忆，而工作记忆正是专家们赖以取得卓越成就的宝贵资源。在体育运动中，这种现象可能由外部事件引发，例如观众向赛场投掷物品。但通常情况下，其根源在于内部因素，例如运动员的思绪被负面想法所占据。在胜负攸关的时刻，运动员承受的压力可能会压倒他们的感官，导致他们发挥失常。对于网球运动员来说，这可能是害怕打出糟糕的一球。对于谈判者来说，这可能是怀疑自己能否达成有利的交易或赢得对方的尊重。

W. Timothy Gallwey, author of the classic Inner Game of Tennis , describes the dread that some people feel when a ball is hit to their backhand. “Uh-oh,” the player says to himself. “You’re going to look clumsy again.” Gallwey says that this internal critic is much more devastating to performance than hundreds of taunting fans in the grandstand. Likewise, a negotiator who scolds himself or herself for being anxious reinforces self-criticism and compounds the distraction.

网球经典著作《网球的内在游戏》的作者W·蒂莫西·加尔韦描述了一些人在反手击球时所感受到的恐惧。“糟了，”球员心想，“你又要出丑了。”加尔韦认为，这种内心的批评对表现的破坏性远大于看台上数百名球迷的嘲讽。同样，谈判者如果因为焦虑而责备自己，只会加剧自我批评，使注意力更加分散。

Resolving to put aside negative thoughts often does more harm than good, since it takes focus away from playing the game. Gallwey says that telling someone to “keep your eye on the ball” is counterproductive. Instead, more active focusing is required. For tennis, he prescribes the mantra “bounce-hit.” That means saying “bounce” to yourself when the ball starts its rebound from the court’s surface, and then saying “hit” at the moment the ball makes impact with the strings of the racquet. This simple exercise constitutes concentration instead of pleading for it. It displaces internal distractions with outward focus on the relevant environment—in this case, the flight of the ball over the net, on the court, and then onto the face of the racquet.

试图摒除负面想法往往弊大于利，因为它会分散注意力，使人无法专注于比赛。加尔韦指出，告诉别人“盯紧球”是适得其反的。相反，需要更积极的专注。他推荐网球练习“弹跳-击球”的口诀。也就是说，当球从球场表面开始反弹时，在心里默念“弹跳”，然后在球击中球拍拍面的瞬间默念“击球”。这个简单的练习能够帮助人们集中注意力，而不是强迫自己集中注意力。它用对外部环境的关注——在这个例子中，就是球越过球网、落在球场上，最终击中球拍面的过程——来取代内心的干扰。

Let’s translate this technique to negotiation. Your entire attention should be focused on what your counterpart is saying and how she is saying it. Not just her words, but her posture and the expression that just flickered across her face. It’s akin to watching the tennis ball. You’re observing the direction of what is being said, its pace, and its spin. If you’re deeply attentive, your mind will be quieted.

让我们把这个技巧运用到谈判中。你应该全神贯注于对方所说的话以及她的说话方式。不仅要关注她所说的话，还要关注她的姿态和脸上闪过的表情。这就像观察网球一样。你要观察说话的方向、节奏和旋转。如果你全神贯注，你的思绪自然就会平静下来。

Top athletes also are masters of pace and timing. Legendary UCLA basketball coach John Wooden used to tell his players, “Be quick, but don’t hurry.” The same applies at the bargaining table. When a deadline looms, a caucus or a time-out may provide a moment for reflection and allow participants to regain presence of mind. Even pausing for a second or two before responding can occasion deeper comprehension of what is taking place.

顶尖运动员也都是节奏和时机的掌控者。传奇的加州大学洛杉矶分校篮球队教练约翰·伍登曾告诉他的队员们：“动作要快，但不要着急。” 这句话同样适用于谈判桌。当最后期限临近时，小组讨论或暂停可以提供反思的时间，让参与者重新集中注意力。即使只是在回应前停顿一两秒钟，也能加深对当前局势的理解。

Champion race car driver Jackie Stewart remembers an event where he was going over 150 miles per hour but suddenly sensed the distinct smell of green grass. He immediately eased up on the pedal, knowing that around the corner, out of his sight, one of his rivals must have skidded onto the infield. The best negotiators shift mental gears smoothly, switching back and forth from the micromoments in an exchange to the macroperspective about how the overall process is progressing. By stepping back from minutia this way, they give themselves the chance to check on their own emotional state—whether they are being calm and alert, patient and proactive, and practical and creative.

赛车冠军杰基·斯图尔特回忆起一次经历：当时他的车速超过每小时150英里，突然闻到一股青草的清香。他立刻松开油门，因为他知道，在不远处，他的某个对手肯定已经滑进了内场。优秀的谈判者能够流畅地转换思维模式，在谈判过程中的细微之处和整个谈判进程的宏观视角之间自如切换。通过这种方式，他们能够从琐碎的细节中抽身出来，审视自身的情绪状态——是否保持冷静警觉、耐心积极、务实创新。

The best negotiators are also monitoring how things might look to their counterparts. In Getting Past No: Negotiating Your Way from Confrontation to Cooperation , Bill Ury emphasizes the importance of being fully present: deeply engaged with the other party while at the same time taking in everything as if one were a detached observer. He calls this process “going to the balcony.” It requires the emotional competence to be center stage yet with the viewpoint of a person sitting way up in the last row. Developing that capacity enables you to understand that what you just said may not necessarily be what your negotiating partner heard (or that what you thought you heard wasn’t what he or she meant).

优秀的谈判者还会密切关注对方的感受。在《超越拒绝：从对抗到合作的谈判之道》一书中，比尔·尤里强调了全然投入的重要性：既要与对方深度互动，又要像一个超然的旁观者一样观察一切。他把这个过程称为“登上阳台”。这需要具备既能置身于谈判中心，又能保持旁观者视角的能力。培养这种能力能让你明白，你刚才说的话未必是你的谈判伙伴听到的（或者你以为自己听到的并非对方真正想表达的意思）。

THE PRACTICE OF MINDFULNESS

正念的练习

To develop balance and resilience in negotiation, you can also tap the well of mindfulness training. In its most rigorous form, mindfulness is at the heart of the Buddhist practice of Vipassana (or “insight”) meditation. While other kinds of Buddhist meditation try to clear the mind of conscious thought or direct attention to a single image or idea, insight practitioners seek a nonjudgmental awareness of their passing thoughts and feelings. Vipassana followers believe that if our minds are constantly occupied with rehashing the past or anticipating the future, we are never fully alive in the present. They locate themselves in the immediate moment through quiet exercises in which they pay careful attention to their breathing. They become aware of their thinking in a detached, unforced manner.

为了在谈判中培养平衡感和韧性，你还可以借助正念训练的力量。正念最严谨的形式体现在佛教内观（或称“洞察”）禅修的核心。其他类型的佛教冥想试图清除意识中的杂念，或将注意力集中于某个单一的图像或概念，而内观禅修者则追求对自身转瞬即逝的念头和感受保持一种不加评判的觉察。内观禅修者认为，如果我们的思绪总是被对过去的反复回想或对未来的担忧所占据，我们就永远无法真正活在当下。他们通过安静的练习，专注于呼吸，从而将自己定位于当下。他们以一种超脱、自然的方式觉察自己的思维。

This rich and subtle philosophy cannot be distilled in a few short paragraphs, and it’s beyond the purview of this book to provide a tutorial in the techniques. There are many books available that do so expertly. The purpose here is simply to point to another fruitful method for developing the emotional balance necessary for peak performance.

这种丰富而精妙的哲学理念无法用寥寥数语概括，本书也无意深入讲解其中的技巧。市面上已有许多书籍对此进行了精辟的阐述。本书的目的仅在于介绍另一种有助于培养情绪平衡的有效方法，而情绪平衡对于达到最佳状态至关重要。

A monastic life of quiet contemplation is light-years from the multitasking world in which most of us live, of course, yet there is growing interest in pragmatic applications of mindfulness. The General Mills company offers employees mindfulness workshops and yoga sessions. These sessions are aimed partly at reducing stress, but deeper benefits have emerged. The company’s deputy general counsel, Janice Marturano, says, “It’s about training our minds to be more focused, to see with clarity, to have spaciousness for creativity, and to feel connected.” All those traits she names are key assets in negotiation. In the same spirit, Bill George, former CEO of the medical technology company Medtronic, says, “The main business case for meditation is that if you’re fully present on the job, you will be more effective as a leader, you will make better decisions, and you will work better with other people.” Those, too, are attributes of great negotiators.

当然，与我们大多数人身处的忙碌喧嚣的世界相比，隐居修行、静思冥想的生活可谓天壤之别。然而，人们对正念的实际应用越来越感兴趣。通用磨坊公司为员工提供正念工作坊和瑜伽课程。这些课程的部分目的是为了减轻压力，但更深层次的益处也逐渐显现。该公司副总法律顾问珍妮丝·马图拉诺表示：“这关乎训练我们的思维，让我们更加专注，看得更清晰，拥有更大的创造力空间，并感受到彼此的联结。”她提到的所有这些特质都是谈判中的关键要素。同样，医疗技术公司美敦力的前首席执行官比尔·乔治也表示：“冥想的主要商业价值在于，如果你能全神贯注于工作，你就能更有效地领导，做出更好的决策，并与他人更好地合作。”这些也正是优秀谈判者的必备素质。

It doesn’t matter what techniques or practices you use to develop presence of mind. David Hoffman, a Boston-based mediator and coeditor of Bringing Peace into the Room: How the Personal Qualities of the Mediator Impact the Process of Conflict Resolution, handles a wide range of cases, including bitter family disputes. He’s dedicated to being emotionally balanced and centered, especially in the middle of hot conflict. He realizes that when he is edgy or distracted himself, it amplifies other people’s anxieties.

无论你采用何种技巧或方法来培养临场应变能力，都无关紧要。大卫·霍夫曼是一位常驻波士顿的调解员，也是《化解冲突：调解员的个人素质如何影响冲突解决过程》一书的合著者。他处理过各种各样的案件，包括激烈的家庭纠纷。他致力于保持情绪平衡和沉着冷静，尤其是在激烈的冲突中。他意识到，当他自己感到紧张或心不在焉时，会加剧他人的焦虑。

Mindfulness has deep roots. Japanese Zen master Shunryu Suzuki, founder of the first Buddhist monastery in the United States, said, “If your mind is empty, it is always ready for anything; it is open to everything. In the beginner’s mind, there are many possibilities; in the expert’s mind, there are few.” This stance is the antithesis of being on automatic pilot. It requires self-awareness and a willingness to put aside, at least for a time, preconceptions and snap judgments about other parties’ behavior and intentions.

正念有着深厚的渊源。日本禅宗大师铃木俊隆（Shunryu Suzuki）是美国第一座佛教寺院的创始人，他曾说过：“如果你的心是空的，它就随时准备好迎接任何事物；它对一切都持开放态度。在初学者的心中，可能性很多；在专家的心中，可能性却很少。”这种态度与自动驾驶模式截然相反。它需要自我觉察，并且愿意暂时放下对他人行为和意图的先入为主的观念和草率的判断。

Psychologist Ellen Langer describes a Western version of mindfulness that includes constantly seeing things anew. She takes issue with some coaches’ notions about helping athletes get into a flow by practicing a skill to “the point of doing it without thinking.” Langer believes that overlearning can be dangerous. Imagine an American driver on an English roadway where traffic flows in the opposite direction. She must “unlearn” her driving instincts and habituate to those of the English.

心理学家艾伦·兰格描述了一种西方版本的正念，其中包括不断地以全新的视角看待事物。她对一些教练帮助运动员进入“心流”状态的观点持不同意见，这些教练认为应该通过反复练习技能直到“不假思索地完成”才能达到这种状态。兰格认为过度学习可能很危险。试想一下，一位美国司机在英国的道路上行驶，而英国的交通方向与美国相反。她必须“摒弃”原有的驾驶习惯，转而适应英国人的驾驶方式。

In negotiation, the practice of mindfulness could involve sensing the first stirrings of one’s own anger in a detached way. Then, instead of either nurturing that feeling or trying to suppress it, a mindful negotiator would register the irritation. This process is different from reasoning it through or trying to argue oneself out of the feeling. The point of mindfulness is becoming aware of one’s thoughts and feelings without prematurely judging them as valid or inappropriate, useful or dysfunctional. It’s accepting their presence and moving on, just as a traveler on a train might take in the passing scene.

在谈判中，正念练习可以包括以一种超脱的方式觉察自身愤怒的萌芽。然后，一位有正念的谈判者不会去滋养或试图压抑这种感觉，而是会觉察到这种恼怒。这个过程不同于试图通过理性分析或辩解来消除这种感觉。正念的关键在于觉察自己的想法和感受，而不急于评判它们是合理还是不恰当，有用还是无益。它意味着接受它们的存在，然后继续前行，就像火车上的旅客欣赏窗外的风景一样。

As Csikszentmilhalyi says, controlling one’s consciousness is not a mere cognitive skill. “At least as much as intelligence,” he writes, “it requires a commitment of emotions and will. It is not enough to know how to do it; one must do it, consistently, the same way as athletes or musicians who must keep practicing what they know in theory. And this is never easy.” But it can be done.

正如齐克森米哈赖所说，控制意识并非仅仅是一种认知技能。“它至少与智力一样重要，”他写道，“需要情感和意志的投入。仅仅知道如何做到这一点是不够的；必须持之以恒地去做，就像运动员或音乐家必须不断练习他们理论中所掌握的东西一样。而这绝非易事。”但这并非不可能。

EMOTIONAL PREPARATION

情绪准备

Serious negotiators prepare. They understand the markets in which they function. They run the numbers and read draft contracts. They scout their counterparts and develop a plan B in case things don’t go as expected. You can do all that and more, however, and still not be prepared if you haven’t readied yourself emotionally.

优秀的谈判者会做好充分的准备。他们了解自己所处的市场环境，仔细分析数据，阅读合同草案，考察对方，并制定备用方案以防万一。然而，即便你做了所有这些，甚至更多，如果你没有做好情绪上的准备，仍然可能一事无成。

Six straightforward questions can help you develop a personalized fitness routine. The more thought you give to each one, the more useful this assignment will be. It’s essential to be honest with yourself about your temperament, strengths, and shortcomings.

六个简单的问题可以帮助你制定个性化的健身计划。你对每个问题思考得越深入，这项任务就越有用。诚实地面对自己的性格、优势和不足至关重要。

Right now may be a good time to go through this exercise. If you have ten minutes or so, find a pen and paper for making some notes. Slow down a bit as well. (If you’re rushed, it might make sense to come back to this exercise when you’re not quite as busy.) When you’re ready, turn the paper so that it’s in landscape format and make a six-cell matrix: three columns across, split into two rows.

现在或许是完成这个练习的好时机。如果你有十分钟左右的时间，可以找支笔和纸做些笔记。同时，放慢速度。（如果你时间紧迫，最好等到不那么忙的时候再做这个练习。）准备好后，将纸张横向放置，画一个六格矩阵：三列，两行。

As the first two questions are linked, consider them together:

前两个问题是相互关联的，请将它们放在一起考虑：

1. What Do You Want to Feel Going into a Negotiation? 2. Why?
1. 你希望在谈判开始时有什么样的感觉？ 2. 为什么？

Jot down the first emotions that occur to you, then step back and think of others you could add to the list. Now reflect for a moment on why you identified those feelings and make a few notes in box 2. Don’t hurry to read the text that’s coming next. Make sure that you’ve given these first two questions some thought before reading about how others have responded. Okay?

记下你脑海中浮现的第一个情绪，然后退后一步，想想你还可以添加哪些其他情绪。现在花点时间思考一下你为什么会想到这些情绪，并在第二个方框里做一些记录。不要急着阅读接下来的内容。在阅读其他人的回答之前，请确保你已经认真思考过这两个问题。好吗？

I use this six-step exercise in MBA and executive negotiation courses. Typically, when I start out, students say that they want to be relaxed, focused, and confident. Intuitively, people associate those positive emotions with the pathway to agreement.

我在MBA和高管谈判课程中使用这套六步练习。通常，在练习开始时，学员们会表示他们希望保持放松、专注和自信的状态。人们直觉上会将这些积极情绪与达成协议联系起来。

But then other students chime in on the discussion. It’s fine to be calm, they say, but they don’t want to be complacent. They want to be alert and maybe a bit on edge, so that they have the energy to drive the process forward. Rather than debate whether it’s one or the other, most students come to realize that they need to be both optimistic and watchful. Check the notes that you made in the first two boxes and think about the balance you want to strike among different feelings. Now you’re ready for the next question.

但随后其他学生也加入了讨论。他们说，保持冷静固然重要，但他们不想安于现状。他们希望保持警觉，甚至略带一丝紧张，这样才能有精力推动进程。与其争论究竟应该保持乐观还是谨慎，大多数学生最终意识到，他们需要兼顾乐观和警惕。回顾一下你在前两个方框中做的笔记，思考一下你想在不同情绪之间找到怎样的平衡。现在，你已经准备好回答下一个问题了。

3. What Can You Do Beforehand to Put Yourself in Your Ideal Emotional State?
3. 你可以事先做些什么来让自己处于理想的情绪状态？

Again, make a few notes on the form.

再次在表格上做一些备注。

This question takes people aback if they haven’t thought before about manipulating their own emotional state, but they soon come up with practical suggestions. I’ve heard students say, “It’s just like with exams. Don’t tense yourself up with last-minute cramming. Give yourself time to decompress.”

这个问题可能会让那些以前从未考虑过如何控制自身情绪的人感到惊讶，但他们很快就能提出一些切实可行的建议。我曾听学生们说：“这就像考试一样。不要临时抱佛脚，让自己紧张起来。给自己一些时间放松。”

The same is true in negotiation—and the less time you have to get ready, the more important that advice is. Say that you’re at your desk working on your quarterly budget. The phone rings. It’s your counterpart in a tough transaction that has dragged on far too long. Your every impulse may be to leap right into that conversation.

谈判也是如此——准备时间越少，这条建议就越重要。假设你正在办公桌前制定季度预算，电话铃响了。是你的谈判对手打来的，他们正在进行一项棘手的交易，而且拖延了太久。你很可能会立刻投入到这场谈判中。

It would be smarter, though, to say, “Glad you called. Let me wrap something up here, and I’ll get back to you in three minutes flat.” Then you could lean back and maybe close your eyes for a moment. Even right now, if you imagine yourself doing that, you may feel how your tension would ease, leaving you better prepared when you return the call.

不过，更明智的做法是说：“很高兴您来电。我这里还有点事要处理，三分钟后马上回复您。”然后您可以靠在椅背上，或许还可以闭上眼睛休息一会儿。即使现在，如果您想象一下自己这样做，您或许也能感受到紧张感会逐渐消退，让您在回电时更加从容。

Other people suggest simple meditation exercises as a way of putting aside distracting thoughts. Visualization, too, may help. Imagine having the right balance of calm and alertness. What will that feel like? Or if you sometimes fault yourself for being impatient, think about what it’s like to listen without interrupting. If you are sometimes too withdrawn, picture yourself leaning into the conversation and being more expressive.

其他人建议通过简单的冥想练习来排除杂念。视觉化练习也可能有所帮助。想象一下自己处于平静与警觉的平衡状态。那会是什么感觉？或者，如果你有时会因为自己缺乏耐心而自责，不妨想想不打断别人倾听是什么感觉。如果你有时过于内向，可以想象自己积极参与谈话，更加坦诚地表达自己的想法。

Do what you can to minimize distractions beforehand. When you go to an important meeting, the drive may be easy or traffic may be snarled. Circumstances beyond your command will affect your mood—maybe for better, maybe for worse. If it’s the latter, bringing that frustration into the room won’t be in your best interest. Do what you can to put yourself in the proper state.

尽量提前减少干扰。参加重要会议时，路途可能顺畅，也可能交通拥堵。一些无法掌控的情况会影响你的情绪——或许是好转，或许是恶化。如果是后者，把这种沮丧带到会议室对你没有任何好处。尽你所能让自己保持最佳状态。

Let’s say that you’re emotionally prepared. Move on to question 4.

假设你已经做好了心理准备，请继续回答第4题。

4. What Can Throw You off Balance During a Negotiation?
4. 谈判中哪些因素会让你失去平衡？

Once again, make a few notes on the exercise form before reading about other people’s responses.

再次提醒，在阅读其他人的回答之前，请在练习表格上做一些笔记。

Here I’m talking about emotional hot buttons that, if pushed, can make you underperform. These triggers vary from person to person. Insults get under some people’s skin but just roll off other people’s backs. Likewise, some negotiators have infinite patience, while others get frustrated when talks drag on.

我这里指的是那些情绪上的敏感点，一旦被触动，就会导致你发挥失常。这些触发点因人而异。有些人会被侮辱激怒，而有些人却毫不在意。同样，有些谈判者耐心无穷，而另一些人则会在谈判拖延时感到沮丧。

Think back to negotiations where you didn’t function at your best. Maybe you lost your temper, maybe not. But if you pride yourself on your self-control, take an honest look at yourself. Are there times that you disengage and withdraw emotionally? Look for patterns and tendencies. Also think about when in the process problems seem to arise. Do things go wrong early or more often at the end, when you’re trying to close a deal? Candid feedback from negotiation teammates can help.

回想一下那些你表现不佳的谈判经历。也许你当时发了脾气，也许没有。但如果你以自己的自制力为傲，那就认真审视一下自己。你是否有时会情绪低落、退缩？寻找其中的规律和倾向。同时，想想问题似乎总是在谈判的哪个阶段出现。是谈判初期就出了问题，还是经常在最后阶段，也就是你试图达成交易的时候出现问题？来自谈判伙伴的坦诚反馈会很有帮助。

5. What Can You Do in the Midst of Negotiation to Regain Your Balance?
5. 在谈判过程中，你可以做些什么来重新获得平衡？

Again, jot down your own thoughts before reading further.

再次提醒，在继续阅读之前，请先记下自己的想法。

Problems in negotiation aren’t due to just other people’s actions, however. They also depend on how you respond. You can’t control other people’s behavior, but you do have a say over how you react to it. And if you’re self-aware, you’ll be alert to the first internal signs of annoyance before it blossoms into full-scale anger. But losing your temper isn’t the only way to falter; there are more subtle ways of being off your game as well. If a negotiation is dragging on and on, you may lose concentration. Your energy may wane. What then?

然而，谈判中的问题并非仅仅源于他人的行为，也取决于你的应对方式。你无法控制他人的行为，但你可以掌控自己如何回应。如果你有自知之明，就能在恼怒情绪演变成彻底的愤怒之前，敏锐地察觉到最初的内心波动。但发脾气并非导致谈判失败的唯一途径；还有一些更为隐蔽的方式会让你状态不佳。如果谈判旷日持久，你可能会注意力不集中，精力也会逐渐耗尽。那么，接下来该怎么办呢？

One easy answer is taking a break. It works like a reset button, interrupting whatever dysfunctional pattern has emerged. And remember to take a break before you actually need it, so that you’re constantly performing at the highest level. We are physical beings, after all. Sometimes, of course, you can’t leave the room, but when you’re feeling weary or irritated, take a deep breath. It’s familiar advice because it works. When you’re tense or tired, your respiration slows. Reoxygenating the blood does wonders.

一个简单的解决方法就是休息一下。它就像一个重启按钮，可以打断任何已经出现的紊乱模式。记住，要在真正需要休息之前就休息，这样才能始终保持最佳状态。毕竟，我们都是生理生物。当然，有时候你可能无法离开房间，但当你感到疲惫或烦躁时，深呼吸一下。这是一个耳熟能详的建议，因为它确实有效。当你紧张或疲惫时，呼吸会减慢。给血液重新充氧会带来奇效。

Without doing anything different physically, you can also break negative cycles by shifting the conversation. If you’ve been getting nowhere jostling over the details of a deal, talk about broad principles and concerns.
