It you’re stuck at that level, see if focusing on process issues jump-starts the interaction. These tactical moves may be useful in themselves. More fundamentally, asserting control will help you recenter yourself.

即使不采取任何实际行动，你也可以通过转变谈话方向来打破消极循环。如果你们在交易细节上争论不休却毫无进展，不妨谈谈更广泛的原则和顾虑。如果仍然卡在这一层面，那就看看聚焦流程问题是否能重启对话。这些策略本身就可能有效。更重要的是，掌控局面有助于你重新找到自我中心。

6. What Do You Want to Feel When You’re Done?
6. 你完成之后希望自己有什么样的感觉？

When I ask this question in classes, some students blurt out “Relieved.” That says a lot about the stress they must feel while they’re negotiating. It’s understandable, of course. Negotiation is work. It demands concentration, resilience, and creativity in a context where the stakes may be high and outcomes uncertain.

当我在课堂上问这个问题时，有些学生脱口而出“松了口气”。这充分说明了他们在谈判时承受的压力。当然，这也可以理解。谈判是一项工作。它需要在风险高、结果不确定的情况下，保持专注、坚韧和创造力。

But those who feel that negotiation is an ordeal pay a price twice over. Going into the process, their apprehension makes them defensive and closed minded. And if they are looking at the exit door all the while, they may settle cheap or walk away empty-handed. With a little more time and a lot more positive emotion, they could do much better.

但那些觉得谈判是一种折磨的人，会付出双重代价。谈判之初，他们的担忧会让他们变得防备心强、思维封闭。如果他们始终想着离开，最终可能只会做出廉价的妥协，甚至空手而归。但如果他们能多花些时间，并保持积极的心态，他们就能做得更好。

Some MBA and executive students answer “Satisfied.” When I probe for what they mean, people speak of being satisfied with the outcome, all things considered, but also feeling satisfied with their own performance. They may have maintained their balance throughout the process, or if they had a setback, they recovered well enough.

一些MBA和高管培训学员回答“满意”。当我追问他们具体含义时，他们表示，总体而言，他们对结果感到满意，同时也对自己的表现感到满意。他们或许在整个过程中保持了良好的心态，或者即使遇到挫折，也能很好地恢复过来。

Reminding yourself of what you want to feel going into negotiation and then taking simple steps to get into that state is worthwhile. You’ll gain a heightened sense of self-efficacy and confidence. Also remember the promotion-priming technique developed by Adam Galinsky and his colleagues that’s described in chapter 2. Taking a few minutes to write down the positive behaviors you want to engage in helps you perform at your best in negotiation.

在谈判前，提醒自己想要达到的状态，然后采取一些简单的步骤来达到这种状态，是值得的。你会获得更强的自我效能感和自信心。此外，还要记住亚当·加林斯基及其同事开发的“促进启动”技巧，该技巧在第二章中有详细介绍。花几分钟时间写下你想要采取的积极行为，有助于你在谈判中发挥最佳水平。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Be simultaneously calm and alert, patient and proactive, practical and creative.

■ 同时保持冷静和警觉，耐心和积极主动，务实和创新。

■ Diagnose and address the causes of anxiety.

■ 诊断并解决焦虑的根源。

■ Know your own hot buttons.

■ 了解自己的敏感点。

■ Don’t confirm your counterparts’ worst fears.

■ 不要证实对方最坏的担忧。

■ Be emotionally prepared to negotiate.

■做好谈判的情绪准备。

#↩

[ 6 ] The Swing of Things

[ 6 ] 事物的摇摆

Jazz trumpeter Wynton Marsalis says, “The real power of jazz—and the innovation of jazz—is that a group of people can come together and create art, improvised art, and can negotiate their agendas with each other. And that negotiation is the art.”

爵士小号手温顿·马萨利斯说：“爵士乐的真正力量——以及爵士乐的创新之处——在于一群人可以聚在一起创作艺术，即兴艺术，并且可以彼此协商各自的创作意图。而这种协商本身就是艺术。”

Jazz is negotiation? Absolutely. The late Richard Holbrooke, the US envoy who ended the bloody conflict in the former Yugoslavia and more recently tried to forge stability in Pakistan and Afghanistan, said, “Negotiation is like jazz. It is improvisation on a theme. You know where you want to go, but you don’t know how to get there. It’s not linear.”

爵士乐是谈判吗？绝对是。已故的理查德·霍尔布鲁克曾是美国特使，他结束了前南斯拉夫的血腥冲突，最近又致力于在巴基斯坦和阿富汗建立稳定。他曾说过：“谈判就像爵士乐。它是围绕一个主题的即兴演奏。你知道你想去哪里，但你不知道该如何到达那里。它不是一条直线。”

In a jazz combo, players with different skills and tastes—and competing egos—must negotiate over what and how to play. The marvel is that a quartet of musicians, complete strangers, can jam together to create something new and exciting, all without an apparent plan or tight control over whatever happens next. “The bass—you never know what they’re going to do,” Marsalis says.

在爵士乐组合中，技艺、品味各异，甚至彼此之间存在竞争意识的乐手们必须协商演奏什么以及如何演奏。令人惊叹的是，这四位素不相识的音乐家能够即兴演奏，创造出新颖而激动人心的作品，而这一切似乎都没有事先计划，也无法严格控制接下来的发展。“贝斯手——你永远不知道他们会做什么，”马萨利斯说道。

Getting in sync is imperative, whatever the genre or whether the musicians are old friends or rivals. Marsalis explains that it’s “like what the UN does. They sit down, and they try to work things out.” The Roots have remained on the hip-hop scene for twenty years in spite of the fact that two founders—drummer Ahmir “Questlove” Thompson and emcee Tariq “Black Thought” Trotter—don’t get along. When an interviewer recently asked for the secret of the group’s long success, Trotter answered, “Two tour buses.”

无论什么音乐类型，也无论音乐人是老朋友还是竞争对手，保持步调一致都至关重要。马萨利斯解释说，这“就像联合国那样。他们坐下来，努力解决问题。”尽管两位创始人——鼓手阿米尔·“奎斯特洛夫”·汤普森和说唱歌手塔里克·“黑思想”·特罗特——关系不睦，The Roots乐队依然在嘻哈乐坛屹立了二十年。最近，当一位采访者问及乐队长期成功的秘诀时，特罗特回答说：“两辆巡演巴士。”

Jazz and hip-hop musicians don’t just cope with conflict and uncertainty. They thrive on it by working with whatever the other players give them, whether those notes are flat or sharp. Once a quartet finds its groove, Marsalis says, “The four of us can now have a dialogue. We can now have a conversation. We can speak to each other in the language of music.”

爵士乐和嘻哈音乐家不仅能应对冲突和不确定性，还能从中汲取力量，无论其他乐手演奏的音符是偏高还是偏低，他们都能与之和谐共处。马萨利斯说，一旦四重奏找到彼此的节奏，“我们四个人就能进行对话，就能进行交流，就能用音乐的语言彼此沟通。”

That’s just as true when you’re negotiating. After all, conducting a negotiation isn’t like leading a symphony orchestra. You can’t hand out sheet music to the other parties, tap your baton, and expect them to follow your lead. Others at the table will have their own preferred styles and tempos. They may want to be the star soloist and treat you, at best, as an accompanist.

谈判时也是如此。毕竟，谈判并非指挥交响乐团。你不能把乐谱发给对方，然后敲敲指挥棒，就指望他们跟着你走。谈判桌上的其他人都有自己偏好的风格和节奏。他们可能想成为主角，而你充其量只是个伴奏者。

I’m not just speaking metaphorically. Negotiators who get in a groove can tackle the toughest problems. It’s not a question of being colleagues or competitors. Even well-intended people often talk past one another. Nor is good negotiation chemistry a matter of luck. Rather, it depends on being both internally centered yourself and externally aware of other parties’ emotional states.

我并非只是在打比方。谈判者一旦进入状态，就能解决最棘手的问题。这与同事或竞争对手无关。即使是出于好意的人，也常常各说各话。良好的谈判默契并非运气使然，而是取决于谈判者自身既要保持冷静，又要敏锐地察觉对方的情绪状态。

In both negotiation and jazz, this process of learning, adapting, and influencing takes place moment to moment in listening and responding. You reflect, affirm, rebut, reshape, and respond to whatever your counterparts put forth. And as in jazz, it’s impossible to anticipate every twist and turn. Like it or not, you have to improvise right from the start. If you’re threatened unexpectedly, you have to stand up for yourself without escalating tensions. Or if your counterpart surprises you with a generous offer, you need to accept in such a way that he or she doesn’t suffer remorse and pull it back.

无论是谈判还是爵士乐，学习、适应和影响的过程都贯穿于聆听和回应的每一个瞬间。你需要反思、肯定、反驳、调整并回应对方提出的任何观点。就像爵士乐一样，你不可能预料到每一个转折。不管你喜不喜欢，你都必须从一开始就随机应变。如果你意外受到威胁，你必须在不激化矛盾的情况下维护自身权益。或者，如果对方提出慷慨的提议，你需要以一种不会让对方后悔并反悔的方式接受。

As such moments flash by, you are negotiating on multiple levels. Substantively, you respond to specific demands and offers by saying yes, no, or maybe. On another level, you are also defining the relationship as easy or strained, open or closed, cooperative or competitive. On still another plane, you are setting the tempo and tone of the negotiation process. And you must do all of this on the fly.

当这些瞬间转瞬即逝时，你其实是在多层面进行谈判。在实质层面，你通过回答“是”、“否”或“也许”来回应具体的要求和提议。在另一个层面，你也在定义这段关系是轻松还是紧张、开放还是封闭、合作还是竞争。再往后，你还在掌控谈判的节奏和基调。而所有这一切都必须你临场发挥。

An MBA student was in his final round of interviews at a consulting firm. He had a lot of social polish and glowing references. In earlier rounds, he had demonstrated his technical skills and his knowledge of business generally. The final meeting with the senior partners seemed like a formality; it was just a matter of tweaking the terms of an official offer. Then the head of the firm asked genially, “When was the last time you had to think on your feet?” The question caught the candidate off guard, and he paused. “Well,” he said, stroking his chin. “Let me think.”

一位MBA学生正在一家咨询公司进行最后一轮面试。他社交能力很强，推荐信也非常好。在之前的几轮面试中，他已经展现了自己的技术能力和商业知识。与高级合伙人的最后一次会议似乎只是走个形式，只不过是敲定正式录用条件而已。这时，公司负责人和蔼地问道：“你上次需要临场应变是什么时候？”这个问题让这位候选人措手不及，他愣了一下。“嗯，”他摸着下巴说，“让我想想。”

It was an awkward moment for everybody. Right now as you’re reading this book, the right answer may have come to you immediately: “Oh, about a half second ago.” It’s easy to be agile when nothing is on the line, of course. It’s a different matter for most people when the personal stakes are high.

对所有人来说，那都是个尴尬的时刻。此刻，当你读到这本书时，或许已经立刻想到了正确的答案：“哦，大概半秒钟前吧。” 当然，如果没什么事发生，灵活应变很容易。但对大多数人来说，一旦事关重大，情况就完全不同了。

Many managers I’ve surveyed fault themselves for not being more nimble negotiators, especially in coping with belligerent tactics. Many also remember getting stuck when they’ve had to choose between revealing key information or fudging the facts. “I tend to get rattled when I think I’ve made a mistake,” one person said. “I begin to doubt myself, which makes me second-guess my moves, which hinders my agility.”

我调查过的许多管理者都自责谈判技巧不够灵活，尤其是在应对咄咄逼人的策略时。许多人也记得，当他们必须在透露关键信息和捏造事实之间做出选择时，常常会陷入两难境地。“我一旦觉得自己犯了错，就会慌乱不已，”一位受访者说，“我会开始怀疑自己，反复斟酌自己的决定，从而影响我的反应能力。”

Such worries are understandable. You can’t preprogram yourself to always do and say the right thing. Even in seemingly simple negotiations, you can’t know exactly what to do at a particular point until you get there. Let’s say that you want to nail down a service contract with a new customer. What’s the first thing you should say after the prospect welcomes you to her office, let alone the second or the third? It all depends on how she begins the conversation. She might open in different ways:

这种担忧是可以理解的。你不可能预先设定好程序，总是能说出和做对的事情。即使是看似简单的谈判，在真正遇到某个特定时刻之前，你也无法确切地知道该怎么做。假设你想和一位新客户敲定一份服务合同。在客户热情地欢迎你来到她的办公室后，你应该说的第一句话是什么？更不用说第二句或第三句了。这一切都取决于她如何开启对话。她可能会以不同的方式开场：

Version 1. “Chris, we’re looking forward to partnering with you. Let’s figure out a deal that works well for both of us.”

版本一：“克里斯，我们期待与你合作。让我们一起商讨一个对双方都有利的方案。”

Version 2. “Good that you could come, Chris. My colleagues have put you on the short list of possible providers for this contract.”

版本 2：“克里斯，你能来真是太好了。我的同事们已经把你列入了这份合同的候选供应商名单。”

Version 3. “It’s time for you to fish or cut bait, Chris. We like your proposal, but you’ve got to come way down in price to beat your competition.”

版本 3：“克里斯，是时候做出选择了。我们喜欢你的方案，但你必须大幅降低价格才能击败竞争对手。”

Each statement would warrant a different response. Even if you knew in advance what your counterpart would say, you’d still want to hear her exact words and gauge her attitude. The demand that we drop the price might sound like an obvious bluff. Or the talk about “partnering” could seem insincere. And you won’t know how you’ll feel yourself—cautious or confident—until you’re really there. Only then can you sense if you’ll be content settling for half a loaf or pressing for more.

每句话都需要不同的回应。即使你事先知道对方会说什么，你仍然想听到她原话，并揣摩她的态度。要求我们降价听起来可能像个明显的虚张声势。或者，谈论“合作”可能显得不够真诚。而你只有真正身临其境，才能知道自己会作何感想——谨慎还是自信。也只有到了那时，你才能感受到自己是甘愿接受半块面包，还是会坚持争取更多。

Some negotiators seem to have a natural gift for improvising. The rest of us might wish that negotiation came with a pause button that would let us freeze the action, ponder what the other side meant, and weigh what to say next. Even better would be a replay function, so that we could backtrack and try another response if our initial approach fell flat. Sorry, but there are no such gizmos in the real world. And there aren’t do-overs, either. Instead, we have to extemporize.

有些谈判者似乎天生擅长即兴发挥。我们其他人或许会希望谈判有个暂停键，让我们能暂停谈判，仔细思考对方的意图，再斟酌下一步该说什么。如果能有回放功能就更好了，这样如果最初的应对策略失败，我们还可以回溯并尝试另一种回应。可惜，现实世界里没有这样的设备。也没有重来的机会。我们只能随机应变。

Standard negotiation books don’t offer answers, but you can stretch yourself by borrowing practices from other domains where improvisation is explicitly practiced and taught. Jazz is one such rich resource. You can draw valuable lessons also from theater, psychotherapy, and, as you’ll see in the next chapter, even warfare. Musicians, actors, therapists, and soldiers engage in very different enterprises. At the heart of it, though, their agility rests on similar principles.

标准的谈判书籍无法提供答案，但你可以借鉴其他领域中那些明确实践和教授即兴发挥的技巧，从而拓展自己的谈判视野。爵士乐就是这样一个丰富的资源。你还可以从戏剧、心理治疗，甚至（正如你将在下一章中看到的）战争中汲取宝贵的经验。音乐家、演员、治疗师和士兵从事着截然不同的工作。然而，从本质上讲，他们的敏捷性都建立在相似的原则之上。

Improvisation isn’t merely a technique. It requires a special mind-set: a blend of unflinching realism about the situation you’re in, coupled with a positive belief that you’ll muddle through nonetheless. Nor is improvisation simply making up things as you go along. If it were, anyone could sit down at a piano and conjure great jazz. It isn’t a blind process of trial and error, either. Improv comedy troupes would be booed off the stage if they randomly tossed out lines, hoping to stumble upon something funny. It certainly isn’t waiting passively for something to happen. Even taciturn psychotherapists know when it’s time to stop listening to a patient’s sorrows and interject a question that sparks insight. Instead, improvisers survive and even prosper because they do three things especially well:

即兴创作不仅仅是一种技巧，它需要一种特殊的心态：既要对自身所处情境保持毫不动摇的现实感，又要抱有积极乐观的信念，相信自己最终能够克服困难。即兴创作也并非随心所欲地编造。如果真是这样，任何人都可以坐在钢琴前即兴创作出伟大的爵士乐。它也不是盲目地试错。如果即兴喜剧团体随意抛出台词，指望碰巧找到笑点，他们早就被观众喝倒彩赶下台了。它当然也不是被动地等待事情发生。即使是沉默寡言的心理治疗师也知道何时应该停止倾听患者的悲伤，而是应该提出一个能够启发他们思考的问题。相反，即兴表演者之所以能够生存甚至取得成功，是因为他们尤其擅长以下三件事：

1. They Pay Close Heed.
1. 他们密切关注。

They have powers of attention that go well beyond active listening.

他们的注意力能力远远超出了积极倾听的范畴。

2. They Know When and How to Influence and Adapt to the People with Whom They Deal.
2. 他们知道何时以及如何影响和适应与他们打交道的人。

Jazz musicians call this soloing and comping.

爵士乐手们把这称为独奏和伴奏。

3. They Are Proactive; Even Provocative.
3. 他们积极主动，甚至具有挑衅性。

They take considered risks in order to drive the action forward.

他们会经过深思熟虑后承担风险，以推动行动向前发展。

PAYING HEED

重视

Improvising starts with paying heed; giving full attention to what others are expressing substantively and emotionally. That involves taking in not only the meaning of words but also tone of voice, facial expressions, and posture. It requires all your senses. Jazz great Herbie Hancock has described the process as being so intense that “sometimes I’m listening with my toes.”

即兴演奏始于专注聆听；全神贯注于他人表达的内容和情感。这不仅包括理解词义，还包括语气、面部表情和姿态。它需要调动你所有的感官。爵士乐大师赫比·汉考克曾形容这个过程如此投入，“有时我甚至要用脚趾去聆听”。

Distraction hampers understanding, just like static on the car radio. It’s often internal chatter that most interferes with real listening, even in everyday conversation. We’ve all had awkward moments at parties where our mind wanders instead of focusing on what someone else is saying. “I didn’t catch his name,” we might tell ourselves, as we tap our mental toes, just waiting for him to stop droning on so that we can tell our favorite anecdote. And most of us have been on the other side of such interactions, noting as we are talking how the listener’s eyes scan the room for someone more interesting.

分心就像汽车收音机里的杂音一样，会阻碍理解。即使在日常对话中，最容易干扰真正倾听的往往是内心的杂念。我们都曾在聚会上经历过尴尬的时刻：思绪飘忽不定，无法集中注意力听别人说话。“我没听清他的名字，”我们可能会这样对自己说，同时在心里默默地敲着脚趾，等着他终于讲完，好让我们有机会分享自己最喜欢的趣事。而且，我们大多数人都曾有过类似的经历，注意到在说话的时候，对方的目光总是在房间里四处游移，寻找更有趣的人。

Being out of sync is frustrating enough in social situations. In negotiation, it is crippling. Your counterpart may be only in midsentence, but you’re already scripting what to say when she’s done—if you let her get that far. While you’re busy stifling feelings, weighing options, or interpreting something said earlier, the interaction can run away from you.

在社交场合中，沟通不畅已经够令人沮丧了。在谈判中，这更是致命的。对方可能还在说话，但你已经在盘算着她讲完后该说什么——前提是你让她说完。当你忙于压抑情绪、权衡利弊或揣摩对方之前说过的话时，谈判的走向可能就会失控。

“Active listening” techniques taught in human relations seminars don’t solve the problem. Saying something such as “If I understand you correctly, your concern is . . .” is at best a gesture of acknowledgment, a technique for clarifying factual issues. At worst, it sounds formulaic and patronizing.

人际关系研讨会上教授的“积极倾听”技巧并不能解决问题。诸如“如果我理解正确的话，您的顾虑是……”之类的说法，充其量只是一种表示认可的姿态，一种澄清事实的技巧。而最糟糕的是，它听起来陈词滥调，居高临下。

Paying heed in negotiation involves turning off one’s inner dialogue and absorbing what is happening in the here and now. Doing so is both challenging and liberating. When the other party is putting forth a complex proposal, it’s easy to get stuck mentally on a particular point at the cost of missing everything else that follows. Instead, when you hear something troublesome, you should be listening more intently to pick up on other aspects of the offer that might ultimately form the basis of agreement.

谈判中的专注意味着要关闭内心的对话，全神贯注于当下发生的一切。这样做既具有挑战性，又令人受益匪浅。当对方提出复杂的方案时，我们很容易陷入对某个细节的纠缠，从而忽略了后续的所有信息。相反，当你听到一些棘手的问题时，你应该更加认真地倾听，以便捕捉到方案中其他可能最终构成协议基础的方面。

As Flow author Mihaly Csikszentmilhalyi notes, “It is difficult to notice the environment as long as the attention is mainly focused inward, as long as most of one’s psychic energy is absorbed by the concerns and desires of the ego. People who know how to transform stress into enjoyable experience spend very little time thinking about themselves.”

正如《心流》作者米哈里·契克森米哈赖所指出的那样，“只要注意力主要集中在内心，只要大部分精神能量都被自我的担忧和欲望所消耗，就很难注意到周围的环境。懂得将压力转化为愉悦体验的人，很少会花时间思考自己。”

Staying in the flow of conversation is easier said than done, though, especially when another person’s unexpected behavior upsets your plans. Thinking that you have to make the perfect response at exactly the right moment only makes matters worse. The stronger your need to perform flawlessly, the less you’re likely to deliver. Letting go of such impulses costs you nothing.

保持对话流畅说起来容易做起来难，尤其当对方出乎意料的行为打乱你的计划时。总想着在恰当的时机做出完美的回应，只会让情况变得更糟。你越是渴望表现得完美无瑕，就越容易事与愿违。放下这种冲动对你来说没有任何损失。

Great improvisers of all types succeed because they stay loose under pressure. That’s true for actors onstage, star athletes in clutch situations, and top negotiators, too. Just watch how relaxed the best improv comics are when another performer is holding forth. That other person may be spinning out a bizarre story about an accountant in the Wild West who’s lost his abacus, but you’ll see no strain or struggle on the listener’s face. She’s not worrying about when to chime in or what to say. Instead, you’ll see only her deep interest in hearing more. Whenever her time comes, she’ll have enough material on which to build. By contrast, thrust an amateur up on that same stage, and he’ll be bound up in a swirl of paralyzing thoughts: “What am I doing here?” “What would be funny?” “Why can’t I think of anything?”

各种类型的优秀即兴表演者之所以成功，是因为他们能在压力下保持放松。这不仅适用于舞台上的演员，也适用于关键时刻的明星运动员，以及顶尖的谈判专家。只需观察一下，当另一位表演者滔滔不绝地讲述时，最优秀的即兴喜剧演员是多么的放松自在。即使对方正在讲述一个关于西部荒野会计丢失算盘的离奇故事，你也不会在听众脸上看到任何紧张或挣扎。她不会担心何时插话或说什么。相反，你只会看到她对继续讲述充满浓厚的兴趣。一旦轮到她发言，她就会有足够的素材可以展开。相比之下，如果把一个业余人士放到同样的舞台上，他就会陷入各种令人窒息的思绪中：“我在这里干什么？”“什么会好笑？”“为什么我想不出任何笑点？”

It’s easy for negotiators to fall into the same kind of self-defeating behavior. The other party’s mouth may be moving, but you won’t hear the words if your own mental wheels are turning too fast. “Is this really their best offer?” you may be thinking. “What am I going to tell my boss?” “Should I come back strong or be more conciliatory?”

谈判者很容易陷入这种自我挫败的行为模式。对方可能在说话，但如果你自己的思绪飞快运转，你根本听不进去。“这真的是他们给出的最优报价吗？”你可能会想。“我该怎么跟老板说？”“我应该强硬回应，还是采取更温和的态度？”

Mental tension is debilitating twice over. It puts all your focus on the downside, highlighting everything that could go wrong. It also shifts attention away from the other players on the stage. They may be throwing out bits of useful material, but they fall on deaf ears. You must turn off that chatter to improvise successfully.

精神紧张会带来双重负面影响。它会让你把所有注意力都放在负面因素上，放大所有可能出错的地方。它还会让你忽略台上其他演员。他们或许会提供一些有用的信息，但你却充耳不闻。要想即兴发挥成功，你必须屏蔽掉这些杂音。

Sigmund Freud stressed the need for “even, hovering attention,” an attitude that takes in everything as it transpires without rushing to judgment. That doesn’t mean negotiators should mimic the stereotypical analyst who rarely breaks her silence (and then only to ask, “What makes you say that?”). But many negotiators could learn from therapists’ forbearance—their willingness to let certain comments pass while also sensing when the moment is right to offer support or pose a challenge.

西格蒙德·弗洛伊德强调需要“均匀、专注的注意力”，这种态度意味着要全然关注事态发展，而不急于下判断。这并不意味着谈判者应该效仿那种很少打破沉默（即使打破也只是问“你为什么这么说？”）的刻板分析师。但许多谈判者可以从治疗师的克制中学习——他们愿意对某些言论置之不理，同时也能敏锐地把握提供支持或提出挑战的时机。

Negotiators must be more proactive than therapists, of course, by floating proposals when it’s appropriate and drawing lines when necessary. But the timing has to be right for each. Trumpeter Miles Davis often said that the biggest challenge in jazz improvisation is maintaining the discipline “ not to play all the notes you could play, but to wait, hesitate, let the space become a part of the configuration.”

当然，谈判者必须比治疗师更积极主动，在适当的时候提出建议，在必要时划清界限。但时机对双方都至关重要。小号手迈尔斯·戴维斯常说，爵士即兴演奏最大的挑战在于保持一种自律：“不是把所有能弹的音符都弹出来，而是等待、犹豫，让留白成为整体结构的一部分。”

You don’t need a therapist’s or musician’s ear to pick up when a new and promising note is sounded in negotiation. George Shultz, in his memoir of his years as Secretary of State in the Ronald Reagan administration, recalls a seemingly small remark made by a Soviet diplomat at the 1986 arms reduction summit in Reykjavik, Iceland. It came in his first meeting with Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, who was deputy minister of defense (equivalent to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff in the United States). US experts on the Soviets had not expected Akhromeyev to be part of the delegation.

你不需要像心理治疗师或音乐家那样敏锐的耳朵，就能在谈判中捕捉到新的、充满希望的音符。乔治·舒尔茨在他回忆录中讲述了自己担任罗纳德·里根政府国务卿的岁月，其中提到了1986年在冰岛雷克雅未克举行的裁军峰会上，一位苏联外交官看似微不足道的一句话。那是在他与谢尔盖·阿赫罗梅耶夫元帅的首次会面中，阿赫罗梅耶夫当时是苏联国防部副部长（相当于美国的参谋长联席会议主席）。美国苏联问题专家此前并未预料到阿赫罗梅耶夫会出席此次峰会。

Shultz knew that his counterpart had a distinguished military record, but not much beyond that. He was intrigued, therefore, when Akhromeyev casually described himself as being “one of the last of the Mohicans.” Shultz asked what he meant by that. The official explained that he was one of the last of the World War II commanders still active in government.

舒尔茨知道他的对手有着辉煌的军旅生涯，但除此之外却知之甚少。因此，当阿赫罗梅耶夫漫不经心地自称是“最后的莫希干人之一”时，舒尔茨感到十分好奇。他询问这话是什么意思。这位官员解释说，他是二战时期最后一位仍在政府任职的指挥官。

Secretary Shultz, however, had heard something more in the remark, so he pressed further. “In boyhood,” Akhromeyev added, “I was raised on the adventure tales of James Fenimore Cooper.” Shultz recognized the comment as a positive sign. He took the former general “to be a man with a sense of history and an awareness of the American way” and found him to be “more at ease with himself, more open, more ready for real conversation, than had the professional negotiators of times past with whom we customarily dealt.” Akhromeyev ended up chairing the working group and doing most of the talking.

然而，舒尔茨国务卿却从这句话中听出了更深层的含义，于是他进一步追问。“我小时候，”阿赫罗梅耶夫补充道，“是读詹姆斯·费尼莫尔·库珀的冒险故事长大的。”舒尔茨认为这是一个积极的信号。他认为这位前将军“既有历史感，又了解美国文化”，而且“比我们以往接触的那些职业谈判者更自在、更坦诚、更乐于进行真正的对话”。最终，阿赫罗梅耶夫担任了工作组主席，并包揽了大部分发言工作。

Openness is key to creativity in negotiation. If the parties aren’t paying heed to what the other is truly saying, they might as well be mailing form letters back and forth. Breaking an impasse requires a new understanding of the problem and perhaps of the parties’ relationship, as was the case with Shultz and Akhromeyev. But that can happen only if at least one of them is paying heed.

开放的态度是谈判中发挥创造力的关键。如果双方不认真倾听对方的真实想法，那还不如互寄格式化的信函。打破僵局需要对问题以及双方关系有新的理解，舒尔茨和阿赫罗梅耶夫的案例就是如此。但这只有在至少一方愿意倾听的情况下才有可能发生。

LEARNING TO COMP

学习计算

Strong negotiators aren’t shy about taking the lead. They also know when to relinquish it, at least for a while. In jazz, the best solos are exhilarating, but effective comping (accompanying or complementing what the other players are doing) is an essential part of the art as well. It is a group activity, after all, a process of continual give-and-take. Performers who hog the spotlight and don’t support the other players aren’t invited back for the next gig.

优秀的谈判者从不羞于占据主导地位。他们也懂得何时应该放手，至少暂时如此。在爵士乐中，最精彩的独奏固然令人振奋，但有效的伴奏（为其他乐手的演奏伴奏或补充）也是这门艺术不可或缺的一部分。毕竟，爵士乐是一种集体活动，一个持续互动、互惠互利的过程。那些独占风头、不配合其他乐手的演奏者，不会被邀请参加下一场演出。

“It is not enough to be an individual virtuoso,” says Frank Barrett, author of Yes to the Mess: Surprising Leadership Lessons from Jazz. Even as one musician takes the lead, the rest of the players must listen deeply. “They need to interpret others’ playing, make instantaneous decisions in regard to harmonic and rhythmic progressions.” Barrett speaks with authority as both a professor of organizational behavior at the Naval Postgraduate School and a former member of the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra. “None of this responsiveness can happen unless players are receptive and taking in one another’s gestures,” he says.

“仅仅成为个人演奏大师是不够的，”《拥抱混乱：爵士乐中令人惊讶的领导力启示》一书的作者弗兰克·巴雷特说道。即使一位乐手担任主导，其他乐手也必须认真聆听。“他们需要理解他人的演奏，并就和声和节奏的进行做出即时判断。”巴雷特作为海军研究生院组织行为学教授和汤米·多尔西乐团的前成员，对此深有体会。“如果乐手们不能虚心接受并理解彼此的演奏，所有这些互动都无从谈起，”他说道。

Comping effectively is just as important in negotiation. In the course of the dialogue, each side expects a chance to convince the other of the merits of its position. Usually the parties insist upon it. Letting each other talk is only the first step. If nobody is listening, the conversation goes nowhere.

有效沟通在谈判中至关重要。在对话过程中，双方都希望有机会说服对方接受自己立场的优点。通常情况下，双方都会坚持这一点。让彼此发言仅仅是第一步。如果没人倾听，对话就毫无进展。

Even while your counterpart is speaking, you should lean into the conversation and shape his or her behavior. The questions that you pose or even a nod of your head can encourage constructive statements and keep the other party from painting himself into a corner. “Tell me more about that,” you might interject if things are going well. Or if you need to get someone back on track, ask, “What could we learn from how other people have solved this problem?”

即使对方正在发言，你也应该积极参与对话，引导对方的行为。你提出的问题，甚至只是点头示意，都能鼓励对方发表建设性的言论，避免陷入僵局。如果讨论进展顺利，你可以插话道：“请详细说说这个。” 如果你需要引导对方回到正轨，可以问：“我们可以从其他人解决这个问题的方式中学到什么？”

Once again this goes way beyond so-called active listening. It’s not just acknowledging what others have stated but also influencing what they are saying and how they are saying it. Striking the right balance between soloing and comping thus requires awareness of when to step back and when to step in. Annotating each and every thing that someone else says will eventually drive even the most patient person nuts. Letting some things pass, at least for the moment, intensifies the impact of what you say when you do jump in.

这远不止是所谓的积极倾听。它不仅仅是认可他人所说的话，更在于影响他们所说的话以及他们表达的方式。因此，在独白和配合之间找到合适的平衡点，需要意识到何时该退后一步，何时该介入。对别人说的每一句话都进行注释，最终会让最有耐心的人也抓狂。至少暂时忽略一些事情，会让你在介入时更有影响力。

According to Barrett, when jazz musicians comp, they agree “to suspend judgment, to trust that whatever the soloist is doing right now will lead to something, to blend into the flow and direction of the idea rather than to break off in an independent direction.” For musicians, this means abandoning the illusion of full control over whatever happens next.

巴雷特认为，爵士乐手在伴奏时，会达成共识：“放下评判，相信独奏者当下的演奏最终会引出新的内容，融入整体的思路和方向，而不是另辟蹊径。” 对乐手而言，这意味着放弃对接下来一切的完全掌控。

Abandoning control and supporting other parties may be a hard pill for type-A negotiators to swallow, but it doesn’t require compromising your ultimate objectives. And it has nothing to do with being submissive. Rather, it simply involves dialing back on the urge to dominate each moment of the transaction. (Paradoxically, that kind of microcontrol actually lessens your power to get where you want to go.) You may exert more influence by following the example of the drummers and bass players, who aren’t front and center but who drive the rhythm and tempo of the whole performance.

放弃控制权、支持其他方，对A型性格的谈判者来说或许难以接受，但这并不意味着要牺牲你的最终目标。这与唯唯诺诺也毫无关系。这仅仅意味着要克制住掌控谈判每一个环节的冲动。（矛盾的是，这种事无巨细的控制实际上会削弱你达成目标的能力。）你可以效仿鼓手和贝斯手的做法，他们虽然不在台前，却掌控着整场演出的节奏和韵律，从而发挥更大的影响力。

To understand effective comping, you only have to recall instances of it being done poorly. We’ve all seen well-intended teammates bump into each other while making a proposal or a sales pitch. Each may interrupt the other to underscore a point or add technical details. Those particular comments may be relevant, but if there’s constant butting in, any benefit of having more information is quickly outweighed by the loss of flow and coherence.

要理解有效的沟通技巧，只需回想一下沟通技巧运用不当的例子即可。我们都见过这样的场景：好心的团队成员在做提案或销售演示时互相插话。每个人都可能打断对方，强调某个观点或补充一些技术细节。这些评论或许有一定道理，但如果不断有人插话，那么获得更多信息带来的好处很快就会被沟通的不流畅和缺乏连贯性所抵消。

Comping isn’t politely taking turns, either. Instead, it’s finding ways while you’re listening to bring out the best in your counterparts, be they allies or antagonists. It’s in your interest to coax them to disclose their true priorities instead of concealing them. You’re better off as well if you can encourage and augment their tentative attempts at problem solving rather than provoke haggling by contesting their every assertion.

合作并非只是礼貌地轮流发言。相反，它指的是在倾听的同时，想方设法激发对方（无论盟友还是对手）的最佳潜能。引导他们坦诚地表达自己的真正诉求，而不是试图掩盖，对你更有利。与其反驳他们的每一个主张，引发讨价还价，不如鼓励并支持他们尝试解决问题的努力，这样对你更有利。

When you’re matched with the right people, skillful comping can be transformational. Even if they talk far more than you do, you may guide the conversation by supporting their best ideas and reshaping other ones. In the end, they may feel that you accepted their proposal, when you deftly got them to voice much of what you wanted.

当你遇到合适的人时，巧妙的互补技巧可以带来变革性的影响。即使他们比你滔滔不绝，你也可以通过支持他们最好的想法并重新构思其他想法来引导对话。最终，当你巧妙地引导他们表达出你大部分的想法时，他们可能会觉得你接受了他们的提议。

Let’s say that the other side tosses out three demands, two of which are out of the question. Your natural reaction may be to focus on what’s not workable and why. The other party may then respond in the same spirit and tear apart your arguments. This mode of discourse can deteriorate into a negative exchange where one side brings buckets of paint, the other supplies the brushes, and both end up stuck in opposite corners.

假设对方提出了三项要求，其中两项根本行不通。你自然而然的反应可能是关注哪些要求行不通以及原因。对方也可能以同样的态度回应，驳斥你的论点。这种争论模式很容易演变成一场负面交锋，一方拿着油漆桶，另一方拿着刷子，最终双方都陷入了僵局。

Comping, by contrast, involves picking up a seed of an idea that you can then nourish. A jazz musician doesn’t echo what the soloist is doing; rather, he or she selects some piece of it to underscore and develop. In our hypothetical negotiation, that could mean focusing on the one promising theme that the other party put on the table and using that as a scaffold for building more general agreement. That makes much more sense than hammering on all the things that won’t work.

相比之下，伴奏则是指捕捉一个想法的种子，然后加以培育。爵士乐手并非简单地重复独奏者的演奏，而是从中选取一些片段进行强调和发展。在我们假设的谈判中，这意味着要专注于对方提出的那个有希望的主题，并以此为基础构建更广泛的共识。这比纠缠于所有行不通的事情要明智得多。

A little verbal highlighting may be all that’s needed. “Let’s focus on that idea for a minute,” you might say, or “Maybe we could fold that into what we were talking about earlier.” If you’re dealing with someone who knows you well, a raised eyebrow might signal “Don’t go there,” while a tilt of your head could send the message “Maybe now we’re getting someplace.”

或许只需要一些口头强调。“我们先来仔细想想这个想法，”你可以说，或者“也许我们可以把它融入到我们之前讨论的内容里。”如果你面对的是一个很了解你的人，扬起眉毛可能意味着“别往那方面想”，而歪着头则可能传达出“也许我们现在找到方向了”的信息。

Some negotiators are naturals at letting other parties hold the floor while nevertheless steering the conversation. It’s partly listening for glimmers of substantive information from which an agreement can be forged. It’s also picking up on people’s feelings and comping emotionally—with a shared laugh or a sigh—anything that boosts the positive and disrupts the negative flow.

有些谈判者天生擅长让对方畅所欲言，同时又能巧妙地引导对话。这部分在于倾听对方话语中可能透露出的实质性信息，从而促成协议的达成。此外，他们还能敏锐地察觉对方的情绪，并给予情感上的回应——比如一起发笑或叹息——任何能够增强积极氛围、打破消极情绪的举动都会被他们利用。

Comping skills are put to the test when you have to deal with people whose styles and assumptions conflict with your own. Here your ability to bring out the best in others is most important, whether their behavioral bandwidth is large or small. Tough characters who have little flexibility and less smarts may miss or ignore most of your cues. Even so, exerting some small measure of influence is better than beating your head (or theirs) against the wall.

当你不得不与那些风格和假设与你相悖的人打交道时，你的沟通技巧就会受到考验。此时，无论对方的行为包容度如何，你激发他人潜能的能力都至关重要。性格强硬、缺乏灵活性且智力欠佳的人可能会忽略或忽视你的大部分暗示。即便如此，施加一些影响也比徒劳无功要好得多。

In the end, you have to comp regardless of whether your counterparts are sweethearts or thugs. Even in one-shot, arm’s-length deals, rewarding whatever positive things that others express—instead of amplifying the negative—is a pragmatic way to get things done.

最终，无论对方是友善的还是恶劣的，你都必须给予补偿。即使是一次性的、非公开的交易，奖励他人表达的积极行为——而不是放大消极行为——也是一种务实的达成协议的方式。

BEING PROVOCATIVE

挑衅

Paying heed is one aspect of improvising. Comping is another. Being provocative is a third. When Ambassador Holbrooke negotiated, he sometimes seemed more like Muhammad Ali than a typical diplomat. “He’s yakking and talking. He’s jiving,” marveled a colleague. Though he added: “The first time you see it, you think it’s just bull.” In fact, it was Holbrooke’s way of pumping himself up and energizing the negotiation process.

认真倾听是即兴发挥的一个方面，即兴发挥是另一个方面，挑衅则是第三个方面。霍尔布鲁克大使谈判时，有时看起来更像拳击手穆罕默德·阿里，而不是典型的外交官。“他滔滔不绝，妙语连珠，”一位同事惊叹道。不过，这位同事又补充说：“你第一次看到他这样，会觉得他纯粹是在胡说八道。” 事实上，这是霍尔布鲁克给自己打气、激发谈判活力的方式。

Great jazz musicians stir up things as well. Familiar routines and old assumptions have to be disrupted, even though doing so entails risk. Otherwise nothing new can be created. Frank Barrett calls this trait “provocative competence.” It tops his list of key principles in improvisation.

伟大的爵士音乐家也喜欢打破常规。熟悉的惯例和旧有的观念必须被打破，即使这样做意味着风险。否则，就无法创造出新的东西。弗兰克·巴雷特称这种特质为“挑衅能力”，并将其列为即兴演奏的关键原则之首。

Frank uses the word provocative in the positive sense of a willingness to abandon the status quo and venture into the unknown, at least partway. For a negotiator, that could be voicing a novel idea or being more (or less) confrontational than usual. Beyond experimenting, it is a way of taking the initiative. Saxophonist John Coltrane said that he deliberately played songs in difficult and unfamiliar keys because it “made me think” instead of just having his fingers play the notes automatically.

弗兰克使用“挑衅性”一词，赋予其积极的意义，即愿意放弃现状，至少部分地冒险进入未知领域。对于谈判者而言，这可能意味着提出新颖的想法，或者比平时更具（或更不具）对抗性。除了尝试之外，这也是一种主动出击的方式。萨克斯管演奏家约翰·科尔特兰曾说过，他故意用复杂且不熟悉的调演奏乐曲，因为这“让我思考”，而不是让手指机械地弹奏音符。

Provocation can be aimed at others as well. Clarinetist Benny Goodman’s famed Carnegie Hall concert in 1938 began with a dull rendition of “Don’t Be That Way.” His band was uptight playing in that historic venue before a society audience dressed in tuxedos and evening gowns. Goodman himself was unable to get his musicians to swing, but drummer Gene Krupa galvanized them with a drum solo so wild that jazz critic Phil Schaap calls it “nearly cacophonous.” Krupa hit every part of his kit as hard and as fast as he could, “not trying to wake up the crowd,” says Schaap, but “trying to wake up the band. He’s trying to relax them or scare them beyond their fear.”

挑衅也可以针对他人。单簧管演奏家本尼·古德曼 (Benny Goodman) 1938 年在卡内基音乐厅举行的著名音乐会以一首沉闷的《别那样》(Don't Be That Way) 开场。他的乐队在这座历史悠久的场馆里，面对着身着燕尾服和晚礼服的上流社会观众，显得有些拘谨。古德曼本人也无法让他的乐手们进入状态，但鼓手吉恩·克鲁帕 (Gene Krupa) 用一段狂野的鼓独奏点燃了全场，以至于爵士乐评论家菲尔·沙普 (Phil Schaap) 称之为“近乎刺耳”。克鲁帕用尽全力、以最快的速度敲击着鼓组的每一个部件，“他不是想唤醒观众，”沙普说，“而是想唤醒乐队。他试图让他们放松下来，或者让他们感到前所未有的恐惧。”

Fear of mistakes is a great inhibitor in negotiation. It freezes us and makes us brittle. If we fixate on all that could go wrong, it’s hard to imagine how things could go right. Stephen Nachmanovitch, author of Free Play: Improvisation in Life and Art , connects reluctance to experiment to “fear of being thought a fool (loss of reputation) and fear of actually being a fool (fear of unusual state of mind).”

害怕犯错是谈判中的一大阻碍。它会让我们僵住不动，变得脆弱不堪。如果我们总是盯着所有可能出错的地方，就很难想象事情会如何顺利进行。斯蒂芬·纳赫马诺维奇（Stephen Nachmanovitch）在其著作《自由游戏：生活与艺术中的即兴创作》（Free Play: Improvisation in Life and Art）中，将人们不愿尝试的原因归结为“害怕被认为是傻瓜（名誉受损）和害怕自己真的成了傻瓜（害怕处于不寻常的精神状态）”。

Fear throws us off balance, not just emotionally but physically. Our muscles tighten and our vision narrows. As Nachmanovitch observes, this literally cramps our style. “If I ‘try’ to play, I fail; if I force the play, I crush it; if I race, I trip. Anytime I stiffen or brace myself against some error or problem, the very act of bracing would cause the problem to occur.”

恐惧会让我们失去平衡，不仅是情绪上的，也是生理上的。我们的肌肉会紧绷，视野会变得狭窄。正如纳赫马诺维奇所观察到的，这会切实地束缚我们的发挥。“如果我‘尝试’打球，我会失败；如果我强行打球，我会搞砸；如果我急于求成，我会绊倒。任何时候，当我僵硬地或试图避免犯错或解决问题时，这种抗拒本身反而会导致问题的发生。”

The answer in both jazz and negotiation is venturing out into unfamiliar waters far enough to be energized and creative, but not so far that you are in over your head. Ed Sarath, former head of the jazz department at the University of Michigan, says that the trick for musicians is to be 80 percent in their comfort zone, 20 percent outside of it. A player who is completely comfortable just recycles past performances.

无论是爵士乐还是谈判，答案都在于要勇于涉足陌生的领域，既要保持足够的活力和创造力，又不能超出自身能力范围。密歇根大学爵士乐系前系主任埃德·萨拉斯认为，音乐家的诀窍在于80%的时间待在舒适区，20%的时间走出舒适区。完全安于现状的乐手只会重复过去的表演。

“I don’t like a comfortable person,” Miles Davis once said. “I can’t be around them if they’re just . . . you know. Nothing bounces off them. You get nothing.” Davis himself was notorious for making his fellow players un comfortable. He actually barred his muscians from practicing together, to keep the group vibrant when it finally got together. The signature cut “So What” from his classic 1959 album Kind of Blue was created on the spot and is played in the D-Dorian mode, something the group had never heard of until Davis explained it moments before the recording tape started to roll. Working in that strange mode was scary, but it forced everyone to abandon old conventions and in their place jointly create the bestselling jazz album of all time.

“我不喜欢安于现状的人，”迈尔斯·戴维斯曾说过，“如果他们只是……你知道的，我就没法和他们待在一起。什么都无法触动他们，你什么也得不到。”戴维斯本人就以让其他乐手感到不自在而闻名。他甚至禁止乐手们一起练习，以确保乐队最终聚在一起时充满活力。他1959年的经典专辑《Kind of Blue》中的代表作《So What》就是即兴创作的，并以D-Dorian调式演奏。在录音开始前，戴维斯解释了这种调式，乐队成员此前从未听说过。在这种陌生的调式下演奏令人胆战心惊，但也迫使所有人抛弃旧有的惯例，共同创作出了有史以来最畅销的爵士专辑。

Sarath’s 80–20 rule is a good standard for negotiators too. You need the 80 percent so that you can move forward and dampen fears about making irreversible mistakes. But the 20 percent discomfort is just as important. It inoculates you against complacence and heightens your senses so that you’re alert for both danger and opportunities.

萨拉特的80/20法则对谈判者来说也是一个很好的标准。你需要80%的积极性，这样才能推进谈判进程，并减轻对犯下不可挽回的错误的恐惧。但剩下的20%的不安感同样重要。它能让你避免自满，并提高你的感知能力，使你对危险和机遇都保持警惕。

There are lots of ways to get up to the 80 percent comfort level. The preparation tools covered in part 1 of this book can give you confidence that you’re headed in the right direction. The presence of mind techniques described in the prior chapter will help you recognize how far you’ve gotten.

有很多方法可以让你达到八成的舒适度。本书第一部分介绍的准备工具可以让你确信自己正朝着正确的方向前进。前一章描述的临场应变技巧将帮助你认识到自己已经取得了多大的进步。

You will get stuck sometimes. You may lose your train of thought or not have the perfect answer to a tough question. That’s bound to happen when you operate on the edge. Trumpeter Tommy Turrentine said that when you’re doing a solo and you lose focus, “You better have something to play when you can’t think of nothing new, or you’ll feel funny laying out all the time.” Jazz musicians stockpile familar licks they can fall back on until inspiration kicks back in.

你有时会遇到瓶颈。你可能会思路中断，或者无法完美回答棘手的问题。当你处于极限状态时，这种情况在所难免。小号手汤米·图伦廷曾说过，当你独奏时如果走神，“你最好事先准备好一些可以演奏的乐句，以防万一想不出新的东西，否则你会一直尴尬地躺着。”爵士乐手会储备一些熟悉的乐句，以便在灵感再次涌现时可以随时使用。

Likewise, as a negotiator, you can minimize the impact of freezing up by having a few stock moves on hand that will buy you time to regain your footing. Shift the conversation to process and treat whatever just occurred as a mutual problem. “Maybe it’s just me,” you might say, “but it feels as if we’re getting lost in the weeds. Let’s recap what we’ve agreed upon so we can put this particular issue in context.”

同样，作为谈判者，你可以事先准备一些应对策略，以尽量减少因紧张而导致的局面僵住的影响，从而争取时间重新站稳脚跟。将谈话的重点转移到后续步骤上，并将刚才发生的事情视为双方共同面临的问题。“也许只是我的感觉，”你可以说，“但我觉得我们好像陷入了细节的泥沼。让我们回顾一下我们之前达成的共识，以便更好地理解这个问题。”

You can also build your confidence by seeking out ideas and techniques beyond your usual experience. If you run a supply chain, for example, read the sports pages to see how pro teams try to balance their payrolls as they negotiate with superstars and journeymen. Or if you’re in sports, pay attention to the foreign news and watch how diplomats forge alliances.

你还可以通过探索自身经验之外的理念和技巧来增强自信。例如，如果你负责供应链，可以阅读体育版面，了解职业球队如何在与明星球员和普通球员谈判时努力平衡薪资支出。或者，如果你从事体育行业，可以关注国际新闻，观察外交官如何缔结联盟。

Look especially for examples of other people using provocative competence to stir things up. You seldom want to be provocative in the inflammatory sense, but sometimes you have to shock other parties to get their attention. Donald Dell tells about how in the 1970s he tried to dissuade high school basketball star Moses Malone from signing a multimillion-dollar contract to play in the American Basketball Association. At that point, the teenager was the shyest person Dell had ever met. “Almost seven feet tall and all kneecaps and elbows, he couldn’t bring himself to look at me.”

尤其要留意其他人运用挑衅性能力来搅动风云的例子。你很少会想用煽动性的方式来挑衅，但有时你必须让对方感到震惊才能引起他们的注意。唐纳德·戴尔讲述了他在20世纪70年代如何试图劝阻高中篮球明星摩西·马龙不要签下一份价值数百万美元的合同去美国篮球协会打球。当时，这个少年是戴尔见过的最害羞的人。“他身高将近七英尺，膝盖和手肘都很粗壮，根本不敢看我。”

Dell was getting nowhere trying to explain the unfairness of the contract clause that gave the pro team a perpetual option to extend the deal. Malone was so nervous that he wasn’t hearing a word. Dell realized that he had to say something else. “I stopped midsentence, paused for a moment, and then said, ‘Moses, have you ever heard of slavery?’ His head shot up immediately, and he stared at me intently. ‘Because,’ I said, ‘if you sign this contract, that’s like virtual slavery. It could be for the next sixteen years of your life, and I’ve never seen a contract like this one.’ ”

戴尔试图解释合同条款的不公平之处，该条款赋予职业球队永久续约的选择权，但马龙却听不进去。戴尔意识到自己必须换个说法。“我话说到一半停了下来，沉默片刻后说道：‘摩西，你听说过奴隶制吗？’他立刻抬起头，目不转睛地盯着我。‘因为，’我说，‘如果你签了这份合同，那就等于实际上的奴隶制。这可能意味着你未来十六年的人生都将如此，而且我从未见过这样的合同。’”

It was a risky move, but Malone got the point and was saved from signing a deal that would have cost him tens of millions of dollars over his career.

这是一个冒险的举动，但马龙明白了其中的道理，避免了签署一份会让他职业生涯损失数千万美元的合同。

BENDING THE RULES OF IMPROV

打破即兴表演的规则

Improv comics bring a jazz mind-set to their work. They speak of the “beats” that set the pace and mark transitions in their performance. Like musicians, they solo and comp. Everything they say adds information that propels the story forward. A comic wouldn’t start a skit by merely saying, “Hi,” and leaving it at that. Instead, she might open by saying “Brad! I never expected to see you here at the South Pole.”

即兴喜剧演员将爵士乐的思维方式融入到他们的表演中。他们会谈到那些决定节奏、标记表演转折的“节拍”。就像音乐家一样，他们既会独奏也会伴奏。他们说的每一句话都为故事增添了信息，推动剧情发展。一个喜剧演员不会仅仅以一句“嗨”开始一个小品，然后就此结束。相反，她可能会这样开场：“布拉德！我真没想到会在南极见到你。”

Performers call such an opening an “offer.” It gives the other players material to work with. When they build on someone else’s offer, comics call that “agreement.” Thus, a performer who hears the South Pole line might respond, “Yeah, when my company said it was giving me the southern territory, I was thinking Florida, maybe.” With that simple call-and-response, the two are off and running. Their agreement is open ended. It doesn’t seal a specific deal. But it serves as a platform on which they can construct their relationship and develop whatever they imagine they’re doing on the frozen continent.

表演者把这种开场白称为“提议”。它为其他演员提供了创作素材。当他们在此基础上进行发挥时，喜剧演员称之为“协议”。因此，听到“南极”这个梗的演员可能会回应说：“是啊，我们公司说要给我南方的地盘时，我想的是佛罗里达，或许吧。” 就这样，两人开始了对话。他们的协议是开放式的，并没有达成具体的交易。但它提供了一个平台，让他们可以在此基础上构建彼此的关系，并发展他们想象中在冰封大陆上的一切。

You have the same opportunity when you set the stage for negotiation. Your offers, in the broad sense, don’t have to be about dollars and cents. They can be suggestions about how to proceed or even more subtle gestures that set the tone for the process. How you comport yourself may send a richer message than the words you use. If you’re tight lipped or inscrutable, you’re leaving it up to your counterpart to define the interaction. Instead, it’s usually in your best interest to provide something for them to respond to.

在谈判筹备阶段，你也拥有同样的机会。从广义上讲，你的提议不必局限于金钱。它们可以是关于如何推进谈判的建议，甚至是更为微妙的姿态，这些都能为整个过程定下基调。你的言行举止可能比你使用的语言更能传递丰富的信息。如果你沉默不语或难以捉摸，就等于把决定权交给了对方。相反，通常情况下，你最好是提供一些信息，让对方可以做出回应。

Some rules of improv comedy don’t apply to negotiation literally, yet they still provide useful lessons. One of the precepts, for instance, is “always agree—never negate.” In our South Pole example, it would be a cardinal sin to reply, “Antarctica? My name is Angela, and we’re in the middle of the Sahara.”

即兴喜剧的一些规则并不完全适用于谈判，但它们仍然能提供一些有用的经验。例如，其中一条准则是“永远同意，永远不要否定”。在我们之前提到的南极点例子中，如果有人回答说：“南极洲？我叫安吉拉，我们现在在撒哈拉沙漠的中心地带。”那简直是不可饶恕的罪过。

A blunt contradiction stops the action onstage. If the players can’t agree on who they are and where they’re situated, they certainly can’t figure out where to go next. No matter how preposterous one person’s statement is, the other must accept it and move forward. This ethic gives the skit a loose sense of direction and continuity. Early commitments to role, relationship, and context allow all the players to focus on what’s unfolding and put aside the countless options that might have been available at the beginning.

直白的矛盾会让舞台上的表演戛然而止。如果演员们无法就自己的身份和处境达成一致，他们当然也无法确定下一步该怎么走。无论一个人的说法多么荒谬，另一个人都必须接受并继续前进。这种原则赋予了小品一种松散的方向感和连贯性。早期对角色、关系和背景的明确设定，让所有演员都能专注于正在发生的事情，而将一开始可能存在的无数种选择搁置一边。

Long before Dick Costolo became CEO of Twitter, he was an improv comic. He still usually answers other people’s assertions with “Yes, and . . .” rather than opposing them with the word but . Sometimes in negotiation, however, you have to say no loudly. When the other party is demanding the moon, the sun, and the stars, you’ve got to bring him back to earth. You may also have to draw a clear line in regard to acceptable behavior, whether the transgression is an insult, evasion, or a broken promise. Nevertheless, negotiators have to be smart about when and how to disagree. The word no is a verbal stop sign. If someone is being unreasonable, you need to flag her down. But you also have to pave the way to where you want her to go next.

在迪克·科斯托洛成为推特CEO之前，他曾是一名即兴喜剧演员。他至今仍然习惯用“是的，而且……”来回应别人的观点，而不是用“但是”来反驳。然而，在谈判中，有时你必须大声说“不”。当对方提出过分的要求时，你必须让他认清现实。你可能还需要明确划定可接受行为的界限，无论这种过错是侮辱、回避还是违背承诺。尽管如此，谈判者必须懂得何时以及如何表达不同意见。“不”就像一个口头上的停止信号。如果有人不讲道理，你需要提醒她。但你也必须为她接下来的行动铺平道路。

Bill Ury’s 2007 book The Power of a Positive No: Save the Deal, Save the Relationship—And Still Say No suggests ways of saying no that protect your core interests while still offering counterparts a graceful way to move in a more constructive direction. In some cases, you can make a no sound like a yes. For example, you might say, “Your idea might work provided we could also . . .” Even when you must disagree, it’s in your interest to shift the perspective rather than force a counterpart to defend his position. “Look, the reality is that we’re not going to see eye to eye on all the details,” you might assert, “so instead of rehashing the past, let’s find some practical way of moving forward.”

比尔·尤里 (Bill Ury) 2007 年出版的《积极拒绝的力量：挽救交易，挽救关系——即使拒绝也要说不》一书，提出了一些拒绝的方法，既能保护你的核心利益，又能为对方提供一个优雅的过渡方式，引导他们朝着更具建设性的方向发展。在某些情况下，你可以让“不”听起来像“是”。例如，你可以说：“你的想法或许可行，前提是我们也能……” 即使你必须表示反对，你也应该转换视角，而不是强迫对方捍卫自己的立场。你可以这样说：“你看，现实是我们不可能在所有细节上都达成一致，所以与其重提旧事，不如我们来寻找一些切实可行的前进方向。”

Another rule in improv is “Never ask questions.” They are a no-no in skits because they make the other person do all the work. If a comic opens a scene by demanding, “What are you doing here?” other players have nothing to build on. They bear all the responsibility for establishing the parties’ identities, relationship, and situation. It’s as if the conversation hasn’t begun at all.

即兴表演的另一条规则是“永远不要提问”。在小品中提问是绝对禁止的，因为这会让对方承担所有工作。如果一个喜剧演员以“你在这儿干什么？”这样的问题开场，其他演员就无从下手。他们必须独自承担所有建立人物身份、关系和情境的责任。就好像对话根本没有开始一样。

By contrast, questions are essential in negotiation. It’s a process of inquiry and exploration, after all. Reaching a durable, value-creating agreement depends on discovering how the parties’ true interests can best be dovetailed. But they have to be the right kind of questions. Rhetorical challenges such as “What in the world makes you think your property is worth so much?” make others more entrenched. Asking instead “How can we figure out a reasonable value for the property?” raises the same issue but shifts the focus from a specific number to a mutual search for relevant principles and standards.

相比之下，提问在谈判中至关重要。毕竟，谈判本身就是一个探究和探索的过程。达成持久且能创造价值的协议，取决于如何才能最好地契合各方的真正利益。但问题必须切中要害。诸如“你凭什么认为你的房产值这么多钱？”之类的质问只会让对方更加固执己见。而换个问法，“我们如何才能确定房产的合理价值？”虽然提出了同样的问题，但却将重点从具体的数字转移到了共同寻求相关的原则和标准上。

Questions aren’t the only way to glean information. Often in negotiation, they’re not even the best method. Say that a salesperson quotes you a marginally acceptable price. You’d love to know if she’s willing to go lower, but asking that question directly would be a mistake, as she wouldn’t have any reason to say yes. To learn if there’s room to bargain, you might do better by counteroffering or saying something ambiguous like “Ouch. That may be too rich for my blood.”

提问并非获取信息的唯一途径。在谈判中，提问往往并非最佳方法。假设销售人员报出的价格勉强可以接受。你很想知道她是否愿意降价，但直接问这个问题是错误的，因为她没有任何理由答应。为了了解是否有讨价还价的空间，你或许可以尝试提出还价，或者说一些模棱两可的话，比如“哎呀，这个价格可能太高了。”

Honoring another rule of improv comedy, “Maintain eye contact,” is possible only in face-to-face negotiation, though it’s instructive across the board. Steady gaze enables stage performers to pick up cues from their fellow artists—not only their words but also their expressions, gestures, and posture. If each individual is in the same here and now, then the whole troupe is in sync. (Just think how averting your own eyes from someone else who’s talking feels like you’re stepping back, even if you haven’t moved an inch.) Whenever you get lost in your private thoughts and disconnect with others, you squander power to influence them.

即兴喜剧的另一条规则是“保持眼神交流”，这条规则虽然在各种场合都适用，但只有在面对面的交流中才能做到。稳定的眼神能让舞台表演者捕捉到其他演员的细微动作——不仅是他们的言语，还有他们的表情、手势和姿态。如果每个人都专注于当下，那么整个团队就能步调一致。（想想看，即使你一动不动，当你移开视线，不去看正在说话的人时，也会感觉像是在后退。）每当你沉浸在自己的思绪中，与他人失去联系时，你就是在浪费影响他人的力量。

Eye contact is a physical form of comping. It’s how you tell a counterpart “I’m right here, working with you.” In negotiation, it establishes your presence and compels others to take you into account. A slight nod of the head can signal that they’re headed in a fruitful direction. A quizzical look may say that you’re skeptical or don’t understand.

眼神交流是一种肢体语言。它向对方传达“我就在这里，与你并肩作战”的信息。在谈判中，眼神交流能够确立你的存在感，并促使对方重视你的观点。轻微的点头可能暗示着谈判正朝着有利的方向发展。而疑惑的眼神则可能表明你心存疑虑或尚未理解。

Nonverbal behavior is rich in emotional content. You lose a lot of bandwidth when you have to negotiate long distance by email or phone. As a consequence, those mediums demand special effort to ensure that you are understood correctly. In turn, you need to be careful interpreting other people’s written language. You don’t want to construe a message as a veiled threat when the words might have been composed hastily. Likewise, when you’re on the phone, you don’t want to make others feel as if they are talking into the void. Interjections such as “Okay,” “How come,” and “Let’s hold that issue for later” give the conversation color and texture, and also keep you focused and engaged.

非语言行为蕴含着丰富的情感信息。当你需要通过电子邮件或电话进行远程沟通时，你的注意力会受到很大限制。因此，使用这些沟通方式需要格外注意，以确保对方能够正确理解你的意思。反过来，你也需要谨慎解读他人的书面语言。你不希望将匆忙写下的信息解读为隐晦的威胁。同样，在电话沟通中，你也不希望让对方感觉像是在对着空气说话。诸如“好的”、“为什么”、“我们把这个问题留到以后再说”之类的感叹词，能够为对话增添色彩和层次感，也能让你保持专注和投入。

You must be emotionally secure and upbeat to make the most of these techniques. I remember conducting an improv exercise in my MBA class almost ten years ago. It was called “instant expert.” I would pick out students to perform, and then the rest of the class came up with topics that they’d probably know nothing about.

要想充分发挥这些技巧的效用，你必须情绪稳定、积极乐观。我记得大约十年前，我在MBA课堂上组织过一次即兴表演练习，叫做“即时专家”。我会挑选一些学生上台表演，然后其他同学提出一些他们可能一无所知的领域。

The first person chosen to stand in front of the room had to give a three-minute talk on haute couture. The guy looked angry and scared. The presentation was a flop. I’m sure that the three minutes felt like an hour to him.

第一个被选中站在房间前面的人要就高级时装做三分钟的演讲。那家伙看起来又生气又害怕。演讲彻底失败了。我敢肯定，对他来说，这三分钟感觉像一个小时那么漫长。

Then I picked a woman in the back row. Her face fell when she was told that she would be an expert on monarch butterflies. But as she strode down the aisle, her expression changed. She stood tall and smiled at her classmates. “I’m so glad to tell you about monarchs,” she said. “I’m only sorry that I have only three minutes to describe what I’m passionate about.” In her enthusiasm, she was able to dredge up a few facts that she did know about butterflies, and then she embellished her story by describing the joys of scientific discovery. The time flew by, and she got wild applause from her classmates.

然后我选中了后排的一位女生。当得知她将扮演帝王蝶专家时，她的脸色顿时黯淡下来。但当她迈着大步走过过道时，她的表情立刻变了。她挺直身子，面带微笑地看着同学们。“我很高兴能和大家分享帝王蝶的故事，”她说，“可惜我只有三分钟的时间来描述我热爱的事物。”她热情洋溢地回忆起一些自己了解的蝴蝶知识，然后又绘声绘色地描述了科学发现的乐趣。时间飞逝，同学们报以热烈的掌声。

“What’s your secret?” I asked her. “How did you transform yourself so quickly?”

“你的秘诀是什么？”我问她。“你怎么能这么快就改变自己？”

“My first reaction was being scared because I had been picked,” she said. “But then I thought, ‘If I’ve got to do this, I might as well make the best of it.’ ”

“我的第一反应是害怕，因为我被选中了，”她说。“但后来我想，‘既然我必须做这件事，那我不如把它做到最好。’”

It was a prime example of saying “yes to the mess.” And the power of having that attitude has been borne out by recent research by my psychologist colleague Alison Wood Brooks. She has found that if you’re feeling anxious, don’t try to suppress that emotion. Instead, put yourself on a positive emotional path by transforming that nervous energy into excitement, just as my student did. Alison has found that if your heart is racing, the simple step of saying out loud “I’m excited” can significantly enhance your ability to perform. It’s certainly worth a try.

这正是“欣然接受混乱”的绝佳例子。我的心理学家同事艾莉森·伍德·布鲁克斯（Alison Wood Brooks）最近的研究也证实了这种态度的力量。她发现，如果你感到焦虑，不要试图压抑这种情绪。相反，要像我的学生那样，将紧张的能量转化为兴奋，从而让自己走上积极的情绪道路。艾莉森发现，如果你的心跳加速，只需大声说出“我很兴奋”，就能显著提升你的表现能力。这绝对值得一试。

BEING IN (OR OUT OF) SYNC

同步（或不同步）

A powerful way to understand how these improv principles work in negotiation is seeing what happens when they’re violated. Take the following exchange between a defense attorney representing an insurance company and a plaintiff’s lawyer whose client was injured in an auto accident. It’s from an unscripted instructional tape created by Gerry Williams, a pioneer in the negotiation field.

要了解这些即兴谈判原则如何在谈判中发挥作用，一个有效的方法是观察当这些原则被违反时会发生什么。以下是保险公司辩护律师和原告律师之间的一段对话，原告的委托人在车祸中受伤。这段对话出自谈判领域的先驱格里·威廉姆斯制作的一盘即兴教学录像带。

From the start, the plaintiff’s lawyer has extended himself by being cooperative and polite, while the blustering defense attorney makes extravagant claims. This segment comes after about forty-five minutes of fruitless back-and-forth.

从一开始，原告律师就表现得非常配合和礼貌，而对方律师则咄咄逼人，提出了许多夸张的指控。这一部分是在双方进行了大约四十五分钟毫无结果的拉锯战之后出现的。

Defense attorney: We’re going to have housewives on that jury. You know how people feel about liquor. The rich, young playboy out for a night of carousing. Don’t you think those things are going to cut it down?

辩护律师：我们会在陪审团里安排一些家庭主妇。你知道人们对酒的态度。那些年轻有钱的花花公子晚上出去寻欢作乐。你不觉得这些会减少酒的发生吗？

Plaintiff’s lawyer: One question: How do you assess liability here?

原告律师：请问：您如何评估本案的责任？

Defense attorney: Oh, probably about . . . seventy-five percent your boy’s fault.

辩护律师：哦，大概有……百分之七十五是你儿子的错。

Plaintiff’s lawyer: If that’s your position, I want a judge involved . . . If you are really hung up on that figure, then I say there’s no use talking.

原告律师：如果这就是你的立场，我希望法官介入……如果你真的执着于那个数字，那我觉得没必要谈了。

Defense attorney: We could call it off if you want.

辩护律师：如果你愿意，我们可以取消这次庭审。

Plaintiff’s lawyer: I think that’s probably wise.

原告律师：我认为这或许是明智之举。

After these parties reached impasse, they were brought into separate rooms, where they privately disclosed their bottom lines. The plaintiff’s lawyer said that he would accept $80,000 to settle the case. The defense lawyer was willing to pay $75,000. They had no way of realizing it themselves, but they were only $5,000 apart.

双方陷入僵局后，被分别带到不同的房间，私下透露各自的底线。原告律师表示愿意接受8万美元和解，而被告律师则愿意支付7.5万美元。他们自己根本无法达成和解，但双方的报价只相差5000美元。

The stalemate might have been averted if the attorneys were more agile. Specifically, if the plaintiff’s lawyer had paid closer heed, even in the closing moments of the exchange, he would have picked up on a positive note buried at the end of the defense attorney’s harangue.

如果双方律师反应更敏捷，僵局或许可以避免。具体来说，如果原告律师在交锋的最后时刻更加留心，就能从被告律师冗长的辩词中发现一个积极的信号。

Look back at the defense lawyer’s statement that begins the dialogue. He starts by cartooning the claimant as a playboy out on a wild spree, implying that he doesn’t deserve a penny. But then he softens his tone and makes a switch: “Don’t you think those things are going to cut it down?” Unfortunately, that comment didn’t register with the other lawyer. Had he heard it, he could have responded, “Maybe it would reduce the amount a little. But before we figure out any adjustment, let’s calculate a reasonable number for all the damages. Then we can talk about a fair discount for my client’s role. Okay?”

回顾一下辩方律师在对话开始时的发言。他先是把原告描绘成一个挥霍无度的花花公子，暗示他一分钱都不配得到。但随后他的语气缓和下来，话锋一转：“你不觉得那些东西会减少赔偿金额吗？” 可惜的是，对方律师并没有听进去这句话。如果他听到了，他本可以回应道：“也许会减少一些赔偿金额。但在我们确定任何调整方案之前，先来计算一下所有损失的合理总额。然后我们再来讨论我方当事人所扮演的角色，并给予合理的折扣。好吗？”

It’s understandable that the plaintiff’s lawyer had given up listening, though, in view of all the hot air the he had heard up to that point. But it’s in contentious situations that you especially need to be listening for a positive theme on which you can comp. Writing off somebody as irredeemable is self-fulfilling.

原告律师听了那么多空话，放弃倾听也是可以理解的。但在充满争议的情况下，你尤其需要留意那些可以作为参照的积极论点。轻易断定某人无可救药，只会适得其反。

Look also at the different nature of the questions in this short exchange. For all his bluster, the defense lawyer raises a reasonable point: If the injured claimant was partly at fault, shouldn’t that reduce his recovery? Had his counterpart heard this invitation, they could have then discussed various ways of calculating responsibility.

还要看看这段简短对话中问题的不同性质。尽管辩方律师语气强硬，但他提出的观点却不无道理：如果受伤的索赔人负有部分责任，那么他的赔偿金额是否应该减少？如果对方律师听取了这一建议，他们就可以讨论各种计算责任的方法了。

Instead, the plaintiff’s lawyer leans back in his chair, wags his finger, and with a relaxed smile on his face, poses a different kind of question, one that shuts the door on possible agreement. The query catches the other attorney by surprise. It’s the first one put to him in almost an hour of talk. After a little hesitation, he appears to pull a number out of thin air, and it’s a ridiculous figure to boot. The plaintiff, eager to end this pointless discussion, then jumps on the 75 percent estimate and lashes it around the other fellow’s neck not just once (“If that’s your position”) but twice (“If you are really hung up on that figure”).

原告律师没有继续讨论，而是向后靠在椅子上，摇了摇手指，脸上带着轻松的微笑，提出了一个截然不同的问题，这个问题彻底断送了双方达成协议的可能性。这个问题让对方律师措手不及，因为这是近一个小时的谈话中，对方律师第一次提出这样的问题。他略作犹豫，随即抛出一个数字，而且这个数字荒谬至极。原告急于结束这场毫无意义的讨论，于是抓住这个75%的估算值，反驳道：“如果你坚持这个数字的话”，而且是反驳了两次：“如果你真的那么在意这个数字的话”。

The parties in this vignette failed to get in sync. Right to the end, the defense lawyer mistook his counterpart’s good manners as a sign of weakness. In turn, the plaintiff’s lawyer thought he was dealing with a pettifogger. If just one of them had been more nimble, they might have reached agreement. As it was, however, neither was able to influence or adapt to the other.

这起案件中的双方始终未能达成一致。直到最后，辩方律师仍将对方的礼貌误解为软弱的表现。而原告律师则认为对方是个吹毛求疵的人。如果他们中哪怕有一方更灵活一些，或许就能达成共识。然而，事实是，双方都无法影响或适应对方。

The one thing that they had in common was an inability to work outside their respective comfort zones. If the hard-bargaining defense lawyer had been paired with somebody just like him, they likely would have haggled their way to an acceptable number. And if the cooperative plaintiff’s attorney had met his clone, they might well have shared information that would have led to a creative agreement.

他们唯一的共同点就是都无法跳出各自的舒适区。如果那位精于讨价还价的辩护律师遇到一个和他一样的人，他们很可能就能讨价还价到双方都能接受的价格。而如果那位合作的原告律师遇到他的“克隆人”，他们或许会分享一些信息，从而达成一项富有创意的协议。

In real-world negotiation, however, you can’t limit yourself to dealing with people who match your own temperament and style. There are rugged individualists who expect others to look after themselves at the bargaining table. Others are relationally oriented. Stretch yourself so that you can deal with both types and everyone in between.

然而，在现实谈判中，你不能只和那些与你性格和风格相符的人打交道。有些人是强势的个人主义者，他们期望对方在谈判桌上各司其职；而有些人则注重人际关系。你应该拓展自己的能力范围，以便能够应对这两种类型的人，以及介于两者之间的所有人。

AN APPRECIATIVE MIND-SET

感恩的心态

Improvisation rests on having what Frank Barrett calls an appreciative mind-set. Appreciation as he means it doesn’t signify the same warm gratitude a parent feels when a grown child calls with birthday wishes. It’s a bit closer to appreciation in the sense of broad comprehension, taking into account all aspects of a situation, both good and bad, in a clear-eyed manner. But it’s more than that as well. It is an attitude that whatever has befallen you, you can make some good of it, as Barrett says. In other people’s eyes, that optimism may seem misplaced or even irrational. Yet it is often useful to believe that somewhere in the trash heap in which you’ve landed there are bits and pieces of a solution that could be cobbled into a workable deal.

即兴发挥的基础在于拥有弗兰克·巴雷特所说的“欣赏的心态”。他所说的欣赏并非指父母收到成年子女生日祝福电话时那种温暖的感激之情。它更接近于一种更广阔的理解，即以清醒的视角审视事物的方方面面，无论好坏。但它又远不止于此。正如巴雷特所说，这是一种无论遭遇何种境遇，都能从中汲取积极因素的态度。在旁人看来，这种乐观或许显得不合时宜，甚至有些不理性。然而，相信即便身处困境，也能找到一些可以拼凑成可行方案的碎片，往往是有益的。

The late investment banker Bruce Wasserstein was known for his brash confidence. His former colleague Laurence Grafstein tells of a time that he was running late for a meeting. His assistant told him the finance minister of Slovakia had been waiting for him in the conference room.

已故投资银行家布鲁斯·沃瑟斯坦以其大胆自信而闻名。他的前同事劳伦斯·格拉夫斯坦讲述了这样一个故事：有一次沃瑟斯坦开会迟到了，他的助理告诉他，斯洛伐克财政部长已经在会议室等他了。

“Arriving well behind schedule, Bruce proceeded to launch into a distinctive, long-winded Wassersteinian monologue about all of the different issues facing Slovakia’s privatization program, corporate sector, and politics generally given its recent separation from the Czech Republic. And why, of course, Slovakia needed a banker like Bruce to steer it forward. The guests and his colleagues tried unsuccessfully to interrupt several times. Finally, the finance minister said, ‘Excuse me, Mr. Wasserstein. We are not from Slovakia. We are from Slovenia.’ The way Bruce told it, the room went silent, with ashen faces around the table. After a brief pause, Bruce—always a bit faster and more confident than most of us—answered: ‘And that’s precisely your strategic dilemma.’ What was the poor Slovenian finance minister to do, other than cave?”

布鲁斯姗姗来迟，随即开始了一段冗长而又极具沃瑟斯坦风格的独白，内容涵盖了斯洛伐克私有化计划、企业界以及政治领域在近期脱离捷克共和国后所面临的种种问题。当然，他还解释了为什么斯洛伐克需要像布鲁斯这样的银行家来引领国家前进。在场的客人和同事们几次试图打断他，但都无功而返。最后，财政部长说道：“抱歉，沃瑟斯坦先生。我们不是斯洛伐克人，我们是斯洛文尼亚人。” 布鲁斯说完这句话，房间里顿时鸦雀无声，围坐在桌旁的人脸色都变得苍白。短暂的停顿之后，布鲁斯——他总是比我们大多数人反应更快、更自信——回答道：“而这正是你们面临的战略困境。” 可怜的斯洛文尼亚财政部长除了屈服还能怎么办呢？

Several years ago, the jazz critic David Hajdu wandered into a Greenwich Village club where Charles McPherson, a little-known but highly regarded saxophonist, was leading a band. As Hajdu settled down at his table, his eyes wandered over to the trumpeter, who was turned away from the audience and even from the rest of the band. “I couldn’t place him,” Hajdu wrote later. “He looked like an older version of Wynton Marsalis.”

几年前，爵士乐评论家大卫·哈杜（David Hajdu）偶然走进格林威治村的一家俱乐部，当时鲜为人知但备受推崇的萨克斯风演奏家查尔斯·麦克弗森（Charles McPherson）正在带领一支乐队演出。哈杜在自己的桌边落座后，目光不由自主地落在了背对着观众甚至乐队其他成员的小号手身上。“我当时想不起来他是谁，”哈杜后来写道，“他看起来像是年纪稍长的温顿·马萨利斯（Wynton Marsalis）。”

Marsalis, by that time, was regarded skeptically by some jazz aficionados who faulted him for being too cautious and conservative. This trumpeter was dressed stylishly in an Italian-cut suit and had the burnished elegance, as Hajdu put it, of Marsalis and his musician brothers. But there “was a weight upon him; he didn’t smile, and his eyes were small and affectless.” The trumpeter didn’t have the “youthful élan that Wynton Marsalis has always called to mind.” But it really was Marsalis, as became obvious when he played a solo, the plaintive “I Don’t Stand a Ghost of a Chance with You.” Hajdu was there, so he should describe Marsalis’s rendition:

那时，一些爵士乐迷对马萨利斯持怀疑态度，认为他过于谨慎保守。这位小号手身着一套剪裁合身的意大利式西装，举手投足间散发着马萨利斯及其音乐家兄弟们那种优雅的气质，正如哈伊杜所说。但他“身上似乎带着某种沉重感；他不苟言笑，眼神空洞而缺乏情感”。这位小号手没有“温顿·马萨利斯身上那种令人想起的青春活力”。但当他演奏独奏曲——哀婉动人的《我与你毫无胜算》时，这一点便显而易见。哈伊杜当时也在场，所以他应该来描述马萨利斯的演奏：

He performed the song in murmurs and sighs, at points nearly talking the words in notes. It was a wrenching act of creative expression. When he reached the climax, Marsalis played the final phrase, the title statement, in declarative tones, allowing each successive note to linger in the air a bit longer. “I don’t stand . . . a ghost . . . of . . . a chance . . .”

他低声吟唱着这首歌，时而轻声叹息，时而几乎是用音符吟诵歌词。这是一次令人心碎的创作表达。当乐曲达到高潮时，马萨利斯以陈述句式的音调演奏了最后一个乐句，也就是标题的那句，让每一个音符在空气中停留得更久一些。“我不再……像幽灵……一样……拥有……机会……”

The room was silent until, at the most dramatic point, someone’s cell phone went off, blaring a rapid singsong melody in electronic beeps. People started giggling and picking up their drinks. The whole moment—the whole performance—unraveled.

房间里一片寂静，直到最激动人心的时刻，有人手机突然响起，刺耳的电子音效伴随着急促的旋律响起。人们开始窃笑，纷纷拿起饮料。整个过程——整场演出——就此崩塌。

Marsalis paused for a beat, motionless, and his eyebrows arched. I scrawled on a sheet of notepaper, “Magic Ruined.” The cell phone offender scooted into the hall as the chatter in the room grew louder. Still frozen at the microphone, Marsalis replayed the silly cell phone melody note for note. Then he repeated it, and began improvising variations on the tune. The audience slowly came back to him. In a few minutes, he resolved the improvisation—which had changed keys once or twice and throttled down to a ballad tempo—and ended up exactly where he had left off: “with . . . you.” The ovation was tremendous.

马萨利斯停顿了一下，一动不动，眉毛微微挑起。我在一张便笺纸上潦草地写道：“魔法毁了。” 那个用手机的家伙溜进了走廊，房间里的喧闹声越来越大。马萨利斯仍然僵在麦克风前，一音不差地重复着那段滑稽的手机旋律。然后他又重复了一遍，并开始即兴演奏。观众的注意力慢慢回到了他身上。几分钟后，他结束了这段即兴演奏——其中有一两次转调，节奏也放慢到了抒情曲的程度——最终回到了他刚才停顿的地方：“和……你们。” 掌声雷动。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Pay heed. Go beyond active listening.

■ 注意倾听。超越被动聆听。

■ Be provocative. Stir things up.

■ 要敢于挑衅，要搅动风云。

■ Venture outside your comfort zone.

■ 走出你的舒适区。

■ “Comp” in order to evoke the best from your counterparts.

■ “竞争”是为了激发对手的最佳状态。

■ Say no when necessary, but offer an alternative.

■ 必要时要说“不”，但要提供替代方案。

■ Develop an appreciative mind-set.

■ 培养感恩之心。

#↩

[ 7 ] Situational Awareness

[ 7 ] 情境意识

American F-86 Sabre jet fighters and North Korean MiG-15s battled fiercely throughout the Korean War. The rival Russian-built plane was faster, soared higher, and was more heavily armed. Nevertheless, American pilots won more than 90 percent of the dogfights.

在整个朝鲜战争期间，美国F-86佩刀式战斗机和朝鲜米格-15战斗机展开了激烈的空战。这款俄制战机速度更快、飞行高度更高、火力也更强大。尽管如此，美国飞行员仍然赢得了超过90%的空战胜利。

Military analysts initially chalked up the dominance of the F-86 to pilot superiority, but that was just part of the story. Even after the Russians substituted their own well-trained pilots for the North Korean fliers, the Americans still had a whopping five-to-one advantage in combat. It took the maverick intelligence of John Boyd, an air force colonel and Pentagon gadfly, to recognize what was going on.

军事分析家最初将F-86的优势归功于飞行员的优越性，但这只是故事的一部分。即使苏联用训练有素的飞行员替换了朝鲜飞行员，美军在战斗中仍然拥有五比一的巨大优势。正是空军上校、五角大楼的“刺头”约翰·博伊德凭借其特立独行的智慧，才洞察到了其中的真相。

Deadly combat may seem an odd topic for this book, especially coming on the heels of a chapter on jazz and improv. Bear with me. Former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres likened strategic negotiators to hunters. “A good hunter doesn’t aim at the bird. If he does, he will miss,” he said. “He aims ahead of the bird, anticipating its travel.” Foresight is essential in negotiation, both in cases where there are clear winners and losers, and in more collaborative ventures.

这本书的主题或许略显突兀，尤其是在刚刚读完爵士乐和即兴演奏章节之后。请耐心听我解释。以色列前总理西蒙·佩雷斯曾将战略谈判者比作猎人。“优秀的猎人不会瞄准鸟儿。如果他那样做，就会失手，”他说，“他会瞄准鸟儿的前方，预判它的飞行路线。” 无论是在胜负分明的情况下，还是在更注重合作的项目中，远见卓识在谈判中都至关重要。

Military doctrine can teach us a lot about anticipation and decision making in dynamic, rapidly changing environments. So can competitive games such as chess and basketball. US Marine Corps doctrine defines maneuver warfare as “a state of mind born of a bold will, intellect, initiative, and ruthless opportunism.” Will, intellect, and initiative are all negotiation virtues, but what of ruthless opportunism? Negotiation need not—and in most instances should not —be “ruthless” on a personal basis. But we shouldn’t flinch from tackling tough problems. And we should seize opportunities to innovate.

军事理论可以教会我们很多关于在动态、瞬息万变的环境中进行预判和决策的知识。国际象棋和篮球等竞技运动也能提供类似的启示。美国海军陆战队理论将机动战定义为“一种源于大胆意志、智慧、主动性和果断机会主义的心态”。意志、智慧和主动性都是谈判的必备素质，但果断机会主义又该如何解释呢？谈判无需——而且在大多数情况下也不应该——在个人层面上采取“果断”的态度。但我们不应回避棘手的问题，也应该抓住创新的机会。

So back to aerial warfare. Boyd’s core interest was military strategy, but he was an eclectic reader well versed in history and philosophy. He was interested in how people make decisions under pressure. “Machines don’t fight wars. Terrain doesn’t fight wars,” he said. “Humans fight wars. You must get into the minds of humans. That’s where battles are won.”

回到空战的话题。博伊德的核心兴趣在于军事战略，但他博览群书，对历史和哲学也颇有研究。他很感兴趣的是人们在压力下如何做出决策。“机器不会打仗，地形也不会打仗，”他说，“打仗的是人。你必须了解人的思想，才能赢得战争。”

According to biographer Grant Hammond, Boyd was fascinated by what others might see merely as “a confusing and disorderly fur ball of a fight among swarming planes.” In the seeming chaos of air-to-air combat, Boyd recognized underlying order. “What initially excited him was that it was limitless,” says Hammond. “It could start or end at any altitude, from any direction. It was all azimuth and multidimensional. It was, he would realize, the best way to think about a problem.”

据传记作家格兰特·哈蒙德所述，博伊德对其他人眼中“飞机群起而攻之，混乱不堪的混战”着迷不已。在看似混乱的空战中，博伊德却看到了内在的秩序。“最初让他兴奋的是它的无限性，”哈蒙德说道，“它可以从任何高度、任何方向开始或结束。它关乎方位角，是多维的。他后来意识到，这才是思考问题的最佳方式。”

Boyd concluded that the success of the American fighter was due to two design factors. First, it had hydraulic controls that enabled it to transition from one activity—climbing, banking, and accelerating—more rapidly than the MiG. Second, the F-86 had a bubble canopy that gave its pilots superior “situational awareness,” which allowed them to process information and make decisions more quickly. Each maneuver by the F-86 compounded its edge over its opponent until it achieved dominance.

博伊德总结道，美国战斗机的成功归功于两个设计因素。首先，它采用液压控制系统，使其能够比米格战机更快地完成爬升、转弯和加速等动作之间的转换。其次，F-86的气泡式座舱盖赋予飞行员卓越的“态势感知能力”，使他们能够更快地处理信息并做出决策。F-86的每一次机动都使其优势不断扩大，最终取得绝对优势。

From this specific example, Boyd formulated a general model of dynamic interaction. He called it the OODA loop—a recurring process of Observing, Orienting, Deciding, and Acting. As he saw it, success in any encounter hinges on cycling through this loop faster than the enemy or by disrupting the enemy’s ability to connect those activities efficiently. His full-blown version had dozens of elements. We need only the core features here.

基于这个具体案例，博伊德构建了一个动态交互的通用模型。他称之为OODA循环——观察、判断、决策和行动的循环过程。在他看来，任何遭遇战的成功都取决于能否比敌人更快地完成这个循环，或者能否有效地干扰敌人将这些活动串联起来。他的完整版本包含数十个要素，而我们这里只需要其核心部分。

Boyd’s model differs starkly from a conventional linear framework in which facts are gathered and analyzed, and then a choice is made. By contrast, actions in his OODA loop stimulate reactions from other parties, which then constitute new data to observe, digest, and further act upon. You can think of his rapid-decision-making process as a wheel within a wheel, running inside the larger strategic cycle of learning, adapting, and influencing that I’ve stressed throughout the book.

博伊德的模型与传统的线性框架截然不同，后者是先收集和分析事实，然后再做出选择。相比之下，在他的OODA循环中，行动会激发其他方的反应，这些反应又构成新的数据，供观察、消化并进一步采取行动。你可以把他的快速决策过程想象成一个嵌套的轮子，它运行在我在本书中反复强调的更大的战略循环——学习、适应和影响——之中。

Boyd emphasized two complementary elements of this microlevel learning. Observing entails heeding the actions of other parties and assembling that information into a larger mosaic of understanding. Orienting then compares what is actually unfolding with prior experience and expectations. Boyd was intent on spotting “mismatches” between expectations, no matter how well-founded, and the resulting reality.

博伊德强调了这种微观学习的两个互补要素。观察意味着关注其他方的行为，并将这些信息整合起来，形成更全面的理解。定位则是将实际发生的情况与先前的经验和预期进行比较。博伊德致力于发现预期（无论多么合理）与最终现实之间的“不匹配”。

Negotiation is its own kind of fur ball. Offers and demands volley back and forth. What was said just now may contradict whatever was expressed five minutes ago. One issue gets resolved, but then another pops up. At any given moment, it can be hard to know where our counterpart is coming from or who’s up and who’s down. Even so, there is often underlying order in the chaos of negotiation. But it takes situational awareness to see where we are in the process, and it takes agility to engage other parties effectively.

谈判本身就像一团乱麻。双方你来我往，攻防转换频繁。刚才说的话可能和五分钟前说的完全相反。一个问题解决了，另一个问题又冒了出来。在任何时刻，我们都很难判断对方的立场，也很难分辨谁占上风谁又吃亏。即便如此，谈判的混乱之中往往也存在着某种内在的秩序。但这需要敏锐的洞察力才能看清谈判进程，也需要灵活的应变能力才能有效地与其他各方沟通。

OBSERVE: WHAT ARE WE LOOKING FOR?

观察：我们在寻找什么？

Erin Egan was merely in her midtwenties, but there she was at the bargaining table where a deal worth millions of dollars was being hammered out. She worked for a European industrial giant that deals with General Electric and other megacorporations. It wasn’t that Erin was a financial wizard or a precocious engineer. Just a few years earlier, she had graduated with a degree in international affairs from a small liberal arts college. Nor was she highly placed in her organization. Yet her boss soon recognized her uncanny ability to speed-read a room. That’s why Erin was often brought along to important negotiations. She wouldn’t say anything during the sessions, but when there was a break, the lead negotiator would huddle with her and ask, “Okay, what just happened in there?”

艾琳·伊根当时才二十五六岁，却身处谈判桌前，参与敲定一项价值数百万美元的交易。她就职于一家与通用电气和其他大型企业有业务往来的欧洲工业巨头。艾琳并非金融奇才或早慧的工程师。几年前，她才从一所小型文理学院毕业，获得国际事务学位。她在公司里的职位也并不高。然而，她的老板很快就发现了她敏锐的洞察力，能够迅速读懂谈判桌上的气氛。因此，艾琳经常被带去参加重要的谈判。谈判期间她一言不发，但休会时，首席谈判代表会凑到她身边，问：“刚才那边发生了什么？”

A person like Erin might spot fissures in the other team. “Did you see how their finance person rolled her eyes when the marketing guy was talking?” she’d observe. “They’re just not on the same page.” Or she might explain why the nos they heard on various proposals could mean different things. “When they refused to lower the front-end payment, they said it flat out and didn’t falter. They don’t expect to buckle,” she could conclude. “But they protested too much about guaranteeing the price for three years. My bet is that they just want us to think they’ve made a big concession when they finally concede.”

像艾琳这样的人或许能发现对方团队的裂痕。“你看到他们的财务人员在市场部人员发言时翻白眼了吗？”她会这样观察。“他们俩根本不在一个频道上。”或者，她可能会解释为什么他们听到的各种提案被拒绝可能意味着不同的事情。“当他们拒绝降低前期付款时，他们直截了当地说了算，毫不含糊。他们并不打算妥协，”她可能会这样总结。“但他们对三年价格保证的问题却百般阻挠。我猜他们只是想让我们觉得，当他们最终让步时，他们已经做出了很大的让步。”

It’s as if Erin has social sonar, a way of seeing the interpersonal crosscurrents below the surface and the forces that shape their flow. But just as a person with normal vision would struggle to describe color to someone who sees only in shades of gray, Erin can’t explain how she spots things that many of us would miss.

艾琳仿佛拥有社交声呐，能够洞察人际交往中暗流涌动的微妙之处，以及影响其走向的各种力量。但就像视力正常的人很难向只能看到灰色的人描述颜色一样，艾琳也无法解释她是如何发现我们大多数人都会忽略的事物的。

Researchers call what Erin does “sense-making.” It’s the ability to connect the dots and construct a coherent picture. It also requires knowing what constitutes a significant dot and what’s irrelevant data. The key lies in looking for relationships among items rather than viewing elements in isolation. In basketball, it’s called having court sense. Bob Cousy, the Hall of Fame Boston Celtics player, says, “I just played. The defense tells you what you must do, every time down the floor. For me, it was easy. Maybe that’s because I have a vivid imagination.”

研究人员将艾琳的工作称为“意义建构”。这是一种将零散信息联系起来，构建连贯图景的能力。它还需要知道哪些信息点是重要的，哪些是无关紧要的数据。关键在于寻找事物之间的联系，而不是孤立地看待各个元素。在篮球中，这被称为球场意识。名人堂成员、波士顿凯尔特人队球员鲍勃·库西说：“我只是打球。防守会告诉你每次进攻该怎么做。对我来说，这很容易。也许是因为我想象力丰富吧。”

A clever experiment illustrates how the mind interprets what it sees. Imagine a test where you’re given a quick glimpse at a chessboard with randomly placed pieces. You’re then asked to re-create the setup from memory. Studies show that most people can perform this task just about as well as an expert player.

一个巧妙的实验说明了大脑如何解读所看到的信息。想象一下，你被要求快速浏览一个棋盘，棋子摆放的位置是随机的。然后，你需要凭记忆重新摆放好棋盘。研究表明，大多数人都能像专业棋手一样出色地完成这项任务。

But it’s a different story if subjects are shown a board from a real game. In that case, masters have near perfect recall, while novices do little better than when the pieces are strewn by chance. Masters succeed because experience has taught them to see the pieces in relation to one another . They notice that the white queen is well protected, for example, but also see that a black knight is two moves away from threatening one of her rooks. Those relationships, in turn, are clues to the players’ intentions and how the game has developed to that point.

但如果给受试者展示真实棋局的棋盘，情况就截然不同了。在这种情况下，大师们几乎能完美回忆起棋局，而新手们的表现甚至不如棋子随意散落时。大师们之所以能成功，是因为经验教会了他们观察棋子之间的相互关系。例如，他们会注意到白后受到严密保护，同时也会注意到黑马只需两步就能威胁到白车。这些关系反过来又为理解棋手的意图以及棋局发展至今提供了线索。

Chess master and writer Graham Burgess says that pattern recognition helps the analytic process and sparks ideas that a player might miss otherwise. “Many blunders, rather than being ‘hallucinations’ or ‘blind spots,’ can be explained by the relevant pattern not being recognized.” He recalls watching a game where a player seemed to be unlucky, having overlooked something that Graham admits he might have missed as well. But the second time he saw a similar situation, “I would think that they had been a bit careless, and should have seen it coming. Third and fourth time, I would groan, having anticipated the idea a move or two earlier.”

国际象棋大师兼作家格雷厄姆·伯吉斯认为，模式识别有助于分析过程，并能激发棋手原本可能忽略的思路。“许多失误与其说是‘幻觉’或‘盲点’，不如说是未能识别出相关的模式。”他回忆起观看的一场比赛，其中一位棋手似乎运气不佳，忽略了一些格雷厄姆承认自己也可能忽略的东西。但当他第二次看到类似情况时，“我会觉得他们有点粗心，应该预料到这种情况。第三次、第四次，我就会叹气，因为我早在一两步之前就预料到了。”

Being attentive not only helps us learn about specific moves and strategies but also deepens our pattern recognition skills more generally. As Graham reflects on his own thinking, “Thus, seeing the same idea a few times changed from being something I would not have seen in advance to being an idea I recognized as an inherent possibility in certain types of positions, an idea to be taken into account (to some extent subconsciously) when planning and calculating.”

保持专注不仅能帮助我们学习具体的招法和策略，还能更广泛地提升我们的模式识别能力。正如格雷厄姆反思自己的思考时所说：“因此，几次看到同一个想法，就从我事先不会想到的，变成了我意识到在某些类型的局面中固有的可能性，一个在计划和计算时（在某种程度上是下意识地）需要考虑的想法。”

Much of sense-making is context specific and is perfected only through long practice. Newly hatched chicks look like identical balls of yellow fluff to most of us, yet with barely a glance, a professional chicken sexer (I’m not making up this job) can catalog thousands of them a day as males or females. It’s a valuable skill, since the earlier the hens can be put on a special diet, the more productive they will be. An expert could point to the subtle differences he sees, but even if we could then recognize them, it would take lots of practice to match the speed and accuracy of the pros.

许多认知能力都依赖于具体情境，并且只有通过长期的实践才能精进。刚孵出的小鸡在我们大多数人眼里都像一团毛茸茸的黄色小球，但专业的鸡性别鉴定师（我可没瞎编）只需一眼就能一天鉴定出成千上万只小鸡的性别。这是一项非常宝贵的技能，因为母鸡越早接受特殊饮食，产蛋量就越高。专家或许能指出他观察到的细微差别，但即便我们也能识别出来，也需要大量的练习才能达到专业人士的速度和准确度。

Military personnel, in turn, try to feel out an enemy’s resources and intentions. They speak of identifying surfaces and gaps. Surfaces are hard and solid—the enemy’s strengths—while gaps are weak points vulnerable to exploitation. Attacks against surfaces waste energy. Finding or creating gaps enables success.

反过来，军事人员也会试图摸清敌人的资源和意图。他们会谈到识别敌方的“表面”和“缺口”。“表面”坚硬而坚实，代表着敌人的优势；而“缺口”则是敌人容易利用的弱点。攻击“表面”会浪费能量，而找到或制造“缺口”则能带来胜利。

The opposition will do its best to disguise surfaces and gaps, however, and the passage of time can change their contours.
