The US Marine Corps’s Warfighting manual states: “Due to the fluid nature of war, gaps will rarely be permanent and will usually be fleeting. To exploit them demands flexibility and speed.”

敌方会竭尽全力掩盖表面和漏洞，但时间的流逝也会改变它们的轮廓。美国海军陆战队的作战手册指出：“由于战争的瞬息万变，漏洞很少会永久存在，通常都是转瞬即逝的。要利用这些漏洞，就需要灵活应变和快速行动。”

Negotiation is likewise a process of making sense of a situation and the people on the other side. It takes place on three levels. One is substantive. It’s about testing to see what is a real point of resistance and what is a mere bluff. It also involves seeing connections among the issues up for discussion and how your priorities match up with those of other parties. A second level is interpersonal and process focused. It’s an appraisal of how well people are engaging one another (or what’s getting in the way). The third level is contextual. It’s recognizing how larger circumstances influence people’s perceptions about their interests and options. Who seems to have the better walkaway? Is time on one person’s side rather than on the other’s?

谈判同样是一个理解局势和对方人物的过程。它发生在三个层面。第一层面是实质性的，旨在检验对方真正的阻力点和虚张声势的程度。它还包括分析待讨论议题之间的关联，以及自身与对方的优先事项是否一致。第二层面是人际关系和流程层面，旨在评估双方的互动情况（或阻碍因素）。第三层面是情境层面，旨在认识到更大的环境因素如何影响人们对自身利益和选择的认知。谁似乎更有优势？时间是否站在一方而非另一方？

Sense-making is thus a holistic linking of microdevelopments and macrotrends. It entails deep engagement with the immediate moment and, at the same time, detached awareness of what came before and what may ensue. Erin’s insights about an unfolding negotiation are based on seeing its elements in relation to one another. While the marketing person on the other team was speaking, she was attending to how his own colleagues listened. When she made judgments about which issues were negotiable, they were based on hearing how one no compared with another.

因此，意义建构是对微观发展和宏观趋势的整体性联系。它既需要对当下时刻的深入参与，同时也需要对过去和未来可能发生的情况保持客观的认知。艾琳对谈判进程的洞察，正是基于对谈判要素之间相互关系的理解。当对方团队的营销人员发言时，她会留意对方同事的倾听方式。当她判断哪些问题可以谈判时，她的判断依据是比较不同“不”字时的回应。

ORIENT: HOW SHOULD WE INTERPRET WHAT WE SEE?

方向：我们应该如何解读我们所看到的事物？

Observing and orienting are coupled in Boyd’s OODA loop. Although orienting is the second step in the process, it involves reaching back and drawing on experience and expectations to assess what you see in the present.

在博伊德的OODA循环中，观察和判断是紧密相连的。虽然判断是该过程的第二步，但它需要回顾过往经验和预期，并以此来评估当下所见。

To get a toehold, you need a theory of the case: a provisional sense of what you could be facing. Does the negotiation present an opportunity for mutual gain, or will it more likely be a toe-to-toe haggle? In transactions that are solely about price, a better result for one party means a worse one for the other, but many more cases have creative potential. Absent strong evidence to the contrary, you should start with the premise that the pie can be expanded through wise trades. The cost of exploring that possibility is small, so don’t discard it.

要想站稳脚跟，你需要对谈判局面有一个大致的了解：对可能面临的情况有一个初步的认识。谈判是否会带来互利共赢的机会，还是更有可能演变成一场你来我往的讨价还价？在纯粹以价格为导向的交易中，一方的利益提升意味着另一方的利益受损，但更多情况下，谈判中蕴含着创造性的潜力。除非有强有力的反证，否则你应该首先假设可以通过明智的交易来扩大利益蛋糕。探索这种可能性成本很低，所以不要轻易放弃。

You’ll also form expectations about whether your counterpart will be open and trusting, or suspicious and hostile. If you’ve dealt with the person before, you may have a basis for making a judgment, but bear in mind that his or her circumstances may have changed, for better or worse.

你也会对对方是坦诚信任还是多疑敌对形成预期。如果你之前和这个人打过交道，或许可以据此做出判断，但也要记住，他/她的境况可能已经发生了变化，无论好坏。

Dealing with a stranger, you may have little to go on, but as a general matter, tilt your expectations toward the optimistic end of the spectrum. A friendly comment is virtually costless. Likewise, disclosing some of your priorities prudently needn’t lessen your bargaining power. If such moves aren’t reciprocated, you can adjust your approach accordingly.

与陌生人交往时，你可能掌握的信息有限，但一般来说，最好保持乐观的态度。一句友好的评论几乎不需要任何成本。同样，谨慎地透露一些你的优先事项并不会削弱你的谈判筹码。如果对方没有做出相应的回应，你可以相应地调整你的方法。

Others may claim that it’s wiser to demonstrate your resolve by starting hard. After softening up the other party, supposedly you can become more cooperative later, if you so desire. I’m skeptical about that approach, however. It gives counterparts little reason to be forthcoming. If you expect someone to be a shark, he’s more likely to act like one. Nice doesn’t always trump nasty, but consider which approach will give you more flexibility going forward.

有些人可能会说，一开始就采取强硬态度来展现决心才是明智之举。据说，先软化对方，之后如果愿意的话，就可以变得更加合作。但我对这种做法持怀疑态度。它会让对方缺乏坦诚合作的动力。如果你预料到对方会像鲨鱼一样，他更有可能真的像鲨鱼一样行事。友好并不总是能战胜恶劣，但你应该考虑哪种方式能让你在未来拥有更大的灵活性。

The more precisely you define your expectations, positive or negative, the more alert you will be for signs that confirm or contradict those assumptions. In Streetlights and Shadows : Searching for the Keys to Adaptive Decision Making , Gary Klein says that complex, ambiguous situations call for having “strong ideas, weakly held.” Making a guess forces you to weigh the evidence on hand and see what it would take for you to reverse your judgment. Being specific about your assumptions also reminds you of the risk of being wrong.

你对预期（无论是积极的还是消极的）的定义越精确，就越能敏锐地察觉到那些证实或反驳这些假设的迹象。在《路灯与阴影：寻找适应性决策的关键》一书中，加里·克莱因指出，复杂且模糊的情况需要“坚定但又不固执己见”的理念。做出猜测会迫使你权衡现有证据，并思考什么会促使你改变判断。明确你的假设也能提醒你存在出错的风险。

Klein adds, “Anticipatory thinking lets us manage our attention so that we are looking in the right places to spot anomalies in the case as they appear.” It’s not the same thing as prediction. Rather, it’s a matter of opening up our minds to various possibilities and how they would manifest themselves.

克莱因补充道：“预见性思维让我们能够更好地管理注意力，从而在案件出现异常情况时，能够及时发现并关注正确的方向。”这与预测不同。更确切地说，它是一种开放思维的方式，让我们能够接受各种可能性以及它们可能呈现出的表现形式。

It’s easy to ignore bad news. Consider, for example, this exchange between an airline pilot and his copilot as they waited for the control tower to clear them for takeoff from National Airport outside of Washington, DC, on January 13, 1982. The Air Florida Boeing 737 had been deiced earlier, but flights were backed up, and freezing rain was still falling.

人们很容易忽略坏消息。例如，1982年1月13日，在华盛顿特区郊外的国家机场，一位航空公司飞行员和副驾驶在等待塔台许可起飞时，发生了这样一段对话。这架佛罗里达航空公司的波音737客机此前已经除冰，但航班仍然积压，冻雨仍在下。

Copilot: Anti-ice?

副驾驶：防冰？

Pilot: Off. [ This internal device should have been on, but the first officer doesn’t challenge him. Later the pilot says, “real cold, real cold.” ]

飞行员：关掉。[这个内部装置本应开启，但副驾驶没有质疑他。后来飞行员说：“真冷，真冷。”]

Copilot: Let’s check the ice on those tops [wings] again, since we’ve been sitting here awhile.

副驾驶：既然我们已经在这里坐了一段时间了，那就再检查一下机翼顶部的冰吧。

Captain: No. I think we get to go in a minute.

船长：不，我想我们马上就可以走了。

Copilot: [ As they are rolling down the runway ] God, look at that thing. That don’t seem right, does it? [ Then he repeats the comment, apparently referring to ground speed. ] Uh, that’s not right.

副驾驶：（飞机在跑道上滑行时）天哪，看看那东西。这好像不太对劲，对吧？（然后他重复了一遍这句话，显然是指地速。）呃，这不太对劲。

Pilot: Yes, there it is, eighty.

飞行员：是的，就是八十。

Copilot: Naw, I don’t think that’s right . . . Ah, maybe it is.

副驾驶：不，我觉得不对……啊，也许是对的。

Pilot: Hundred and twenty.

飞行员：一百二十。

Copilot: I don’t know. [ There is the sound of the plane straining unsuccessfully to gain altitude. ]

副驾驶：我不知道。[传来飞机努力爬升但未成功的声响。]

Pilot: Stalling. We’re falling.

飞行员：飞机失速了。我们正在坠落。

Copilot: Larry, we’re going down!

副驾驶：拉里，我们要坠毁了！

Captain: I know it.

船长：我知道。

Those were their last words just before Air Florida flight 90 crashed into the top of a major bridge and plunged into the Potomac River. Both men were killed, along with seventy-six others on board or on the ground. The black box recording is an example of a mismatch between hopes and commitments on the one hand, and grim reality on the other.

就在佛罗里达航空90号航班撞上一座主要桥梁顶部并坠入波托马克河之前，那是他们说的最后一句话。两人全部遇难，机上和地面上的其他76人也一同遇难。黑匣子记录展现了希望与承诺与残酷现实之间的巨大落差。

National Airport had been closed by heavy snow. Even after it reopened, flights were backed up. The doomed plane had been deiced at the gate, but conditions were so bad that the ground service tow couldn’t get traction. Reverse thrust on the engines proved futile as well. Finally, a vehicle with chains got the plane moving. It then had to wait in a long line for almost an hour before getting to the takeoff runway. According to the subsequent National Transportation Safety Board review, the crew was aware of snow and ice buildup.

由于大雪，国家机场被迫关闭。即使重新开放后，航班仍然积压严重。这架失事飞机在登机口已进行除冰，但由于路况恶劣，地面拖曳设备无法使其获得足够的牵引力。反推发动机也无济于事。最终，一辆装有防滑链的车辆才使飞机得以移动。随后，飞机又不得不排了近一个小时的长队才到达起飞跑道。根据美国国家运输安全委员会随后的调查报告，机组人员当时已意识到跑道上积雪和结冰的情况。

Why, then, in spite of mounting signs of danger, did the pilot still attempt to take off? The best guess is that he didn’t want to prolong what had been a frustrating delay by going back for more deicing. Intent on leaving, he shut out any information that would disrupt his original plan.

那么，尽管危险迹象日益明显，飞行员为何仍试图起飞呢？最合理的推测是，他不想因为再次除冰而延长已经令人沮丧的延误。一心只想离开的他，屏蔽了任何可能干扰他原计划的信息。

He also shut out the fact that he was engaged in a negotiation with his copilot. He didn’t hear the latter’s remark about the wing as a suggestion to turn back, nor did he understand that questions about the instrument readings were a plea to abort takeoff. The pilot failed to put the pieces together and make sense of the conversation as a whole. And there may also have been failure on the copilot’s part to recognize that he would have to be much more insistent to get through to his higher-ranking captain.

他还忽略了自己当时正在与副驾驶进行谈判的事实。他没有把副驾驶关于机翼的评论理解为返航的建议，也没有意识到询问仪表读数实际上是请求中止起飞。这位飞行员未能将所有信息串联起来，理解整个对话的含义。而且，副驾驶可能也没有意识到，他必须更加坚持己见才能让级别更高的机长明白他的意思。

Contrast the Potomac case with the miraculous landing of US Airways flight 1549 in New York’s Hudson River on January 15, 2009. What was supposed to be a routine flight quickly became an emergency when a bird strike took out both engines minutes after takeoff. The tape of Captain Chesley “Sully” Sullenberger’s communication with air-traffic controllers is a riveting example of the tough-mindedness that Colonel Boyd insisted upon.

将波托马克事件与2009年1月15日全美航空1549号航班在纽约哈德逊河的奇迹般迫降进行对比。原本应该是一次例行飞行，起飞几分钟后，由于鸟击导致双引擎失效，迅速演变成一场紧急事件。切斯利·“萨利”·萨伦伯格机长与空中交通管制员的通话录音，生动地展现了博伊德上校所坚持的坚韧不拔的精神。

Sullenberger first reported that he had lost thrust and would return to New York’s LaGuardia Airport. Mere seconds later, he was told that a runway was being cleared for him, but the pilot replied, “Unable.”

萨伦伯格最初报告说飞机失去推力，将返回纽约拉瓜迪亚机场。仅仅几秒钟后，他就被告知跑道正在为他清理，但飞行员回答说：“不行。”

The controller apparently still hadn’t grasped the urgency of the situation and offered a different runway. Sullenberger answered, “I’m not sure if we can make any runway. What’s over to our right? Anything in New Jersey, maybe Teterboro?”

管制员显然还没意识到情况的紧迫性，又提议使用另一条跑道。萨伦伯格回答说：“我不确定我们能不能使用任何跑道。我们右边有什么？新泽西州那边的跑道吗？泰特伯勒机场怎么样？”

The controller confirmed Teterboro’s availability and identified a runway, but Sullenberger saw that he was losing speed and altitude. “We can’t do it,” he radioed.

管制员确认了泰特伯勒机场的可用性并指定了一条跑道，但萨伦伯格发现飞机正在失去速度和高度。“我们做不到，”他通过无线电说道。

Again the controller’s awareness was a beat behind, so he asked, “Okay, which runway would you like at Teterboro?”

管制员的反应又慢了一步，于是他问道：“好的，您想在泰特伯勒机场使用哪条跑道？”

“We’re gonna be in the Hudson,” the pilot replied, his mind fixed on landing the plane safely.

“我们要飞到哈德逊河上了，”飞行员回答道，他一心想着安全降落飞机。

Sullenberger recognized the mismatch between what he expected and the peril he was now facing. As his Airbus A320-216 lost altitude, he just as swiftly accepted that the fallback he would have preferred—landing at Teterboro—wouldn’t work either. He wasted no time thinking about what might have been or how he might be second-guessed later. As his alternatives dwindled, his entire attention was directed at doing his best in a harrowing situation. Sullenberger executed a water landing that was smooth enough to keep the aircraft intact and floating. While passengers and crew waited on the wings for rescue boats, the captain himself remained inside to inspect the plane from front to back to make sure that everyone else had exited safely.

萨伦伯格意识到他预想的情况与眼前的险境截然不同。随着他的空客A320-216飞机逐渐下降高度，他迅速接受了原本希望的备选方案——降落在泰特伯勒机场——也行不通的事实。他没有浪费时间去想其他可能的结果，也没有去担心日后会被人质疑。随着选择越来越少，他全身心地投入到应对这惊心动魄的局面中。萨伦伯格成功地完成了水上迫降，飞机平稳地保持了完整并漂浮在水面上。当乘客和机组人员在机翼上等待救援船只时，机长本人则留在机舱内，从前到后仔细检查飞机，确保所有人都安全撤离。

DECIDE: WHEN MUST WE CHOOSE?

做出决定：我们何时必须做出选择？

Observing and orienting set up deciding and acting. But even if you perform the first two steps well, there will likely be ambiguity about how other parties will respond to what you choose to do and say. If you’re thinking about making a concession, can you be sure that your counterpart will reciprocate? Or if you issue a threat, will the other side back down or respond in kind?

观察和判断是决策和行动的基础。但即便你前两步做得很好，对方对你选择采取的行动和所说的话的反应也可能存在不确定性。如果你考虑做出让步，你能确定对方会做出相应的回应吗？或者，如果你发出威胁，对方会退缩还是会以牙还牙？

In their book Make Your Own Luck: 12 Practical Steps to Taking Smarter Risks in Business , Eileen Shapiro and Howard Stevenson say that “acting in the face of uncertainty is scary, because you are acting before all the facts are in—though in truth you are always acting before all the facts are in, whether you are doing what you planned to do or making a shift based on new information.” Deciding to do one thing can eliminate other possibilities. Either you put the first offer on the table or wait for the other side to lay down its demand, but you can’t do both. Psychological research on “loss aversion” shows that trimming options feels painful.

在他们的著作《创造你的运气：在商业中更明智地承担风险的12个实用步骤》中，艾琳·夏皮罗和霍华德·史蒂文森指出：“在不确定性面前采取行动令人恐惧，因为你是在掌握所有事实之前就采取行动——尽管事实上，无论你是按原计划行事，还是根据新信息做出调整，你总是在掌握所有事实之前就采取行动。” 决定做一件事可能会排除其他可能性。你要么主动提出报价，要么等待对方提出要求，但你不能两者兼顾。关于“损失厌恶”的心理学研究表明，减少选择会让人感到痛苦。

Vacillation is a cardinal sin in the US Marine Corps. According to David Freedman, author of Corps Business: The 30 Management Principles of the U.S. Marines, the marines regard it as even “worse than making a mediocre decision, because a mediocre decision, especially if swiftly rendered and executed, at least stands a chance.” There’s a time to develop your options, but there comes a time to exercise them. The more alternatives you keep open, the more factors there are to analyze and manage. Even the greatest chess players don’t contemplate all the eventualities. There are just too many. A player looking forward eight moves would confront more options than there are stars in the galaxy.

在美国海军陆战队，犹豫不决是大忌。据《海军陆战队事务：美国海军陆战队的30项管理原则》一书的作者大卫·弗里德曼所说，海军陆战队员认为犹豫不决甚至“比做出平庸的决定更糟糕，因为平庸的决定，尤其是在迅速做出并执行的情况下，至少还有一线生机”。制定方案固然重要，但更重要的是付诸行动。你保留的备选方案越多，需要分析和管理的因素就越多。即使是最伟大的棋手也无法考虑到所有可能的情况，因为可能性实在太多了。一个棋手如果只考虑未来八步，他所面临的选择将比银河系中的恒星还要多。

Sometimes you can hedge, of course. Even when the US Marines have only a short time to plan for combat, they prepare for both the most likely and the most dangerous courses of action the enemy might take. Having a bump plan in reserve prepares them for the probable turn of events and also the most threatening.

当然，有时候可以采取一些应对措施。即使美国海军陆战队只有很短的时间来制定作战计划，他们也会为敌人最有可能采取的行动以及最危险的行动做好准备。制定一个备用方案，既能让他们应对可能发生的变故，也能让他们应对最具威胁的局面。

A bias for action is a counterweight to inertia. I’m talking about an inclination, not an ironclad rule to leap before looking. You shouldn’t be rash. Sometimes waiting and seeing are best. Nevertheless, your general tendency should be to press ahead even when some important facts are still hazy. The test of that proposition is spelling out when taking action would be un wise or premature. Specifically, standing pat makes sense provided that:

行动倾向是对抗惯性的制衡力量。我指的是一种倾向，而不是不经思考就贸然行动的铁律。你不应该鲁莽行事。有时候，等待和观察才是最佳选择。然而，你的总体倾向应该是即使一些重要事实仍然模糊不清，也要勇往直前。检验这一论断的关键在于，明确指出何时采取行动是不明智的或为时过早的。具体而言，在以下情况下，按兵不动是合理的：

• It’s costless. That is, if all your options remain open and you won’t lose credibility.

• 这是零成本的。前提是你的所有选择都仍然开放，而且你不会因此失去信誉。

• You believe that time is on your side and your options will improve.

• 你相信时间站在你这边，你的选择会越来越好。

• There’s a good chance that by learning more, you can make a wiser choice.

• 通过了解更多信息，你很有可能做出更明智的选择。

• Sleeping on the decision will make you more comfortable with your choice.

• 多考虑一下你的决定，你会对自己的选择更加满意。

On the other hand, the less true that one or more of those factors appears to be, the more likely it’s time to take a deep breath and move ahead.

另一方面，如果这些因素中的一个或多个看起来不太属实，那么就越有可能应该深吸一口气，继续前进。

Making a decision is invigorating. It deepens commitment and heightens awareness. This is true in many domains. Academy Award winner Russell Crowe is fierce about making choices when creating a movie character for himself: getting down an accent, sensing how the person would move, what he’d wear, and how he’d look. “As [director Martin] Scorsese said, ‘Man, you don’t get anywhere until you make a decision,’ ” he once recalled. “So start making decisions quickly, you know. But be open and lucid enough and fluid enough to change your mind if you prove yourself wrong. Okay?”

做决定令人精神振奋。它能加深投入，提升认知。这在很多领域都是如此。奥斯卡影帝罗素·克劳在塑造电影角色时，对每一个选择都极其认真：琢磨口音，感受角色的举止、穿着和外貌。“正如（导演马丁·）斯科塞斯所说，‘伙计，你不做决定就寸步难行，’”他曾回忆道。“所以，要尽快做出决定。但也要保持开放、清醒和灵活的心态，以便在发现自己错了的时候能够及时改变主意。明白吗？”

ACT: WHAT SHOULD WE LEARN BY TAKING ACTION?

行动：我们通过采取行动应该学到什么？

Deciding and acting give you the edge in framing choices for your counterparts, rather than their framing the choices for you. Stirring the pot also can dispel uncertainty. Colonel Boyd drew on Napoléon for the proposition that “early tactics, without apparent design, operate in a fluid, adaptable manner to uncover, expand, and exploit adversaries’ vulnerabilities and weakness.” Smoking out other parties’ positions and intentions works, however, only if you are able to make sense of what occurs as a result of your actions.

主动决策和行动能让你在为对手构建选择框架时占据优势，而不是被对手牵着鼻子走。搅动局势也能消除不确定性。博伊德上校曾引用拿破仑的观点，认为“早期战术，即使没有明显的计划，也能以灵活多变的方式运作，从而发现、扩大并利用对手的弱点和薄弱环节。”然而，只有当你能够理解自身行动的后果时，探明对方的立场和意图才能奏效。

Jenny Rudolph conducts research at Massachusetts General Hospital on how doctors diagnose problems and prescribe treatment in cases where time is short and information is incomplete and ambiguous. Her findings are both instructive and unsettling. One of her experiments was set in an operating room with residents training to be anesthesiologists. Rather than putting an actual patient at risk, Rudolph used a highly realistic mannequin wired up to monitors that registered simulated pulse, blood pressure, and respiration. The twenty-nine-year-old “patient” had been prepped and sedated for an emergency appendectomy, but suddenly it developed problems breathing.

珍妮·鲁道夫在麻省总医院进行一项研究，探讨医生如何在时间紧迫、信息不完整或模糊的情况下诊断病情并制定治疗方案。她的研究结果既具有启发意义，又令人不安。她的一项实验是在手术室进行的，参与者是正在接受麻醉师培训的住院医师。为了避免让真正的病人面临风险，鲁道夫使用了一个高度逼真的人体模型，模型连接着监测设备，可以模拟脉搏、血压和呼吸。这个29岁的“病人”已经做好术前准备并接受了镇静，准备进行紧急阑尾切除手术，但突然出现了呼吸困难。

Rudolph observed the spontaneous decision-making strategies these doctors used. She cataloged four types of practitioners:

鲁道夫观察了这些医生所采用的自发决策策略。她将医生分为四类：

1. Stalled.
1. 停滞不前。

Two of the thirty-nine doctors in the study didn’t know where to begin. Their patients died.

研究中的39名医生中有2名不知道从何入手。他们的病人最终去世了。

2. Fixated.
2. 固定。

Eleven doctors made a quick and sensible diagnosis—only it was wrong in this particular case. They stuck with it even as the patient’s condition was deteriorating. These patients died as well.

十一位医生迅速做出了看似合理的诊断——只是在这个病例中却是错误的。即使病人病情不断恶化，他们仍然坚持己见。这些病人最终也都去世了。

3. Diagnostic Vagabonds.
3. 诊断流浪者。

Seventeen others avoided this trap. They were open minded but too much so. They jumped from one possibility to another so quickly that they could not identify what treatment was working and what was not. None of their patients survived either.

另有十七人避免了这种陷阱。他们思想开放，但过于开放。他们迅速地从一种可能性跳到另一种可能性，以至于无法分辨哪种治疗方法有效，哪种无效。他们的病人也无一幸免。

4. Adaptive Problem Solvers.
4. 自适应问题解决者。

The nine remaining doctors initially reached the same conclusion as did the “fixated” group, but unlike them, they treated it as a platform for further testing and not a certainty. Unlike the vagabonds, they didn’t drop a diagnosis until there was clear cause for doing so. Seven of the nine adaptive problem solvers found the real cause of the patient’s problem before she “expired.”

剩下的九位医生最初得出的结论与“固执己见”的医生组相同，但与他们不同的是，他们将此视为进一步检验的平台，而非确凿无疑的结论。与那些“流浪医生”不同，他们直到有明确的理由才放弃诊断。这九位适应性强的医生中，有七位在病人“去世”前找到了她问题的真正根源。

It is sobering that the vast majority of subjects—all smart, well-educated people—were unable to diagnose and treat a problem in a systematic, practical way. There’s little evidence that negotiators do much better. Having seen and talked with many of them over the years, my sense is that they fall into similar categories. Some have trouble getting started. They’re not stalled, exactly—events may push them along—but they’re largely reactive. They don’t choose a course of action. Instead, the other party sets the course.

令人深思的是，绝大多数受访者——他们都是聪明且受过良好教育的人——都无法系统、切实地诊断和解决问题。几乎没有证据表明谈判者在这方面做得更好。多年来，我接触过许多谈判者，我的感觉是他们大致可以归为几类。有些人难以着手。他们并非停滞不前——事态发展可能会推动他们前进——但他们大多是被动的。他们不主动选择行动方案，而是由对方来决定方向。

Then there are the fixated types. A negotiation colleague of mine describes such people as “often wrong, never in doubt.” Dealing with them is frustrating. They make their plans, charge ahead, and keep on charging even when it should be clear that it’s time to change direction. French philosopher Émile Chartier observed, “Nothing is more dangerous than an idea when it is the only one you have.”

还有一些固执己见的人。我的一位谈判界同事这样形容这类人：“他们常常犯错，却从不怀疑自己。”与他们打交道令人沮丧。他们制定计划，一意孤行，即使明明应该改变方向，也依然我行我素。法国哲学家埃米尔·夏蒂埃曾说过：“没有什么比你只有一种想法更危险的了。”

By contrast, negotiation vagabonds pinball their way through the process. They have no apparent method for choosing a path or weighing alternatives. They overreact to whatever they saw or heard most recently. They may be conciliatory one moment and hostile the next. They may seem poised to say yes to an agreement but at the last minute chase after another deal.

相比之下，谈判中的“流浪汉”们就像弹珠一样在谈判过程中漫无目的地游荡。他们似乎没有选择路径或权衡各种方案的明确方法。他们对最近看到或听到的任何事情都反应过度。他们可能前一秒还表现得和蔼可亲，下一秒就变得充满敌意。他们可能看起来准备同意一项协议，但在最后一刻却又急于达成另一项交易。

Successful negotiators are flexible but not erratic. They start with a clear hypothesis about how to approach a case but then test it. If their initial assumption is basically sound, each cycle of observing and orienting helps them recalibrate their position so that their strategic and tactical adjustments become progressively smaller. But if their expectations are off the mark, they recognize the mismatch and let them go in the spirit of Gary Klein’s advice about having strong ideas held weakly.

成功的谈判者灵活而不失策略。他们首先会有一个清晰的假设来处理问题，然后进行验证。如果最初的假设基本正确，那么每一次观察和调整都会帮助他们重新校准立场，从而使战略和战术上的调整幅度逐渐减小。但如果预期与实际情况不符，他们会意识到这种不匹配，并按照加里·克莱因关于“坚定信念，但不要过于执着”的建议，果断放弃。

If I could pick whom I’d want to deal with in an important negotiation, it would be an adaptive learner. I couldn’t hope to dominate or manipulate her—she’d be too smart for that—but she’d be someone with whom I could work. She’d see that I was ready to get down to business. And like Erin Egan, she’d recognize when I really mean no on a given issue and not waste time trying to get me to bend. Instead, the adaptive learner would reorient and look for another way to attack the problem. Of course, I’d have to be at my best too. I wouldn’t want to degrade my counterpart’s ability to make good decisions—negotiation is different from combat, in this respect—but I’d want my OODA loop to be at least as fast as hers.

如果让我选择在重要谈判中合作的对象，我会选择一位适应性强的学习者。我不可能掌控或操纵她——她太聪明了，做不到——但她会是我可以合作的对象。她会看出我已经准备好进入正题。而且，就像艾琳·伊根一样，她会明白我何时真的拒绝某个问题，不会浪费时间试图让我妥协。相反，这位适应性强的学习者会重新调整策略，寻找解决问题的其他方法。当然，我也必须保持最佳状态。我不想削弱对方的决策能力——谈判与战斗在这方面截然不同——但我希望我的OODA循环至少能和她一样快。

It’s easy to recite the observe-orient-decide-act mantra, but each step must be executed well. Failing to spot a mismatch subverts the whole process. So does indecision. You have to monitor your own behavior to make sure that it aligns with your intentions. Are you saying no too readily? (Or yes, for that matter?) Are you talking at the expense of listening? Are you too comfortable? Do you need to push harder or risk floating an off-the-wall idea? You may then pledge to be more curious and open minded (or to have more backbone, if that’s what is lacking).

背诵“观察-判断-决策-行动”这套流程很容易，但每一步都必须认真执行。如果未能发现任何不匹配之处，整个过程就会功亏一篑。犹豫不决也是如此。你必须审视自己的行为，确保它与你的意图一致。你是否太容易说“不”？（或者，说“是”也一样？）你是否只顾自己说而忽略了倾听？你是否过于安逸？你是否需要更加努力，或者冒险提出一些看似异想天开的想法？之后，你或许应该下定决心，让自己更加好奇、更加开放（或者，如果缺乏的是勇气，那就更有魄力）。

It’s hard to face up to our own shortcomings, of course, and all too easy to be overconfident about our ability to observe and learn. A leader who ruled his country for more than forty years put it well: “The truly strange thing in your lives is that you not only fail, but you fail to learn your lesson . . . No matter how much your beliefs betray you, this is never accepted by you. You are distinguished by your inability to recognize the truth, no matter how irrefutable.”

当然，承认自身的缺点很难，而对自己的观察和学习能力却很容易过分自信。一位统治国家四十余年的领导人曾精辟地指出：“你们人生中最奇怪的事情在于，你们不仅失败，而且还无法从中吸取教训……无论你们的信念如何背叛你们，你们都永远不会接受。你们的显著特点在于无法认清真相，无论真相多么无可辩驳。”

It is one thing to recognize this truth in the abstract, but it’s another to live by it. The writer was the Libyan leader Mu‘ammar Gadafi, who several years later refused political asylum even as his regime was collapsing around him. Gaddafi was captured, beaten, and killed by rebel forces.

在理论上认识到这个真理是一回事，践行它又是另一回事。这句话的作者是利比亚领导人穆阿迈尔·卡扎菲，几年后，即便他的政权已摇摇欲坠，他仍然拒绝寻求政治庇护。卡扎菲最终被反叛武装俘虏、殴打致死。

PLANS VERSUS PLANNING

计划与规划

What happens to strategy if everything is in flux? General Dwight Eisenhower, architect of the D-day invasion that paved the way to an Allied victory in World War II, said famously, “Plans are worthless.” What’s forgotten is that he added, “Planning is everything.”

如果一切都在变化，战略会变成什么样？二战盟军最终取得胜利的诺曼底登陆战役的策划者德怀特·艾森豪威尔将军曾说过一句名言：“计划毫无价值。” 但人们往往忘记了，他还补充道：“计划至关重要。”

That’s not a contradiction. In any context, a well-conceived planning process sharpens objectives, exposes possible obstacles, and illuminates potential paths, even though the exact route may not be determined until the interaction is well under way. Plans can only be provisional, whether they are for combat, launching a new business, making a deal, or resolving a dispute. In both warfare and negotiation, the fog of uncertainty, unknowns, and changing circumstances make anticipating every possibility impossible. US Marine Corps doctrine states:

这并非自相矛盾。在任何情况下，精心设计的计划流程都能明确目标、发现潜在障碍并指明方向，即便最终路径可能要等到互动进行到一定程度才能确定。无论是作战、创业、达成交易还是解决争端，计划都只能是暂时的。在战争和谈判中，不确定性、未知因素和不断变化的环境都使得预见所有可能性成为不可能。美国海军陆战队条令指出：

“ The further ahead we think, the less our actual influence becomes. Therefore, the further ahead we consider, the less precision we should attempt to impose. Looking ahead thus becomes less a matter of influence and more a matter of laying the groundwork for possible future actions. As events approach and our ability to influence them grows, we have already developed an appreciation for the situation and how we want to shape it.”

“我们思考得越远，实际影响力就越小。因此，我们考虑得越远，就越不应该追求精确。展望未来与其说是为了施加影响，不如说是为了给未来可能的行动奠定基础。随着事件临近，我们影响事件的能力也随之增强，我们已经对形势以及我们希望如何塑造形势有了更清晰的认识。”

This reality complicates coordination and planning in the military, especially communication between high-level officers who devise strategy and troops in the field who must execute it. A similar challenge occurs in business between senior managers who create marketing campaigns or oversee procurement, and the salespeople and purchasing agents who conduct the actual deals.

这种现实使得军队的协调和计划变得更加复杂，尤其是在制定战略的高级军官和必须执行战略的一线部队之间沟通方面。类似的挑战也存在于商业领域，即负责制定营销活动或监督采购的高级管理人员与实际执行交易的销售人员和采购代理之间。

The solution in the military has been to distinguish means and ends when giving orders. The Marine Corps’s Warfighting manual states that every mission has two parts: the task and the intent behind it. “The task denotes what is to be done, and sometimes when and where ; the intent explains why . Of the two, the intent is predominant.”

军队的解决方案是在下达命令时区分手段和目的。海军陆战队的作战手册指出，每项任务都包含两部分：任务本身及其背后的意图。“任务指明要做什么，有时还包括何时何地去做；意图则解释了为什么。在这两者中，意图更为重要。”

When changed circumstances make a specific task obsolete, soldiers can look to its underlying purpose and devise another way of accomplishing it. “It is this freedom for initiative that permits the high tempo of operations that we desire. Uninhibited by restrictions from above, subordinates can adapt their actions to the changing situation. They inform the commander what they have done, but they do not wait for permission.”

当情况发生变化导致某项任务过时时，士兵可以探究其根本目的，并找到其他完成任务的方法。“正是这种自主性使得我们能够实现所需的快节奏作战。不受上级限制，下属可以根据不断变化的情况调整行动。他们会向指挥官汇报自己的行动，但无需等待许可。”

Officers are drilled to make their statements of intent clear and concise. For instance, intent might be expressed as “control the bridge in order to prevent the enemy from escaping across the river.” An ambiguous statement could be misconstrued to justify an action contrary to what the commander actually meant or leave troops baffled about what to do next. Soldiers are told to ask for clear directions if none have been given.

军官们接受过严格的训练，必须清晰简洁地表达意图。例如，意图可以表述为“控制桥梁，阻止敌人渡河逃脱”。含糊不清的表述可能会被误解，从而导致采取与指挥官实际意图相悖的行动，或者让士兵们不知所措。士兵们被告知，如果没有得到明确的指示，就应该主动询问。

Karl Weick, a renowned organizational theorist at the University of Michigan, has adapted the concept of commander’s intent to leadership in general. Indeed, his distillation of what leaders need to convey instructions is itself a model of clarity:

密歇根大学著名组织理论家卡尔·韦克将指挥官意图的概念应用于领导力领域。事实上，他对领导者传达指令所需要素的提炼本身就是清晰表达的典范：

Situation:

情况：

Here’s what I think we face.

我认为我们面临的是这样的情况。

Task:

任务：

Here’s what I think we should do.

我认为我们应该这样做。

Intent:

意图：

Here’s why.

原因如下。

Concerns:

担忧：

Here’s what we should watch for.

以下是我们应该关注的事项。

Feedback:

反馈：

Now, talk to me.

现在，跟我说说吧。

Negotiating on behalf of others—your company, organization, or client—is exasperating when people whose interests you’re trying to serve can’t explain their priorities coherently. While that may be their failing, it can be yours, too, if you don’t press for clarification. Likewise, if you ask others to negotiate for you, state your underlying intent so that they can improvise intelligently when circumstances change. To sharpen your description of what you want to achieve, be explicit about what you don’t want to happen. Often when you negotiate, of course, you will report only to yourself. When selling a house or seeking a new job, don’t confuse plans with planning, or short-term means for long-term ends. Remembering your fundamental intent will allow you to employ a robust strategy.

代表他人（公司、组织或客户）进行谈判时，如果对方无法清晰地阐述他们的优先事项，那将令人非常恼火。虽然这可能是他们的失误，但如果你不追问，也可能是你的失误。同样地，如果你请他人为你谈判，务必阐明你的根本意图，以便他们在情况发生变化时能够灵活应对。为了更清晰地描述你想要达成的目标，请明确说明你不希望发生的事情。当然，谈判时，你通常只会向自己汇报。在出售房屋或寻找新工作时，不要将计划与规划混淆，也不要用短期手段来实现长期目标。牢记你的根本意图，才能让你制定出有效的策略。

On June 5, 1944, the eve of the Normandy landings, Eisenhower radioed a stirring order to American forces in Britain waiting to cross the treacherous English Channel. “You are about to embark on the great crusade,” he said. “The tide has turned! The free men of the world are marching to victory!”

1944年6月5日，诺曼底登陆前夕，艾森豪威尔向驻扎在英国等待渡过险恶英吉利海峡的美军发出了一份激动人心的无线电命令。“你们即将踏上伟大的征程，”他说。“战局已经逆转！全世界的自由人民正走向胜利！”

Tucked into his wallet, however, was a second message, which he had scrawled on flimsy notepaper and was holding in reserve. “Our landings in the Cherbourg and Havre area have failed to gain a satisfactory foothold, and I have withdrawn the troops,” it said. “If any blame or fault attaches to the attempt, it is mine alone.”

然而，他的钱包里还藏着第二张纸条，那是他潦草地写在薄薄的便笺纸上，留作备用。“我们在瑟堡和勒阿弗尔地区的登陆行动未能取得令人满意的立足点，我已经撤回了部队，”纸条上写道。“如果这次行动有任何过错或失误，那都是我个人的责任。”

Fortunately for the world, Ike never had to deliver that second message, but privately he allowed for the possibility of failure. In spite of unprecedented preparation—the massing of ships, planes, armament, and hundreds of thousands of military personnel—he knew that success was not guaranteed.

幸运的是，艾克最终不必传达第二个信息，但私下里，他确实考虑到了失败的可能性。尽管做了前所未有的准备——集结了舰艇、飞机、武器装备和数十万军事人员——他仍然明白成功并非唾手可得。

LEARNING ON THE GROUND

实地学习

In conflicts today, soldiers must be prepared both to fight hostile forces and to negotiate with local officials, contractors, and citizens caught in the cross fire. In 1997, Marine Corps general Charles Krulak described the scope of future military missions:

在当今的冲突中，士兵必须做好与敌对势力作战以及与被卷入交火的当地官员、承包商和平民进行谈判的准备。1997年，海军陆战队上将查尔斯·克鲁拉克描述了未来军事任务的范围：

“In one moment in time, our service members will be feeding and clothing displaced refugees, providing humanitarian assistance. In the next moment, they will be holding two warring tribes apart—conducting peacekeeping operations—and, finally, they will be fighting a highly lethal midintensity battle—all in the same day . . . all within three city blocks. It will be what we call the ‘three-block war.’ ”

“前一刻，我们的军人还在为流离失所的难民提供食物和衣物，提供人道主义援助；下一刻，他们就可能要隔离两个交战的部落——执行维和行动；而最后，他们又会投入一场高强度、高伤亡的战斗——所有这些都将在同一天发生……而且都发生在三个街区之内。这就是我们所说的‘三街区战争’。”

In 2007 Major Leonard Lira was sent to Iraq for a second tour. The task of his unit—the 2-14 Cavalry—was securing Taji, a town just north of Baghdad. Lira and other senior officers were told to stop the flow of insurgents transporting arms, explosive devices, and suicide bombers. They concluded that security could more likely be achieved by promoting reconciliation in that area rather than using lethal means. One of the army-sponsored projects was improving local irrigation systems so that farmers would have income and city dwellers would have much-needed food. Experts from the US Department of Agriculture engineered an efficient design. Lira’s unit had the job of getting local factions to work together to get the system built.

2007年，伦纳德·利拉少校第二次被派往伊拉克。他所在的部队——第2-14骑兵团——的任务是确保巴格达北部城镇塔吉的安全。利拉和其他高级军官奉命阻止叛乱分子运送武器、爆炸装置和自杀式炸弹袭击者。他们认为，与其使用致命手段，不如通过促进当地和解来更有可能实现安全。军方资助的项目之一是改善当地的灌溉系统，以便农民能够获得收入，城市居民能够获得急需的粮食。美国农业部的专家设计了一套高效的灌溉系统。利拉所在的部队的任务是促使当地各派系合作，共同建设这套系统。

Prior to deployment, members of Lira’s unit were given negotiation training. They had been taught about zones of agreement, BATNAs (walkaway options), and other familiar concepts. Staff had also practiced role playing exercises. “Although the training was extensive,” Lira said later, “none of it adequately prepared the unit for what it encountered in Iraq.”

在部署之前，利拉所在部队的成员接受了谈判训练。他们学习了协商一致区域、最佳替代方案（BATNA）以及其他一些熟悉的概念。工作人员还进行了角色扮演练习。“尽管训练内容很广泛，”利拉后来表示，“但这些训练都不足以让部队为在伊拉克遇到的情况做好准备。”

Lira had initially organized forums to foster collaboration. “All of the tribes made public declarations of reconciliation,” he said, “but away from the forum table, they would return to their entrenched positions and try to exclude each other from the local committee.” The new irrigation ditches were often blocked or sabotaged. Violent conflicts sometimes ensued.

利拉最初组织论坛是为了促进合作。“所有部落都公开宣布和解，”他说，“但离开论坛后，他们又会回到各自根深蒂固的立场，试图将对方排除在地方委员会之外。”新建的灌溉渠经常遭到堵塞或破坏。有时甚至会引发暴力冲突。

At first Al Qaeda in Iraq was blamed. It turned out, though, that most of the trouble was caused by certain farmers who were trying to squeeze out competitors by cutting off their water supply. Lira’s team had been working with “Negotiation 1.0 tools,” as he termed them, but the simple “linear, lockstep, checklist” prescriptions just didn’t apply in the complex and fast-changing environment they faced. Lira turned to other frameworks to deal with planning in dynamic contexts. “Once we gained the rest of the story on why the water wasn’t flowing,” he explained, “we were able to help the local reconciliation council and city government lead a negotiation process to allow the irrigation canals to function correctly.”

起初，伊拉克基地组织被指责为罪魁祸首。但事实证明，大部分问题是由一些农民造成的，他们试图通过切断竞争对手的水源来挤垮他们。利拉的团队一直在使用他所谓的“谈判1.0工具”，但这种简单的“线性、固定步骤、清单式”方法在他们面临的复杂且瞬息万变的环境中根本行不通。利拉转而采用其他框架来应对动态环境下的规划。“一旦我们了解了水源中断的真正原因，”他解释说，“我们就能够帮助当地调解委员会和市政府主导谈判进程，从而使灌溉渠恢复正常运转。”

This change in negotiation strategy exemplifies double-loop learning. It involves rapid OODA assessment of your micromoves and their consequences. But on a second, higher level, it entails critical reflection on whether you are looking at a problem in the right way. Lira had the discipline to dispense with his Negotiation 1.0 tool kit and develop a more sophisticated approach. The negotiation practices of the 2-14 Cavalry became a model for army units elsewhere.

这种谈判策略的转变体现了双环学习。它包括对你的微行动及其后果进行快速的OODA循环评估。但从更高层次上看，它还要求你批判性地反思自己看待问题的方式是否正确。利拉有足够的自律性，摒弃了他原有的谈判1.0工具包，并发展出一套更为精细的方法。第2-14骑兵团的谈判实践成为了其他部队的典范。

Military negotiators also have to be agile in the moment. In 2003, in the early days of the war in Iraq, Lieutenant Colonel Chris Hughes led a unit of soldiers to meet with Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani in Najaf to help build local support for the American effort. A growing crowd of civilians was anxious about the soldiers’ intentions and alarmed that they might be about to violate the sanctity of the nearby mosque. Rumors, perhaps started by agitators, flew quickly that the Americans were there to arrest the ayatollah.

军事谈判人员也必须具备临场应变能力。2003年，伊拉克战争初期，克里斯·休斯中校率领一支部队前往纳杰夫会见大阿亚图拉阿里·西斯塔尼，旨在争取当地民众对美军行动的支持。越来越多的平民聚集在此，他们对士兵的意图感到担忧，并担心他们可能会亵渎附近清真寺的圣地。谣言迅速传播开来，或许是某些煽动者散布的，称美军此行的目的是逮捕阿亚图拉。

To Dan Baum, a New Yorker writer watching on television in the States, it looked like a disaster in the making. “The Iraqis were shrieking, frantic with rage,” he wrote later. “From the way the lens was lurching, the cameraman seemed as frightened as the soldiers. This is it, I thought. A shot will come from somewhere, the Americans will open fire, and the world will witness the My Lai massacre of the Iraq war.”

对于身在美国通过电视观看的《纽约客》撰稿人丹·鲍姆来说，这看起来像是一场即将发生的灾难。“伊拉克人尖叫着，怒火中烧，”他后来写道。“从镜头晃动的姿态来看，摄影师似乎和士兵们一样害怕。我想，完了。枪声会从某个地方传来，美国人会开火，全世界将目睹伊拉克战争中的美莱村大屠杀。”

But that didn’t happen. Hughes and his soldiers didn’t try to force their way down the packed street. Nor was a single shot fired. Instead, Hughes stepped forward, holding his rifle high but pointed downward. “Smile,” he said to his troops. “Don’t point your weapons at ’em. Relax.” He then ordered them to kneel and point their weapons down, as he had done. When the tension abated, he said, “Calmly stand up and move backward. Continue smiling.” The soldiers withdrew. Hughes bowed his head slightly to the crowd and let communication with the ayatollah wait for another day.

但这一切并未发生。休斯和他的士兵没有试图强行挤过拥挤的街道，也没有开一枪。相反，休斯向前走了一步，高举步枪，但枪口朝下。“微笑，”他对士兵们说，“不要用枪指着他们。放松。”然后，他命令他们像他一样跪下，枪口朝下。当紧张的气氛缓和下来后，他说：“冷静地站起来，向后退。继续保持微笑。”士兵们撤退了。休斯向人群微微颔首，决定将与阿亚图拉的会面留待日后。

Hughes hadn’t expected to negotiate with an angry mob that day, nor had he ever been taught the specific gesture of having his troops kneel down. But keeping the purpose of his mission paramount—earning the confidence of the ayatollah and his supporters—enabled him to improvise in the moment. The mosque was the holiest Shia shrine in Iraq. Violence there could incite massive opposition to the US-led coalition. “It was a very deliberate turn,” Hughes explained later. “If somebody shot a round in the air, there was going to be some sort of massacre.” Chris Hughes (now a general) observed the escalating scene, reoriented himself, and acted with patience, respect, and resolve.

休斯那天并没有预料到要与愤怒的暴民谈判，也从未接受过让士兵下跪的特定礼仪训练。但他始终将任务目标放在首位——赢得阿亚图拉及其支持者的信任——这使他能够随机应变。这座清真寺是伊拉克什叶派最神圣的圣地。那里发生的暴力事件可能会激起民众对美国领导的联军的强烈反对。“这是一个经过深思熟虑的转变，”休斯后来解释说，“如果有人朝空中鸣枪，就会发生某种屠杀。”克里斯·休斯（现已晋升为将军）观察着不断升级的局势，调整了自身策略，并以耐心、尊重和坚定的决心采取行动。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Observe, orient, decide, and act—again and again and again.

■ 观察、判断、决定、行动——一遍又一遍。

■ Watch out for mismatches between what you expected and what’s actually unfolding.

■ 注意预期与实际发生的情况之间的差异。

■ Have a bias for action from start to finish.

■ 从始至终都倾向于行动。

■ Prepare for what’s most likely to transpire and for what would be most challenging.

■ 为最有可能发生的情况和最具挑战性的情况做好准备。

#↩

PART 3

第三部分

Managing the Process

流程管理

Consider Northern Ireland, where the ancient conflict known as the Troubles ended, when longtime enemies came together to form a power-sharing government. This was almost eight hundred years after Britain began its domination of Ireland, eighty-six years after the partition of Ireland, thirty-eight years after the British Army formally began its most recent mission in Ireland, eleven years after the peace talks began, and nine years after the peace agreement was signed. In the negotiations which led up to that agreement, we had seven hundred days of failure and one day of success.

以北爱尔兰为例，在那里，被称为“动乱”的古老冲突终于结束，昔日的宿敌走到了一起，组建了权力分享政府。这距离英国开始统治爱尔兰已近八百年，距离爱尔兰分裂已过去八十六年，距离英国军队正式开始其在爱尔兰的最新军事行动已过去三十八年，距离和平谈判开始已过去十一年，距离和平协议签署已过去九年。在达成该协议的谈判过程中，我们经历了七百天的失败，只有一天的成功。

—SENATOR GEORGE MITCHELL, SPECIAL ENVOY TO NORTHERN IRELAND

——乔治·米切尔参议员，北爱尔兰特使

#↩

[ 8 ] Openings

[ 8 ] 开端

Katie Stevenson was toying with a career change. She had gone to work for Hiking magazine right out of college. The people there were fine, and she enjoyed the mix of editorial and administrative work. The pay was ridiculously low, however, and there was little prospect for advancement.

凯蒂·史蒂文森正在考虑换工作。她大学毕业后就直接去了《徒步旅行》杂志社工作。那里的同事都很好，她也很喜欢编辑和行政工作的结合。但是，薪水低得可怜，晋升机会也微乎其微。

A self-described geek, Katie developed a web-hosting business on the side to supplement her income. Within a couple of years, it required full-time attention, so she left the magazine. When her new venture continued to grow, she hired freelancers to handle some of the work. The money was better, though not great, and the hours proved grueling.

自称极客的凯蒂为了补贴家用，兼职做起了网站托管业务。几年后，这项业务需要她全职投入，于是她离开了杂志社。随着新业务的不断发展，她雇佣了一些自由职业者来处理部分工作。收入虽然有所提高，但仍然不算丰厚，而且工作时间也相当辛苦。

As a result, Katie looked into an opening at Pullman Press, a small publishing company she admired. She doubted that the job would be a step up, though, as the firm was advertising for an information technology specialist to upgrade its internal network and automated ordering system. Katie had the necessary technical skill, but she wanted a position with more management responsibility and creative potential.

因此，凯蒂开始关注普尔曼出版社的招聘信息，这家小型出版社是她一直很欣赏的。不过，她也怀疑这份工作是否真的能让她晋升，因为该公司当时正在招聘一名信息技术专家，负责升级内部网络和自动化订购系统。凯蒂具备必要的技术技能，但她更想要一份能够承担更多管理责任、拥有更多创造空间的工作。

She went ahead with an interview nevertheless, thinking that she’d at least expand her contacts. As it happened, Katie hit it off with the Pullman people. She was frank about her reluctance to take a backroom job and went on to describe what she wanted to do: namely, find a place where she could use social media to deliver content and tap into online communities.

尽管如此，她还是决定去面试，心想至少可以拓展一下人脉。结果，凯蒂和普尔曼公司的人一拍即合。她坦诚地表达了自己不太愿意从事幕后工作，并描述了自己的职业规划：她想找一个可以利用社交媒体发布内容、融入线上社群的地方。

The Pullman team was excited about her ideas and impressed by her obvious ability to implement them. Midway through, Katie realized that instead of the casual getting-to-know-you chat she had expected, she was in an important negotiation. Butterflies stirred in her stomach. This new job they were scoping seemed almost too good to be true. “I wish I wasn’t so casual,” she told herself. “I’d better not mess this up.”

普尔曼团队对她的想法很感兴趣，也对她出色的执行能力印象深刻。谈话进行到一半，凯蒂意识到，这并非她预想的轻松的互相了解的聊天，而是一场重要的谈判。她感到一阵紧张。他们正在洽谈的这份新工作似乎好得令人难以置信。“我真希望自己不要这么随意，”她对自己说，“我可不能搞砸了。”

Katie’s mood tumbled, but everybody else still looked relaxed and pleased. She thought to herself that it was easy to be agreeable so long as everything was broad brush, but working out the details would be tricky. Turning the job into a more senior position than was advertised would raise organizational issues. Who’d report to whom? What resources would be shifted into this new initiative? Soon they’d have to tackle the awkward matter of money.

凯蒂的情绪顿时跌落谷底，但其他人看起来依然轻松愉快。她心想，只要事情大致明了，保持顺从很容易，但要落实细节就难了。把这份工作提升到比招聘广告上更高的职位，会引发组织架构方面的问题。谁向谁汇报？哪些资源会转移到这项新计划中？很快，他们就不得不面对棘手的资金问题了。

Everything worked out eventually. It took three follow-up meetings, but Katie got a terrific job at Pullman, where she is prospering. But now, five years later, she still describes her first realization that she was in a negotiation as feeling as if “a cloud was passing over the sun.” To that point, the conversation had been warm and easy. Suddenly she felt a chill.

一切最终都顺利解决了。虽然经历了三次后续会议，凯蒂最终在普尔曼找到了一份非常棒的工作，并且在那里发展得很好。但五年后的今天，她仍然记得自己第一次意识到自己身处谈判之中时的感受，就像“乌云遮住了阳光”。此前，谈话一直轻松愉快。突然间，她感到一阵寒意袭来。

It was the same people in the same room, exploring the same possibilities. The only change was all in Katie’s head. Having a job on the line cast the conversation in shadows. When it seemed that there was nothing to lose, she’d been herself. When the stakes got higher, she started worrying about the impression she was making. “How hard can I push on pay,” she asked herself, “when I don’t have a clue what these guys are getting?” Sure, the Pullman people all seemed congenial, but did some of them have private agendas?

还是那些人，还是那些人，还是那些探讨同样可能性的人。唯一的变化只存在于凯蒂的脑海中。工作岌岌可危让她的谈话蒙上了一层阴影。当一切似乎都无关紧要时，她还能做真实的自己。但随着风险越来越大，她开始担心自己给人的印象。“我到底能在薪酬问题上争取到多少？”她问自己，“我根本不知道这些人拿多少工资。”没错，普尔曼公司的人看起来都很友善，但他们当中会不会有人另有图谋呢？

The irony, of course, is that Katie had gotten that far by being open, engaged, and confident. Had she been guarded and anxious from the start, the possibility of creating a new position might never have arisen. Paradoxically, seeing something as a negotiation can make it harder to reach agreement. It colors our perceptions of people and influences how we relate to them. That’s true whether a negotiation emerges from a conversation, as it did with Katie, or our intent from the outset is making a deal. The impressions and attitudes that are triggered when we realize we are negotiating can have lasting impact on the process—sometimes for the better, though often for the worse. Yes, it’s possible to get off to a poor start and regain our balance later. And we can begin well but run out of energy. But openings matter. Negotiation is challenging enough without making it harder on ourselves by starting on the wrong foot.

当然，讽刺的是，凯蒂之所以能走到今天，正是因为她的坦诚、积极和自信。如果她从一开始就小心翼翼、焦虑不安，那么创造新局面的可能性或许永远不会出现。矛盾的是，把某件事看作是谈判反而会使达成协议更加困难。它会影响我们对他人的看法，并影响我们与他人的相处方式。无论谈判是像凯蒂那样源于对话，还是我们从一开始就打算达成交易，情况都是如此。当我们意识到自己正在谈判时所产生的印象和态度，会对谈判过程产生持久的影响——有时是积极的，但通常是消极的。没错，我们有可能开局不利，但之后又能重回正轨。我们也可能开局不错，但后劲不足。但开局至关重要。谈判本身就充满挑战，如果一开始就走错路，只会让谈判更加艰难。

WHO, WHAT, AND HOW

谁、什么以及如何

This chapter offers a fine-grained analysis of openings. We’ll pay special attention to the dance of negotiation, how what one person says influences whatever his counterpart says next. In the early moments, three important things take place—engaging, framing, and norming—and they happen simultaneously.

本章将对开场白进行细致的分析。我们将特别关注谈判的互动过程，即一方的发言如何影响对方接下来的发言。在谈判初期，有三个重要环节同时发生——建立联系、构建框架和规范化。

Engaging defines the who of negotiation. It’s about identity, roles, and relationships. As social psychologists and neuroscientists have demonstrated, we form judgments of other people ultrafast (just as they do of us). On a visceral level, we label someone as friend or foe. We also measure power and status. At the first hello, we reckon whether dealing with them is going to be easy or hard. The less we know about particular people, the more our impressions are driven by our personality and circumstance. The nature of negotiation in particular can tilt us toward negative assessments. If we’re unsure about whether to trust another party, we may read ambiguous comments and behavior as hostile.

参与决定了谈判的对象。它关乎身份、角色和关系。正如社会心理学家和神经科学家所证明的那样，我们能以极快的速度对他人的判断做出反应（就像他们判断我们一样）。在直觉层面，我们会将某人标记为朋友或敌人。我们也会衡量对方的权力和地位。在初次见面时，我们就会判断与对方打交道是容易还是困难。我们对特定对象了解越少，我们的印象就越容易受到自身性格和所处环境的影响。谈判的性质尤其容易使我们倾向于做出负面评价。如果我们不确定是否应该信任对方，我们可能会将模棱两可的言论和行为解读为敌意。

Framing, in turn, is the what of negotiation. It’s the way the parties define the task. Are we pursuing a partnership, resolving a conflict, or simply haggling? Is this a matter of high principle or is it run of the mill? Such questions can’t be answered unilaterally. They often must be negotiated, though this is rarely done explicitly. The who of negotiation—how the parties see each other relationally—is bound up in what they think they are addressing.

框架构建，反过来，就是谈判的内容。它指的是谈判双方如何定义谈判任务。我们是在寻求伙伴关系、解决冲突，还是仅仅在讨价还价？这是一个关乎崇高原则的问题，还是一件琐碎的小事？这些问题无法单方面解答。它们通常需要通过谈判来解决，尽管这种谈判很少会公开进行。谈判的对象——即谈判双方如何看待彼此的关系——与他们认为自己正在处理的问题息息相关。

Finally, norming is the how of negotiation. It’s the way that parties establish the tone and pace of the process. The how is likewise tightly linked to the who and the what , the manner in which parties relate to one another and define the task at hand. How people actually interact sometimes doesn’t square with their intentions or self-image. Mismatches undermine performance.

最后，规范化是谈判的方式。它指的是各方如何确定谈判的基调和节奏。同样，“方式”也与“对象”和“内容”紧密相关，即各方如何相互联系以及如何定义手头的任务。人们实际的互动方式有时与他们的意图或自我认知并不一致。这种不匹配会损害谈判的成效。

You negotiate how to negotiate each and every time you sit down at the bargaining table. That was brought home to me by a project a colleague and I did several years ago. We videotaped real estate professionals negotiating a long-term deal involving a shopping center about to be built. Participants played the role of either the local developer or a national retailer who might anchor the new mall. We stipulated that most provisions in the agreement had been worked out, but the parties were still deadlocked over the use, assignment, and subletting provisions. The developer wanted strict control over how the leased space would be used, so that the anchor tenant wouldn’t compete with smaller stores in the mall. In turn, the tenant insisted on having flexibility to adapt to changing market conditions. Our participants had been called in to try to bridge this gap.

每次坐到谈判桌前，你都要协商如何谈判。几年前我和一位同事做的一个项目让我对此有了更深刻的体会。我们拍摄了房地产专业人士就一项即将兴建的购物中心的长期租赁协议进行谈判的过程。参与者分别扮演当地开发商或可能成为新购物中心主力店的全国性零售商。我们设定协议的大部分条款已经敲定，但双方在租赁用途、转让和转租条款上仍存在分歧。开发商希望严格控制租赁空间的使用方式，以避免主力店与购物中心内的小商店形成竞争。而主力店则坚持要有灵活性，以适应不断变化的市场环境。我们的参与者被请来试图弥合双方的分歧。

My colleague and I sought to analyze how negotiators tackle tough issues over the contract language that would define the parties’ respective rights and responsibilities. We wanted people to be themselves, so our instructions were simple: Figure out what you want to get, we told them, and figure out how to get it.

我和同事试图分析谈判者如何处理合同条款中关于各方权利和义务的棘手问题。我们希望参与者能够展现真实的自我，因此我们的指示很简单：弄清楚自己想要什么，然后想办法去实现它。

What follows are verbatim transcripts of the opening moments of two separate pairs of professionals negotiating the same lease. As you’ll see, sometimes one party will interrupt the other. Other times a speaker will begin with one thought and then jump to another, without completing his sentence smoothly. That’s the way that people talk. More important, you’ll also see that the two pairs negotiated very differently. Reading text on the printed page isn’t the same as hearing tone of voice or seeing body language, of course, but the contrasting dialogue is striking.

以下是两组专业人士就同一租赁协议进行谈判的开场白逐字记录。你会发现，有时一方会打断另一方。有时，说话者会从一个想法开始，然后突然跳到另一个想法，句子表达得不够流畅。这就是人们说话的方式。更重要的是，你还会发现这两组谈判者的谈判方式截然不同。当然，阅读纸上的文字与聆听语气或观察肢体语言是不同的，但这种对比鲜明的对话确实引人注目。

Their different approaches can’t be explained by culture. These four participants were all white middle-aged male lawyers from the Boston area. Instead, the key variable was how they viewed the negotiation process—specifically, the way that they managed the who , what , and how of opening. We took participants to an on-campus studio and had them sit at a small, round table. Then we flipped on the cameras and left the room. They took it from there. Here’s the first pair:

他们不同的谈判方式无法用文化来解释。这四位参与者都是来自波士顿地区的中年白人男性律师。关键变量在于他们如何看待谈判过程——具体来说，是他们如何处理谈判开场白中的“谁”、“什么”和“如何”这几个环节。我们把参与者带到校园内的一间工作室，让他们围坐在一个小圆桌旁。然后我们打开摄像机，离开了房间。接下来就由他们自己展开讨论。以下是第一组参与者：

Tenant A: Welcome to my office.

租户A：欢迎来到我的办公室。

Developer A: How are you, John? [ Half standing to shake the tenant’s hand. ]

开发商A：约翰，你好吗？（半站着与租户握手。）

Tenant A: Just fine. Good to see you again.

租户A：我很好。很高兴再次见到你。

Developer A: You have nice offices here.

开发商A：你们这里的办公室很不错。

Tenant A: Thank you, thank you. You ought to come out here more often.

租户A：谢谢，谢谢。你应该常来这里看看。

Developer A: Very impressive. Listen, I understand you have a meeting in about forty-five minutes, so we should try to get through these clauses as quickly as we can.

开发人员A：非常棒。听着，我知道你大约四十五分钟后有个会议，所以我们应该尽快处理完这些条款。

Tenant A: Uh-hmm.

租户A：嗯。

Developer A: Frankly, I understand these are the only clauses left to finalize in the deal. It’s important to us to get it closed. We’re ready to start construction.

开发商A：坦白说，我知道这是交易中仅剩的几个需要敲定的条款了。对我们来说，完成交易至关重要。我们已经准备好开工建设了。

Tenant A: Uh-hmm.

租户A：嗯。

Developer A: We have everything set, all our permits, land all under control. Ah, and obviously you’re the key tenant. We need you.

开发商A：我们一切就绪，所有许可证都已办妥，土地也完全在掌控之中。啊，当然，您是关键租户。我们需要您。

Tenant A: Well, we’re well aware of that.

租户A：嗯，我们很清楚这一点。

Developer A: I know that. On the other hand, if we can’t do a deal, we’re going to have to look for somebody else. But I see no reason we can’t reach agreement on these two clauses. I guess as a starting point, you’ve managed to . . . [ pause ] Did you draft this lease?

开发商A：我知道。另一方面，如果我们无法达成协议，我们就得另找他人。但我认为我们完全可以就这两项条款达成一致。我想，作为起点，你已经做到了……（停顿）这份租赁协议是你起草的吗？

Tenant A: I had a hand in it, but our senior corporate counsel did the yeoman’s work.

租户 A：我参与了其中，但我们公司的高级法律顾问做了大量工作。

Developer A: Boy, I must say they’ve come up with the shortest use-and-assignment-and-subletting clause I’ve ever seen. And ah . . .

开发商A：哎呀，我得说，他们想出了我见过的最短的使用、转让和转租条款。啊……

Tenant A: Oh, I’ve seen ’em shorter, but that’s all right.

租户A：哦，我见过更短的，不过没关系。

Developer A: Well, maybe if you eliminated it entirely, it would have been the only thing, but—

开发者A：嗯，或许如果你把它完全移除，那就只剩下它了，但是——

Tenant A: I’d be glad to.

租户A：我很乐意。

Developer A: Well . . .

开发商A：嗯……

Tenant A: Why don’t we do that, then we can all go home and go to lunch.

租户A：我们为什么不那样做呢？这样我们就可以回家吃午饭了。

Developer A: I think that we’d have a good lease. The only problem is I don’t think it would be financeable, and I don’t think we’d get any other tenants. And we don’t want you in there freestanding. You don’t want to be in there freestanding. So I think there’s . . . I’m sure you’ve before . . . you’ve done lots of other deals where there are satellite tenants and have responded to their needs. We’ve certainly done a lot of other deals that way. This is going to be a spectacular regional mall. So let’s try to get into it and see if we can’t reach agreement.

开发商A：我觉得我们可以签一份不错的租赁合同。唯一的问题是，我认为融资可能行不通，而且我觉得我们也找不到其他租户。我们不希望你们在那里独立经营，你们自己也不想。所以我觉得……我相信你们以前……你们做过很多类似的交易，都有卫星租户，也满足了他们的需求。我们当然也做过很多类似的交易。这将是一个非常棒的区域性购物中心。所以，让我们试着谈谈，看看能不能达成协议。

Tenant A: You know what our position is. You and I aren’t going to argue as to what’s financeable or not, but if you think that you can finance a lease with a blackout clause, then the use-and-assignment clause isn’t going to cause any more problems. I wish we shared your enthusiasm for the market. We think it’s going to be a good market, but we’re not willing to take the risk to the extent that you are. You’re the developer. It’s a natural risk for you. We’re willing to go in and anchor your mall. And as you said, you need us—

租户A：您知道我们的立场。你我不会在融资问题上争论什么能不能融资，但如果您认为可以通过包含禁售条款的租赁协议来融资，那么使用和转让条款就不会造成任何问题。我希望我们也能像您一样对市场充满热情。我们认为市场前景不错，但我们不愿意承担像您那样大的风险。您是开发商，这对您来说是自然而然的风险。我们愿意入驻您的购物中心，成为主力租户。正如您所说，您需要我们——

Developer A: No question.

开发商A：没问题。

Tenant A: —maybe more than we need you.

租户A：——或许我们比需要你更多。

This conversation was all unscripted. Ostensibly, these negotiators were laying the foundation for a business relationship that would run a decade or more. Yet in a mere two minutes, the developer states that he’s ready to have someone else anchor his mall, and the tenant answers that’s fine with him. From start to finish, there’s a rat-a-tat-tat of aggressive questions and snide comebacks.

这场对话完全是即兴的。表面上看，这些谈判者似乎在为一段长达十年甚至更久的商业合作关系奠定基础。然而仅仅两分钟后，开发商就表示他愿意让其他商家入驻他的购物中心，而租户也欣然接受。从始至终，双方你来我往，针锋相对，你问我，你回我，你回我。

When I show the video clip in class, I ask people where it went wrong. Often somebody says it’s when the developer talks about finding another tenant. But then someone else usually points out how that comment is a defensive response to the tenant’s flatly saying that he’s “well aware” that the developer needs him. As one viewer put it, “The poor developer extends an olive branch, but the tenant whacks him with it.”

我在课堂上播放这段视频时，会问大家哪里出了问题。通常有人会说问题出在开发商谈到要找其他租户的时候。但随后通常会有人指出，这番话其实是对租户直截了当地表示“我很清楚”开发商需要他这种说法的一种防御性回应。正如一位观众所说：“可怜的开发商伸出了橄榄枝，结果却被租户狠狠地打了一巴掌。”

Others go back even earlier, noting that the parties rush through any pleasantries and jump right into talking about the project. A few are turned off by what they hear as a presumptuous tone when the developer claims it’s necessary to get through “these clauses as quickly as we can,” since they have only forty-five minutes in which to negotiate. These points are all valid. And they’re easy to make if we have the luxury of reflection, after stopping the video or rereading the transcript. If we had time to think, we’d hope to be more adroit ourselves.

还有一些人追溯到更早的时期，注意到双方匆匆略过寒暄，直接进入项目讨论。一些人对开发商的傲慢语气感到反感，开发商声称由于只有45分钟的谈判时间，必须“尽快敲定这些条款”。这些观点都很有道理。如果我们有时间思考，比如暂停视频或重读文字记录，这些观点就很容易理解。如果我们有时间思考，我们希望自己也能更加机敏。

The problem here is more than the sum of the flippant remarks, however. At the heart of it, neither party seems mindful of where the conversation should go. They get caught up in verbal skirmishing, each one intent on topping whatever the other one just said. And remember, we didn’t tell anyone to be antagonistic. These negotiators stumbled into that behavior.

然而，问题远不止这些轻率的言论。归根结底，双方似乎都没有意识到谈话应该朝着哪个方向发展。他们陷入了唇枪舌战，都想在对方刚才说的话上压倒对方。记住，我们并没有要求任何人采取对抗态度。这些谈判者是无意中陷入了这种行为的。

Just look at the long statements that each party makes near the end of the segment. They’re odes to negativity. The developer manages to squeeze a quartet of “don’t”s into a mere ten seconds and throws in a “problem” for good measure. Predictably, the tenant responds in kind, countering that there’s no point in “arguing” whether the lease would be financeable. “You know what our position is,” he says.

看看双方在节目结尾处的长篇发言，简直就是负面情绪的颂歌。开发商在短短十秒钟内就抛出了四条“禁止事项”，还顺带加了一条“问题”。不出所料，租户也予以了反驳，认为“争论”租赁是否可融资毫无意义。“你知道我们的立场，”他说。

In this brief opening segment, the parties have resolved the who question: they will be foes, and the relationship won’t be easy. While they’re still jostling over power—who’s up and who’s down—the prospective tenant seems to be winning the battle. As to framing what this negotiation entails, for them it’s about whose contract language will prevail. And in regard to setting norms for how they will interact, both parties are playing contradict-and-challenge, though neither one may have consciously decided to do so.

在这段简短的开场白中，双方已经明确了彼此的关系：他们将成为对手，而且关系不会轻松。尽管他们仍在争夺主导权——谁占上风谁落下——但准租户似乎占据了上风。至于谈判的具体内容，对他们来说，关键在于合同条款的最终效力。而在制定双方互动规范方面，双方都在玩弄相互矛盾和挑战的游戏，尽管他们可能并非有意为之。

This confrontation wasn’t inevitable, however. Yes, the participants had tough issues to resolve, but we taped other negotiators who collaborated successfully (again, with no instruction from us). The best of them were natural improvisers. Contrast the interaction between the two we just met and this second pair:

然而，这场冲突并非不可避免。没错，参与者确实面临着棘手的问题需要解决，但我们也录制了其他谈判者成功合作的片段（同样，他们并没有接受我们的任何指导）。其中最优秀的谈判者都是天生的即兴发挥者。请对比一下我们刚才遇到的两位谈判者和第二组谈判者的互动：

Developer B: Well, Mike, we’ve given you a tour of the new space. Why don’t we see if we can get down to the business at hand that was dumped on both of us in the past two weeks? [ Pause .]

开发商B：好了，迈克，我们已经带你参观了新场地。不如我们来看看过去两周里我们俩都忙得不可开交的那些事儿吧？（停顿）

Tenant B: Well, it looks like we’re fairly far along with this lease. At least that’s what I was informed, but they leave the tough part for us, Tom.

租户B：嗯，看来我们的租约已经履行得相当顺利了。至少我是这么被告知的，但他们把最棘手的部分留给了我们，汤姆。

Developer B: Right, right. That is either a sign of how well we are doing or how poorly we are doing—

开发商B：对，对。这要么说明我们做得有多好，要么说明我们做得有多差——

Tenant B: [ Laughs .]

租户B：（笑）

Developer B: —within our respective organizations. One of the things that I did here, and I just want to . . . and you’ve done enough of these deals all over the country to have a fair sense of where we’re coming from, and probably done ’em from both sides. The last response, as I understand it (it may have been the guy on our side who didn’t want to take long notes), was, I guess what—we’re down to use, assignment, and subletting. Which is it. And got a great response, a good negotiating response last time: company policy.

开发商B：——在我们各自的组织内部。我在这里做的一件事，而且我只想说……你在全国各地做过很多类似的交易，应该很清楚我们的立场，而且你可能也从双方的角度都做过。据我了解，上次的回复（也可能是我们这边那个不想做详细笔记的人说的），我想是这样的——我们现在只剩下使用权、转让权和转租权了。就是这样。上次我们得到了一个很好的回复，一个很有谈判意义的回复：公司政策。

Tenant B: Right, right, company policy.

租户B：对，对，公司规定。

Developer B: As I think ought to be indicative of what you and I found in the lease—which is a picture of your leverage . . . If we can work out particular problems you’ve got, no problem. I just can’t, you know, have you run a Chandler Warehouse in there—

开发商B：我认为这应该能反映出你我在租赁合同中发现的情况——也就是你的谈判筹码……如果我们能解决你遇到的具体问题，那就没问题。但我不能，你知道，让你在那里开一家像钱德勒仓库那样的店——

Tenant B: Right.

租户B：好的。

Developer B: —when I’ve got sixty or seventy tenants counting on your sterling name coming in. What . . . what can you help me with? What sort of thing is behind the company policy line?

开发商B：——我有六七十个租户都指望着你们的良好声誉呢。我……我能帮上什么忙？公司政策背后到底有什么猫腻？

Tenant B: Well, the clause that’s in the lease right now is, I guess, our standard clause.

租户 B：嗯，目前租赁合同中的条款，我想，是我们的标准条款。

Developer B: It’s great. I love it from your point of view.

开发者B：太好了。我非常赞同你的观点。

Tenant B: It certainly is a good one. The, ah . . . and it, of course, is designed to give us flexibility, obviously. Our concerns are typical concerns regarding changes in circumstances and having the necessary flexibility. But I understand that you have counterconcerns that make this difficult from your perspective. I guess since I haven’t been in the prior negotiations, and I understand you haven’t either—

租户B：这确实是个好方案。嗯……当然，它的设计显然是为了给我们提供灵活性。我们担心的是情况变化以及需要必要的灵活性等常见问题。但我理解你们也有各自的顾虑，从你们的角度来看，这确实比较困难。我想，因为我之前没有参与过谈判，而且我知道你们也没有——

Developer B: Right.

开发商B：好的。

Tenant B: —we probably have to try to understand the concerns of the two parties. And I was interested in what particular problems you foresaw with this clause at this mall. And then maybe we can work through it from there.

租户B：——我们或许应该先了解双方的顾虑。我很想知道您预见到这条条款在这个商场里会引发哪些具体问题。然后我们或许可以从那里入手解决问题。

I’ve viewed these clips countless times but am still struck by how different this second opening is. What might sound at first like light banter is, on closer look, the negotiators’ way of getting in sync. In the two minutes it took the first pair to get into a tussle, these other two have their suit coats off and are set to solve the practical problems facing their respective companies.

这些片段我看了无数遍，但第二个开场白的差异仍然让我印象深刻。乍听之下像是轻松的闲聊，仔细观察就会发现，这是谈判者们磨合的方式。第一组谈判者还在争执不休的两分钟里，这两组谈判者已经脱下西装外套，准备着手解决各自公司面临的实际问题。

In a sense, both pairs negotiated how they would negotiate, but only the second did this well. They found a way to talk with each other, not at each other, as in the first case. They did so implicitly. Neither negotiator in the second pair said, “I think we should use a collaborative, problem-solving approach. Don’t you agree?” Such a question is off-putting, as it seems to compel just one reasonable answer.

从某种意义上说，两组谈判者都探讨了如何进行谈判，但只有第二组做得更好。他们找到了一种彼此交流的方式，而不是像第一组那样互相指责。他们的交流是含蓄的。第二组谈判者中，没有一个人说：“我认为我们应该采用合作解决问题的方法。你同意吗？”这样的问题令人反感，因为它似乎只要求一个合理的答案。

Rather than speaking in the abstract, developer B enacts what he proposes right at the start by characterizing “the business at hand that was dumped on both of us.”

开发商 B 并没有空谈理论，而是在一开始就身体力行地阐述了他的方案，他描述了“我们俩都不得不面对的这个棘手问题”。

His statement presumes that he and his counterpart have much in common and are engaged in the same task. Then, having lobbed the ball into the tenant’s court, he stops for a beat and waits to hear the response. After a brief pause, tenant B follows the “Yes, and” rule of improv comics and builds on the opening comment: “Well, it looks like we’re fairly far along with this lease. At least that’s what I was informed, but they leave the tough part for us, Tom.”

他的发言假定他和对方有很多共同点，并且正在做同一件事。然后，他把问题抛给了租户，停顿了一下，等待对方的回应。短暂的沉默后，租户B遵循即兴喜剧演员的“是的，而且”的规则，在开场白的基础上继续说道：“嗯，看来我们的租约进展得相当顺利了。至少我是这么被告知的，但他们把最棘手的部分留给了我们，汤姆。”

Hearing that, developer B grins and adds a “Yes, and” himself by saying, “That is either a sign of how well we are doing or how poorly we are doing within our respective organizations.” His crack prompts a knowing laugh from the would-be tenant. In just seconds, they are off and running.

听到这话，开发商B咧嘴一笑，补充道：“没错，而且，”他自嘲道，“这要么说明我们各自的公司业绩有多好，要么说明我们各自的公司业绩有多差。”他的这番话逗得那位准租户会心一笑。几秒钟之内，他们就出发了。

Engaging is inherently a mutual process. In this exchange, the parties have agreed that either they’ll play the heroes here, rescuing the deal from disaster, or they’ll both be the garbagemen who clean up the mess left by the earlier negotiators. This shared attitude is reinforced by their positive language. (Note, for instance, tenant B’s reminder that “we’re fairly far along” and developer B’s concurrence, “Right, right.”)

参与本质上是一个双向的过程。在这次交流中，双方都同意，要么他们扮演英雄的角色，力挽狂澜，避免交易失败；要么他们都扮演收拾残局的“清洁工”，清理之前谈判者留下的烂摊子。他们积极的措辞也强化了这种共识。（例如，租户B提醒说“我们已经取得了相当大的进展”，而开发商B则表示赞同：“对，对。”）

In the same spirit, these two negotiators call each other Tom and Mike. They also favor the plural we to the singular I and you. By contrast, developer A and tenant A mention each other’s name only once, and their use of the singular pronoun widens the gap between them. Each attributes motives to the other. Perhaps developer A is correct when he asserts, “You don’t want to be in there freestanding,” but nobody likes to be told what he thinks or wants.

同样，这两位谈判者也互称汤姆和迈克。他们也更倾向于使用复数形式的“我们”，而不是单数形式的“我”和“你们”。相比之下，开发商A和租户A只提到过对方一次，而且他们使用单数代词，这进一步拉大了彼此之间的距离。双方都试图揣测对方的动机。或许开发商A的说法是对的，“你不想在那里建独立式建筑”，但没有人喜欢别人告诉自己该怎么做。

Zeroing in on grammar may seem like nitpicking, but the language that we use influences how other people see us. It would be silly to claim that we can win friends and influence strangers just by dropping their names into every other sentence, Dale Carnegie to the contrary. But those pronouns in particular signal how people regard a relationship. I and you say one thing, while we and us say quite another.

纠结于语法或许看似吹毛求疵，但我们使用的语言确实会影响他人对我们的看法。如果说只要每隔一句话就提到陌生人的名字就能赢得朋友、影响他人，那就太荒谬了——戴尔·卡耐基的观点恰恰相反。但这些代词尤其能体现人们对一段关系的看法。“我”和“你”表达的是一回事，而“我们”和“我们自己”则表达的是另一回事。

The second pair of real estate negotiators also swapped flattery and little jokes. More subtly, they mirrored each other’s posture and mannerisms. Within moments, they were doing serious work. Whereas the first pair was out of sync from the beginning, trading assertions and challenges back and forth. The one thing that the two agreed on—and agreed upon early—was seeing each other as foes. Once such impressions form, it’s hard to discard them.

第二组房地产谈判者也互相奉承、开着玩笑。更微妙的是，他们还模仿彼此的姿态和举止。没过多久，他们就开始认真工作了。而第一组从一开始就不合拍，你来我往地互相指责、挑战。两人唯一达成共识——而且很早就达成了共识——就是把对方视为敌人。一旦这种印象形成，就很难消除。

The two pairs also framed their task (the what of negotiation) differently. The first two negotiators acted as if their job was to pound stakes in the ground and defend their positions. (Indeed, the tenant uses that exact word.) They never inquire about underlying interests or disclose their own priorities, for that matter. They soon get into their own kind of sync by falling into a game of me-against-you. It’s doubtful that either guy meant to get into a wrestling match. Each may picture himself as a cooperative negotiator but blame the other person for the friction here. If so, each may be half right, as neither one seemed to be thinking, “Is this conversation going where I want it to?”

这两组谈判者对谈判任务（谈判内容）的理解也截然不同。前两位谈判者仿佛在为自己的行为负责，就像是在地上插桩，捍卫自己的立场。（事实上，租户用的就是这个词。）他们从未探究过对方的潜在利益，也从未透露过自己的优先事项。很快，他们就陷入了一场你死我活的较量，仿佛达成了某种默契。恐怕他们俩都不是故意要打起来的。他们或许都认为自己是合作型的谈判者，却把摩擦的责任归咎于对方。如果真是这样，他们或许都说对了一半，因为他们似乎都没有认真思考过：“这场对话是否朝着我想要的方向发展？”

As for the latter two, I can’t say that their collaborative behavior was consciously orchestrated. Maybe yes, maybe no. But in the video, both parties are clearly more attentive to how their relationship is taking shape. The talk about the problem being dumped in both their laps helped establish a bond. It also set up their predecessors as useful foils to play against. In defining the task before them, these negotiators aligned themselves against the problem rather than against each other.

至于后两位，我不能断言他们的合作行为是刻意安排的。也许是，也许不是。但在视频中，双方显然都更加关注彼此关系的形成。他们谈到问题被一股脑地抛到他们身上，这有助于建立联系。这也让他们意识到，前任谈判者是值得借鉴的参照对象。在明确摆在他们面前的任务时，这些谈判者将自己置于问题本身，而不是彼此对抗。

Pair B also attended to a third aspect of openings: establishing norms for going forward, namely the how of negotiation. Unlike developer A, who asked bluntly, “Did you draft this lease?” developer B used humor to depersonalize the issues. Note how he dismisses the tenant’s original proposal with the remark, “I love it from your point of view” and then asks earnestly, “What sort of thing is behind the company policy line?”

B组还关注了开场白的第三个方面：建立后续谈判的规范，也就是谈判的方式。与开发商A直截了当地问“这份租约是你起草的吗？”不同，开发商B用幽默的方式淡化了问题的个人色彩。请注意，他先是轻描淡写地说“我喜欢你的想法”，然后认真地问：“公司政策背后究竟隐藏着什么？”

That’s when the banter stops and the substantive work begins. Tenant B answers the specific question by explaining that the draft language was designed to give his company flexibility to deal with changes in circumstances. He acknowledges that the developer may have counterconcerns. Then he goes further by suggesting that they lay out the practical interests of the parties before reviewing specific language for the lease: “I guess since I haven’t been in the prior negotiations, and I understand you haven’t either, we probably have to try to understand the concerns of the two parties.”

这时，闲聊戛然而止，实质性工作开始了。租户B回答了具体问题，解释说草案措辞旨在赋予他的公司应对情况变化的灵活性。他承认开发商可能存在不同的顾虑。然后，他进一步建议，在审查租赁合同的具体条款之前，双方应该先明确各自的实际利益：“我想，既然我没有参与之前的谈判，而且我理解你也没有，我们或许应该先努力了解双方的顾虑。”

No one has rattled a saber—or made a concession, for that matter. No one has tried to justify his position. Instead, tenant B continues by inquiring about “what particular problems you foresaw with this clause at this mall. And then maybe we can work through it from here.” They are able to advance the process because of what they accomplished in defining the relationship and the task.

没有人亮出武力——或者做出让步。也没有人试图为自己的立场辩护。相反，租户B继续询问“您预见到这条条款在这个商场里会造成哪些具体问题。然后我们或许可以从这里入手解决。”他们之所以能够推进进程，是因为他们已经明确了彼此的关系和任务。

Note how the first pair gives almost no attention to process. The two just wing it. The sole exception comes just fifteen seconds after the men sit down. The landlord thanks the tenant for a tour of the latter’s offices and then says, “Listen, I understand you have a meeting in about forty-five minutes, so we should try to get through these clauses as quickly as we can.”

注意第一组人几乎完全不注意流程，两人只是随性而为。唯一的例外出现在两人坐下仅仅十五秒后。房东感谢租户带他参观办公室，然后说道：“听着，我知道你大约四十五分钟后有个会，所以我们应该尽快把这些条款谈完。”

When I stop the video at a later spot for class discussion, students criticize that remark as being pushy. They feel it comes too soon, before there’s been any attempt to build rapport. I ask them what this fellow could do, though, given that time is short and there are important issues to resolve. If you’re pressed for time yourself, how should you make that clear at the outset without being provocative?

当我暂停视频进行课堂讨论时，学生们批评我刚才那句话太咄咄逼人。他们觉得这句话说得太早了，还没来得及建立任何融洽的关系。我问他们，既然时间紧迫，而且还有重要问题需要解决，这个人又能做些什么呢？如果你自己也时间紧迫，该如何一开始就坦诚地表达出来，又不显得咄咄逼人呢？

Viewers have good suggestions. Modest tweaks to the wording might elicit a different response. Saying “we should” sounds as if it’s all decided. The word quickly might mean “efficiently” to one person but “hurriedly” to another. If the developer were given a second chance, he might have split his comment in two: “I think we have only forty-five minutes today, is that correct?”

观众们提出了很好的建议。稍微修改一下措辞，或许就能得到不同的回应。“我们应该”听起来好像一切都已成定局。“快速”这个词对某些人来说可能意味着“高效地”，而对另一些人来说则可能意味着“匆忙地”。如果给开发者第二次机会，他或许会把评论分成两部分：“我想我们今天只有四十五分钟，对吗？”

Even if the developer is certain on that point, double-checking is courteous. In this instance, it would also prompt a yes from the other side—a word he’d like the other side to get used to saying. With that settled, he could then ask, “Okay, so how can we make best use of the time we’ve got?” Such a question touches each of the engaging, framing, and norming bases. It invites the other person to connect and implies that they have a common task. It’s a first step in articulating a process for getting that task done.

即使开发人员对此很有把握，再次确认也是一种礼貌。在这种情况下，再次确认也能促使对方给出肯定的答复——他希望对方能习惯说“是”。确认之后，他就可以问：“好的，那么我们如何才能最有效地利用时间呢？” 这样的问题涵盖了参与、框架构建和规范建立这三个方面。它邀请对方参与进来，并暗示他们有一个共同的任务。这是制定完成任务流程的第一步。

GETTING OFF ON THE RIGHT FOOT

良好的开端

Let’s test the engaging → framing → norming model of openings by considering three questions about the friendly pair of negotiations:

让我们通过考虑关于友好谈判双方的三个问题来检验“吸引→框架→规范”的开场白模型：

1. Don’t they duck the power issue? After all, the tenant is in the stronger position.

1. 他们是不是在回避权力问题？毕竟，租户处于更有利的地位。

2. Given their styles, weren’t they just lucky to be paired together? Either of them just as well could have been matched up against Mr. You-Need-Us.

2. 考虑到他们的风格，他们能被分到一组是不是很幸运？他们中的任何一个都完全有可能和那个“你需要我们”先生对决。

3. What specific skills and attitudes explain their success?

3. 他们的成功归功于哪些具体技能和态度？

By design, there was a power imbalance in this exercise. The prospective tenant could locate its store elsewhere in the region. By contrast, the developer was under pressure to make a deal with a big-name national chain. His financing depended on getting a long-term lease with a creditworthy tenant. That’s why the parties were working from the retailer’s standard contract language.

这项交易的设计初衷就是为了制造权力失衡。潜在租户可以选择在区域内其他地方开设店铺。相比之下，开发商则面临着与知名全国连锁店达成交易的压力。他的融资依赖于与信誉良好的租户签订长期租赁合同。正因如此，双方才采用了零售商的标准合同条款。

The first words out of tenant A’s mouth are, “Welcome to my office.” Though our participants were in a nondescript studio, he claims it as his own turf, and developer A slips into a subservient role. The host, not terribly gracious, leans way back in his chair and says little. The developer, who seems nervous in most viewers’ eyes, fills the awkward silences by motormouthing—which compounds his anxious appearance. Thus, the stage was already set when he says, “We need you.”

租户A开口的第一句话是：“欢迎来到我的办公室。”尽管我们身处一间毫不起眼的工作室，但他却声称这是他的地盘，开发商A也立刻摆出了一副卑躬屈膝的姿态。这位主持人态度冷淡，几乎没怎么说话，身体向后靠在椅背上。在大多数观众看来，开发商显得有些紧张，他喋喋不休地填补着尴尬的沉默——这反而加深了他焦虑不安的神情。因此，当他开口说“我们需要你”时，一切似乎都已就此定型。

The second pair doesn’t waste time posturing. Both parties are at ease and engaged. The developer finesses the power issue when he refers to the tenant’s initial proposal as “a picture of your leverage.” Loosely translated, this might mean “Only someone in your position of power would even dare ask for all that.” The subtext, of course, would be “Come on, you can throw me some crumbs here.”

第二对双方没有浪费时间摆姿态。双方都显得轻松自在，积极投入。开发商巧妙地利用了权力问题，将租户最初的提议称为“你筹码的体现”。简单来说，这可能意味着“只有像你这样有权有势的人才敢提出这么多要求”。当然，言下之意是“来吧，你至少可以给我一点甜头吧”。

Underneath the joshing, these parties are also negotiating important aspects of the relationship. But still, why would you ever want to remind the other side that it is up and you are down? In the right circumstances, it can be a smart move. First of all, it establishes credibility. If everyone knows that’s how it is, there’s little to be gained by pretending otherwise. If you bluff that you’ve got clout when you really don’t, the other side may feel compelled to teach you otherwise by throwing its weight around.

在玩笑的背后，双方也在协商关系中的重要方面。但是，你为什么要提醒对方自己处于劣势呢？在某些情况下，这可能是一个明智之举。首先，它能建立信誉。如果大家都知道事实如此，那么假装不一样就没什么意义了。如果你虚张声势地声称自己很有影响力，而实际上并非如此，那么对方可能会觉得有必要通过展现实力来让你明白事实并非如此。

Acknowledging the imbalance expresses your confidence that you can do all right in spite of that fact. When developer B notes his counterpart’s leverage, he smiles broadly and emphasizes the word picture with an upward, cheerful inflection. He is both granting tenant B’s power and signaling that any agreement reached will have to work for him too. He isn’t making a threat, but his whole demeanor seems to say that, deal or no deal, the sun will come up tomorrow. By comparison, developer A’s comment about finding another tenant seems feeble.

承认这种不平衡，表明你相信即便如此，你也能妥善处理。当开发商B注意到对方的筹码时，他笑容满面，语气轻快而愉悦地强调了“画面”这个词。他既承认了租户B的实力，也暗示着任何达成的协议都必须对他有利。他并非在威胁，但他的整个举止似乎在说，无论最终能否达成协议，太阳明天照常升起。相比之下，开发商A关于寻找其他租户的说法就显得苍白无力了。

It’s easier to express self-assurance in person than over the phone. In this instance, the developer’s eyes are wide open. He can register his counterpart’s reaction and correct any misimpressions immediately. The same words about leverage written in a text or email might seem snide or resentful, but in the right setting, such moves are risk free. They may encourage the other side to open up and offer more than a noncommittal “um-hmm.” And if this particular tenant is in a rotten mood or feels compelled to dominate, developer B hasn’t displayed weakness or made any substantive concessions. In fact, his smile and easy manner demonstrate his poise.

当面表达自信比电话沟通更容易。在这种情况下，开发商B目光敏锐，能够察觉对方的反应并立即纠正任何误解。同样的话语，如果用短信或邮件表达，可能会显得尖刻或充满怨恨，但在合适的场合，这种做法却毫无风险。它或许能鼓励对方敞开心扉，提供更多实质性的信息，而不仅仅是含糊其辞的“嗯哼”。即便这位租户心情不好，或者想要占据主导地位，开发商B也没有表现出任何软弱或做出任何实质性让步。事实上，他的微笑和轻松的举止恰恰展现了他的沉着冷静。

How such a comment is received depends on our luck, good or bad, in regard to who’s sitting on the other side of the table. In our project, it was a quirk of scheduling that Mike and Tom (the second pair) happened to be matched up. If their calendars had been different, Tom might have been with tenant A (Mr. You-Need-Us). I can only speculate about what would have transpired, but it surely would have been different on both sides of the table.

这样的评论会如何被接受，取决于我们运气好坏，取决于坐在桌子对面的是谁。在我们的项目中，迈克和汤姆（第二组）碰巧被安排在一起，纯属日程安排上的巧合。如果他们的日程安排不同，汤姆可能就会和租户A（那位“你总得找我们帮忙”先生）一起了。我只能猜测会发生什么，但可以肯定的是，双方的反应都会截然不同。

Suppose that Tom led off, just as he did before, by referring to the business at hand being dumped in their laps. (Recall that he paused at that point and waited for a response.) Perhaps this tenant would have said something unhelpful such as, “What do you mean by that?”

假设汤姆像之前那样，首先提到眼前的事情被一股脑地抛给了他们。（回想一下，他当时停顿了一下，等待回应。）也许这位房客会说一些毫无帮助的话，比如：“你这话是什么意思？”

Tom might privately wonder if that remark was meant as a challenge, though he’d be wise not to make much of it so early in the conversation. Rather than being defensive, he could let the remark pass and see if other small talk might draw the tenant into the conversation. Or he could take the question literally, and explain that since they both were new to the negotiation, it would make sense to confirm what issues were already settled and what was left to resolve. If that failed, he could ask, “So, what’s the best way we can wrap up what our colleagues were working on?”

汤姆或许会私下里琢磨那句话是不是在挑衅，不过在谈话初期，他最好不要对此反应过度。与其摆出防御姿态，不如先别急着回应，看看其他闲聊能否把租户引到谈话中来。或者，他也可以按字面意思理解，解释说既然双方都是谈判新手，那么确认哪些问题已经解决、哪些问题还有待解决就显得尤为重要。如果这种方法行不通，他可以问：“那么，我们怎样才能最好地完成同事们正在做的工作呢？”

Whatever unfolded would depend on both what Tom said and his bearing. My guess is that he would have handled the tough negotiator more successfully. He seems confident, though not threatening. He’d be less likely to invite the testing and put-downs that the nervous developer endured. Nor does he seem to be the type to get bogged down in one-upsmanship.

事情的最终走向取决于汤姆的言辞和他的态度。我猜他应该能更成功地应对那位难缠的谈判者。他看起来很自信，但并不咄咄逼人。他不太可能像那位紧张的开发人员那样，招致试探和贬低。而且，他似乎也不是那种会陷入争强好胜的泥潭的人。

Negotiations go better, of course, when parties have compatible styles like Mike and Tom. They both pay heed. They also know how to solo and how to comp. (Note how each uses positive words to encourage the other along.) Even their jokes push the negotiation forward. More fundamentally, they say yes to the mess, as jazz expert Frank Barrett would say. They are coming into this case late and with limited information, but they act as if this is a new opening—an opportunity for their respective companies to renegotiate how they will negotiate.

当然，如果谈判双方风格相近，比如迈克和汤姆，谈判就会更加顺利。他们都非常认真倾听。他们也都懂得如何独当一面，如何互相配合。（注意他们是如何用积极的语言鼓励对方的。）就连他们的玩笑也推动了谈判的进展。更重要的是，正如爵士乐专家弗兰克·巴雷特所说，他们欣然接受了这种混乱局面。他们介入此事的时间较晚，掌握的信息也有限，但他们却把这当作一个全新的契机——一个让各自公司重新协商谈判方式的机会。

FIRST IMPRESSIONS

第一印象

We get one chance to make a first impression. New research by my HBS colleague Amy Cuddy suggests that the impression that people typically hope to make may work to their disadvantage.

我们只有一次机会给人留下第一印象。我的哈佛商学院同事艾米·卡迪（Amy Cuddy）的最新研究表明，人们通常希望给人留下的印象可能反而会对自己不利。

Amy, a social psychologist, has built upon extensive research on “spontaneous trait inferences,” people’s impressions when they first see another person’s facial features.
