In seconds, we make assessments on multiple dimensions. Amy focuses on perceptions of warmth and competence, as they comprise 80 percent of our overall evaluation. Our initial judgment is about warmth, specifically whether we believe a person feels warm or cold toward us . (This is like the friend-or-foe assessment we mentioned earlier.) It’s how we read someone’s intentions, positive or negative. A second or so later, we assess her competence, especially her ability to carry out her inclination. Does she have the capacity to do us good or harm?

社会心理学家艾米基于对“自发性特质推断”的大量研究，即人们初次看到他人面部特征时的印象。短短几秒钟内，我们就能从多个维度进行评估。艾米着重研究了我们对温暖和能力的感知，因为这两项占我们整体评价的80%。我们最初的判断是关于温暖的，具体来说，就是我们认为对方对我们是热情还是冷漠。（这类似于我们之前提到的敌友判断。）这是我们解读他人意图的方式，无论是积极的还是消极的。大约一秒钟后，我们会评估她的能力，尤其是她实现自身意愿的能力。她有能力对我们有利还是有害？

Amy’s studies have revealed a curious paradox. We want others to be concerned about us. Yet we prefer other people to see us as competent. In the context of negotiation, competence can mean both holding a strong hand and being skillful at the process.

艾米的研究揭示了一个有趣的悖论。我们希望别人关心我们，但我们更希望别人认为我们能力出众。在谈判中，能力既可以指在谈判中占据优势，也可以指技巧娴熟。

Now here’s the key: people tend to see warmth and competence as inversely related. Thus, if we view the person that we’re dealing with as competent, then we assume that he feels less warm toward us. That means that the more successful we are in proving our competence, the more distance from others we create. The price of looking supercompetent (our natural impulse) is that we look like foes to other people.

关键在于：人们往往认为热情和能力成反比。因此，如果我们认为对方能力很强，就会假定他对我们不够热情。这意味着，我们越是成功地证明自己的能力，就越会与他人保持距离。展现出超强的能力（这是我们的本能）的代价是，我们会被他人视为敌人。

We’ve just seen how this dynamic plays out verbally, when the first pair of real estate negotiators jostles over position, while the second two endeavor to establish connection. As Amy and others note, similar messages are transmitted through facial expressions and body posture. Indeed, the impact of physical signals may be stronger.

我们刚才已经看到这种动态是如何在语言层面上体现出来的：第一组房地产谈判者为了争夺地位而互相推诿，而第二组则努力建立联系。正如艾米和其他人所指出的，类似的讯息也会通过面部表情和肢体语言传递。事实上，肢体信号的影响力可能更大。

With pair A, you probably don’t have to be told that’s Mr. You-Need-Us leaning way back on the right. The beleaguered developer is hunched down on the left. With pair B, it’s harder to tell who’s who—and that’s the point. They’ve teamed up to clean up the mess that their respective predecessors made. (Here it’s the developer who’s on the right and the tenant seated on the left.) Perhaps their posture is carefully calibrated, but more likely it has happened naturally. Because each side sees the other as warm, they are wholly engaged in a process of reciprocal, reinforcing feedback. Smiles are begetting smiles.

A组两人，你大概不用别人提醒就知道右边那位是“求助先生”，左边那位是疲惫不堪的开发商。B组两人则很难分辨谁是谁——而这正是重点。他们联手收拾各自前任留下的烂摊子。（这里右边是开发商，左边是租户。）他们的姿势或许是精心调整的，但更有可能是自然而然形成的。因为双方都觉得对方很友善，所以他们全身心地投入到这种互惠互利的互动中。笑容带来了更多的笑容。

Amy and her colleagues Dana Carney and Andy Yap (both of Columbia University) have significantly advanced our understanding of the biochemical aspect of social interaction. Familiar research on body language has focused on what your expressions, gestures, and posture communicate to other people. Specifically, they have discovered that the way in which you carry yourself not only affects how others see you (confident or vulnerable, for example) but also actually causes you to have those feelings, too!

艾米和她的同事达娜·卡尼（Dana Carney）和安迪·叶（Andy Yap）（均来自哥伦比亚大学）极大地增进了我们对社交互动生物化学方面的理解。以往关于肢体语言的研究主要集中在你的表情、手势和姿势向他人传达的信息上。而他们的研究则发现，你的举止不仅会影响他人对你的看法（例如，自信还是脆弱），而且实际上也会让你自己产生相应的感受！

The researchers measured hormone levels of subjects who were told to maintain a particular body position for just a couple of minutes. When people sat or stood in a closed manner, their cortisol level went up. Cortisol is the so-called fight-or-flight hormone, produced by the adrenal glands atop the kidneys. It both results from and activates anxiety.

研究人员测量了受试者在被要求保持特定身体姿势几分钟后的激素水平。当人们以封闭的姿势坐着或站着时，他们的皮质醇水平会升高。皮质醇是所谓的“战斗或逃跑”激素，由位于肾脏上方的肾上腺分泌。它既是焦虑的诱因，也是焦虑的激活剂。

But when subjects instead assumed the open stances—power poses, as Amy calls them—cortisol went down and testosterone increased for both men and women. Testosterone, the male sex hormone—also produced in smaller quantities by the female ovaries—is associated with confidence and risk taking.

但当受试者摆出开放的姿势——艾米称之为“力量姿势”——时，男性和女性的皮质醇水平都下降了，睾酮水平则上升了。睾酮，这种男性性激素——女性卵巢也会少量分泌——与自信和冒险精神有关。

Most important, these hormone changes persist and impact behavior. More than fifteen minutes after assuming the power poses, subjects were more likely to roll dice to double a $2 stake. Risk taking is associated with dominance. It’s just speculation at this point, but it may have other positive effects in negotiation. A confident person might be more willing to float a novel solution to a problem, for example. She might also take the chance of relaxing a bit and feeling more warmly toward her counterpart.

最重要的是，这些激素变化会持续存在并影响行为。在摆出强势姿势超过15分钟后，受试者更有可能掷骰子来赢取双倍的2美元赌注。冒险与支配地位相关。目前这只是推测，但它可能在谈判中产生其他积极影响。例如，自信的人可能更愿意提出解决问题的新方案。她也可能借此机会放松一下，对对方产生更友好的感觉。

You can put Amy, Dana, and Andy’s insights to work today without going to the gym or wading through piles of scholarly articles. You just need to be aware of your body when you prepare to negotiate and throughout the process. Opening up your physical stance can expand your thinking. There may be ripple effects as well. When you feel—and display—an easy confidence, others may become more comfortable with you.

你今天就可以运用艾米、达娜和安迪的见解，无需去健身房或研读大量学术文章。你只需要在谈判准备和谈判过程中注意自己的身体状态。舒展身体姿态可以拓展你的思维。这或许还会产生连锁反应。当你感到并展现出轻松自信时，其他人也会更容易与你相处。

Circumstances can trigger anxiety, of course. Most of us have no trouble carrying on a casual conversation with a stranger waiting for a bus, but good luck to us if we were called up from the audience to do exactly the same thing at an improv comedy club. Every once in a while, the situation is reversed. There is great tension, and then someone dispels it. Just below the surface of a looming confrontation may lay the seeds for new understanding and engagement.

当然，某些情境会引发焦虑。我们大多数人都能轻松地与等公交车的陌生人闲聊，但如果在即兴喜剧俱乐部被叫上台做同样的事情，那就难上加难了。偶尔，情况会反过来。气氛紧张，但有人会化解它。在即将爆发的冲突之下，或许就埋藏着新的理解和交流的种子。

On September 16, 2001, Courtney Cowart was heading to Lower Manhattan on the Lexington Avenue subway line. She was returning to Ground Zero, where five days earlier, she had escaped a blinding maelstrom of dust and debris as the World Trade Center collapsed almost on top of her. Here is her story in her own words.

2001年9月16日，考特尼·考沃特乘坐莱克星顿大道地铁线前往曼哈顿下城。她正返回世贸中心遗址，五天前，世贸中心大楼几乎在她头顶坍塌，她侥幸从漫天尘土和瓦砾中逃生。以下是她用自己的话讲述的故事。

Down the steps I went and boarded the first train. There in my car on one of the benches sat a skinny old wizened Sikh wearing an elaborate gray silk turban. No one would sit on the same bench with him. His bench was completely empty, with everyone bunched up on the other side of the subway car. He sat there alone, perfectly straight and still, without a sound, but with tears just streaming down his face.

我走下台阶，登上了第一班列车。车厢里，一位瘦削的锡克教老人坐在长椅上，头戴精致的灰色丝绸头巾。没有人愿意和他坐在同一张长椅上。他的长椅空空如也，所有人都挤在车厢的另一边。他独自一人坐在那里，身子笔直，一动不动，一声不吭，泪水却止不住地流淌。

As the train decelerated, he reached into his pocket and pulled out a crumpled dollar bill. Then he stooped over a Hispanic mother with an infant in her arms sitting by the doors. Into the baby’s little fist he gently tucked the crumpled dollar bill, looking straight into the woman’s eyes. She frowned back and looked at me with a huge question mark on her face and was about to protest when I blurted out urgently, “Don’t stop him. He needs to do this.”

火车减速时，他伸手进口袋，掏出一张皱巴巴的美元钞票。然后他弯下腰，走到坐在车门边的一位抱着婴儿的西班牙裔母亲身边。他轻轻地把那张皱巴巴的美元钞票塞进婴儿的小拳头里，目光直视着那位母亲的眼睛。她皱起眉头，一脸疑惑地看着我，正要抗议，我却急切地脱口而出：“别拦着他。他必须这么做。”

She was silent for a moment and then replied, “So we know that he is not cruel?”

她沉默了一会儿，然后回答说：“所以我们知道他并不残忍？”

And I said, “Yes. So we know that he is not cruel.”

我说：“是的。所以我们知道他并不残忍。”

The doors opened. He stepped out. The doors closed. We looked at each other, and all of us, every person in that car, burst into tears.

车门开了。他走了出去。车门关上了。我们面面相觑，车里的每个人，都嚎啕大哭起来。

The anxiety that people bring to new experiences has many sources and can take many forms. That is also true for its release. The shared anxiety of the New York subway riders was overwhelming. The sorrow of the Sikh was different but no less intense. Then something happened.

人们面对新体验时的焦虑来源众多，表现形式也多种多样。释放焦虑的方式亦是如此。纽约地铁乘客们共同的焦虑令人窒息。锡克教徒的悲伤虽有所不同，但同样强烈。然后，意想不到的事情发生了。

We cannot know for sure, but something in Cowart’s face, perhaps an open attentiveness, invited the questioning look from the Hispanic mother. Though the two women had never met, they were connected by the mother’s unspoken plea for help and reassurance. Cowart’s spontaneous response could not have been rehearsed. Its urgency had to match the intensity of the moment. The protective mother who had felt threatened only an instant earlier was shocked into a new understanding and new relationships with Cowart, the Sikh, and everyone else in that subway car.

我们无法确定，但考沃特脸上的某种神情——或许是一种坦诚的关注——引起了那位西班牙裔母亲的疑惑目光。尽管两人素未谋面，但母亲无声的求助和安慰却将她们联系在了一起。考沃特的即兴反应显然并非事先排练，其紧迫感必然与当时的紧张气氛相符。就在前一刻还感到受到威胁的那位护子心切的母亲，此刻却震惊地与考沃特、那位锡克教徒以及地铁车厢里的其他人建立了新的理解和关系。

Openings are opportunities. They are moments in which mood is set, issues are framed, and relationships are established. If these moments are recognized and expressed emotionally, they can be openings to new understandings and possibilities.

开端即机遇。它们是情绪定型、问题界定和关系建立的时刻。如果这些时刻能够被感知并以情感表达出来，它们便能开启通往全新理解和可能性的大门。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Begin negotiation with an eye to how you want to finish.

■ 谈判之初就要考虑你希望如何结束谈判。

■ Use opening moments to engage your counterpart, frame the issues, and define the process.

■ 利用开场机会与对方互动，阐明问题，并明确流程。

■ Don’t rush. Small talk reduces tension and builds relationships.

■ 不要着急。闲聊可以缓解紧张气氛，建立关系。

■ Avoid small ego battles that can cost you the war.

■ 避免因小的自尊心之争而导致战争失败。

■ Use posture to reduce stress and build your confidence.

■ 通过调整姿势来减轻压力，增强自信。

#↩

[ 9 ] Critical Moments

[ 9 ] 关键时刻

A colleague once told me that if something is cheap and easy to reverse, it’s an experiment. But if it’s not both those things, it’s a commitment. That applies to negotiation. Much of what you may do along the way falls into the no-harm-in-trying category. Being polite at the outset, for example, is costless. If the other side misreads your courtesy as a lack of resolve, you can disabuse them of that notion.

一位同事曾告诉我，如果某件事成本低廉且易于撤销，那它就是一次实验。但如果它既不便宜又容易撤销，那就是一项承诺。这同样适用于谈判。谈判过程中你所做的很多事情都属于“尝试一下也无妨”的范畴。例如，一开始保持礼貌是零成本的。如果对方误以为你的礼貌是缺乏决心，你可以借此机会打消他们的疑虑。

But sometimes you must take a step that could either help or hurt your cause, and there’s no easy way to backtrack. If you reveal important information, for example, you can’t take it back. Likewise with issuing a take-it-or-leave-it ultimatum. Committing yourself to a strategy is also a critical choice.

但有时你必须采取一些可能对你的事业有利也可能有害的行动，而且没有简单的回头路。例如，如果你透露了重要信息，就无法收回。发出“要么接受，要么放弃”的最后通牒也是如此。选择并执行某种策略也是一项至关重要的决定。

Daniel Yin was back on campus for the second module of an HBS executive program for people who run their own companies. He and his brother Steven had founded a high-end publishing firm that puts out gorgeous coffee table art and travel books in another part of the world. For reasons you’ll soon understand, I’ve disguised names here, been vague about the country in which they do business, and converted the currency to US dollars. The rest is true.

丹尼尔·尹回到校园，参加哈佛商学院高管培训项目的第二个模块，该项目面向那些经营自己公司的企业家。他和他的兄弟史蒂文在世界另一端创办了一家高端出版社，专门出版精美的画册和旅游书籍。出于一些原因，你很快就会明白，我在这里隐去了他们的名字，模糊了他们开展业务的国家，并将货币单位换算成了美元。其余内容属实。

Daniel and I met for lunch along with a few of his program classmates. After we exchanged pleasantries, he broke in and said, “First off, I want to thank you, Professor. The negotiation classes you taught proved very helpful to me recently.” Everyone likes a compliment, so I smiled, expecting for him to tell me about a recent acquisition or resolution of some copyright claim.

我和丹尼尔以及他的一些同学一起吃了午饭。寒暄过后，他突然开口说道：“首先，我想感谢您，教授。您最近开设的谈判课程对我帮助很大。” 谁都喜欢听赞美，所以我笑了笑，以为他要跟我讲讲最近收购的资产或者解决的版权纠纷。

I was startled, however, when he continued, “What I learned was crucial when my brother Steven was kidnapped. I had to negotiate his release. For a whole month, we didn’t know if we’d see him alive again.”

然而，他接下来的话却让我大吃一惊：“我学到的东西在我弟弟史蒂文被绑架时至关重要。我不得不与绑架方谈判，让他获释。整整一个月，我们都不知道是否还能活着见到他。”

It never occurred to me that one of my students would use negotiation concepts he learned in my course in such circumstances. But Daniel was convinced that the frameworks we had used in analyzing business transactions applied to his brother’s kidnapping case too. In fact, many of the points he made anticipated themes in this book.

我从未想到我的学生会在这种情况下运用他在课堂上学到的谈判概念。但丹尼尔坚信，我们之前分析商业交易的框架也适用于他哥哥的绑架案。事实上，他提出的许多观点都预示了本书的主题。

Daniel spoke, for example, about the importance of presence of mind. “I had to have the mental discipline to see everything that was happening from a neutral point of view.” He also thought hard about BATNAs, “not just for us but for the kidnapper too.” The family had no walkaway alternative. It had to negotiate. But Daniel realized that his counterpart had to negotiate as well. “He makes a profit only if he makes a deal.”

例如，丹尼尔谈到了保持冷静的重要性。“我必须具备足够的心理素质，才能以客观中立的视角看待所有发生的事情。”他还认真思考了最佳替代方案，“不仅是为了我们，也是为了绑匪。”家属别无选择，只能谈判。但丹尼尔意识到，绑匪也必须谈判。“只有达成协议，他才能获利。”

Daniel also took great care in formulating his offers to influence the kidnapper’s perception of deal space. He considered the roles and interests of all the parties, including the police—not all of whom he trusted. Daniel’s analysis was impressive, as was his poise in a time of great stress. But Daniel didn’t mention how well he handled critical moments in the negotiation. That skill may have been the most important factor in his success.

丹尼尔在制定方案时也格外用心，力图影响绑匪对交易空间的认知。他考虑到了各方的角色和利益，包括警方——尽管他并非完全信任警方。丹尼尔的分析能力令人印象深刻，他在巨大压力下所展现出的沉着冷静也同样令人钦佩。但丹尼尔并未提及他在谈判中如何出色地处理关键时刻。而这或许才是他最终成功的关键因素。

I’m not talking here about critical choices that can be understood only in hindsight. Those are the province of historians. In 1940 Adolf Hitler’s decision to suspend Germany’s air assault upon England and attack the Russians on the Eastern Front proved to be a turning point in World War II, though no one could have known that at the time. Instead, I’m focusing on moments where, with appropriate reflection, you should recognize that doing one thing forecloses something else. Your ability to hedge or straddle may be limited at best, but you still must make a decision.

我这里说的并非那些只能事后才能理解的关键抉择，那是历史学家的领域。1940年，希特勒决定暂停德国对英国的空袭，转而进攻东线苏军，这被证明是二战的转折点，尽管当时无人能够预料到这一点。我关注的是，在某些时刻，经过适当的反思，你应该意识到，做一件事就意味着放弃做另一件事。你左右摇摆或权衡的能力或许有限，但你仍然必须做出决定。

MANAGING CRITICAL MOMENTS

应对关键时刻

Kidnapping for money has become common in Daniel’s country. The professionals who do it are shrewd. They know how to play on people’s emotions. After snatching someone, they wait several days before making contact. They want to amp up fear to a point where a family will pay anything to get the victim back safely.

在丹尼尔的国家，绑架勒索赎金的案件屡见不鲜。那些职业绑匪手段老练，深谙如何利用人们的情感。绑架之后，他们会拖延数日才与人质联系，以此来加剧受害者家属的恐惧，迫使他们不惜一切代价也要将人质安全救回。

Daniel nevertheless used the time to his own advantage. First, he received a crash course in ransom negotiation from the police. They told him that it’s not like the movies. In this country, kidnappers don’t state a demand, nor do they impose a deadline. Instead, when they do call, they insist that the family put the first number on the table . Right at the outset, Daniel would face a crucial decision: How much to offer for his brother’s return? There would be no second chance.

然而，丹尼尔却利用这段时间为自己谋利。首先，他接受了警方的紧急赎金谈判培训。警方告诉他，这不像电影里演的那样。在这个国家，绑匪不会提出具体要求，也不会设定最后期限。相反，当他们打电话来时，会坚持要求家属先说出第一个数字。丹尼尔一开始就面临着一个关键抉择：为了救回弟弟，他应该出多少钱？没有第二次机会了。

Daniel reviewed his accounts and figured that he could come up with $1 million, maybe somewhat more in a week or two. The fact that Steven was a full partner in the business limited how much Daniel could borrow on his own. He’d pay whatever it took to guarantee his brother’s safe release. If that meant financial ruin for the extended Yin family, they would find a way to survive.

丹尼尔查看了自己的账目，估计一两周内能筹到一百万美元，或许还能更多。由于史蒂文是公司的正式合伙人，丹尼尔能独自借到的钱有限。他愿意付出任何代价来确保弟弟的安全获释。即便这意味着尹氏家族将面临破产，他们也会想方设法生存下去。

The telephone finally rang just before seven on a Sunday evening.

星期天晚上七点前，电话终于响了。

“I have a message from Steven Yin,” said the voice on the other end of the line.

“我收到史蒂文·尹的留言，”电话那头传来声音。

“Who is this?” Daniel asked.

“这是谁？”丹尼尔问道。

“Your brother is all right,” said the caller. “He wants you to know how much he appreciated the gold cuff links you gave him for his birthday last week. What else? Oh, the generous toast that you made, about him being both your brother and your best friend—that meant the world to him.”

“你弟弟没事，”来电者说。“他想让你知道，他多么感激你上周送他的金袖扣作为生日礼物。还有什么呢？哦，还有你慷慨激昂的祝酒词，说他既是你的弟弟又是你最好的朋友——这对他意义非凡。”

There had been crank calls earlier, but this one was legitimate. Only the immediate family had been at Steven’s birthday dinner. And the cuff links were antiques that Daniel had purchased on a recent business trip. Yet in spite of having had the three days to prepare, Daniel was speechless.

之前也接到过骚扰电话，但这次是真的。史蒂文的生日晚宴只有他的直系亲属参加。而且那副袖扣是丹尼尔最近出差时买的古董。尽管有三天时间准备，丹尼尔还是哑口无言。

“Tell Steven that we are doing as well as we can,” he finally said. “Tell him we are praying for him.”

“告诉史蒂文，我们正在尽力照顾他，”他最后说道。“告诉他，我们正在为他祈祷。”

Daniel glanced over at a policeman sitting at the dining room table and listening to the conversation through headphones. A tape recorder had clicked on the instant the phone had rung. He gestured for Daniel to continue.

丹尼尔瞥了一眼坐在餐桌旁、戴着耳机听着电话对话的警察。电话铃声一响，录音机就响了。他示意丹尼尔继续说下去。

“What do you want us to do?”

“你们想让我们怎么做？”

“I’ll make this quick. I’ve already invested a lot in preserving the safety of your brother. I paid people well to treat him with respect; to be careful. I thought you should know that before telling me: What you are going to pay?”

“我就长话短说。为了保护你弟弟的安全，我已经投入了很多。我付了高薪聘请别人尊重他、小心谨慎。我觉得你应该先了解这些，再告诉我：你打算付多少钱？”

Daniel loved his brother and was sitting on a lot of cash. What should he do?

丹尼尔很爱他的哥哥，而且手头还有不少钱。他该怎么办？

“We can pay you fifty thousand dollars right now,” Daniel told the kidnapper.

“我们现在就可以付给你五万美元，”丹尼尔对绑匪说。

“That’s ridiculous,” was the response. “You’ll have to do much better than that.” The telephone line went dead.

“太荒谬了，”对方回应道，“你得拿出更好的表现才行。”电话线随即断了。

Daniel had a good explanation for his lowball number. He had anticipated that his first offer would be a critical move, one that would shape his broader strategy. He thought hard about the long-term consequences of his answer. While preparing for the negotiation, he realized that his first offer, no matter how lavish, would not secure Steven’s release. The kidnapper would reject it, confident that he could get more.

丹尼尔对自己的低价有合理的解释。他预料到第一次报价至关重要，将决定他整体的策略。他仔细考虑了自己回答的长远后果。在准备谈判的过程中，他意识到，无论第一次报价多么诱人，都无法确保史蒂文获释。绑匪肯定会拒绝，因为他相信自己能索要更多。

With that in mind, Daniel reconsidered his objectives. “My paramount goal at that point was to simply keep the conversation going,” he explained. The $50,000 figure probably was less than the kidnapper expected, yet it was a starting point—that’s what Daniel meant by adding the words “right now.”

考虑到这一点，丹尼尔重新审视了自己的目标。“我当时的首要目标就是让对话继续下去，”他解释道。5万美元的赎金可能低于绑匪的预期，但这只是一个起点——这就是丹尼尔加上“现在”这个词的含义。

One of his program classmates asked, “Weren’t you taking a big risk with your brother’s life?” Daniel didn’t think so. In fact, he worried more about the risk of making a high offer. If he had started with $500,000, the kidnapper might have assumed that the family could pay ten times that. In laying out his first number, Daniel was already thinking about the end game.

他的一位同学问：“你拿你弟弟的性命冒险，难道不是吗？”丹尼尔并不这么认为。事实上，他更担心的是开出高价的风险。如果他一开始就开出50万美元，绑匪可能会觉得他们家能拿出十倍的价钱。丹尼尔在报出第一个数字时，就已经在考虑最终结果了。

Daniel and the police listened to the tape of the first call over and over again. “This is good,” said the head detective. “We know this guy. He’s done at least eight kidnappings this year.” Daniel stifled the impulse to ask why, after so many times, the police still hadn’t made an arrest. Instead, he merely asked, “It’s good?”

丹尼尔和警察一遍又一遍地听着第一通电话的录音。“不错，”警探长说，“我们认识这个人。他今年至少绑架了八人。”丹尼尔强忍住想问为什么这么多次了，警察还是没抓到人。他只是问了一句：“不错？”

“Oh yes,” said the detective. “He’s very professional. He knows what he’s doing. Now, if it were some amateur, someone who doesn’t know how to play the game, it would be very different.” To Daniel, the situation was by no means a game, yet he was thinking like a chess player himself. There would be further moves, he told himself, trying to draw some comfort from the kidnapper’s closing words. This was the beginning of the bargaining, not the end.

“哦，是的，”侦探说，“他非常专业，知道自己在做什么。如果换成一个业余人士，一个不懂套路的人，情况就完全不同了。”对丹尼尔来说，这绝非一场游戏，但他却像个棋手一样思考着。他告诉自己，事情还会有后续发展，并试图从绑匪的最后几句话中找到一丝安慰。这只是谈判的开始，而不是结束。

The second phone call came the next evening. “You have a prosperous business, Mr. Yin,” the kidnapper said. “Don’t insult me with any more low offers. You can easily pay many times what you said.”

第二个电话是在第二天晚上打来的。“尹先生，您生意兴隆，”绑匪说，“别再用低价侮辱我了。您完全可以支付您刚才说的数倍。”

“Sir,” replied Daniel. “You know what is happening in the economy. Things are bad, our credit line is gone. It’s not our fault. It’s happening to everyone.”

“先生，”丹尼尔回答说，“您知道现在的经济形势。情况很糟糕，我们的信用额度用完了。这不是我们的错，每个人都面临着同样的问题。”

“Well, sell your big Mercedes, then,” said the kidnapper. Daniel thought he heard a trace of exasperation. “It’s not mine to sell,” Daniel answered. “The bank is about to repossess it.”

“那你就把你那辆奔驰卖了吧，”绑匪说道。丹尼尔觉得他听出了一丝恼怒。“车不是我的，”丹尼尔回答道，“银行马上就要收回它了。”

“Make me another offer,” the caller said over the crackle of the cell phone.

“再给我报个价吧，”电话那头传来一阵手机杂音。

“I can find sixty thousand dollars,” said Daniel. “Maybe sixty-five.”

“我能找到六万美元，”丹尼尔说。“也许六万五千美元吧。”

“That’s not enough,” said the kidnapper, hanging up.

“这还不够，”绑匪说完便挂断了电话。

Once Daniel had committed to his strategy, he didn’t falter. He focused on influencing the kidnapper’s perceptions. “I wanted to keep him interested but at the same time really anchor his expectations,” Daniel said. “I was very careful to be consistent, increasing my offers only a little at a time.”

丹尼尔一旦确定了策略，便毫不动摇。他专注于影响绑匪的认知。“我想让他保持兴趣，但同时也要让他明确预期，”丹尼尔说。“我非常谨慎地保持一致，每次只略微提高报价。”

The negotiations dragged on for three weeks. In each of the daily calls, Daniel would pose a personal question that only his brother could answer. Next time, the kidnapper would need to have the appropriate answer to prove that Steven was still alive. It was an arduous process. Something needed to be done to bring it to a close. By day twenty-five, Daniel had offered $78,000, and still the kidnapper insisted on more. “Call me back tomorrow,” said Daniel. “I may have another option.” This time he was the one to hang up.

谈判持续了三周。每天的电话里，丹尼尔都会问一个只有他哥哥才能回答的私人问题。下次，绑匪就必须给出相应的答案，才能证明史蒂文还活着。这是一个漫长而艰辛的过程。必须采取一些措施来结束这场谈判。到了第二十五天，丹尼尔已经提出支付7.8万美元，但绑匪仍然坚持要更多。“明天再打给我，”丹尼尔说，“我可能还有别的办法。” 这次，是他挂断了电话。

When Daniel got the call next evening, he claimed that he had contacted a loan shark, an underworld figure who could provide another $20,000. “That gets us into the nineties,” the kidnapper said. “That’s better, but it’s still not enough.”

第二天晚上丹尼尔接到电话时，绑匪声称他已经联系了一个高利贷者，一个黑道人物，可以再提供2万美元。“这样我们就凑够9万美元了，”绑匪说。“情况好转了，但还是不够。”

“You don’t understand,” said Daniel. “I haven’t borrowed the money from him yet. The moment that I do, we owe interest of one percent per day.”

“你不明白，”丹尼尔说。“我还没向他借钱呢。一旦借了，我们就得每天支付百分之一的利息。”

“That’s your problem,” said the kidnapper.

“那是你的问题，”绑匪说道。

“Actually, it’s a problem for both of us,” Daniel said. “If I’ve got to pay interest, it will come out of any money I borrow. So if we keep negotiating, the loan shark is going to cut into the amount that you get. There’s no way around it.”

“实际上，这对我们俩来说都是个问题，”丹尼尔说。“如果我要付利息，利息就会从我借的钱里扣除。所以如果我们继续谈判，放高利贷的人肯定会减少你最终能拿到的钱。这是没办法避免的。”

“Let me think about it,” said the caller.

“让我考虑一下，”来电者说。

“Of course,” said Daniel, “but the commitment he gave me is good only until noon tomorrow. I either have to take the money then, or he’ll lend it to other people.”

“当然，”丹尼尔说，“但他给我的承诺只到明天中午才有效。我要么明天中午就把钱拿走，要么他就把钱借给别人。”

The kidnapper hung up but called back in five minutes with a counteroffer. “Make the amount an even one hundred thousand, and we have a deal,” he said.

绑匪挂断电话，五分钟后又打回来，提出了一个还价。“把金额定在十万整，我们就成交。”他说。

“I can do that,” said Daniel after a deliberate pause.

“我可以做到，”丹尼尔故意停顿了一下后说道。

Daniel got instructions on making the transfer for his brother. The money would be in cash, of course, small bills. The police promised not to interfere. They also assured Daniel that if the family paid the ransom, the kidnapper would keep his word. “Don’t worry about that,” said the detective. “He knows that if he doesn’t deliver, we’ll tell anyone dealing with him in the future not to pay.”

丹尼尔收到了如何替他哥哥转账的指示。当然，钱要用现金，而且是小额钞票。警方承诺不会干预。他们还向丹尼尔保证，如果家人支付赎金，绑匪就会信守承诺。“别担心，”侦探说，“他知道如果他不兑现承诺，我们会告诉以后所有跟他打交道的人不要付钱。”

Thirty minutes after Daniel passed a duffel bag to a stranger, a gray van drove past the Yins’ downtown office, and Steven was pushed out on the street, blindfolded. The public was told that he had managed to escape. The authorities didn’t want to encourage more kidnappings.

丹尼尔将一个帆布包交给陌生人三十分钟后，一辆灰色面包车驶过尹氏位于市中心的办公室，史蒂文被蒙住双眼推下车。警方对外宣称他成功逃脱。当局不希望鼓励更多绑架案发生。

The whole negotiation took almost a month, but Daniel felt that time was on his side. He increased his offers, though only a little each time. There was enough on the table to protect Steven from harm, but not enough for the kidnapper to keep this game with the Yins going. Maybe he could find someone else to grab whose family wouldn’t be so patient and disciplined.

整个谈判持续了将近一个月，但丹尼尔觉得时间站在他这边。他提高了报价，虽然每次只提高一点点。他提出的条件足以保护史蒂文免受伤害，但不足以让绑匪继续和尹家玩这场游戏。或许他可以找个别的绑匪，找个家人没那么耐心和自律的人下手。

That’s not how Daniel felt privately, of course. “It was so stressful, so emotional,” he says. “I had to dedicate myself to being very focused about strategy.” The kidnapper initially controlled the pace of the negotiations and communication, but Daniel’s bold action was what brought the process to a successful close. He knew he couldn’t make a take-it-or-leave-it offer. There was too much at stake. So he concocted the loan shark story as a way to dangle an attractive offer, but only for a short time. “I wanted to create a deadline,” he said, “but one that would just be arbitrary, because he could call my bluff.”

当然，丹尼尔私下里并非如此。“当时压力巨大，情绪也十分紧张，”他说，“我必须全神贯注于策略。”绑匪最初掌控着谈判和沟通的节奏，但丹尼尔的果断行动最终促成了行动的成功。他知道自己不能提出一个要么接受要么放弃的方案，因为事关重大。于是，他编造了放高利贷的故事，以此来抛出一个诱人的条件，但只是暂时的。“我想设定一个最后期限，”他说，“但这个期限必须只是个空头支票，因为他完全可以识破我的虚张声势。”

It wasn’t a card that he could have easily played again if it didn’t work this time. The mythical loan brought the package to a little less than $100,000. Without it, they were still in the high seventies. Psychologically, it could be hard for the kidnapper to take a big step backward. As Daniel expected, the kidnapper came back for a small sweetener to make it a six-figure deal. If satisfying the kidnapper’s ego was necessary, that was okay with Daniel. Many moments in this negotiation were important, but two especially. The first was imposed on Daniel when the kidnapper insisted that he make the first offer. But at the close, it was Daniel who forced the issue and restored Steven to the family. “Emotionally, I wanted to resolve this right away,” he told us, “but rationally, I knew that if I tried to rush things, panicking would only make things worse.”

如果这次没成功，他恐怕很难再用这张牌了。那笔虚构的贷款让赎金总额略低于10万美元。如果没有这笔钱，他们也只能拿到7万美元出头。从心理上讲，绑匪很难做出如此大的让步。正如丹尼尔预料的那样，绑匪又回来索要一些“额外好处”，让赎金达到六位数。如果满足绑匪的自尊心是必要的，丹尼尔也乐意这么做。谈判过程中有很多关键时刻，但有两个尤其重要。第一个时刻是绑匪强加给丹尼尔的，他坚持要丹尼尔先提出报价。但在谈判的最后阶段，是丹尼尔主动出击，最终让史蒂文回到了家人身边。“从情感上来说，我当时很想立刻解决这个问题，”他告诉我们，“但理智上，我知道如果我操之过急，惊慌失措只会让事情变得更糟。”

Few of us will face the choices that Daniel confronted, but his experience illustrates principles that apply to critical moments in negotiation across the board:

我们当中很少有人会面临丹尼尔所面临的选择，但他的经历阐明了一些原则，这些原则普遍适用于谈判中的关键时刻：

1. Use Tactical Moves to Execute Strategy.
1.运用战术手段执行战略。

Daniel’s low first offer established a slow but steady path to agreement.

丹尼尔最初的低价报价为最终达成协议奠定了缓慢但稳步前进的基础。

2. Be Decisive in the Face of Risk.
2. 面对风险要果断。

All of Daniel’s alternatives entailed risk. He believed that the prospect of getting some money would keep the kidnapper from acting rashly.

丹尼尔的所有选择都存在风险。他相信，得到一些钱的诱惑会让绑匪不敢轻举妄动。

3. Focus on Your Ultimate Objective, Not Necessarily the Immediate Consequences of Your Decision.
3. 关注你的最终目标，而不是你的决定的直接后果。

Daniel knew that his first offer would not be accepted.

丹尼尔知道他的第一个报价不会被接受。

4. Be Consistent.
4. 保持一致性。

Once Daniel committed to this approach, he had to stay with it. If he had doubled his offer midway in the talks, the kidnapper might have held out for even more.

丹尼尔一旦决定采取这种策略，就必须坚持下去。如果他在谈判中途将报价翻倍，绑匪很可能会索要更多。

5. Be Prepared to Force Agreement, but Take Care to Time Your Moves Well.
5. 要做好迫使对方同意的准备，但要注意把握好行动的时机。

Daniel’s patient bargaining set up his closing gambit.

丹尼尔耐心的谈判为他最后的绝招奠定了基础。

CONFRONTING TOUGH ISSUES

直面棘手问题

Lakhdar Brahimi is the UN diplomat who “navigates by sight.” He is always well prepared, but he keeps his eyes (and mind) wide open for new and better information. He triages as he searches for the elements of a workable deal by sorting issues into three areas.

拉赫达尔·布拉希米是一位“以眼见为先”的联合国外交官。他总是做好充分准备，但同时也时刻保持敏锐的观察力，寻求新的、更有效的信息。在寻找可行协议的关键要素时，他会将问题归纳为三个方面，并进行优先级排序。

His upper zone is out of reach. It contains any item that’s nonnegotiable for the other side. “You don’t need to waste your time asking for it,” Brahimi says. “You will not get it.” Down at the bottom are things that you can get “free of charge,” as he puts it. “And it will be really stupid to pay for something that is there for the taking.” In the middle area are the points that are open to negotiation.

他的上层区域是无法逾越的。那里包含了对方绝对不会妥协的条款。“你不用浪费时间去问，”布拉希米说，“你肯定得不到。” 最下层区域是你可以“免费”获得的东西，正如他所说。“花钱买唾手可得的东西真是愚蠢至极。” 中间区域则是可以协商的条款。

“So don’t lose your time asking for the impossible,” he concludes. “Don’t waste your resources paying for what is free. Concentrate on that area where give-and-take is possible.”

“所以，不要浪费时间去要求不可能的事情，”他总结道。“不要浪费资源去为免费的东西付费。把精力集中在那些可以互惠互利的领域。”

Brahimi’s triage model can help you focus your energy where it will do the most good. But the signage in the negotiation landscape is poor. There aren’t obvious boundaries between yes, maybe, and no. And those boundaries are in shades of gray and can move as you generate options and relationships evolve.

布拉希米的分类模型可以帮助你把精力集中在最有效的地方。但谈判领域的指示牌并不清晰。“是”、“也许”和“否”之间并没有明确的界限。而且，这些界限模糊不清，会随着你提出的选项和关系的演变而变化。

At any given moment, though, you should have a rough sense of which issues are the toughest. Testing that line is a critical moment in negotiation. If you veto something that’s crucial to those on the other side, it could be a deal breaker. Even if it’s not, they may feel the need to ask for something they know that you want.

不过，在任何特定时刻，你都应该大致了解哪些问题最棘手。试探这条底线是谈判的关键时刻。如果你否决了对方非常重视的事项，可能会导致交易失败。即使否决的事项并非至关重要，他们也可能觉得有必要提出一些他们知道你想要的东西。

Think carefully about what you mean in saying no, as well as how and when to express it. A true no is required when there is a line you simply won’t cross even if that results in an impasse. Your position could be based on principle: such as a refusal to pay a kickback as the price of winning a contract. Or it could be based on the practical fact that you can get a better deal elsewhere. By contrast, a strategic no rules out a proposal that you actually could live with, but you expect that the other side will improve it if you hold out. It’s a matter of gauging your counterparts’ baseline, as explained in chapter 2. It comes down to weighing risk and reward. The more room you think they have to move, the more confidently you can say no. You’ll win if their purported take-it-or-leave-it offer proves to be a bluff. If you’re wrong, though, it could cost you the deal.

仔细思考你拒绝的含义，以及如何、何时表达。真正的拒绝是必要的，当你坚持自己的底线，即使这意味着陷入僵局，你也绝不会越过这条底线。你的立场可能基于原则，例如拒绝支付回扣作为赢得合同的代价。也可能基于实际情况，例如你可以在其他地方获得更好的交易。相比之下，策略性拒绝是指你实际上可以接受的提议，但你预期如果你坚持下去，对方会做出改进。这需要你评估对方的底线，正如第二章所述。归根结底，就是权衡风险和回报。你认为对方的让步空间越大，你就越能自信地说“不”。如果他们所谓的“要么接受要么放弃”的提议最终被证明是虚张声势，你就能获胜。但如果你判断错误，则可能会失去这笔交易。

In some cases, you can afford to take that chance. In others, not. You can try to hedge, of course. Rather than rejecting a demand by saying “There’s no way I’m ever paying that much,” you could soften your stance and respond, “Oh. I didn’t plan on paying so much.” The first version ties you to the mast. The second gives you wiggle room in case the other side doesn’t budge. But because this kind of no isn’t as emphatic, it may not be as convincing.

在某些情况下，你可以承担这种风险。但在另一些情况下，则不然。当然，你可以尝试一些折中方案。与其直接拒绝对方的要求，说“我绝对不会付那么多钱”，不如缓和一下语气，回应说：“哦，我没打算付这么多钱。” 第一种说法让你寸步难行。第二种说法则给你留有余地，以防对方不肯让步。但由于这种拒绝不够斩钉截铁，可能也不够令人信服。

A variant of this approach is a pliable no . It rejects the demand as things stand, but it links your ultimate answer to other issues. For instance, you might look a car salesman in the eye and give a flat no to his “last, best offer,” but then add that you’d meet the price provided he includes an extended warranty.

这种方法的变体是“灵活的拒绝”。它拒绝了对方的要求，但将你的最终答案与其他因素联系起来。例如，你可以直视汽车销售员的眼睛，断然拒绝他的“最终最低报价”，但随后补充说，如果他提供延长保修，你可以接受这个价格。

My colleague Bill Ury observes that when you say no to others, you’re really affirming something that’s important to you. He gives the example of an employee whose boss asks him to sacrifice weekend time with his family in order to complete yet another last-minute assignment. Always yielding to such demands isn’t the answer. Nor is simply refusing and leaving it at that.

我的同事比尔·尤里指出，当你对别人说“不”时，实际上是在肯定对你而言重要的东西。他举了一个例子：一位员工的老板要求他牺牲周末陪伴家人的时间，去完成又一项临时任务。总是顺从这样的要求并非解决之道，而简单地拒绝后就此作罢也并非良策。

Instead, Bill recommends what he calls a yes-no-yes. The employee might start by saying that being a good parent is important to him. (That’s the yes to his own priorities.) The subsequent no nixes the request that he work that particular Saturday. But right after that, he could add a second yes. He could suggest, for example, that going forward, they discuss a flextime system in which occasional weekend work would be matched by his leaving early some weekdays to pick up his children from school.

比尔建议采用他所谓的“是-否-是”策略。员工可以先表示，做一个好父亲对他来说很重要。（这是他自己优先事项的肯定。）接下来的“否”表示他拒绝了在那个周六加班的请求。但紧接着，他可以补充第二个“是”。例如，他可以建议，今后可以讨论弹性工作制，偶尔的周末加班可以用他工作日提前下班去接孩子放学来弥补。

Bill describes this technique in his book The Power of a Positive No. This pairing of yeses and nos complements the concept of surfaces and gaps in negotiation (the idea adapted from the military strategy we saw earlier). Your counterparts need to know where you draw the line on important issues. If they don’t, they have every reason to keep pushing beyond that. In walling off certain areas, though, it’s in your interest to open doors to other possibilities that may serve their needs, at least in part.

比尔在他的著作《积极拒绝的力量》中描述了这种技巧。这种“是”与“否”的结合，与谈判中的“表面”与“缺口”概念相辅相成（这个概念借鉴了我们之前看到的军事策略）。你的谈判对手需要知道你在重要问题上的底线在哪里。如果他们不知道，他们完全有理由继续越界。然而，在划定某些界限的同时，你也应该为他们打开其他可能性之门，这些可能性至少可以部分满足他们的需求。

Some negotiators don’t have any trouble saying no. Instead, the problem is coaxing them to say yes. This is especially true with disputes. (Recall the expensive fight among co-op neighbors over $902 window bars.) People may privately wish they could go back and have a fresh start. Often that’s hard, but it’s not impossible.

有些谈判者毫不犹豫地说“不”，难的是如何说服他们“是”。在纠纷中尤其如此。（想想合作公寓邻居们为了902美元的窗户防护栏而展开的那场代价高昂的争斗。）人们或许私下里希望能够回到过去，重新开始。这通常很难，但并非不可能。

FROM NO TO YES

从“不”到“是”

For years, the Humane Society battled with the trade association of the major egg-producing companies in the United States. The society opposed factory farming in general, and, in particular, the practice of caging hundreds of thousands of birds into a single chicken house. It spent millions on lawsuits against the producers. The companies fought back just as vigorously. The only apparent leverage that each side had was the ability to inflict costs on the other. The society never achieved a victory in court, while the egg producers couldn’t shake the bad publicity the litigation was causing.

多年来，美国人道协会与美国主要鸡蛋生产商的行业协会展开了激烈的斗争。该协会反对工厂化养殖，尤其反对将数十万只鸡关在同一个鸡舍里的做法。他们花费数百万美元起诉这些生产商。这些公司也进行了同样猛烈的反击。双方唯一明显的筹码似乎就是互相施加经济压力。该协会从未在法庭上取得胜利，而鸡蛋生产商则始终摆脱不了诉讼带来的负面影响。

But then something happened. In the summer of 2011, Gene Gregory, head of the trade organization, used an intermediary to send a message to Wayne Pacelle, president of the Humane Society. “Can we just talk?” he asked.

但后来发生了一件事。2011年夏天，行业协会主席吉恩·格雷戈里通过中间人向人道协会主席韦恩·帕塞勒传递了一条信息。“我们能谈谈吗？”他问道。

This proved to be a critical moment. The two longtime adversaries met privately. They agreed that the legal battles in state after state were getting them nowhere, so they decided on a different tack. Together they would lobby Congress for stricter federal regulation of poultry farms. That clearly was a victory for the Humane Society, but it was also a win for the producers. Uniform regulations would simplify operations for the big companies and level the field for competitors.

事实证明，这是一个关键时刻。两位长期的对手私下会面。他们一致认为，在各州之间旷日持久的法律诉讼毫无进展，于是决定另辟蹊径。他们将联手游说国会，要求联邦政府加强对家禽养殖场的监管。这无疑对人道协会来说是一次胜利，但对养殖户来说也是如此。统一的监管规定将简化大型企业的运营，并为竞争对手创造公平的竞争环境。

Gregory’s decision to reach out to Pacelle might have backfired if the Humane Society took it as a sign that the producers were losing resolve and could be beaten down with more litigation. Pacelle, in turn, took a risk in collaborating with an organization long seen as “the enemy.” Unlike the warring co-op owners, though, these two realized that they had wasted resources digging themselves into a hole. The time had come to fashion a ladder and climb out.

如果人道协会将此视为生产者们意志消沉、容易被更多诉讼击垮的信号，那么格雷戈里主动联系帕塞勒的决定可能会适得其反。而帕塞勒与这个长期以来被视为“敌人”的组织合作，也同样存在风险。然而，与那些争斗不休的合作社老板不同，这两人意识到他们之前浪费了太多资源，让自己陷入了困境。现在是时候另辟蹊径，走出困境了。

The two men didn’t become friends, but they have developed mutual respect. Gregory understands that Pacelle isn’t trying to put his members out of business. “I’ve found him to be a man of his word,” he says, “and it doesn’t have to be his way or no way.” For his part, Pacelle has come to understand the economic pressures confronting farmers. “They were, kind of, in a race with others in a competitive environment to build efficiencies.” By forging this unexpected relationship, Gregory and Pacelle reframed their objectives. Instead of inflicting costs on each other, they found ways to help advance each other’s agenda. Their adamant nos became pragmatic yeses.

两人并未成为朋友，但彼此之间建立了尊重。格雷戈里明白帕塞勒并非想让他的成员破产。“我发现他是个言而有信的人，”格雷戈里说，“而且事情并非一定要按他的方式来。”帕塞勒也逐渐理解了农民面临的经济压力。“他们就像是在竞争激烈的环境中，与其他人竞相提高效率。”通过建立这种意想不到的关系，格雷戈里和帕塞勒重新调整了各自的目标。他们不再互相造成损失，而是找到了互相帮助推进彼此目标的方法。他们曾经坚决的“不”变成了务实的“是”。

Sometimes it takes an outsider to break a deadlock. In September 1999 Senator George Mitchell returned to Belfast. A year earlier, he had helped Protestants and Catholics reach the Good Friday Agreement to end sectarian bloodshed in Northern Ireland, but the parties had been slow in implementing the terms. Meeting with the key parties yet again, he said:

有时候，打破僵局需要局外人。1999年9月，乔治·米切尔参议员重返贝尔法斯特。一年前，他曾帮助新教徒和天主教徒达成《贝尔法斯特协议》（又称《耶稣受难日协议》），以结束北爱尔兰的教派冲突，但双方在执行协议条款方面进展缓慢。在再次与各主要政党会面时，他表示：

“You know why I love opera? When I go home and put on La Bohème , I know Rodolfo’s going to sing the same words every time, and it gets me prepared to come back to Belfast, because the thing I know is that I’m going to have to sit here and listen to you guys saying the same thing over and over again, every time.”

“你知道我为什么喜欢歌剧吗？每次我回家播放《波西米亚人》时，我知道鲁道夫每次都会唱同样的歌词，这让我做好了回到贝尔法斯特的准备，因为我知道我又要坐在这里，一遍又一遍地听你们说同样的话。”

According to the New York Times , “His listeners were men with no history of enjoying being made fun of. But they laughed.” Mitchell wouldn’t have made such a crack in his first mediation session, nor likely even in his twentieth. But after years of listening to the parties rehash old grudges, it was time to prod them to talk seriously about the future.

据《纽约时报》报道，“他的听众都是些素来不喜欢被人取笑的人。但他们却笑了。”米切尔在第一次调解会议上不会开这样的玩笑，甚至可能在第二十次会议上也不会。但多年来，他听着双方不断重提旧怨，是时候促使他们认真谈谈未来了。

MOVES, TURNS, AND POWER PLAYS

行动、转折和强力进攻

Negotiation is often about more than money or specific terms and conditions. It can also be about who’s running the show. The transaction of power usually takes place below the surface or between the lines of what is said, but it can be as important as the substance itself.

谈判往往不仅仅关乎金钱或具体的条款和条件，它还关乎谁掌握主动权。权力的交锋通常发生在言外之意或字里行间，但它与谈判内容本身同样重要。

Lisa Tschorn was meeting with her boss Stuart Wells about a long-overdue raise and promotion. They’d had a similar talk more than a year earlier that prompted only a small bump in salary. At that time, Stuart had acknowledged Lisa’s diligence and intelligence but said she needed more seasoning to demonstrate “real spark and initiative.”

丽莎·特肖恩正在和她的老板斯图尔特·威尔斯商讨她早就应该得到的加薪和晋升。一年多前，他们也进行过类似的谈话，但当时只小幅涨薪。那时，斯图尔特承认丽莎勤奋聪明，但也说她需要更多历练才能展现出“真正的活力和主动性”。

This time Lisa felt she was ready. She had worked hard the previous twelve months. Early in the conversation, she reminded her boss with justifiable pride about a new product launch that she had headed. But he brushed aside her point by saying, “Lisa, you did a good job, but you were working alongside Clark and Frank. You’re not claiming all the credit, are you?” With that sharp comment, Stuart both dismissed her best argument and belittled her personally.

这一次，丽莎觉得自己准备好了。过去十二个月她一直努力工作。谈话伊始，她就带着理所当然的自豪感向老板提及了她主导的新产品发布会。但他却轻描淡写地说：“丽莎，你做得不错，但你和克拉克、弗兰克一起工作。你不会独揽功劳吧？”斯图尔特这番尖刻的评论，不仅否定了她最有力的论点，也让她颜面尽失。

What’s the best way to deal with real-time challenges like that? Deborah Kolb and Judith Williams, coauthors of Everyday Negotiation: Navigating the Hidden Agendas in Bargaining , catalog four types of possible responses: correcting, diverting, interrupting, and naming. We can think of these as a negotiator’s version of the stock riffs that jazz masters use when they get stuck in the middle of an improvisation.

应对这类实时挑战的最佳方法是什么？《日常谈判：驾驭谈判中的隐性议程》一书的合著者黛博拉·科尔布和朱迪思·威廉姆斯列举了四种可能的应对方式：纠正、转移话题、打断和指出问题。我们可以把它们看作是谈判者版的爵士乐大师在即兴演奏遇到瓶颈时使用的常用技巧。

A correcting move takes issue with an assertion and presents a different way of seeing things. Lisa might respond by saying, “Yes, I appreciated Clark and Frank’s help, but check with them, and they’ll tell you I did the lion’s share of the work.”

纠正性发言是对某种说法提出异议，并提出不同的视角。丽莎可能会回应说：“是的，我很感谢克拉克和弗兰克的帮助，但你去问问他们，他们会告诉你大部分工作都是我做的。”

It takes backbone to contradict one’s boss, of course, but solid preparation can bolster confidence. If Lisa had thought beforehand about both the most likely and the most challenging things that could happen (just as the US Marines do in planning for battle), she might well have anticipated her boss’s cutting remark. And with that in mind, she could have taken the added step of making sure that her two colleagues would back her up.

当然，反驳老板需要勇气，但充分的准备可以增强自信。如果丽莎事先考虑到最可能发生的情况和最具挑战性的情况（就像美国海军陆战队在作战计划中所做的那样），她或许就能预料到老板的尖刻评论。有了这样的准备，她还可以采取进一步措施，确保她的两位同事会支持她。

A diverting move is a variant on this approach. It seeks to depersonalize the conversation by focusing on the substance of the problem. Rather than rising to the bait, Lisa could remind her boss of the revenue the new product is generating and document all the effort she invested to make it succeed.

转移话题是这种方法的变体。它旨在通过聚焦问题的实质来淡化个人恩怨。与其上钩，丽莎不如提醒老板新产品带来的收益，并详细记录她为产品成功所付出的所有努力。

Other times an interrupting move is best. Even a short break can give everyone a chance to settle down and regain perspective. When that’s not possible, other process moves can have the same effect. For example, Lisa might take a breath and say, “Let’s step back for a moment and see what we agree on. You know that we talked about a promotion a year ago, and just now you acknowledged I’m doing a good job. So how do we figure out the best way to move forward?”

有时候，打断一下反而是最好的办法。哪怕只是短暂的休息，也能让大家有机会冷静下来，重新审视问题。如果实在不行，其他一些流程调整也能起到同样的效果。例如，丽莎可以深吸一口气，然后说：“我们先退一步，看看我们有哪些共识。你知道我们一年前讨论过升职的事，而你刚才也承认我工作做得不错。那么，我们该如何找到最佳的推进方案呢？”

Kolb and Williams recommend a naming move for certain cases. It’s a direct statement that you recognize the power play and won’t put up with it. This is a high-risk response, though. You may be 100 percent right, but it puts your counterpart in a position where he may think his only choice is caving in or counterattacking. If somebody angers you, however, don’t suffer silently. For both your sakes, give the person a chance to self-correct before you tune out him or her or storm out the door.

科尔布和威廉姆斯建议在某些情况下使用“点名批评”策略。这是一种直接的声明，表明你识破了对方的权力游戏，并且不会容忍。然而，这是一种高风险的应对方式。你或许百分之百正确，但这会让对方觉得他唯一的选择要么是屈服，要么是反击。但是，如果有人惹恼了你，不要默默忍受。为了你们双方的利益，在你完全无视他/她或者愤然离去之前，先给对方一个自我纠正的机会。

What you say should be matched by how you carry yourself. Remember the real estate negotiation from the chapter on openings—specifically, how the second developer got his prospective tenant to consider adjustments in its standard lease? He mentioned that when his company had asked about revisions earlier, it had gotten “a good negotiating response last time: company policy.” This developer called out the company-policy tactic but did so with a broad smile and a wave of the hand, as if he were sweeping it away. The message was that he wasn’t rattled, nor had he taken offense. His whole manner conveyed that he knew how the game was played.

你的言行举止应该与你的言谈相符。还记得我们在“开业”那一章中提到的房地产谈判吗？特别是第二位开发商是如何让潜在租户考虑修改标准租赁条款的？他提到，之前他的公司询问过修改事宜，得到的答复是“公司政策”。这位开发商指出了对方的“公司政策”策略，但他面带微笑，挥了挥手，仿佛在将其抛诸脑后。这传递出的信息是：他并不慌乱，也没有生气。他的整个态度都表明，他深谙谈判之道。

Well-timed moves and turns can redirect the negotiation process and create an environment for constructive problem solving. The hard part is successfully advocating one’s own social position while also striving for genuine connection with the other side. Not every demand or sarcastic remark needs to be challenged, but if too many pass without resistance, there is the risk that preconceptions will be confirmed and roles ratified.

恰当的行动和策略可以引导谈判进程，营造有利于建设性解决问题的环境。难点在于既要成功维护自身的社会地位，又要努力与对方建立真诚的联系。并非每一项要求或讽刺言论都需要反驳，但如果太多此类情况不加抵抗地被接受，就存在先入为主的观念得到强化、角色固化的风险。

My colleague Gerry Williams videotaped experienced family lawyers trying to work out a separation agreement. In this unscripted simulation, Gerry asked the female attorney (Chris) to represent a husband whose wife had run off with the local tennis pro. He had a male attorney (David) represent the wife. The two lawyers were told to handle the case just as they would in real life.

我的同事格里·威廉姆斯拍摄了一段经验丰富的家庭律师试图协商分居协议的视频。在这段模拟场景中，格里让女律师克里斯代表一位妻子与当地网球职业选手私奔的丈夫，并安排男律师大卫代表妻子。两位律师被告知要像在现实生活中一样处理此案。

Chris: I think this is a case with a lot of young children and two young people who have a lot of needs. I think if we can work something out at this juncture without getting ourselves into a litigation stance, we can do a favor for both our clients.

克里斯：我认为这起案件涉及很多年幼的孩子，还有两个有很多需求的年轻人。我认为，如果我们能在现阶段找到解决办法，避免诉讼，就能帮到我们的双方客户。

David: Well, I think it’s a good idea, Mrs. Brougham. May I call you Chris? Is that your first name?

大卫：嗯，我觉得这是个好主意，布鲁厄姆太太。我可以叫你克里斯吗？那是你的名字吗？

Chris: That will be fine.

克里斯：没问题。

David: I think we had a case together a few years ago. Do you recall?

大卫：我想几年前我们一起办过一个案子。你还记得吗？

Chris: Yes, I remember.

克里斯：是的，我记得。

David: I appreciate your offer to sit down and visit about this matter. We had a fun time before, but I didn’t get to know you that well. How long have you been practicing?

大卫：感谢你提出坐下来谈谈这件事。我们之前相处得很愉快，但我对你了解得并不算深。你从事这个行业多久了？

Chris: About five years.

克里斯：大约五年。

David: I see. Do you do a lot of domestic relations work?

大卫：我明白了。你经常处理家庭关系方面的工作吗？

Chris: Enough. It keeps me busy.

克里斯：够了。这让我很忙。

David: How long have you known Tom? Has he been an old client?

大卫：你认识汤姆多久了？他是你的老客户吗？

Chris: No. Tom was referred to me by another divorce client.

克里斯：不，汤姆是另一位离婚客户介绍给我的。

David: I see. Did you do any work for the Smiths prior to this time?

大卫：我明白了。在此之前你为史密斯一家工作过吗？

Chris: Not in this area. I had some contacts with Tom in connection with an investment that he was considering a few years back, but it never came to fruition.

克里斯：不在这个领域。几年前，我曾与汤姆有过一些接触，当时他考虑过一项投资，但最终未能实现。

David: Did you meet Barbara at this time?

大卫：你当时遇到芭芭拉了吗？

Chris begins the conversation by welcoming David, but he then seizes control even though he has the far weaker case. He peppers her with questions, vetting her experience rather than exploring the matter at hand. He has a wide smile, but his tone is patronizing. Nevertheless, Chris maintains her poise. Her posture is straight. Her expression doesn’t falter. She gives short, polite answers to his questions (though David is so quick with the next one, he doesn’t seem to be listening).

克里斯首先欢迎了戴维，但随后戴维却掌控了局面，尽管他的论点远不如克里斯有力。他连珠炮似地抛出一连串问题，与其说是探讨问题本身，不如说是在考察克里斯的经验。他脸上挂着灿烂的笑容，但语气却居高临下。尽管如此，克里斯依然保持着镇定。她身姿挺拔，表情坚定。她礼貌地简短回答了他的问题（但戴维很快就抛出了下一个问题，似乎根本没在听）。

In my class, I stop the video at this point and ask my students how these negotiators are doing. Almost everyone criticizes Chris, men and women alike. They grant that she’s focused and businesslike, but they think she’s dancing to David’s tune. “What should she do about it?” I ask. Many think she’s already put herself in a bad position by letting him dominate. Some say that she should call him out, or else it will be a nonstop interrogation. Others wonder if she’s capable of standing up to him.

在我的课堂上，我会在视频播放到这里时暂停，然后问学生们这些谈判者表现如何。几乎所有人都批评克里斯，无论男女。他们承认她专注且专业，但认为她完全被大卫牵着鼻子走。“她应该怎么办？”我问。许多人认为她让大卫主导谈判已经让她陷入了不利境地。有些人说她应该当面质问他，否则就会变成没完没了的审问。还有人怀疑她是否有能力反抗他。

Almost everyone agrees that Chris must turn around the interaction, or things will go badly for her and her client. I remind viewers that we have the advantage of the pause button. Chris had to respond in real time. Then I resume the video just after David’s question about whether she had recently met Barbara.

几乎所有人都认为克里斯必须扭转局面，否则对她和她的客户都非常不利。我提醒观众，我们有暂停键这个优势。克里斯必须实时回应。然后，我继续播放视频，就在大卫问她最近是否见过芭芭拉之后。

Chris: No. I have not met Barbara yet. I assume that she’s been into your office to see you?

克里斯：不，我还没见过芭芭拉。我猜她来过你的办公室吧？

David: Yes. She came in to see me. She was referred to me by a brother of hers who’s been a good client of mine for years. He’s a politician, but Barbara is a lot different personality than he is.

大卫：是的。她来找过我。她哥哥介绍她来的，他多年来一直是我的好客户。他是个政客，但芭芭拉的性格和他截然不同。

Chris: Well, yes. She had received the complaint, I assume, by the time she saw you?

克里斯：嗯，是的。我猜她见到你的时候应该已经收到投诉了吧？

It’s easy to miss Chris’s diverting move because she executes it so smoothly, but Chris changes the direction of the conversation 180 degrees. Look at how she answers his question about Barbara but then adds a question of her own. It’s a way to reassert control, by both interrupting the process and changing the subject. It’s not a naming move. It says nothing about David’s behavior, but it breaks his rhythm.

克里斯的转移话题的举动很容易被忽略，因为她的动作非常流畅自然，但她却让谈话的方向来了个180度大转弯。注意看她是如何回答大卫关于芭芭拉的问题，然后又抛出一个自己的问题。这是一种重新掌控局面的方式，既打断了大卫的思路，又转移了话题。这并非指责大卫，也并非针对大卫的行为，而是打乱了他的节奏。

Then see how she solidifies her control by asking a second, more pointed question. It reminds David of the legal complaint that has been filed against his client for abandoning her husband and their children. Without embarrassing David, Chris is telling him that she has the upper hand. His smile disappears. He slouches a bit. His expression turns serious. You can almost see his dawning realization that his glib patter doesn’t work with Chris. Her no-nonsense manner carries a message about the professional respect that Chris expects David to show her.

接下来，看看她如何通过第二个更尖锐的问题来巩固自己的优势。这个问题让大卫想起针对他委托人提起的诉讼，指控她遗弃了丈夫和孩子。克里斯并没有让大卫难堪，而是在告诉他，她掌握了主动权。大卫的笑容消失了，他微微弯下腰，表情变得严肃起来。你几乎能看出他开始意识到，他那套花言巧语对克里斯根本不起作用。克里斯毫不含糊的态度传递出一个信息：她希望大卫对她表现出应有的职业尊重。

The interaction between the two is a microexample of the learning, adapting, and influencing model that I’ve emphasized throughout the book. Here it’s Chris who is doing the influencing. But to David’s credit, he reads her signal and adjusts accordingly. After acknowledging that his client has received notice of the suit, he continues:

两人之间的互动是我在书中反复强调的学习、适应和影响模型的一个微缩例子。在这里，是克里斯在施加影响。但值得称赞的是，大卫领会了她的暗示并做出了相应的调整。在确认他的客户已收到诉讼通知后，他继续说道：

David: And she was rather distraught and depressed when she came in, but I managed to get some salient facts from her. And I think that we’re at a point where we can talk about some matters and see if there’s any solution to any of the problems.

大卫：她进来的时候情绪相当低落，但我还是设法从她那里了解到一些关键信息。我认为我们现在可以谈谈一些事情，看看能否找到解决问题的办法。

In a quick pivot, David got down to business, thanks to Chris’s lead. Her move was perfectly timed. She wasn’t hypersensitive about his manner. Chris waited until he was out of oxygen and then put a stop to his rapid-fire interrogation. She couldn’t know whether he was trying to dominate the process or was simply awkward dealing with women. Whatever his motivation, the conversation wasn’t going where she wanted it to, so she took charge—and did it so subtly that David may not have realized what happened.

多亏克里斯的引导，大卫迅速转变思路，开始进入正题。克里斯的举动时机把握得恰到好处。她并没有对他的举止过于敏感。克里斯等到他几乎喘不过气来，才制止了他连珠炮般的盘问。她无法判断他是想掌控局面，还是只是不擅长与女性相处。无论他的动机是什么，谈话的方向都与她预想的背道而驰，于是她接管了局面——而且手法非常巧妙，以至于大卫可能根本没察觉到发生了什么。

Kolb and Williams call dances like this “shadow negotiation.” It’s enacted in a broader social context and is about defining power, roles, and relationships. Specific transactions often implicate larger issues, especially within organizations. Those advantaged by unstated rules and norms have little reason to change them. Others burdened by them grow frustrated. Pressure can build up below the surface of a conversation. Someone who feels disrespected will respond with shame and even anger.

科尔布和威廉姆斯将这种互动称为“影子谈判”。它发生在更广泛的社会背景下，旨在界定权力、角色和关系。具体的交易往往牵涉到更深层次的问题，尤其是在组织内部。那些受益于不成文规则和规范的人几乎没有理由去改变它们。而那些受其束缚的人则会感到沮丧。压力会在对话的表面之下积聚。感到不被尊重的人会以羞愧甚至愤怒来回应。

Was what he just said a put-down, you may ask yourself, or just a poor attempt at humor? Coping with that ambiguity requires awareness of your own feelings as well as those of your counterparts. Effective moves and turns at critical moments aren’t just about what you say, but how and when you say it.

你可能会问自己，他刚才说的话是贬低你，还是只是拙劣的幽默？应对这种模棱两可的情况，需要你既了解自己的感受，也了解对方的感受。在关键时刻，有效的应对和转变不仅仅在于你说了什么，更在于你怎么说、什么时候说。

Critical moments arise when parties aren’t working well on one or more of these levels. Dogged attention to the substantive issues may mask their real conflict or misunderstanding. For example, two negotiators might be haggling about the terms of sale for a small business. Their fight over the wording of a noncompete clause may have more to do with the founder-seller’s need for the new owner’s respect than with financial considerations. Both parties will be stymied, however, if they restrict themselves to using legal jargon as a proxy for dealing with underlying personal issues.

当各方在上述一个或多个层面合作不畅时，就会出现关键时刻。过分关注实质性问题可能会掩盖他们真正的冲突或误解。例如，两位谈判者可能正在就一家小型企业的出售条款讨价还价。他们就竞业禁止条款措辞的争论，或许更多地源于创始人兼卖方希望获得新所有者的尊重，而非出于经济考量。然而，如果双方都局限于使用法律术语来掩盖潜在的个人问题，那么谈判将会陷入僵局。

OUTBURSTS AND RESCUES

爆发与救援

Bill Gates and Steve Jobs had a complex relationship. They were rivals, of course, both in the marketplace and in the public spotlight. But their two companies did substantial business together even as they competed for customers and acclaim. Microsoft actually wrote important software for some Apple devices. Jobs biographer Walter Isaacson likens the relationship at times to “a scorpion dance, with both sides circling warily, knowing that a sting by either could cause problems for both.”

比尔·盖茨和史蒂夫·乔布斯的关系十分复杂。他们当然是竞争对手，无论是在市场上还是在公众视野中。但即便在争夺客户和声誉的同时，他们的两家公司也开展了大量的业务合作。微软甚至为一些苹果设备编写了重要的软件。乔布斯的传记作者沃尔特·艾萨克森有时将这种关系比作“蝎子舞，双方都小心翼翼地盘旋，因为知道任何一方的蛰都会给双方带来麻烦”。

Tension between the two men came to a head when Microsoft was preparing to launch Windows. Jobs felt that the new product blatantly copied Apple’s graphic operating system. He was furious, even though both Microsoft and Apple had borrowed liberally from an operating system developed earlier at Xerox, PARC. Jobs summoned Gates to a meeting. In front of Apple’s top management team, Jobs excoriated him, shouting, “You’re ripping us off! I trusted you, and now you’re stealing from us!”

当微软准备发布Windows系统时，两人之间的矛盾达到了白热化。乔布斯认为这款新产品公然抄袭了苹果的图形操作系统。尽管微软和苹果都曾大量借鉴施乐帕克研究中心（PARC）早期开发的操作系统，但他仍然怒不可遏。乔布斯召见盖茨，在苹果高管面前，他当着所有人的面痛斥盖茨：“你们在剽窃我们的成果！我曾经信任你们，现在你们却在偷窃我们的劳动成果！”

Gates just sat there, however, and then offered another way to look at it. “I think it’s more like we both had this rich neighbor named Xerox, and I broke into his house to steal the TV set and found out you had already stolen it.” Gates’s response is a classic correction move. Perhaps it was spontaneous. Or, knowing Jobs’s mercurial temperament, maybe Gates had it up his sleeve ready to play at the right moment. Rather than fall into the trap of defending himself, Gates cheerfully admitted to being a thief but differed on who it was that he had stolen from. He also reminded Jobs that he had been in on the same heist as well.

然而，盖茨只是坐在那里，然后提出了另一种看待这件事的方式。“我觉得更像是我们俩都有一个叫施乐的富裕邻居，我闯进他家想偷电视机，结果发现你已经偷走了。”盖茨的这番话堪称经典的纠正策略。或许是即兴发挥，又或许，考虑到乔布斯反复无常的脾气，盖茨早已胸有成竹，准备在合适的时机使出这招。盖茨并没有落入为自己辩解的陷阱，而是欣然承认自己是小偷，但对偷窃的对象却提出了不同的看法。他还提醒乔布斯，自己也参与了这起盗窃案。

Jobs’s anger abated somewhat. Later the two men met privately, and Gates demonstrated the new operating system. Jobs was scornful about its design (with some justification) but recognized that he had little legal standing to thwart its release. But Gates’s composure earlier was just as important in preserving the business relationship. Gates says of himself, “I’m good at when people are emotional, I’m kind of less emotional.”

乔布斯的怒气稍稍平息了一些。之后两人私下会面，盖茨向乔布斯演示了新的操作系统。乔布斯对它的设计嗤之以鼻（这并非毫无道理），但他意识到自己几乎没有法律依据阻止其发布。然而，盖茨此前的沉着冷静对于维系双方的商业关系同样至关重要。盖茨曾这样评价自己：“我擅长应对情绪激动的人，而我本人则比较冷静。”

It’s one thing to defuse a tense situation that’s not of your own making. But what if you’re the person who did or said something foolish? Two things may be needed to set things right: a lot of brass and a friend like Kramer, the goofy neighbor on the old Seinfeld show.

化解并非由你造成的紧张局势是一回事，但如果是你做了蠢事或说了蠢话呢？要解决问题，或许需要两样东西：十足的勇气，以及像老版情景喜剧《宋飞正传》里那个傻乎乎的邻居克莱默那样的朋友。

Years ago, a young comic named David had the coveted but highly demanding job of writing for Saturday Night Live. New material had to be cranked out each week, and the rehearsal schedule was brutal. Much of what got written ended up in the wastebasket. Like many comics, David had a big ego plus insecurities to match. He lobbied hard for his material. Sometimes too hard.

多年前，一位名叫大卫的年轻喜剧演员获得了《周六夜现场》的编剧这份令人艳羡却又压力巨大的工作。他每周都必须创作新段子，排练日程也十分紧张。很多写出来的段子最终都被扔进了垃圾桶。和许多喜剧演员一样，大卫自负心强，同时又极度缺乏安全感。他极力争取保留自己的段子，有时甚至用力过猛。

David had gone through a bad streak. The producers had scrapped a half dozen of his sketches. The last one was cut after dress rehearsal. Five minutes before airtime, David accosted Dick Ebersol, the executive producer, in the control room. Ebersol was already wearing his headphones and was intent on the imminent broadcast. Nevertheless, David lit into him, telling him everything that was wrong with the show. Then in a flare of temper, he quit. By the time he got home, David regretted his outburst. His next-door neighbor told him he was stupid for quitting a well-paying job that other writers would kill for.

大卫最近诸事不顺。制片人砍掉了他六个小品，最后一个甚至在彩排后也被删掉了。节目播出前五分钟，大卫在控制室里拦住了执行制片人迪克·埃伯索尔。埃伯索尔已经戴上了耳机，全神贯注于即将到来的播出。尽管如此，大卫还是对他破口大骂，把节目里所有的问题都一一列举出来。然后，他一怒之下辞职了。回到家后，大卫后悔不已。他的邻居说他真是个傻瓜，竟然放弃了这份其他编剧梦寐以求的高薪工作。

“What can I do?” David moaned.

“我能怎么办？”大卫呻吟道。

“Pretend it never happened,” his neighbor said.

“就当这件事没发生过吧。”他的邻居说。

Monday morning, David showed up for the writers’ meeting. His colleagues were too shocked by his arrival to say anything. It wasn’t their place to challenge him (and they probably wondered what was going to happen next). Then Dick Ebersol came in. The writers’ room was just as it had been every Monday in the past. Ebersol shot David a funny look but never said a word.

星期一早上，大卫出现在编剧会议上。他的同事们被他的到来震惊得说不出话来。他们不好意思质疑他（而且他们可能也在猜测接下来会发生什么）。这时，迪克·埃伯索尔走了进来。编剧室里和以往每个星期一一样，一片混乱。埃伯索尔朝大卫投来一个意味深长的眼神，但一句话也没说。

The punch line? Sometimes situations that seem irreversible actually aren’t. It’s just that we’re so involved emotionally we can’t see a way out. That’s when we need a fresh perspective from a friend or colleague who’s more daring than we are ourselves.

关键在于：有时候，看似无法挽回的局面其实并非如此。只是我们深陷其中，看不到出路。这时，我们需要一位比我们更有胆识的朋友或同事，为我们提供一个全新的视角。

There’s a postscript to this particular case. The David here is the comic Larry David, who later became the fabulously successful producer of Seinfeld and then the creator and star of Curb Your Enthusiasm . The real-life neighbor who advised him to act as though his tantrum never happened became the model for Jerry Seinfeld’s fictional neighbor, Kramer. If this story seems familiar, maybe it’s because Larry David later exploited it as a gag in one of his Seinfeld shows.

这个案例还有个后记。这里的大卫指的是喜剧演员拉里·大卫，他后来成为《宋飞正传》的制片人，并凭借此剧一炮而红，之后又创作并主演了《抑制热情》。现实生活中，那位建议他装作没发过脾气的邻居，后来成了杰瑞·宋飞剧中虚构邻居克莱默的原型。如果你觉得这个故事似曾相识，那可能是因为拉里·大卫后来在《宋飞正传》的一集中把它用作了一个笑料。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Recognize what can—and cannot—be accomplished at any given moment.

■ 认识到在任何特定时刻可以完成什么，以及不能完成什么。

■ Know how to say no without ending the negotiation.

■ 懂得如何在不结束谈判的情况下说“不”。

■ Use moves and turns to shift power imbalances.

■ 利用行动和回合来改变力量不平衡局面。

■ Set up the end game.

■ 设定最终目标。

#↩

[ 10 ] Closing

[ 10 ] 结束

A couple of years ago, a colleague of mine was being wooed by a well-regarded university (not my own, incidentally). We’ll call him Ben Evans to spare him embarrassment. Ben was flattered that Arundel University (also a pseudonym) was interested in him and excited about the prospect of moving back East.

几年前，我的一位同事受到一所知名大学的青睐（顺便一提，不是我的母校）。为了避免他尴尬，我们姑且称他为本·埃文斯。本对阿伦德尔大学（也是化名）的关注感到受宠若惊，并对重返东部的前景感到兴奋。

There still were some issues to be worked out, though. Arundel’s usual practice was to have lateral hires come in as visitors for a year before being given a permanent position. “Sorry,” said Ben, “but you know my work well, and I’m not comfortable with being on probation.” Arundel made an exception and agreed to grant him tenure right from the start.

不过，还有一些问题需要解决。阿伦德尔通常的做法是，从外聘人员先以访客身份工作一年，然后再转为正式员工。“抱歉，”本说，“但您很了解我的工作，我不喜欢被试用。”阿伦德尔破例同意从一开始就给他终身教职。

Then there was salary. Arundel’s scale was lower than he had expected. Ben pushed hard for the upper end of the range and won that too. Getting an increase in his research budget proved more difficult, but he made headway there as well.

接下来是薪资问题。阿伦德尔的薪资标准比他预期的要低。本努力争取到了薪资范围的上限，并且成功了。争取增加研究经费则更加困难，但他在这方面也取得了进展。

“Are we all done?” asked the dean when that was resolved.

“都结束了吗？”院长在问题解决后问道。

“Just one more thing,” said Ben. “This is a big move for my wife and me. She’ll have to wind down her present job and find something new near Arundel. We’d like to delay our arrival for a year.” There was silence on the other end of the line, and then the dean said, “Let me get back to you on that.”

“还有一件事，”本说道，“这对我妻子和我来说都是件大事。她得辞掉现在的工作，在阿伦德尔附近找份新工作。我们想推迟一年搬过去。”电话那头沉默了一会儿，然后院长说：“我稍后再回复你们。”

That was around noon on a Wednesday. Thursday came and went. Late Friday morning, the doorbell rang. Ben signed for a FedEx delivery and then opened the white cardboard mailer. Inside was a standard business-size envelope that contained a two-sentence letter:

那是星期三中午左右。星期四过去了。星期五上午晚些时候，门铃响了。本签收了联邦快递的包裹，然后打开了白色的硬纸板信封。里面是一个标准的商务信封，装着一封只有两句话的信：

Dear Professor Evans,

尊敬的埃文斯教授：

We are withdrawing our offer for a faculty position at Arundel University. We wish you well in your academic career.

我们撤回之前向您提供的阿伦德尔大学教职邀请。祝您在学术生涯中一切顺利。

Yours truly,

敬上，

Dean J. Joseph Gibson

迪恩·J·约瑟夫·吉布森

Ben was stunned. Everything had gone so well, with Arundel agreeing to most of what he’d asked for. And for him, the start time wasn’t a deal breaker. He just wanted to raise the issue. If being on board this coming September was that important to Arundel, he’d find a way to manage it. Why didn’t the dean just say no? Ben phoned a friend on the faculty and asked how he could salvage the deal. “It’s over, Ben,” the friend said. “I tried to stick up for you, but people have moved on. As somebody else put it, if you were like this during courtship, marriage was going to be hell.”

本震惊了。一切都进展得那么顺利，阿伦德尔几乎同意了他提出的所有要求。对他来说，开学时间并非决定性因素。他只是想提出这个问题。如果阿伦德尔真的那么在意他能否在九月份入职，他会想办法解决的。院长为什么不直接拒绝呢？本给一位在学院里的朋友打了电话，问他该如何挽回局面。“没办法了，本，”朋友说。“我尽力帮你说话了，但大家都已经释怀了。就像别人说的，如果你恋爱时就这么固执，结婚后肯定会很痛苦。”

Ben didn’t land in the gutter. He has his old job and continues to do great work. But he still kicks himself for blowing what would have been a major step up professionally. He wishes he had taken the original offer without saying a peep. That may be an overreaction, though. After all, he did convert a look-see visitorship into a tenure offer. And he got a bump in salary as well. The deal fell apart only after he asked for still more.

本并没有一蹶不振。他保住了原来的工作，而且工作做得非常出色。但他仍然懊悔不已，因为错失了一次职业生涯的重大飞跃。他后悔当初没吭声地接受最初的邀请。不过，这或许有些反应过度了。毕竟，他确实把一个考察访问的机会转化成了终身教职。而且他的薪水也涨了。只是因为他要求更高的薪水，这笔交易才告吹。

When are you done in negotiation? If we’re not making progress and you have an attractive alternative within your reach, then it’s easy to know that it’s time to walk away. But it’s harder to know whether to wrap it up when negotiation is going well. If you get a satisfactory offer, do we take it or press for more? The art of knowing when to say yes—and how to say it—is essential to negotiation success. So is knowing how to get a yes from the other side.

谈判何时结束？如果谈判毫无进展，而你又有更有吸引力的替代方案，那么很容易判断何时应该结束谈判。但如果谈判进展顺利，何时结束谈判就比较难把握了。如果对方提出了令人满意的报价，我们是接受还是继续争取更高的条件？懂得何时说“是”以及如何说“是”是谈判成功的关键。同样重要的是，要知道如何才能让对方同意。

WHEN TO SAY YES

何时说“是”

The only way to know how far you can go without exploding a deal is by going a little farther than that. Short of that point, you’re operating in a gray area. It’s like driving on the interstate. If the posted limit is sixty-five miles per hour, you almost certainly can go sixty-eight without getting ticketed. You’re probably okay at seventy-two as well, though you should keep your eyes open for patrol cars. At seventy-five miles per hour or more, you could be pushing your luck.

想知道在不破坏交易的前提下你能走多远，唯一的办法就是稍微超前一点。否则，你就处于灰色地带。这就像在州际公路上开车。如果限速是每小时65英里，你几乎肯定可以开到68英里而不会被罚款。72英里可能也没问题，不过你得注意看有没有巡逻车。如果时速达到或超过75英里，那你就有点冒险了。

It’s actually harder in negotiation. Whatever signs are posted are hard to read and may be in a language that’s difficult to grasp. Ben spoke to the dean long distance, but even if they had met face-to-face, they still could have been far apart in respect to what was said and what was meant. Ben felt that he was floating practical questions. No harm in asking, he told himself. On the other end of the line, however, his inquiries sounded like demands, each one more presumptuous than the last.

实际上，谈判比想象中更难。张贴的告示难以辨认，而且使用的语言可能晦涩难懂。本和院长进行了远程通话，但即便他们面对面交流，彼此的理解也可能存在很大偏差。本觉得自己只是提出了一些实际的问题。他告诉自己，问问又何妨。然而，电话那头的他却觉得这些问题像是命令，一个比一个咄咄逼人。

Ben admits that much of the blame for having killed the deal lies with him. He thought only about the upside of sweetening the package, without considering how things looked from the other side. Maybe the dean had risen up through the ranks and worked hard to earn the perks that Ben expected to be handed to him. Other Arundel faculty members may have already resented an outsider getting a better deal than they had themselves.

本承认，这笔交易失败很大程度上要归咎于他。他只想着如何提高条件，却完全没有考虑对方的感受。或许院长一路晋升，辛勤工作才赢得了本以为唾手可得的那些好处。其他阿伦德尔学院的教职工可能也早已对一个外来者获得比他们更好的待遇感到不满。

But the dean bears responsibility for the stalemate too. He may have been stunned by Ben’s audacity. Perhaps he’s someone who has trouble saying no. Ben heard the question “Are we done?” literally, taking it as an invitation to add yet another demand to the mix. But the dean may have meant, “Watch it, my friend, you’re testing my patience.” Ben was treading close to the edge but missed the subtle warning.

但院长也难辞其咎。他或许被本的厚颜无耻吓了一跳。也许他是个不善于拒绝别人的人。本把“我们结束了吗？”这句话理解成了邀请，以为院长又可以提出新的要求。但院长的本意可能是：“注意点，朋友，你这是在挑战我的耐心。” 本当时已经游走在忍耐的边缘，却错过了院长这番微妙的警告。

From where you sit, your counterparts’ baseline will always seem fuzzy. You can’t count on them to give you clear signals, so you have to allow for different possibilities. A back-of-the-envelope decision tree would have helped Ben clarify his choice. One option—a sure thing—would be accepting Arundel’s already handsome offer. The other possibility—counteroffering—could lead to an outcome that could be better, worse, or the same, depending entirely on the dean’s reaction.

从你的角度来看，对方的底线总是模糊不清的。你不能指望他们给你明确的信号，所以你必须考虑各种可能性。一个简单的决策树可以帮助本理清思路。一个选择——稳妥之选——是接受阿伦德尔已经相当优厚的条件。另一个选择——提出还价——则可能导致更好的结果、更差的结果，或者结果相同，这完全取决于院长的反应。

Calculating exact odds for those eventualities is impossible, but Ben knew that deferring his arrival for a year was far from a sure thing. Most likely, he’d get a flat no. Also, as proved to be the case, his request could be the last straw for the university. Even without attaching percentages, however, sketching the alternatives would have underscored how little there was to gain compared with all that could be (and ultimately was) lost.

精确计算这些可能性发生的概率是不可能的，但本知道推迟一年入学远非板上钉钉。他很可能直接被拒绝。而且，正如后来证明的那样，他的请求很可能成为压垮骆驼的最后一根稻草。即便不考虑具体概率，仅仅是列出各种可能性就能凸显出，与可能（最终也确实）失去的一切相比，他所能获得的微乎其微。

That’s not to say you should never push. The downside of counteroffering might not be so stark in other situations. But whenever you ask someone on the other side to improve her offer, there’s a decent chance that she’ll ask for something else in return. Before dragging out a negotiation, therefore, you should have reason to believe that it’s worth the risk. Having a good walkaway option enables you to push harder, of course. If you’re car shopping, for instance, and are stalemated at one dealership, it’s easy to try somewhere else. But cases such as Ben’s call for caution. When someone hands you a tasty piece of cake, with rich frosting to boot, think twice about asking for sprinkles on top. What you stand to gain on the margin may be dwarfed by what you could lose.

这并不是说你永远不应该施压。在其他情况下，还价的弊端可能并不那么明显。但是，每当你要求对方提高报价时，对方很有可能会提出其他条件作为交换。因此，在拖延谈判之前，你应该有理由相信这样做是值得的。当然，拥有一个好的退路能让你更有底气地施压。例如，如果你正在买车，并且在一家经销商那里陷入僵局，很容易就能去别的地方试试。但像本的情况就需要谨慎。当有人递给你一块美味的蛋糕，上面还涂满了浓郁的糖霜时，要三思而后行，不要要求在上面撒些糖屑。你可能获得的微薄收益，与你可能失去的损失相比，可能微不足道。

Several years ago, a small company—call it Brims—paid $225,000 for downtown land in a Northern California coastal community. It planned to build a coffee shop that would serve the local market as well as a growing number of tourists. But the owner of the abutting property fought the development, not wanting to lose the harbor views from his bed-and-breakfast, the Westerly.

几年前，一家名为 Brims 的小公司斥资 22.5 万美元在北加州沿海社区的市中心购置了一块地皮。该公司计划在此建造一家咖啡馆，服务于当地居民以及日益增多的游客。然而，毗邻地块的业主却极力反对这项开发计划，因为他不想失去自家民宿 Westerly 的海港美景。

After failing to block a building permit, the Westerly owner offered to buy the disputed lot from Brims for what it had put into the project: the initial purchase price plus its preliminary development costs, for a total of about $250,000. He said that the figure would “make Brims whole and spare them the risk of litigation.” Brims felt the legal claims were groundless. It rejected the proposal out of hand, without making a counterproposal.

在阻止建筑许可申请失败后，韦斯特利的业主提出以布里姆斯在该项目上的投入为代价，从布里姆斯手中购买争议地块：包括初始购买价格和前期开发成本，总计约25万美元。他表示，这个价格可以“弥补布里姆斯的损失，并避免诉讼风险”。布里姆斯认为这些法律诉讼毫无根据，断然拒绝了这一提议，并未提出任何反方案。

The Westerly owner went to court but lost his bid for a restraining order and failed on other fronts as well. Two months after making his initial proposal, he approached Brims’s lawyer about reopening negotiations. “Look,” she replied. “You didn’t offer nearly enough to tempt my clients last time, and all you’ve done since then is make them angrier.” If he wanted the property, she told him not to be “cute,” as she put it. “Give us your best offer, and we’ll give you either a yes or a no.”

韦斯特利的业主曾诉诸法庭，但申请限制令的努力失败，其他方面也均告失败。在最初提出报价两个月后，他联系了布里姆斯的律师，希望重新谈判。“听着，”她回答说，“你上次的报价根本无法打动我的客户，而且你之后所做的只是让他们更加生气。”她告诉他，如果他真的想要这处房产，就别耍花招。“拿出你的最佳报价，我们会给你一个肯定或否定的答复。”

The next day, the man called and offered $500,000—which was more than enough to buy another prime commercial site in town. In fact, there was a property for sale just two blocks away that already had a good-looking building on it. Brims could be up and running well before its scheduled opening.

第二天，那人打来电话，出价50万美元——这笔钱足够在镇上买下另一处黄金地段的商业用地。事实上，就在两个街区外，有一处待售的房产，上面已经建有一栋外观不错的建筑。布里姆斯餐厅完全可以在预定开业日期前就投入运营。

It looked like a fabulous deal for Brims. It would make money on the project even before selling its first latte. But instead of thanking his lawyer, the local manager told her to counter with a demand for $650,000. “If he’s willing to double the money in barely two months,” he reasoned, “he must be willing to pay a lot more.”

对布里姆斯来说，这看起来是一笔绝佳的交易。即便还没卖出第一杯拿铁，这个项目也能让他盈利。但当地经理非但没有感谢他的律师，反而让她提出65万美元的还价。“如果他愿意在短短两个月内就把钱翻一番，”他推断道，“那他肯定也愿意支付更多。”

The lawyer was shocked by her client’s attitude. She reminded him that they had told the Westerly owner that they’d give a thumbs-up or thumbs-down to his best offer. Haggling now could provoke him into pulling it off the table. “Do you really want to take that chance?” The Brims manager relented but still wonders how much better he might have done. Win or lose, second-guessing ourselves comes with the territory.

律师对客户的态度感到震惊。她提醒他，他们已经告诉韦斯特利的老板，他们会对他的最佳报价表示赞同或反对。现在讨价还价可能会激怒他，让他反悔。“你真的想冒这个险吗？”布里姆斯队的经理最终让步了，但他仍然在想自己原本可以做得更好。无论输赢，事后反思都是人之常情。

Now consider the other side of the transaction. The Westerly owner made it harder to close by raising his offer so dramatically. He should have anticipated that it would rev up Brims’s expectations. A more measured sequence of proposals would have sent Brims a signal that there were limits to how high he was willing to go. And even if the Westerly felt compelled to make a blowout offer, it should have made clear that it wouldn’t consider counteroffers.

现在考虑一下交易的另一方。韦斯特利公司的老板大幅提高报价，反而增加了交易完成的难度。他应该预料到这会提高布里姆斯的预期。如果他采取更稳妥的报价策略，就能让布里姆斯明白他的出价是有上限的。即便韦斯特利公司真的觉得有必要提出一个天价报价，也应该明确表示不会考虑任何还价。

The contentious nature of this case amplified miscommunication. The Westerly owner likely thought he could bully Brims into selling, but he had a weak legal case and only aggravated the company. If, instead, he had approached Brims more collaboratively, he might have bought the property for much less. Who knows? By working together, the parties might have found a place for the coffee shop in the B and B, preserved the open space, and gotten a tax write-off by donating the contested lot to the town.

这起案件的争议加剧了沟通不畅。韦斯特利的老板可能以为他可以胁迫布里姆斯出售房产，但他缺乏法律依据，反而激怒了布里姆斯公司。如果他当初与布里姆斯采取更合作的方式，或许就能以更低的价格买下这处房产。谁知道呢？如果双方能够携手合作，或许就能在民宿里找到咖啡馆的合适位置，保留开放空间，并通过将争议地块捐赠给镇政府获得税收减免。

HOW TO SAY YES

如何说“我愿意”

Accepting a counterpart’s proposal isn’t like hitting the Confirm button when you order a sweater online. You often need to convey more than formal assent to the negotiated terms. What needs to be said depends on your objectives. Compare these alternative ways of expressing agreement:

接受对方的提议并不像在网上订购毛衣时点击“确认”按钮那么简单。你通常需要表达的不仅仅是对协商条款的正式同意。具体要说什么取决于你的目标。比较以下几种表达同意的方式：

A. Yes. That’s terrific! I know you’ve extended yourself to do this deal. You can count on me to make it work great for you too.

A：是的，太棒了！我知道你为了促成这笔交易付出了很多努力。你也完全可以相信我，我一定会让它对你也有好处。

B. All right. I’d hoped to do a little better, but I can make this work. So thank you.

B：好的。我本来希望做得更好一些，但我可以应付。谢谢。

C. Excellent. We’ve got a deal, for sure. I’d really appreciate it, though, if you could help me out on one last item.

C：太好了。这下肯定成交了。不过，如果您能帮我完成最后一件事，我将不胜感激。

D. Good! If you can guarantee delivery by the end of the month, we have a deal.

D：好！如果你能保证月底前交货，我们就成交了。

Example A expresses gratitude. If somebody has made you a generous offer, he knows it. It’s important to show him that you know it too. That’s an end in itself. It also strengthens relationships and may lead to future collaboration.

例A表达了感激之情。如果有人向你提供了慷慨的帮助，他肯定知道。重要的是让他知道你也明白这一点。这本身就是一种目的。它还能巩固彼此的关系，并可能促成未来的合作。

Version B is more measured. It suggests that the other party has pushed you close to the limit. Such a message may be prudent if your counterparts are taking the deal back to their client or boss for approval. It makes them look good—and that’s in your best interest; otherwise they may be sent back for more. But they also need to know that you’re happy enough with the deal to honor your commitments.

版本B则更为谨慎。它暗示对方已经将你逼到了极限。如果你的对方正准备将交易提交给客户或老板审批，这样的信息或许是明智之举。这能让他们看起来更有说服力——而这对你来说也是有利的；否则他们可能会被要求返工。但他们也需要知道你对交易足够满意，并且会履行你的承诺。

Both the first and second examples also include a thank-you. Gratitude should be standard practice in closing, whether the process has been cooperative or acrimonious. If it’s been stressful for you, that’s likely true for them as well. They must have moved at least a little in your direction for you to come to agreement. If ice hockey players can line up to shake hands after a hard-fought game, you can do the same.

第一个例子和第二个例子都包含了感谢。无论过程是合作还是不愉快，在结束谈判时表达感谢都应该是惯例。如果你感到压力很大，对方可能也有同样的感受。他们至少要做出一些让步，你们才能达成一致。如果冰球运动员在激烈的比赛后可以排队握手，你也可以这样做。

Example C, by contrast, is a hedging tactic. It eliminates the downside risk of blowing the deal but still leaves open some possibility of doing better. It might even increase those odds. Declaring commitment unambiguously transforms the final issue from a precondition to a request for a favor. (It wouldn’t hurt to throw in an explicit thanks here as well.)

相比之下，例C是一种对冲策略。它消除了交易失败的下行风险，但仍然保留了取得更好结果的可能性。它甚至可能提高这种可能性。明确表态承诺会将最终问题从一个前提条件转变为一个请求帮忙的问题。（此时，明确表示感谢也无妨。）

Ben Evans wishes he had said this to the Arundel dean. As it happened, being reticent may have reduced his influence. Perhaps the dean wouldn’t have gone along with delaying Ben’s arrival for a full year. But if he was certain that Ben was coming, they might have worked out a reduced fall schedule that would have allowed him to phase in over the course of the year.

本·埃文斯后悔当初没把这些话告诉阿伦德尔学院的院长。结果，他的沉默或许削弱了他的影响力。院长可能不愿意同意让本推迟整整一年入学。但如果院长确信本一定会来，他们或许可以制定一个缩短秋季学期的课程安排，让他能够在这一年中逐步适应。

Example D is conditional. It’s less than full commitment but still expresses enthusiasm. Just as important, it suggests that the negotiations are all but over. Those on the other side will have to decide whether to meet this last condition, of course, but at least they’ve been told that if they agree, they won’t be hit with another one. This last hurdle may be small or large, but framing things this way at least puts the focus on a single issue rather than calling the whole negotiation into question.

例D是有条件的。它虽未完全承诺，但仍表达了热情。同样重要的是，它暗示谈判已接近尾声。当然，对方最终需要决定是否满足最后一个条件，但至少他们已经被告知，如果同意，就不会再有其他条件。这最后一个障碍或许微不足道，或许影响巨大，但这样表述至少能将焦点集中在一个问题上，而不是让整个谈判都受到质疑。

A conditional yes puts the decision in the other party’s hands, however. He or she will have to weigh whether ratifying the deal—including your modification—is better than testing your resolve by saying no to that last demand. Before making such a statement, consider your next move. If your request for, say, prompt delivery is refused, would that be a deal breaker? If that’s the case, say so up front so that the other side doesn’t lock itself in as well. But if you’d actually back down, you’ll need to find a way to do so without losing face or credibility.

有条件的“同意”会将决定权交到对方手中。对方需要权衡，批准协议（包括你的修改）是否比拒绝你最后的要求来考验你的决心更好。在做出这样的表态之前，请考虑你的下一步行动。例如，如果你提出的快速交货要求被拒绝，这是否会导致交易破裂？如果是这样，最好提前说明，以免对方也陷入困境。但如果你真的打算让步，你需要找到一种既能保住面子又不失信誉的方法。

There are other ways to say yes, of course, depending on the situation. The four examples here differ in style and function, but they all are forward looking. They seek to secure agreement and facilitate implementation. Beware of giving grudging acceptance, such as saying “Yes, but you owe me.” That sounds like whining. And if that’s what you feel, think twice about agreeing. There’s little profit in harboring resentment, whether or not you express it.

当然，根据具体情况，还有其他方式可以表示同意。这里列举的四个例子风格和功能各不相同，但都着眼于未来。它们旨在达成共识并促进执行。切忌勉强答应，比如说道“好的，但你欠我一个人情”。这听起来像是在抱怨。如果你有这种感觉，最好三思而后行。心怀怨恨毫无益处，无论你是否表达出来。

Ben couldn’t utter even this weak form of yes. And each time he brought up another issue, it likely raised doubts on Arundel’s part as to whether he truly wanted the job. I still wonder about that myself.

本连这微弱的“是”都说不出口。而且，他每提起一个问题，阿伦德尔就越发怀疑他是否真的想要这份工作。我自己也对此心存疑虑。

PERSUASION

劝说
