Salespeople are taught techniques to overcome customers’ resistance. Placing a pen on the signature line of a contract is supposedly more effective than just handing it to someone, but who knows if that’s true. Likewise, those car salesmen who press a prospect by saying, “Tell me, what do I need to do to put you in this car today?” may repel more people than they win over.

销售人员会学习一些技巧来克服客户的抵触情绪。据说，在合同的签名栏上放一支笔比直接把合同递给客户更有效，但谁知道这是否属实呢？同样，那些汽车销售员如果咄咄逼人地问客户：“告诉我，今天我需要做什么才能让您买下这辆车？”，可能只会吓跑更多的人，而不是赢得更多客户。

That kind of lore is of dubious value, but there’s been useful research on the psychology of decision making, including how framing a proposal influences whether it’s accepted or rejected. Studies of so-called loss aversion show that people tend to give greater weight to what we might lose than what we might gain. Therefore, someone pitching a new project to her boss could do better by saying that his veto would mean losing $100,000 in annual profit rather than telling him his approval would mean gaining exactly the same amount. Other experiments demonstrate the power of reciprocity. People repay small favors handsomely. Charities send out packets of personalized address labels because those token gifts generate bigger contributions.

这类民间传说的价值值得怀疑，但关于决策心理学的研究却颇有价值，例如提案的措辞如何影响其被接受或拒绝。所谓“损失厌恶”的研究表明，人们往往更看重可能失去的东西，而不是可能得到的东西。因此，如果某人向老板推销一个新项目，与其说老板批准意味着获得同样数额的利润，不如说老板的否决意味着每年损失10万美元的利润。其他实验也证明了互惠的力量。人们会慷慨地回报小恩小惠。慈善机构会寄送个性化的地址标签，因为这些小小的礼物能带来更大的捐款。

Sheena Iyengar of Columbia Business School has done fascinating research that shows how giving people too many options can backfire. Whether it’s buying jam in a gourmet shop or choosing among retirement plans at work, the bigger the array of items to select from, the less likely it is that people will pick any of them. Thus, you may increase the odds of closing a deal if you give your counterpart the choice between A and B rather than offer an alphabet soup of possibilities.

哥伦比亚商学院的希娜·艾扬格（Sheena Iyengar）进行了一项引人入胜的研究，揭示了提供过多选择反而会适得其反。无论是在精品店购买果酱，还是在工作中选择退休计划，可供选择的选项越多，人们最终选择的可能性就越小。因此，与其提供一大堆选项，不如让对方在A和B之间做出选择，这样或许能提高成交的几率。

This emerging science offers important lessons for negotiators, but it is far from being the whole story when it comes to persuasion. To convince someone to see what you’re offering more positively, you’ve got to match what you do and say to her particular concerns and perceptions, both those she’s expressed and those beneath the surface. People’s reasons for saying no (or not saying yes as soon as you’d like) fall into several categories:

这门新兴科学为谈判者提供了重要的启示，但它远非说服的全部。要想让对方更积极地看待你提供的方案，你必须根据对方的具体顾虑和认知来调整你的言行，包括她已经表达出来的和隐藏在表面之下的。人们拒绝（或没有像你希望的那样立即答应）的原因可以归纳为以下几类：

1. Substance.
1. 物质。

Your counterpart may not see the full value of what you’re proposing (or the inadequacy of what she’s offered).

你的对方可能看不到你提出的方案的全部价值（或者看不到她提供的方案的不足）。

2. Options.
2. 选项。

She may believe she’d be better off with the status quo or by dealing with somebody else.

她可能认为维持现状或者与其他人合作对她更有利。

3. Timing.
3. 时机。

She may think that time is on her side.

她可能认为时间站在她这边。

4. Process.
4. 流程。

She is uncertain about whether you’re being sufficiently open or fair.

她不确定你是否足够坦诚和公平。

5. Commitment.
5. 承诺。

She may doubt your willingness or capacity to deliver on what you’ve promised.

她可能会怀疑你是否愿意或有能力履行你的承诺。

6. Identity.
6. 身份。

She may feel that you don’t respect her (or worry that if you fast-talk her into saying yes, she won’t respect herself).

她可能觉得你不尊重她（或者担心如果你哄骗她说“是”，她会不尊重自己）。

In negotiation, people typically focus on the first three items—substance, options, and timing—to build a utilitarian case for saying yes. How those issues are explained and framed clearly matters. But negotiation also requires being persuasive on a personal level. Concerns about process, commitment, and identity can stifle people’s willingness to hear you on the substantive merits. Judgments about your openness, reliability, and respect aren’t made in an instant. And they aren’t based on sales gambits or the particular words you choose in extending an offer. Rather, they depend on how you relate to other parties throughout a negotiation.

在谈判中，人们通常关注前三点——实质内容、选择和时间——以此构建一个实用主义的理由来促成最终的同意。如何清晰地解释和阐述这些问题至关重要。但谈判也需要从个人层面进行说服。对流程、承诺和身份的担忧可能会阻碍人们认真倾听你对实质性内容的阐述。人们对你的坦诚、可靠和尊重的判断并非一蹴而就，也并非基于销售技巧或你在提出报价时使用的措辞，而是取决于你在整个谈判过程中如何与各方互动。

Former New York City detective Dominick Misino has been conducting high-wire hostage negotiations since the 1970s. He has a natural gift for connecting with other people, even in dire situations. His frequent successes are all the more remarkable considering how little he has to offer someone in return for a peaceful surrender. He can’t promise clemency or a getaway car.

前纽约市警探多米尼克·米西诺自上世纪70年代起便从事高风险的人质谈判工作。他天生擅长与人沟通，即便在危急情况下也能游刃有余。考虑到他能为和平投降提供的东西少之又少，他屡屡成功就显得更加令人瞩目。他既不能承诺赦免，也不能提供逃跑车辆。

Much of what makes Misino successful resonates with the central themes in this book, notably his presence of mind and emotional attunement. “Top negotiators are excellent listeners,” he says. Misino is always asking questions, trying to build rapport. When he asks hostage takers to tell their side of things, he gets back an earful. “I hear every instance of when the other guy has ever been wronged.” When they tell him that they’ve never been cared for or that they’ve been framed, Misino is nonjudgmental. “The way I look at it, all of it is true—to him. And that’s what matters.”

米西诺成功的许多因素都与本书的核心主题不谋而合，尤其是他临场应变的能力和敏锐的情感洞察力。“顶尖的谈判者都是优秀的倾听者，”他说。米西诺总是不断提问，努力建立融洽的关系。当他要求劫持者讲述他们的遭遇时，他总能听到对方滔滔不绝的讲述。“我能听到对方讲述自己曾经遭受不公待遇的每一个细节。”当他们告诉他自己从未得到过关爱，或者自己被陷害时，米西诺从不妄加评判。“在我看来，对他们而言，这一切都是真的。而这才是最重要的。”

Misino also listens to himself. He says that hostage negotiators have to be aware of the “noise” in their own minds. “Believe me, even if you don’t know what’s going on inside your head, the other guy will,” he notes. “You need to know your hot buttons and limitations.” Early in a conversation, he typically asks if the person wants to hear the unvarnished truth. The answer is almost always yes. (When somebody is in a standoff with police snipers, he observes, “Who in his right mind would have wanted to be lied to?”) But then Misino will attach a condition. The guy has to promise not to hurt anyone even if he hears things he doesn’t like. Nine out of ten times, such promises are kept. “These people may be the outcasts of society,” he says, “but they do have a code of honor.”

米西诺也会倾听自己内心的声音。他说，人质谈判专家必须意识到自己脑海中的“杂音”。他指出：“相信我，即使你不知道自己脑子里在想什么，对方也肯定知道。你需要了解自己的敏感点和底线。”在谈话初期，他通常会问对方是否想听实话。答案几乎总是肯定的。（他观察到，当有人与警察狙击手对峙时，“谁会愿意被骗呢？”）但米西诺随后会附加一个条件。对方必须承诺，即使听到自己不喜欢的话，也不会伤害任何人。十有八九，这样的承诺都会得到遵守。“这些人或许是社会的边缘人，”他说，“但他们确实有自己的荣誉准则。”

To deepen trust, Misino adds, “You use every possible opportunity to agree with your adversary and to get him to agree with you.” He deliberately uses the plural pronoun (as in “ We can work this out”), to “alleviate the bad guy’s isolation and paranoia.” In this context Misino doesn’t comment. He doesn’t argue. Instead, he just takes one simple step after another without explaining where he is headed—though he knows that surrender is the only option. Misino’s key insight about the whole process is stated so simply, it’s easy to slip right past it, so I’ve italicized it for emphasis: “A successful negotiation is a series of small agreements.”

米西诺补充道，为了加深信任，“你要抓住一切机会与对手达成共识，并让他也同意你的观点。”他特意使用复数代词（例如“我们可以解决这个问题”），是为了“减轻对方的孤立感和妄想”。在这种情况下，米西诺不作评论，也不争辩。相反，他只是一步一步地推进，不解释自己的目标——尽管他知道投降是唯一的选择。米西诺对整个过程的关键见解如此简洁，很容易被忽略，所以我用斜体字强调：“成功的谈判是由一系列小的协议组成的。”

For him, persuasion isn’t about carrots and sticks, charm, or bluster. It’s about relational understanding. By being respectful, he elicits respect in return. By listening closely, he teaches the other person to listen to him. In the end, Misino can offer only respect, empathy, and safety. Surprisingly, those often prove sufficient.

对他而言，说服并非靠胡萝卜加大棒、魅力或虚张声势，而是关乎关系的理解。他以尊重待人，赢得对方的尊重；他认真倾听，教会对方如何倾听自己。最终，米西诺所能提供的只有尊重、同理心和安全感。令人惊讶的是，这些往往就足够了。

But let’s take this back to everyday negotiation. How could someone expect to get you to say yes and close a deal if, throughout the process, he’s challenged your every assertion, rebuffed your conciliatory gestures, and shown no understanding of or respect for your point of view? In the face of all that, no matter how eloquent his closing argument or clever his framing, you’d likely turn down his proposal—maybe even if it tops what you’ll get by walking away.

但我们不妨回到日常谈判中来。如果整个过程中，他不断质疑你的每一个主张，拒绝你的任何示好，并且对你的观点毫无理解和尊重，他又怎能指望让你点头同意并达成交易呢？面对这一切，无论他的最后陈词多么雄辩，措辞多么巧妙，你都可能拒绝他的提议——即便这比你直接放弃谈判所能得到的更好。

The same applies when you’re looking to get a yes from others. Relying on a set of tricks and gambits to close deals is inconsistent with building a relationship in which people feel secure enough to say yes. To paraphrase Misino, we ultimately forge agreement by working out small understandings all along the way.

当你想获得他人的同意时，道理也一样。依靠一系列技巧和伎俩来达成交易，与建立一种让人感到足够安全、愿意说“是”的关系背道而驰。套用米西诺的话来说，我们最终是通过逐步达成的小共识来达成协议的。

LAST-MINUTE BLOWUPS

最后一刻爆发

Even everyday transactions can be emotionally charged. The sale of a $3 million Greenwich Village brownstone almost fell apart because of a dispute over a used washing machine that the sellers had removed from the premises two days before the closing. According to Stephen Raphael, the lawyer representing the owners, it wasn’t worth fighting over, “but the buyers had already felt pressured to up their offer and to concede many things, and this was the last straw.”

即使是日常交易也可能充满情绪波动。一套位于格林威治村、价值300万美元的褐石公寓的交易差点告吹，起因是卖方在交割前两天将一台二手洗衣机搬离了房屋。据代表业主的律师斯蒂芬·拉斐尔称，这台洗衣机根本不值得争吵，“但买家已经感到压力，不得不提高报价并做出许多让步，这件事成了压垮骆驼的最后一根稻草。”

At the closing, the sellers still refused to replace the machine. One of the buyers ripped up the seven-figure check for the balance due, put a match to the scraps, and stomped out of the room. The sellers finally relented and agreed to reduce the price by $300. The brokers found the angry buyer at a nearby bar, nursing a drink. They coaxed him back, and the deal was done.

交易结束时，卖方仍然拒绝更换机器。其中一位买家撕毁了那张七位数的尾款支票，点燃碎片，然后怒气冲冲地离开了房间。卖方最终让步，同意降价300美元。经纪人在附近一家酒吧找到了那位愤怒的买家，他正独自喝着酒。经纪人劝说他回来，交易最终完成。

In another sale, a buyer tested the sellers’ patience by haggling over one item after another. Finally, it was too much. The sellers stormed out in the middle of the closing, returned to their home one last time, and removed every lightbulb from all the fixtures. Wolf Jakubowski, who represented both parties, says, “It wasn’t the amount of money that was the issue. It was the principle.”

在另一笔交易中，买家不断就一项又一项商品讨价还价，最终考验了卖家的耐心。卖家忍无可忍，在交易进行到一半时愤然离场，最后一次返回家中，将所有灯具上的灯泡全部卸了下来。代表双方的律师沃尔夫·雅库博夫斯基说：“问题不在于金额，而在于原则。”

Real estate closings can get violent. Fern Hammond, a New York broker, tells the story of an angry woman who flung the set of house keys at a man’s face as hard as she could. “All of a sudden there was blood all over the place,” Hammond says. “Everyone was pushing the papers out of the way.” And the target of the woman’s anger was her own husband! She was furious with him because he had agreed to sell their place for less than she thought it was worth.

房地产交易过程中可能会发生暴力事件。纽约经纪人费恩·哈蒙德讲述了一个愤怒的女人将一串钥匙狠狠砸向一名男子的脸的故事。“突然间，血流成河，”哈蒙德说，“大家都慌忙地把文件推到一边。”而这名女子发泄怒火的对象竟然是她自己的丈夫！她对丈夫非常生气，因为他同意以低于她预期价格的价格出售他们的房子。

When tempers erupt at the end of negotiation, it’s often because pressure has been building up along the way. Buying or selling a home is the biggest financial transaction that many people ever undertake. It’s usually emotional as well. For sellers, parting with a home is often freighted with memories. For many buyers, the transaction is laden with hopes and worries.

谈判结束时双方情绪失控，往往是因为谈判过程中压力不断累积。买卖房屋是许多人一生中最大的一笔财务交易，通常也伴随着情感上的波动。对卖家而言，告别房屋往往承载着许多回忆；对许多买家来说，这笔交易则承载着希望与担忧。

These deals, moreover, are usually conducted at arm’s length, through brokers and lawyers. Offers volley back and forth as the parties haggle price, with each side trying to read the intentions of the other. Preliminary agreement may be reached, but then, while the paperwork is being done, there’s a dormant period when people have time to brood over their decision. Small wonder, then, that these anxieties tumble out when the parties meet—sometimes for the first time—to close the deal.

此外，这些交易通常都是通过经纪人和律师以非公开方式进行的。双方讨价还价，不断交换报价，试图揣摩对方的意图。初步协议或许能够达成，但随后，在办理手续的这段时间里，会有一段沉寂期，人们有时间反复斟酌自己的决定。因此，当双方最终见面——有时甚至是第一次见面——敲定交易时，这些焦虑情绪爆发也就不足为奇了。

Negotiating through intermediaries complicates the process. Brokers and lawyers may contribute expertise, perspective, and credibility, but they complicate communication. It may be unclear who speaks for whom, or who has ultimate authority to approve a deal. When relationships are strained, a tag-team approach may be needed. The first cohort of negotiators may settle some issues but get stuck on others. A new set of negotiators, unburdened by whatever interpersonal issues arose between their predecessors, may be able to wrap things up.

通过中间人进行谈判会使过程复杂化。经纪人和律师或许能提供专业知识、视角和信誉，但他们也会使沟通变得复杂。双方的立场可能不明确，最终谁有权批准交易也难以确定。当关系紧张时，可能需要采用轮换谈判的方式。第一批谈判人员或许能解决一些问题，但在另一些问题上却会陷入僵局。而新一批谈判人员，由于不受前任之间人际关系问题的干扰，或许能够最终达成协议。

Of course, this can be a bargaining gambit as well. It’s a classic move in auto showrooms. You think you’ve reached a deal, but then there’s a bait and switch. You shake hands with the salesman, but then he goes off to confer with his manager. When he finally returns, he wears a hangdog look. “I’m sorry,” he’ll say, “but my boss says it’s gotta be another thousand dollars.” He’ll quickly add that’s really only another $29 in monthly car payments—and in return, he’ll toss in the deluxe floor mats for free.

当然，这也有可能是一种讨价还价的策略。这在汽车展厅里很常见。你以为已经谈妥了，结果却来了个反转。你和销售员握手，他却跑去和经理商量。等他回来的时候，一脸沮丧。“不好意思，”他会说，“老板说还得再加一千美元。”他还会赶紧补充说，其实每月车贷也就多付29美元——作为补偿，他会免费赠送一套豪华脚垫。

Shame on those who resort to such tired old ploys. Shame on us, too, if we’re not prepared for them. Ideally, we should confirm at the outset that we’re negotiating with the right person: someone who can make a binding commitment. When that’s not possible, we should also hold back something in reserve that we can throw in to close the deal.

那些使用如此老套伎俩的人真可耻。如果我们对此毫无准备，我们自己也同样可耻。理想情况下，我们应该在一开始就确认谈判对象是否合适：对方能够做出具有约束力的承诺。如果无法做到这一点，我们也应该有所保留，以备不时之需，最终促成交易。

LUCK AND PERSISTENCE

运气和坚持

Last-minute hang-ups aren’t inevitable. How we negotiate through the process helps set up what happens at the end. Recall Sandy Ritchie’s patient purchase of Bold Island in Maine. For years, he corresponded with its elderly owner. When she was finally ready to sell, Sandy couldn’t afford the price set by her lawyer. She overruled that advice, and Sandy is now the owner. It was a long process, of course, but sometimes one simple gesture can make the difference in everyday transactions.

最后关头出现问题并非不可避免。我们如何协商整个过程，最终决定了结果。想想桑迪·里奇耐心购买缅因州博尔德岛的故事。多年来，他一直与岛上年迈的岛主通信。当岛主最终准备出售时，桑迪却无力承担律师设定的价格。她不顾律师的建议，最终如愿以偿，成为了博尔德岛的主人。当然，这是一个漫长的过程，但有时一个简单的举动就能在日常交易中起到决定性作用。

A young couple, the Owens, had their hearts set on a single-family house in a desirable community. When they made their offer, they asked their broker to pass along a handwritten note to the owners, whom they had not met. In the letter, they explained that they were scientists doing cancer research. On weekends, they enjoyed making improvements on their condo, but they were eager to own a real home. Of all the places they had seen, they said, they loved this one the best. They even emphasized that their offer was negotiable.

一对年轻夫妇，欧文斯夫妇，一心想在理想的社区买一套独栋住宅。他们出价时，请经纪人代为转达一封手写的信，信中他们还未见过房主。信中，他们解释说自己是从事癌症研究的科学家。周末，他们喜欢装修自己的公寓，但渴望拥有一套真正的房子。他们说，在看过的所有房子里，他们最喜欢这套。他们还强调，他们的出价是可以商量的。

The Owens got the house for the price they offered originally. At the closing, they met the sellers, who told them that they were moved by their note. “They said a couple of times that they loved the letter,” the husband recalled. “I don’t think they felt they were just selling it to an anonymous buyer.”

欧文夫妇最终以最初出价的价格买下了这栋房子。在房屋交割时，他们见到了卖方，卖方告诉他们，他们被欧文夫妇的信感动了。“他们好几次都说很喜欢这封信，”欧文夫妇回忆道，“我觉得他们并不觉得只是把房子卖给一个匿名买家。”

Relationships matter in business negotiations too. Jerry Weintraub, the Hollywood music and movie producer, courted Elvis Presley’s manager, “Colonel” Tom Parker, calling him almost daily for a full year in hopes of taking the King of Rock and Roll on a concert tour. Weintraub was young and didn’t have much of a track record, but his persistence and charm eventually prevailed. Parker agreed to let Weintraub put together Presley’s first tour in almost a decade. After the final show, the Colonel spotted Weintraub backstage and told him to follow him. They had to talk.

人际关系在商业谈判中也至关重要。好莱坞音乐和电影制片人杰瑞·温特劳布（Jerry Weintraub）曾竭力争取埃尔维斯·普雷斯利（Elvis Presley）的经纪人“上校”汤姆·帕克（Tom Parker）的青睐，几乎每天都给他打电话，持续了一整年，希望能促成这位摇滚之王的巡回演唱会。温特劳布当时年轻，也没有什么过往的业绩，但他坚持不懈，魅力十足，最终赢得了帕克的认可。帕克同意让温特劳布负责普雷斯利近十年来的首次巡演。最后一场演出结束后，帕克在后台发现了温特劳布，让他跟自己走。他们必须好好谈谈。

The Colonel was trailed by a big guy lugging two large suitcases. The three of them went through a warren of tunnels to a little door leading to an electrical closet. Inside was a bunch of machinery and a table with a lightbulb dangling above it. The Colonel told the other guy to put down the bags and get lost. “I need to talk to Jerry alone.”

上校身后跟着一个壮汉，他拖着两个大箱子。三人穿过迷宫般的隧道，来到一扇通往配电室的小门前。里面摆着一堆机器，还有一张桌子，桌子上方悬挂着一个灯泡。上校让那人放下箱子，赶紧走开。“我要单独和杰瑞谈谈。”

He then had Jerry put the bags on the table and open them. The cases were stuffed with cash. It was money from the sale of T-shirts and concessions. Jerry said he had nothing to do with that; his deal was only for a share of the ticket revenue from the shows. The Colonel and Elvis were giving him half of that, which Jerry felt was already lavish, but Parker insisted on giving him more. “When I have a partner, I have a partner. Now pile up that money.” Here’s how Weintraub describes the scene:

然后他让杰瑞把袋子放在桌上打开。箱子里塞满了现金，是卖T恤和零食的收入。杰瑞说这跟他一点关系都没有；他的合同只是演出门票收入的一部分。上校和埃尔维斯给了他一半，杰瑞觉得这已经很慷慨了，但帕克坚持要给他更多。“有合伙人就是有合伙人。现在把钱都攒起来。” 温特劳布是这样描述当时的场景的：

“It was a mountain of bills, some stained with ketchup, some stained with chives, stacked on the table. The Colonel said, ‘Stand back,’ then raised his cane and brought it down hard on the pile, dividing it into two big piles, which he pushed apart with the cane, saying, ‘That side yours, this side mine. Is that fair?’ ”

“桌上堆着一座小山似的账单，有的沾满了番茄酱，有的沾满了细香葱。上校说：‘都退后！’然后举起手杖，狠狠地砸在账单堆上，把它分成两大堆，再用手杖把它们分开，说：‘这边是你的，这边是我的。公平吗？’”

Elvis’s tour was a huge success. It also made Weintraub’s career. In a mere six weeks, he went from being just another young, ambitious promoter to somebody with a name, a track record, and—thanks to Colonel Parker—$1 million in his pocket.

埃尔维斯的巡演取得了巨大的成功，也成就了温特劳布的事业。短短六周内，他从一个年轻有为的经纪人，摇身一变，成了家喻户晓、业绩斐然，并且——多亏了帕克上校——口袋里揣着一百万美元的大亨。

May we all be so lucky when we close deals. Weintraub was fortunate to be working with a kindred spirit. The Colonel relished the spark and hustle of show business as much as he did. Parker and Elvis already had a ton of money, so they could afford to be generous. And Weintraub had earned their trust because of how hard he had worked on their behalf.

愿我们都能像他一样，在达成交易时如此幸运。温特劳布很幸运能与一位志同道合的人共事。这位上校和他一样，都热爱演艺圈的激情与活力。帕克和埃尔维斯当时已经腰缠万贯，所以他们慷慨大方。而温特劳布之所以赢得他们的信任，是因为他为他们付出了巨大的努力。

But Weintraub also knew how to say yes. In fact, he first expressed his gratitude by saying no: it was too much money, he said; way beyond what he expected. To the Colonel, though, the fifty-fifty split wasn’t about dollars and cents. It was about their relationship. When the Colonel asked if the concession split was fair, Jerry answered, “It’s more than fair.”

但温特劳布也懂得如何说“是”。事实上，他最初表达感激的方式是拒绝：他说，钱太多了，远远超出他的预期。然而，对上校来说，五五分成并非关乎金钱，而是关乎他们之间的关系。当上校问分成是否公平时，杰瑞回答说：“这简直太公平了。”

We began this chapter by seeing how my friend Ben blew his negotiations with Arundel University. We’ll close with another contract story. In the early 1970s, teams in the fledgling World Hockey Association were trying to gain credibility by luring big-name players from the long-dominant National Hockey League. The Philadelphia Blazers had their sights on Derek Sanderson, a former NHL rookie of the year and flashy center on the Boston Bruins.

本章开头，我们讲述了我的朋友本是如何搞砸了与阿伦德尔大学的谈判。最后，我们再讲一个合同故事。20世纪70年代初，新兴的世界冰球协会（WHA）的各支球队试图通过从长期占据主导地位的国家冰球联盟（NHL）挖走大牌球星来提升自身的影响力。费城开拓者队的目标是德里克·桑德森，这位前NHL年度最佳新秀，也是波士顿棕熊队一位球风华丽的中锋。

Sanderson was happy where he was but felt there’d be no harm in finding out what he was worth on the market. He was currently earning $75,000 a year from Boston. The Blazers offered him $2.3 million for three years. “I was stunned,” Sanderson remembers.

桑德森对当时的工作很满意，但他觉得了解一下自己在市场上的价值也无妨。他当时在波士顿的年薪是7.5万美元。开拓者队给他提供了一份三年230万美元的合同。“我当时都惊呆了，”桑德森回忆道。

A friend he had brought to the meeting with him whispered, “Take it. Take it!” But Sanderson just sat there. “Actually, we could make that $2.6 million,” the general manger said. (“That’s when I knew I had them,” Sanderson recalls now.) Still, he didn’t accept. Instead, he said, “It would be awfully hard to leave the Bruins. It was my lifelong dream to play in the NHL.”

他带来的一位朋友低声说：“接受吧，接受吧！”但桑德森只是坐在那里。“实际上，我们可以拿到那260万美元，”总经理说。（“那时我就知道我拿下他们了，”桑德森回忆道。）尽管如此，他还是没有接受。相反，他说：“离开波士顿棕熊队太难了。在NHL打球是我毕生的梦想。”

The Blazers’ offer jumped to $3 million, and Sanderson still wasn’t done. “I’ll need a limo for my girlfriend, of course,” he added. The team said yes to that and even agreed to hire Sanderson’s father as a scout. Sanderson finally ran out of asks. He signed a deal that made him the highest-paid pro athlete in the world at the time, even topping Pelé, the legendary Brazilian soccer star. Was Sanderson smart in pressing for more, or just lucky that he didn’t exasperate Blazers management to a point where it would sign a better player for less?

开拓者队的报价飙升至300万美元，但桑德森仍不罢休。“当然，我还需要一辆豪华轿车送我女朋友，”他补充道。球队同意了，甚至还同意聘请桑德森的父亲担任球探。桑德森最终无计可施。他签下了一份合同，使他成为当时世界上收入最高的职业运动员，甚至超过了巴西传奇足球明星贝利。桑德森坚持索要更高薪水是明智之举，还是仅仅幸运地没有激怒开拓者队管理层，以至于他们转而签下一位薪水更低但能力更强的球员？

In coming to agreement, you have to balance risk and reward. The harder you press, the more you may gain—but also the more you stand to lose. In theory, decision-making models can pinpoint the crossover point where the net payoff becomes negative. Such formulas aren’t much practical use in real negotiation, however, since estimates of messing up a deal are only rough guesses. With some items, there may be no harm in asking, while others shouldn’t even be broached. In between those extremes, however, the pros and cons will be fuzzy.

达成协议时，必须权衡风险与回报。你越是坚持己见，可能获得的收益就越多，但同时也可能失去更多。理论上，决策模型可以精确地指出净收益变为负值的临界点。然而，这类公式在实际谈判中用处不大，因为对交易失败风险的估计仅仅是粗略的猜测。有些事项可以尝试询问，而有些事项则最好不要提及。介于两者之间的事项，其利弊往往难以界定。

It’s safe to start from the premise that whatever you’ve been offered, you can likely do better. That’s not always true, but it’s a fair bet. It’s possible—but not probable—that you’ve magically landed on a package that is the absolute best that your counterpart can do for you. It’s also possible—though not certain—that there are no further ways to expand the pie through creative trades.

可以先假设，无论对方提供什么，你都很有可能找到更好的方案。这并非总是如此，但这种推测不无道理。你或许碰巧得到了对方能提供的最佳方案——虽然可能性不大。同样，也有可能——尽管不能确定——通过创造性的交易，已经没有办法进一步扩大收益。

The probability that there’s more to be gained, however, doesn’t necessarily mean you should keep negotiating. Oil tycoon J. P. Getty is credited with saying, “You must never try to make all the money that’s in a deal. Let the other fellow make some money too, because if you have a reputation for always making all the money, you won’t make many deals.” Likewise, there’s an advantage to keeping things clear and simple instead of fashioning elaborate provisions.

然而，即便更有可能获得更多利益，也并不意味着你应该继续谈判。石油大亨J·P·盖蒂曾说过：“你永远不应该试图独揽交易中的所有利润。要让对方也分到一些钱，因为如果你总是独揽大利，你就很难达成交易。” 同样，保持清晰简洁比制定复杂的条款更有优势。

Whether your instinct is to close the deal or keep dealing, give yourself time to have second thoughts. You can sketch a decision tree (like the ones in chapter 2) and test your assumptions. If you’re inclined to press for more, what’s the evidence for believing that there’s plenty left to win? Likewise, what’s your basis for thinking that there’s no harm in asking? Conversely, if you’re ready to shake hands on a deal, why do you think that you’ve done about the best you can?

无论你的本能是想尽快成交还是继续谈判，都要给自己一些时间仔细考虑。你可以画一个决策树（就像第二章里那样），检验一下你的假设。如果你倾向于争取更多，有什么证据让你相信还有很多机会可以争取？同样地，你又凭什么认为问问也无妨？反之，如果你已经准备好达成协议，为什么你认为自己已经尽力了呢？

Even in cases where relationships and reputations aren’t important, be smart about how hard you press. Asking someone to sweeten an offer is one thing. It’s another to make a demand that requires him to lose face. Emotionally intelligent negotiators sense when they’re pushing too hard and pull back before a proposed deal collapses.

即使在人际关系和名誉并不重要的情况下，也要懂得把握谈判的力度。要求对方提高报价是一回事，提出令对方颜面尽失的要求则是另一回事。情商高的谈判者能够察觉自己何时用力过猛，并在交易破裂前及时止损。

Now a postscript on Sanderson, who pushed, and then pushed some more, and ended up with what was then the fattest contract in the history of sports. His good luck continued, though in an odd way. Sanderson was injured when the new hockey season began, so he got off to a slow start. The Philly team was woeful, attendance was worse, and the owners were in a financial jam. After Sanderson had played only eight games, they bought out his contract for $1 million. He went back to the Bruins a much richer man. Once again Sanderson was a lucky negotiator, as the Blazers folded just a few years later—though that’s not quite the end of this story.

现在来说说桑德森，他锲而不舍地争取，最终签下了当时体育史上最丰厚的合同。他的好运似乎还在继续，尽管方式有些奇特。新赛季开始时，桑德森受伤了，所以他的开局很慢。费城开拓者队战绩糟糕，上座率更是惨淡，老板们也陷入了财务困境。桑德森只打了八场比赛后，球队就以100万美元的价格买断了他的合同。他回到波士顿棕熊队，成了一个更加富有的人。桑德森再次展现了他谈判的运气，因为开拓者队几年后就解散了——但这并非故事的结局。

By Sanderson’s own admission, he was too young to handle the money. He craved the celebrity spotlight, partied hard, drank too much, and did drugs. His on-ice performance suffered, and his career trailed off. He squandered his money and ended up sleeping on a New York City park bench. For all his brashness and immaturity, though, Sanderson had made good friends along the way. His former Bruins teammate Bobby Orr checked him into rehab and paid the bill. Sanderson overcame his addictions, and he got into broadcasting and financial advising. He has been sober for many years.

桑德森自己也承认，他当时年纪太小，无法妥善管理金钱。他渴望成为名人，沉迷于派对、酗酒和吸毒。他的冰球表现受到影响，职业生涯也随之走向衰落。他挥霍无度，最终流落街头，睡在纽约市的公园长椅上。尽管他鲁莽冲动、不成熟，但桑德森也在此过程中结交了一些好朋友。他以前的波士顿棕熊队队友鲍比·奥尔送他去戒毒所，并支付了所有费用。桑德森最终克服了毒瘾，转行从事广播和财务咨询工作。他已经戒毒多年。

The moral of the story? What seems like a good outcome in the short term might prove worse for you later on (as it did for Sanderson for a while). But still later, what seemed bad may turn good again (as it eventually did for him as well). Nobody can plan for such vicissitudes. That’s why you’re doubly lucky when you have good friends.

这个故事的寓意是什么？短期内看似好的结果，之后可能会对你造成更大的伤害（就像桑德森的经历一样）。但再过一段时间，看似糟糕的事情也可能再次好转（就像他最终的经历一样）。没有人能预料到这种变幻莫测的境遇。所以，拥有好朋友会让你倍感幸运。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Take care not to push too far.

■ 注意不要操之过急。

■ Pick the right way to say yes.

■ 选择合适的方式说“是”。

■ When others say no, probe for the underlying reason.

■ 当别人说不时，要探究其背后的原因。

■ Anticipate last-minute blowups.

■ 预料到最后一刻可能会出现突发状况。

■ To conclude a negotiation smoothly, begin that same way.

■ 要顺利结束谈判，就要以同样的方式开始。

#↩

PART FOUR

第四部分

Mastery

精通

You need, I think, to be at the same time arrogant, because you want to solve problems that look insolvable, but you also need to be very, very humble.

我认为，你既要有点傲气，因为你想解决那些看似无法解决的问题，但同时你也要非常非常谦逊。

—UN DIPLOMAT LAKHDAR BRAHIMI

——外交官拉赫达尔·卜拉希米

#↩

[ 11 ] Silk Purses

[ 11 ] 丝绸钱包

A major publishing house signed a contract with a respected author for a biography of Franklin Roosevelt. The writer threw himself into the project, delving into official documents and personal papers. He spent months in the library at Roosevelt’s Hudson River estate in Hyde Park, New York, immersed in his subject’s life and family.

一家大型出版社与一位德高望重的作家签订合同，委托他撰写富兰克林·罗斯福的传记。这位作家全身心投入到这项工作中，深入研究官方文件和私人信件。他花了几个月的时间待在罗斯福位于纽约州海德公园哈德逊河畔的庄园图书馆里，沉浸在罗斯福的生活和家庭之中。

The deadline for the manuscript came and went, as did an extended date. At long last, the author delivered his draft. It was a magnificent narrative, rich with insight, especially about the complex relationship between the thirty-third president and the first lady.

稿件的截稿日期已过，延期也未到。最终，作者交出了初稿。这是一部精彩绝伦的作品，见解深刻，尤其对第三十三任总统和第一夫人之间错综复杂的关系描写得淋漓尽致。

There was only one problem. The finished book was over 1,400 pages long. The publisher admired the writing but was convinced that the massive tome would intimidate even serious readers. The author was told that he had to make cuts. Drastic ones. He refused. Having poured years of effort into the book, he wasn’t about to trash half his work. Stalemated, the parties tore up their contract, and the author repaid his advance. The writer then contacted another house, W. W. Norton & Company. It also was concerned about the length of the draft, but its editors saw a simple solution. They just cut it in two.

只有一个问题。成书超过1400页。出版商欣赏作者的文笔，但确信如此厚重的篇幅即使是严肃的读者也会望而却步。他们要求作者大幅删减。作者拒绝了。他倾注了数年心血，绝不可能放弃一半的成果。双方僵持不下，最终撕毁了合同，作者退还了预付款。之后，作者联系了另一家出版社——W. W. Norton & Company。这家出版社也对书稿的篇幅感到担忧，但他们的编辑想到了一个简单的解决办法：直接删减一半。

The first volume, titled Eleanor and Franklin , was still more than 700 pages, but it won both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award for its author, Joseph Lash. His sequel, Eleanor: The Years Alone , was a bestseller as well. Decades later, both volumes are still in print.

第一卷名为《埃莉诺与富兰克林》，篇幅超过700页，却为作者约瑟夫·拉什赢得了普利策奖和国家图书奖。他的续作《埃莉诺：独处的岁月》也同样畅销。几十年过去了，这两卷书至今仍在发行。

Why didn’t the editors at the first publisher spot this obvious solution? After all, they read the same manuscript and were dealing with an author that they liked and respected. Yet they saw as irreconcilable their own need for a shorter book and his refusal to make cuts. The second publisher had the creativity to recognize that instead of being a problem, the length of the draft was an opportunity. A single creative idea can spell the difference between a deal and no deal, as with Lash and the two publishers. It can also turn a good deal into a great one. Creativity is important in all sorts of fields, of course, from business and diplomacy to sports and the arts themselves.

为什么第一家出版社的编辑们没能发现这个显而易见的解决方案？毕竟，他们读的是同一份稿件，而且作者也是他们喜欢和尊敬的。然而，他们却认为自己需要一本篇幅更短的书，而作者却拒绝删减，这让他们觉得无法调和。第二家出版社则富有创意地意识到，稿件的长度并非问题，而是一个机会。正如拉什与这两家出版社的故事一样，一个创意就能决定成败。它甚至能让一笔不错的交易变成一笔绝佳的交易。当然，创造力在各个领域都至关重要，从商业和外交到体育和艺术本身，无一例外。

Being inventive in negotiation is especially hard, however. We marvel at how a solitary sculptor can look at a rough block of marble and somehow imagine the finished figure lurking within. But it would be even more daunting if there were two sculptors—strangers—each with a hammer and a chisel, trying to fashion something valuable out of the raw material in front of them. Both might be masters of their craft, but each would have his or her own vision of what the final piece should look like. Each would also have a favored way of working and would want credit for the result. That’s the challenge in negotiation.

然而，在谈判中发挥创造力尤其困难。我们惊叹于一位孤独的雕塑家如何能凝视着一块粗糙的大理石，并想象出其中蕴藏的最终形态。但如果两位雕塑家——彼此素不相识——各自手持锤子和凿子，试图用眼前的原材料雕琢出一件有价值的作品，那难度就更大了。他们或许都是各自领域的佼佼者，但对最终作品的形态却有着不同的理解。他们各自也都有自己偏爱的工作方式，并希望获得应有的认可。这就是谈判的挑战所在。

In the 1990s, Stevens Aviation, a sales and maintenance company, began using the slogan “Plane Smart” in its ads. A couple of years later, Southwest Airlines launched its “Just Plane Smart” campaign, prompting Stevens to claim trademark infringement. The companies could have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in litigation costs, but Stevens chairman Kurt Herwald proposed a different idea: he’d arm-wrestle Southwest CEO Herb Kelleher. The winner would get the rights, and the loser would have to donate to a charity of the other’s choice. Kelleher lost the two-out-of-three match and sent a $10,000 check to the Muscular Dystrophy Association. Herwald, in turn, generously allowed Southwest to keep using its slogan. Both companies got great publicity from the stunt. Herwald said later that it was a factor in the subsequent threefold growth of his company’s business.

上世纪90年代，销售和维修公司史蒂文斯航空（Stevens Aviation）开始在其广告中使用“Plane Smart”（飞机智能）的口号。几年后，西南航空公司推出了“Just Plane Smart”（只需飞机智能）的广告活动，这促使史蒂文斯航空声称其商标侵权。两家公司原本可能要花费数十万美元的诉讼费用，但史蒂文斯航空董事长库尔特·赫瓦尔德（Kurt Herwald）提出了一个不同的方案：他要和西南航空公司首席执行官赫伯·凯莱赫（Herb Kelleher）掰手腕。赢家将获得该口号的使用权，而输家则必须向对方选择的慈善机构捐款。凯莱赫在三局两胜的比赛中输掉了比赛，并向肌肉萎缩症协会捐赠了1万美元。作为交换，赫瓦尔德慷慨地允许西南航空公司继续使用该口号。两家公司都因这次“噱头”获得了巨大的宣传效果。赫瓦尔德后来表示，这是他公司业务随后增长三倍的一个因素。

FROM LEMONS TO LEMONADE

从柠檬到柠檬水

People like Kelleher and Herwald have a knack for coming up with creative ways to reach agreement. It may seem like magic when they pull rabbits out of hats, but psychological research shows that attitude has a lot to do with it. Recent studies by Evan Polman and Kyle Emich, from Cornell University and New York University, respectively, found that people were more creative solving problems for others than when asked to solve the same problems for themselves. In the movie Heist , the criminal mastermind (played by Gene Hackman) denies that he’s very smart. “I tried to imagine a fella smarter than myself. Then I tried to think, ‘What would he do?’ ” Psychological distance opens up the imagination. Instead of fixating on what may block our goals, stepping back allows us to see a way around obstacles.

像凯勒赫和赫瓦尔德这样的人，总能想出富有创意的办法达成共识。他们变魔术般的解决问题能力看似神奇，但心理学研究表明，态度在其中起着至关重要的作用。康奈尔大学的埃文·波尔曼和纽约大学的凯尔·埃米奇最近的研究发现，人们在为他人解决问题时比为自己解决问题时更具创造力。在电影《劫匪》中，犯罪天才（由吉恩·哈克曼饰演）否认自己非常聪明。“我试着想象一个比我聪明的人。然后我试着思考，‘他会怎么做？’”心理距离能够激发想象力。与其纠结于可能阻碍我们实现目标的因素，不如退后一步，这样我们才能找到绕过障碍的方法。

Puzzle Number 1
谜题编号 1

The real estate market is soft. You’ve had a For Sale sign on the front lawn for three months without getting a nibble. Finally, a prospective buyer appears, Jones, who’s willing to pay close to your asking price. But there’s a catch: Jones wants to make the deal contingent on the sale of his own property.

房地产市场低迷。你的房子在草坪上挂了三个月的“出售”牌子，却一直无人问津。终于，一个潜在买家出现了，名叫琼斯，他愿意出价接近你的要价。但有个条件：琼斯要求这笔交易的前提是他必须先卖掉自己的房子。

You refuse, understandably. You don’t want to take your house off the market and depend on Jones’s luck—good or bad—in unloading the other place. Jones, in turn, doesn’t want to run the risk of owning two homes. Tweaking the price one way or another won’t solve the underlying problem. Nor will seller financing. What should you do?

你的拒绝是可以理解的。你不想把自己的房子撤出市场，然后把希望寄托在琼斯能否顺利卖掉另一套房子上。琼斯也不想承担拥有两套房子的风险。调整价格并不能解决根本问题，卖方融资也无济于事。你该怎么办？

Any good book on negotiation explains how value is generated by trading on differences. If the owner of a painting likes what she has but someone else really loves it, they should make a deal. Negotiators have come to understand this, at least intuitively. In fact, all successful negotiations create value. Say that I’m about to trade in my car for $8,000, while across town, you’re ready to pay $10,000 for the same model in identical condition. If we find each other through Craigslist and make a private deal, we’ll both be better off. Basically, $2,000 worth of value is created. The only question is how much of that will be profit to me and what will be savings to you.

任何一本好的谈判书籍都会解释如何通过利用差异来创造价值。如果一幅画的主人喜欢她拥有的这幅画，但另一个人却非常喜欢它，那么他们就应该达成交易。谈判者们已经逐渐理解了这一点，至少凭直觉就能明白。事实上，所有成功的谈判都能创造价值。假设我打算以 8000 美元的价格置换我的车，而你在城另一边，准备花 10000 美元购买同一款车，车况也完全相同。如果我们通过 Craigslist 找到彼此，并私下达成交易，我们双方都会受益。基本上，这创造了价值 2000 美元的价值。唯一的问题是，这其中有多少会成为我的利润，又有多少会成为你的节省。

If we’re limited to price, our negotiation within that range is said to be “distributive,” or zero sum. That is, any dollar gain that goes into one party’s pocket comes out of the other one’s. A price of $8,100 would be great for you, while $9,900 works much better for me. As a result, we may haggle. But either of those numbers—and every one in between—would leave each of us better off than no deal.

如果谈判仅限于价格，那么在这个范围内进行的谈判就被称为“分配式谈判”或零和博弈。也就是说，一方获得的任何收益都会从另一方的利益中扣除。8100美元的价格对你来说很合适，而9900美元对我来说则更理想。因此，我们可能会讨价还价。但无论最终成交价是多少，都比没有成交要好。

When negotiators speak of value creation, however, they usually mean finding outcomes that improve their mutual welfare, so that one person’s gains don’t come at the other’s expense. Joint benefit arises from trading on different priorities, expectations, time horizons, or attitudes toward risk. Just as differences of opinion make horse races, they’re also the sources of value in negotiation. Here are some quick examples.

然而，谈判者谈到价值创造时，通常指的是找到能够提升双方福祉的方案，确保一方的获益不会以另一方的损失为代价。共同利益源于对不同优先事项、预期、时间跨度或风险态度的权衡取舍。正如意见分歧造就赛马比赛一样，它们也是谈判价值的来源。以下是一些简要示例。

Valuation Differences.
估值差异。

Two diners may like pie à la mode, for example, but if one is crazy about ice cream and the other adores pie, each should eat what he loves best and then swap plates.

例如，两个食客可能都喜欢冰淇淋派，但如果一个特别喜欢冰淇淋，另一个特别喜欢派，那么每个人都应该吃自己最喜欢的食物，然后交换盘子。

Economies of Scale.
规模经济。

Likewise, ramping a deal up or down can create value. Delivering a larger order may not cost a supplier much more than handling a small one. A buyer thus may get a better per-unit price (and the seller, more profit) by doubling the order.

同样，调整订单规模也能创造价值。交付更大订单的成本可能不会比处理小订单高出多少。因此，买家可以通过增加订单量来获得更低的单价（卖家也能获得更多利润）。

Time Horizons.
时间范围。

Tweaking the time element is another source of value. In the sports world, a long-term contract may provide security for the player while letting the team lock in his salary at today’s rates.

调整合同期限也是其价值所在。在体育界，长期合同既能为球员提供保障，又能让球队锁定其当前的薪资水平。

Differing Expectations.
不同的期望。

Value is also created anytime that a pessimist sells to an optimist. If I think I’ve expanded my business to its limit, while you see a bright future, you should buy it.

当悲观者把东西卖给乐观者时，价值也会被创造出来。如果我认为我的业务已经发展到极限，而你却看到了光明的未来，那么你就应该买下它。

Risk Tolerance.
风险承受能力。

Even if people have identical expectations, value can also be created by allocating risk wisely. A wildcatter may agree that the chances are good that he’s found a productive oil well, but he might worry about being wiped out if it’s a bust. A big company, with a portfolio of investments, is better positioned to bear that risk.

即使人们的预期完全相同，通过合理分配风险也能创造价值。一个石油勘探者可能认为自己找到高产油井的可能性很大，但他也会担心如果勘探失败会血本无归。而拥有投资组合的大公司则更有能力承担这种风险。

A pair of negotiators will weigh these factors differently. And this is good news, since differences can create value. With wise trades, parties can bridge gaps and break impasses. Even where there’s room for agreement on price alone, creativity can enhance value for everyone.

不同的谈判者会对这些因素做出不同的权衡。这其实是好事，因为差异可以创造价值。通过明智的交易，各方可以弥合分歧，打破僵局。即使仅在价格方面存在达成一致的空间，创造力也能提升各方的价值。

It’s one thing to appreciate this idea in the abstract but another to apply it in practice. Just think back to puzzle number 1, where your home buyer wants to make his purchase contingent on the sale of his own property. It’s a common problem. Maybe you’ve figured out a solution, maybe not. Here’s one possibility: you might solve the impasse by tweaking the structure of the contract.

从理论上理解这个理念是一回事，将其付诸实践又是另一回事。回想一下第一个难题，购房者希望将购房与出售其现有房产挂钩。这是一个常见的问题。也许您已经找到了解决方案，也许还没有。这里有一种可能性：您可以通过调整合同结构来解决僵局。

Specifically, you could accept the offer, contingent on Jones’s sale, provided that you add a twist allowing you to keep your house on the market notwithstanding the provisional deal. If another buyer makes you an offer before Jones sells his own house, he or she would then have forty-eight hours to match that price and close the deal. If not, your new buyer would get your house.

具体来说，您可以接受琼斯的报价，但前提是琼斯必须先卖掉自己的房子。不过，您可以附加一个条件，允许您在达成临时协议的情况下继续出售自己的房子。如果在琼斯卖掉自己的房子之前有其他买家向您出价，那么他/她有48小时的时间来匹配这个价格并完成交易。否则，您的房子就归新买家所有。

This arrangement isn’t perfect, but it’s better for both parties than no agreement at all. It lets you have it both ways: you keep alive the chance of selling to Jones but without losing the opportunity to deal with someone else. (Other prospective buyers shouldn’t be deterred from bidding, since the forty-eight-hour deadline will quickly let them know if the house is available.) Jones comes out ahead too. Given a little more time, he may be able to sell his own home and then buy yours, no strings attached. Of course, if you find a buyer before he does, Jones will have to make his choice. If he then walks away, he’s no worse off than doing so today.

这种安排并不完美，但对双方来说都比完全没有协议要好。它让你两全其美：既保留了卖给琼斯的机会，又没有失去与其他买家交易的机会。（其他潜在买家不必因此放弃竞标，因为48小时的期限能让他们很快知道房子是否待售。）琼斯也从中受益。如果给他更多时间，他或许可以先卖掉自己的房子，然后再买下你的房子，没有任何附加条件。当然，如果你在他之前找到了买家，琼斯就必须做出选择。如果他最终放弃，对他来说也并无损失。

OVERCOMING BARRIERS

克服障碍

Roger Fisher, coauthor of the classic Getting to Yes , was fond of saying, “Solutions aren’t the answer.” Process, he would regularly remind us, is paramount.

《谈判力》的合著者罗杰·费舍尔常说：“解决方案并非答案。”他经常提醒我们，过程才是最重要的。

Puzzle Number 2
谜题编号 2

You’ve successfully launched a small real estate brokerage and want to grow the enterprise. You’d love to recruit a superstar salesperson with the visibility and contacts to bring in lots of new business. Having such a person on board also would help you hire other top-notch people. But how do you induce a major league player to take a step down and play in the minors?

你成功创办了一家小型房地产经纪公司，现在想扩大业务。你渴望招募一位人脉广泛、知名度高的销售精英，为公司带来大量新客户。有了这样的人才，你也能更容易地招到其他顶尖人才。但是，如何才能让一位大联盟的明星球员甘愿降级到小联盟呢？

For every example of a clever way to salvage a deal or resolve a conflict, there are needless stalemates that could have been avoided if only someone had looked at the problem from another angle. Strategic behavior often blocks that view. Negotiators frequently bluff, using high demands, low offers, ultimatums, and artificial deadlines. These gambits work sometimes, particularly if the other party is naïve or desperate, but hardball tactics smother creativity. People withhold information, fearful it will be exploited. That leaves everyone in the dark. If no one grasps the parties’ interests, their chances of stumbling upon a good solution are slim. Even negotiators who see potential for expanding the pie may jostle over who gets what slice. Invoking mantras about dealing with “interests, not positions” is all well and good, but fair-minded people will nevertheless want to advance their own agendas.

每出现一个巧妙挽救交易或化解冲突的例子，就会出现一些本可避免的僵局，而这些僵局原本可以通过换个角度看待问题来避免。策略性的行为往往会阻碍这种视角。谈判者经常虚张声势，提出高要求、低报价、发出最后通牒，并人为设定截止日期。这些策略有时确实奏效，尤其是在对方天真或走投无路的情况下，但强硬手段会扼杀创造力。人们会隐瞒信息，害怕被利用。这导致所有人都被蒙在鼓里。如果没人能理解各方的利益，找到好解决方案的机会就微乎其微。即使是那些看到扩大利益蛋糕潜力的谈判者，也会为了争夺份额而争执不休。高谈阔论“关注利益而非立场”固然没错，但公正的人仍然会想要推进自己的目标。

The barriers to creativity are greater when negotiators are acting on behalf of their organizations or clients. Standardized contracts and company policies constrain salespeople’s ability to tailor deals that meet the needs of specific customers. A procurement officer may work overtime to nail down an agreement with a key supplier only to be second-guessed by a senior manager who wasn’t at the table but somehow thinks that their buyer should have gotten a lower price. Inability to reach internal consensus over priorities also hobbles creative negotiation with outside parties.

当谈判者代表其组织或客户行事时，创造力会受到更大的阻碍。标准化的合同和公司政策限制了销售人员根据特定客户需求定制交易的能力。采购员可能加班加点与关键供应商敲定协议，却可能遭到一位并未参与谈判的高级经理的质疑，这位经理认为采购员应该争取到更低的价格。内部无法就优先事项达成共识也会阻碍与外部各方进行创造性谈判。

Company-to-company transactions can likewise breed an us-versus-them mentality that exacerbates people’s natural tendency to be self-righteous about what they think they deserve. Seeing a problem from someone else’s point of view is hard enough. In a group setting, expressing appreciation for an outsider’s interests can seem downright disloyal to your colleagues.

公司间的交易同样会滋生一种“我们与他们”的对立心态，加剧人们天生的自以为是，认为自己理应得到什么。从他人的角度看待问题已经够难了。在群体环境中，对局外人的利益表示赞赏，甚至会被视为对同事的背叛。

The second puzzle, the one about a fledgling firm trying to recruit a superstar, was described by journalist Rob Walker in Inc. magazine. To solve that problem, New York real estate broker Barbara Corcoran focused on the process of negotiation rather than the substantive terms of the deal. The day before the candidate was to appear, she asked her best, most loyal salespeople to dress up for the visit.

第二个难题是关于一家初创公司试图招募一位超级明星，记者罗伯·沃克在《Inc.》杂志上对此进行了描述。为了解决这个问题，纽约房地产经纪人芭芭拉·科克伦将重点放在谈判过程上，而不是交易的实质性条款上。在候选人到访的前一天，她要求自己最优秀、最忠诚的销售人员盛装出席。

When the sales diva arrived the next afternoon, “acting deservedly self-important,” Corcoran groveled and ushered her guest into the conference room, where her team was assembled. “Here are some of the people who work here,” she said. “They’ll tell you what’s good about the company.” And then Corcoran left. The superstar met with the group for almost two hours. That night, she called Corcoran and accepted the job, declaring that meeting the staff convinced her that she couldn’t work anyplace else.

第二天下午，那位销售女王趾高气扬地到来，科克伦卑躬屈膝地将她迎进会议室，她的团队成员都在那里。“这些是我们公司的一些员工，”她说，“他们会告诉你公司有哪些优势。”说完，科克伦就离开了。这位超级明星与团队成员会面了近两个小时。当晚，她打电话给科克伦，接受了这份工作，并表示与员工的会面让她确信，她再也找不到比这里更好的工作了。

After that, Corcoran landed a string of other talented people. Her company grew rapidly. “That wouldn’t have happened,” she says, “if I hadn’t closed the deal with my first high-end salesperson.” Corcoran succeeded not because of what she negotiated but how she negotiated. Instead of dealing with the dollars and cents of compensation, she made relationships paramount. Her fresh approach turned what might have seemed like a weakness—having a small team of younger people—into an asset.

之后，科克伦又招揽了一批又一批优秀人才。她的公司迅速发展壮大。“如果我当初没有签下我的第一位高端销售人员，”她说，“这一切都不会发生。”科克伦的成功不在于她谈判的金额，而在于她的谈判方式。她没有纠结于薪酬的金额，而是将人际关系放在首位。她这种创新的方法，将看似劣势的因素——团队规模小且成员年轻——转化为了优势。

Enlisting her employees as allies was farsighted as well. Instead of feeling upstaged by the arrival of a big-name salesperson, they understood their stake in hiring her. The negotiation process itself demonstrated that everyone was in this together, which built a foundation for future collaboration and mentoring.

将员工争取为盟友也是一项极具远见的举措。员工们并没有因为一位知名销售员的到来而感到压力，反而明白聘用她与自身利益息息相关。谈判过程本身就表明大家齐心协力，这为未来的合作和指导奠定了基础。

BREAKING DEADLOCKS

打破僵局

Being creative in negotiation depends on the attitude you bring to the task. Focusing on whatever it is that won’t work can blind you to solutions that will.

谈判中的创造力取决于你对待谈判的态度。如果只关注那些行不通的方案，你可能会忽略其他可行的解决方案。

Puzzle Number 3
谜题编号 3

In 1995 the Dayton Accords had quelled the bloody conflict in the former Yugoslavia. Even after the agreement was signed, however, violence continued in contested regions. Serbian gunmen were shooting at cars with Bosnian-issued license plates that didn’t use the Cyrillic alphabet. With relationships still bitter, Bosnian officials certainly weren’t going to adopt the Serbian system, nor would Serbs accept the Bosnians’ modern Latin alphabet. Cyrillic type differs from the Latin type used in the book you’re now holding. Any suggestions?

1995年，《代顿协议》平息了前南斯拉夫的血腥冲突。然而，即使在协议签署之后，争议地区的暴力事件仍然持续不断。塞尔维亚枪手向悬挂波斯尼亚牌照、未使用西里尔字母的车辆开枪。由于双方关系依然紧张，波斯尼亚官员当然不会采用塞尔维亚的牌照系统，塞尔维亚人也不会接受波斯尼亚的现代拉丁字母。您现在手中的这本书使用的字体与西里尔字母不同。有什么建议吗？

Strategic behavior is a formidable obstacle to creativity. Organizational constraints are another. Mind-set is the biggest of all. And that’s one thing over which we have real control. The phrase “thinking outside the box” has itself become a cliché. Nevertheless, testing boundaries and turning problems upside down is imperative in negotiation. Joseph Lash’s first publisher missed an opportunity because it was stuck inside the box of thinking in terms of a single volume. That’s what the original contract specified, so it seemed that the only options were either having the author radically cut his draft or junking the project. The second publisher wasn’t encumbered by that assumption; hence, it could recognize the much better alternative of turning one book into two.

战略行为是创造力的一大障碍。组织限制是另一大障碍。而思维模式则是最大的障碍。这也是我们真正能够掌控的因素之一。“跳出思维定式”这句话本身已经成了老生常谈。然而，在谈判中，突破界限、换位思考至关重要。约瑟夫·拉什的第一家出版商错失良机，正是因为他们固守着单卷本的思维模式。最初的合同就是如此规定的，所以他们似乎只有两个选择：要么让作者大幅删减稿件，要么放弃整个项目。第二家出版商则没有受到这种限制；因此，他们能够意识到将一本书拆分成两本书才是更好的选择。

It’s easy to scoff at other people’s lack of imagination, but by definition, it’s impossible to spot our own blind spots. Psychologists say it’s easy to fall prey to “naïve realism”: the ability to see holes in other people’s thinking while being blithely ignorant of our own lapses. We’re all vulnerable to the powerful cognitive and social forces that constrain creativity.

我们很容易嘲笑别人缺乏想象力，但从定义上讲，我们不可能发现自己的盲点。心理学家说，我们很容易陷入“朴素现实主义”：能够看到别人思维中的漏洞，却对自己思维的不足浑然不觉。我们都容易受到强大的认知和社会因素的影响，这些因素会限制创造力。

Pessimism is self-fulfilling. People who believe in the mythical fixed pie, as Harvard Business School professor Max Bazerman calls it, see negotiation strictly in win-lose terms. For them, differences over value, expectations, and other issues are evidence of conflict, not material for constructive trades, so they don’t bother to look for joint gains.

悲观主义会自我实现。正如哈佛商学院教授马克斯·巴泽曼所说，那些相信“固定蛋糕”神话的人，看待谈判完全局限于输赢的二元对立。对他们而言，价值、期望和其他问题上的分歧是冲突的体现，而非建设性交易的素材，因此他们根本不愿寻求共同利益。

At the other extreme are the dreamy optimists who believe that luck is somehow always on their side. No matter how long the odds, they’re convinced a great deal is right around the corner. There’s danger in that kind of optimism as well. Doubling down after losing five times in a row in roulette, because “the law of averages” means that you’re bound to win next time, is a ticket to financial ruin.

另一个极端是那些不切实际的乐观主义者，他们相信好运总是眷顾自己。无论胜算多么渺茫，他们都坚信好事即将发生。这种乐观也暗藏危险。在轮盘赌中连续输了五次后，仍然加倍下注，因为“概率法则”意味着下次一定会赢，这无异于自寻死路。

Stephen Nachmanovitch, improv expert and author of Free Play: Improvisation in Life and Art , says that to be creative, our minds must embody two inner characters: a muse who proposes and an editor who disposes. “The editor criticizes, shapes, and organizes the raw material that the free play of the muse has generated.” He warns, however, that if the critical part of our brains kicks in too soon, “our muse gets edited right out of existence.”

即兴表演专家、著有《自由游戏：生活与艺术中的即兴创作》一书的斯蒂芬·纳赫马诺维奇认为，要发挥创造力，我们的大脑必须同时具备两个内在角色：一个是提出灵感的缪斯，另一个是负责筛选的编辑。“编辑会批判、塑造并整理缪斯自由发挥所产生的原始素材。”但他警告说，如果我们大脑的批判性思维过早启动，“缪斯就会被扼杀在摇篮里。”

It helps to be optimistic while negotiating. That means believing that with a little more effort and imagination, we can solve a problem that at first may seem intractable. The late actress Ruth Gordon (star of the classic black comedy Harold and Maude ) had the motto “Never face facts.” She said that other people are always telling you what isn’t possible. Her advice was to forget about them and make things happen.

谈判时保持乐观很有帮助。这意味着要相信，只要多花些心思和发挥想象力，我们就能解决那些起初看似棘手的问题。已故女演员露丝·戈登（经典黑色喜剧《哈罗德与莫德》的主演）的座右铭是“永远不要面对现实”。她说，别人总是告诉你什么是不可能的。她的建议是，别理会他们，去做你想做的事。

People who are admirably unreasonable like Ruth Gordon relish the challenge of solving a problem that would stump others. It’s akin to what organizational behavior expert Frank Barrett describes as having an appreciative mind-set, or, in the vernacular, saying yes to the mess. That means having a clear-eyed view of whatever we confront, while still believing that there’s something that we can make of it. French anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss called it bricolage. In the United States, it’s called MacGyvering (a nod to the 1980s action-adventure TV series MacGyver ): improvising a solution with a few pieces of junk, some duct tape, and a Swiss Army knife. A healthy defiance of reality is contagious. It can encourage other parties to roll up their sleeves and help search for agreement. But it has to be tempered, of course, by the recognition that not everything is negotiable.

像露丝·戈登这样令人钦佩的“非理性”人士，乐于挑战那些令他人束手无策的问题。这类似于组织行为学专家弗兰克·巴雷特所描述的“欣赏型心态”，或者用通俗的话来说，就是“欣然接受困境”。这意味着对我们所面临的一切保持清醒的认识，同时仍然相信我们能够从中找到解决之道。法国人类学家克劳德·列维-斯特劳斯称之为“拼凑”（bricolage）。在美国，它被称为“麦克盖式发明”（MacGyvering，致敬20世纪80年代的动作冒险电视剧《百战天龙》）：用一些废旧物品、胶带和一把瑞士军刀即兴发挥，找到解决方案。这种健康的“挑战现实”的精神具有感染力。它可以鼓励其他人卷起袖子，共同寻求共识。当然，这种精神也必须受到制约，因为并非所有事情都能协商解决。

The divide between the Bosnians and the Serbians stretches back for centuries. It was unthinkable that either side would buckle under and accept the other’s alphabet for its license plates, yet the late American diplomat Richard Holbrooke mediated a truce. Unburdened by their bloody history, he saw a simple solution: just use the ten letters the two languages have in common.

波斯尼亚人和塞尔维亚人之间的隔阂可以追溯到几个世纪以前。双方都不可能屈服，接受对方的字母作为车牌字母，然而已故的美国外交官理查德·霍尔布鲁克却促成了双方的停火。他没有受到两国血腥历史的束缚，看到了一个简单的解决方案：只需使用两种语言共有的十个字母即可。

A blend of optimism and skepticism can be leavened with a playful attitude. Recall the demeanor of Ambassador Holbrooke “yakking, talking, and jiving” during the middle of the Balkan peace talks. According to Nachmanovitch, “Play is the free spirit of exploration.” Its mood, he adds, “can be impish or supremely solemn.” The lesson for negotiators is that creativity requires shaking up and reordering what we know.

乐观与怀疑的交织，可以与轻松诙谐的态度相得益彰。不妨回想一下霍尔布鲁克大使在巴尔干和平谈判期间“喋喋不休、谈笑风生”的姿态。纳赫马诺维奇认为，“玩乐是自由探索的精神。”他补充道，玩乐的情绪“可以是顽皮的，也可以是极其严肃的。”谈判者从中得到的启示是，创造力需要打破并重新审视我们已知的一切。

Our best ideas don’t often come from lockstep analysis. Rather, it’s through a process of juggling different possibilities, taking elements from each, and fashioning them into a novel solution. Scrabble players naturally shuffle letters in their rack. It’s not nervousness. They’re looking for a sequence that sparks a new idea. And spark is the right word: recent studies using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) scans show how Tetris game players’ brains light up when they actively flip shapes on a video screen.

我们最好的想法往往并非源于死板的分析，而是通过权衡各种可能性，汲取其中的元素，并将它们融合为一个全新的解决方案。玩拼字游戏的人会自然而然地打乱字母架上的字母。这并非出于紧张，而是因为他们在寻找能够激发新想法的字母组合。“激发”一词用得恰到好处：近期利用功能性磁共振成像（fMRI）扫描的研究表明，俄罗斯方块玩家在屏幕上积极翻转方块时，大脑会活跃起来。

Great scientists engage in playful thinking as well. Albert Einstein said that many of his dazzling insights came from what he called “combinatorial play.” He was a visual thinker who toyed with images in his head. Contemplating relativity, for example, he conjured a picture of himself riding a beam of light and carrying a clock. Sometimes great ideas may seem to come in a flash. The nineteenth-century German scientist Friedrich Kekule claimed that the hexagonal chemical structure of the benzene ring came to him in a daydream of six intertwined snakes. Of course, before he had that vision, he had been studying carbon bonds for years. He just had to make the right connections.

伟大的科学家也善于进行游戏式的思考。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦曾说，他许多令人惊叹的洞见都源于他所谓的“组合游戏”。他是一位视觉型思考者，喜欢在脑海中玩弄各种图像。例如，在思考相对论时，他想象自己骑在一束光束上，手里拿着一个钟。有时，伟大的想法似乎会灵光一闪。19世纪的德国科学家弗里德里希·凯库勒声称，苯环的六边形化学结构是他梦见六条相互缠绕的蛇时获得的灵感。当然，在他产生这种想法之前，他已经研究碳键多年。他只是需要建立正确的联系。

We can’t simply wait for inspiration to strike. We have to keep working our ideas. Creative negotiators work both top down and bottom up, inductively and deductively. They play around with concepts and rules of thumb, wondering out loud how adding more issues to the mix could generate more value. If a comprehensive solution doesn’t materialize, they break down the problem into smaller parts. When asked how he thought about complex diplomatic challenges, President Bill Clinton likened them to crossword puzzles: “You start with what you know the answer to and work from that. A lot of problems are like that. You have to find some aspect of it that you understand and build on it until you can unravel the mystery that you’re trying to solve.” Small victories move us forward, bolster our confidence, and expand our influence.

我们不能只是坐等灵感降临，而必须不断完善我们的想法。富有创造力的谈判者会自上而下和自下而上地工作，运用归纳和演绎的方法。他们会反复推敲各种概念和经验法则，并公开思考如何通过增加更多议题来创造更大的价值。如果无法找到全面的解决方案，他们会将问题分解成更小的部分。当被问及如何看待复杂的外交挑战时，比尔·克林顿总统将其比作填字游戏：“你从已知的答案入手，然后以此为基础展开。很多问题都是如此。你必须找到自己能够理解的方面，并以此为基础，最终解开你试图解决的谜团。” 小小的胜利能够推动我们前进，增强我们的信心，并扩大我们的影响力。

THE POWER OF ANALOGIES

类比的力量

Studies by Leigh Thompson and Dedre Gentner of Northwestern University, along with Jeffrey Loewenstein, now at the University of Illinois, show that familiarity with a negotiation concept doesn’t guarantee that people will put it to practical use. The research team looked specifically at contingency clauses: contract terms that can transform differences in expectations into opportunities for mutual gain. For example, an injured baseball player may believe that he is fully healed and will have a great season, while his team is more pessimistic. Rather than arguing about who is right, they would be wise to craft an agreement with a low base salary but big performance bonuses. This contingency clause would reward the player appropriately if he is as healthy as he thinks he is but protect the team if he isn’t.

西北大学的利·汤普森和德德雷·根特纳，以及现任职于伊利诺伊大学的杰弗里·洛温斯坦的研究表明，熟悉某个谈判概念并不能保证人们会将其付诸实践。该研究团队专门研究了应急条款：这类合同条款可以将双方预期上的差异转化为互利共赢的机会。例如，一名受伤的棒球运动员可能认为自己已经完全康复，并且会迎来一个精彩的赛季，而他的球队则持悲观态度。与其争论谁对谁错，他们明智的做法是制定一份基本工资较低但绩效奖金丰厚的协议。如果球员的健康状况真如他所认为的那样，这项应急条款就能给予他相应的奖励；而如果球员的健康状况并非如此，则能保护球队的利益。

The researchers presented this concept to subjects using two familiar pedagogical methods. One group read about trading on different expectations and then did a negotiation exercise in which that was a possible solution. Almost all of its members missed the latent opportunity. Reading about the principle was insufficient.

研究人员采用两种常见的教学方法向受试者介绍了这一概念。一组受试者阅读了关于基于不同预期进行交易的内容，然后进行了一项谈判练习，其中“基于不同预期进行交易”是可能的解决方案之一。几乎所有受试者都错失了潜在的交易机会。仅仅阅读相关原理是不够的。

A second group was introduced to contingency clauses by actually doing a simulation that also had this potential and then debriefing its experience. Unfortunately, when these subjects were given a second simulation, set in a different context but with the same value-creating opportunity, they missed it too. It’s as if after having had a lesson in preparing chocolate pudding, they were no better than novices when it came to making vanilla.

第二组受试者通过实际模拟了解了应急条款，该模拟也具有这种潜在风险，并在模拟结束后进行了经验总结。遗憾的是，当这些受试者进行第二次模拟时（模拟情境不同，但同样具有创造价值的机会），他们也未能成功。这就像学过做巧克力布丁之后，做香草布丁时却和新手没什么两样一样。

But the researchers weren’t done. They tested two additional ways of introducing people to how contingency clauses can be used to generate value. A third group of subjects watched a video of people using this approach. (We’ll get back to them in a bit.) A fourth group did a “warm-up analysis” in which people who were paired up to negotiate first read two different cases in which contingency clauses were used and then compared them. The researchers told them to look for parallels and share their impressions with each other.

但研究人员并未就此止步。他们还测试了另外两种向人们介绍如何利用权变条款创造价值的方法。第三组受试者观看了一段展示人们如何运用这种方法的视频。（我们稍后会详细介绍他们。）第四组受试者进行了一项“热身分析”，他们两两一组进行谈判，首先阅读两个运用权变条款的案例，然后进行比较。研究人员要求他们寻找相似之处，并互相分享各自的感受。

This method did the trick. The fourth group was twice as likely to be creative as the first two were. These subjects applied what they had read and talked about in their own negotiations. The specific instructions about how to talk were critical, however. Still other subjects were given the same minicases and merely asked to discuss if they were successful negotiations. This control group didn’t really learn to be creative either. Its performance was no better than that of people who did the simulation without any kind of introductory training in making comparisons.

这种方法奏效了。第四组的创造力是前两组的两倍。这些受试者将他们阅读和讨论的内容运用到了自己的谈判中。然而，关于如何交谈的具体指导至关重要。还有一些受试者被给予同样的迷你案例，但仅仅被要求讨论这些案例是否构成成功的谈判。这个对照组也没有真正学会如何发挥创造力。他们的表现并不比那些没有接受任何比较技巧入门训练就进行模拟的人更好。

What about group three, the subjects who watched a video of negotiators making good use of a contingency clause? Good news. Afterward, they handled the simulation creatively, too. But here’s something quirky: when they were debriefed, they had no words to describe what they’d done or explanation of why they did it. Their learning was implicit. They became better negotiators without even knowing it.

那么第三组呢？他们观看了一段谈判者巧妙运用应急条款的视频。好消息是，之后他们在模拟谈判中也展现出了创造性。但有趣的是：在事后讨论中，他们无法用语言描述自己的操作，也无法解释这样做的原因。他们的学习是潜移默化的。他们在不知不觉中成为了更优秀的谈判者。

We can read the message of the studies as being half empty or half full. The downside is that learning concepts and analyzing experience are necessary but insufficient in respect to becoming more creative negotiators. The upside is that we can improve, provided we take the added step of ruminating about comparisons between what we’re doing now and what we’ve seen before. This analogical thinking is related to Colonel John Boyd’s OODA loop model, the ongoing process of orienting ourselves by comparing what’s unfolding before us with what we expected initially.

我们可以将这些研究的信息解读为喜忧参半。不足之处在于，学习概念和分析经验固然必要，但仅凭这些不足以成为更具创造力的谈判者。而积极的一面是，如果我们能进一步思考当前做法与以往经验的对比，就能有所进步。这种类比思维与约翰·博伊德上校的OODA循环模型相关，该模型强调通过比较当前情况与最初预期来不断调整自身方向。

The fact that not many people think this way is actually encouraging. It’s something we can do better if we attend to it seriously. While we’re negotiating, our minds should turn over clever solutions we’ve seen elsewhere, no matter how far afield they might seem. We may find lessons, links, or combinations that could be helpful today. As you read about examples—in this book and elsewhere—stop and ask yourself: “Where have I seen that before?” “How could I have used that approach in deals that slipped through my fingers?” “How can I expand my know-how going forward?”

事实上，很少有人这样想，这反而令人鼓舞。如果我们认真对待，就能做得更好。谈判时，我们应该思考之前在其他地方看到的巧妙解决方案，无论它们看起来多么不相关。我们或许能从中找到一些经验、联系或组合，在今天派上用场。当你阅读本书或其他地方的案例时，不妨停下来问问自己：“我以前在哪里见过这种方法？”“如果当初有机会达成交易，我该如何运用这种方法？”“我该如何拓展这方面的知识？”

COLLABORATION

合作

We’ve already noted that creativity is a challenge in negotiation because it involves multiple parties, each with his or her own agenda and style. Two heads can be better than one in other settings. A married couple can always finish a crossword faster than either spouse could alone. One may know science, while the other knows literature. But their real advantage comes from reciprocal contribution: the way that one person’s answers help fill in the blanks for the other. You should strive for the same kind of collaboration in negotiation.

我们之前已经提到，谈判中的创造力是一项挑战，因为它涉及多方参与，而每一方都有自己的目的和风格。在其他情况下，集思广益往往胜过单打独斗。夫妻二人完成填字游戏的速度总是比任何一方单独完成都要快。一方可能精通科学，另一方则精通文学。但他们真正的优势在于相互贡献：一方的答案能够帮助另一方填补空白。在谈判中，你也应该努力实现这种合作。

That’s true even if you are the smartest person in the room and can see the ultimate solution long before it’s apparent to others. Rushing things is often folly. Many years ago, the chief labor negotiator for General Electric, Lemuel Boulware, got himself in legal trouble trying to bypass the traditional bargaining process by simply putting his best—and final—offer on the table right at the start of talks.

即使你是房间里最聪明的人，能比其他人更早看到最终解决方案，也一样。操之过急往往是愚蠢的。多年前，通用电气首席劳资谈判代表莱缪尔·布尔瓦尔就因为试图绕过传统的谈判程序，在谈判伊始就直接抛出他最好的——也是最终的——报价，而惹上了法律麻烦。

He had run all the numbers, analyzed wages in comparable companies, and put together what he thought was a fair and reasonable compensation package. Perhaps it was. Who knows? But, no surprise, the union officials balked. They insisted that crafting a collective bargaining agreement must be mutual, and the courts agreed. Boulware’s approach, even if sincere, blocked the union from advancing any of its ideas—perhaps to both sides’ detriment.

他仔细核算了所有数据，分析了同类公司的工资水平，并制定了一套他认为公平合理的薪酬方案。或许确实如此，谁知道呢？但不出所料，工会官员们却犹豫不决。他们坚持认为，集体谈判协议的制定必须是双方共同参与的，而法院也认同了这一点。布尔瓦尔的做法，即便出于真诚，也阻碍了工会推进任何诉求——这或许对双方都不利。

The chances of an idea being accepted improve if both parties have a hand in developing the deal, especially if other stakeholders need to endorse it. Screenwriter-producer Robert Kosberg is called the “king of the pitch” in Hollywood. To sell an idea to a studio, he says, “You want the listener to become your collaborator so by the time he goes to pitch it to his boss, it’s his story, and he has a vested interest. He’s no longer pitching Bob Kosberg’s project. He’s pitching his project, and I’m lucky if my name gets mentioned.”

如果双方都参与到交易的制定过程中，尤其是当其他利益相关者需要认可时，想法被采纳的几率就会大大提高。编剧兼制片人罗伯特·科斯伯格被誉为好莱坞的“提案之王”。他表示，要想把一个想法卖给制片厂，“你要让听众成为你的合作伙伴，这样当他向老板提案时，这故事就成了他自己的，他会对此产生切身利益。他不再是推销鲍勃·科斯伯格的项目，而是推销他自己的项目，而我的名字能被提及就算幸运了。”

In the best of all worlds, your willingness to toy with problems may inspire your counterpart to take a fresh look at the possibilities. The classic book Getting to Yes tells us to “invent before you judge.” Premature criticism stifles brainstorming, its authors advise. When people are intent on poking holes in one another’s proposals, they miss the seeds of other, more promising ideas.

在理想情况下，你乐于探索问题的态度或许能启发对方以全新的视角审视各种可能性。经典著作《谈判力》（Getting to Yes）告诉我们“先创造，后评判”。作者指出，过早的批评会扼杀头脑风暴。当人们一心只想挑剔对方的提议时，就会错过其他更有前景的想法的萌芽。

A dialogue where both parties are building solutions, not tearing them down, will be peppered with comments such as “Just thinking out loud,” “How can we go to school on what others have done?,” “This may be off the wall, but,” and “Wouldn’t it be great if we could . . . ?” In negotiation, that kind of interchange requires a high level of comfort, openness, and trust.

双方共同构建解决方案而非互相否定的对话中，会穿插着诸如“我只是随便想想”、“我们如何借鉴他人的经验？”、“这可能有点异想天开，但是……”以及“如果我们能……那该多好啊？”之类的评论。在谈判中，这种交流需要高度的舒适感、开放性和信任。

Parties need to feel free to play with options that test the boundaries of practicality; otherwise they limit their options. However, brainstorming can happen only if there’s a mutual understanding that floating ideas is not the same as making an offer. Even with good intentions, it’s hard to separate inventing from judging. Whatever ideas are voiced may color perceptions and anchor expectations. Temporarily suspending judgment is helpful but not always possible.

各方需要能够自由地探索各种可能突破实际可行性界限的方案；否则，他们的选择就会受到限制。然而，头脑风暴只有在各方都明白提出想法并不等同于提出报价的前提下才能有效进行。即便出于好意，也很难将构思与评判完全区分开来。任何提出的想法都可能影响人们的认知，并左右人们的预期。暂时搁置评判固然有益，但并非总是可行。

Babson College professor Lakshmi Balachandra has studied potential investors’ reactions to almost two hundred pitches by entrepreneurs. The substantive merit of their business plans matters, of course, but interpersonal dynamics often seal the deals. A presenter’s poise, passion, and eye contact are in themselves strong predictors of success. Likewise, in negotiation, creative ideas don’t sell themselves.

巴布森学院教授拉克希米·巴拉钱德拉研究了潜在投资者对近两百位创业者路演的反应。商业计划书的实质内容固然重要，但人际互动往往才是促成交易的关键。演讲者的仪态、热情和眼神交流本身就是成功的重要预测指标。同样，在谈判中，创意本身并不会自行推销。

Timing is important as well. We have to resist the impulse to announce our brilliant solution until others understand the problem it addresses. Moreover, proposals are always relative in negotiation. That is, they’re weighed against what our counterparts can get elsewhere and, also, what they think they’d gain by pressing us further. There’s no magic formula for calculating the perfect moment to introduce a new idea that will bring a negotiation to a fruitful end. That’s inevitably an intuitive judgment, one that requires experience and emotional intelligence. When we’re assessing whether the time is right, we should consider the following:

时机也很重要。我们必须克制住急于宣布我们绝妙方案的冲动，直到对方理解它所解决的问题。此外，谈判中的提议总是相对的。也就是说，我们会权衡对方能从其他途径获得什么，以及他们认为如果继续施压会得到什么。没有万能公式可以计算出提出新想法并促成谈判圆满结束的最佳时机。这必然是一种直觉判断，需要经验和情商。当我们评估时机是否合适时，应该考虑以下几点：

• Have we earned our counterpart’s confidence?

• 我们是否赢得了对方的信任？

• In listening to his or her proposals, have we modeled the respect that we want given to our own ideas?

• 在听取他或她的建议时，我们是否以身作则，展现出我们希望自己的想法得到尊重的那种尊重？

• Does the other side have realistic expectations?

对方的期望是否现实？

• Have we managed other potential obstacles to agreement, such as strategic behavior and organizational constraints?

• 我们是否已克服其他可能阻碍达成协议的障碍，例如战略行为和组织限制？

• Are there other things that we still could do to increase the odds of acceptance?

• 我们还可以做哪些其他事情来提高被录取的几率？

Skilled psychotherapists have a keen sense of timing. Judith Coche is a clinician in Philadelphia. A New York Times profile noted her ability to intercede between bickering spouses, “pulling out unexpected common threads in the stories the couples were telling, giving the assemblage a whiff of fresh perspective.” Sometimes that means putting forth a provocative notion. “Causing the right amount of trouble is an art form,” Coche says. She also does what she calls “seeding,” putting forth a suggestion but letting it germinate if people aren’t quite ready to accept it.

技艺精湛的心理治疗师对时机有着敏锐的把握。朱迪思·科切是费城的一位临床心理治疗师。《纽约时报》的一篇人物特写指出，她善于调解夫妻间的争吵，“从夫妻讲述的故事中挖掘出意想不到的共同点，为整个过程带来一丝新的视角。” 有时，这意味着提出一些颇具争议的观点。“制造适度的麻烦是一门艺术，”科切说道。她还会进行她所谓的“播种”，提出建议，但如果人们还没有完全准备好接受，就让它慢慢生根发芽。

Negotiation likewise has similar ebbs and flows. Proposals ignored or rejected early on can be revisited, revised, and integrated later, when the parties realize that they are stuck. Nachmanovitch says that people often have to pass through such a phase to be truly creative. For negotiators, confronting an impasse may be the equivalent of hitting rock bottom. That’s not a pleasant prospect, but it can jolt a person into thinking creatively.

谈判同样有起伏。早期被忽略或拒绝的提议，可以在双方意识到陷入僵局后重新审视、修改并整合。纳赫马诺维奇认为，人们往往需要经历这样一个阶段才能真正发挥创造力。对于谈判者而言，遭遇僵局可能相当于跌入谷底。这并非令人愉快的经历，但它却能激发人们的创造性思维。

ALIGNING INCENTIVES

调整激励机制

We’ve looked at three puzzles so far in this chapter. The first described an imaginative solution to the problem of selling a home in the midst of a weak market. The second described a clever process for recruiting top talent to a fledgling firm. The third, involving license plates in the Balkans, underscored the importance of having a playful, optimistic mind-set. Here is a final conundrum, which illustrates another important aspect of creativity:

本章目前为止我们探讨了三个谜题。第一个谜题描述了在市场疲软的情况下如何巧妙地出售房屋。第二个谜题介绍了一种为初创公司招募顶尖人才的巧妙方法。第三个谜题与巴尔干地区的车牌有关，强调了保持轻松乐观的心态的重要性。以下是最后一个谜题，它阐明了创造力的另一个重要方面：

Puzzle Number 4
谜题编号 4

A neighborhood was alarmed about a landfill operator’s application to increase the size of the dump. The residents had long been angry about windblown litter from the site landing all over their lawns. Expanding the facility would only make matters worse, they claimed. They vowed to continue their opposition unless the operator guaranteed payment to an independent contractor who’d clean up future debris to their full satisfaction. The operator refused, convinced that the neighbors would make a sweetheart deal with someone’s brother-in-law to fix problems that the landfill hadn’t even caused. His business could end up overpaying substantially.

一个社区对垃圾填埋场运营商申请扩大填埋场规模感到担忧。长期以来，居民们一直对垃圾被风吹散、散落在自家草坪上的垃圾感到愤怒。他们声称，扩建填埋场只会让情况更加糟糕。他们誓言，除非运营商保证支付给独立承包商一笔费用，由其负责清理未来的垃圾，并确保清理工作完全符合他们的要求，否则他们将继续反对。运营商拒绝了这一提议，他坚信居民们会与某人的姻亲达成某种默契，让承包商来解决一些并非由填埋场造成的问题。这样一来，他的公司最终可能会支付过高的费用。

The parties were at an impasse: the operator couldn’t get his revised permit, and the neighbors still had trash floating into their yards. How could both sides do better?

双方陷入僵局：经营者无法获得修改后的许可证，而邻居们仍然饱受垃圾漂流之苦。双方该如何改进？

The parties here had a long and antagonistic history, with each side imputing bad motives to the other. The lack of trust stymied creative problem solving. Town officials were caught in the middle. They were sympathetic to the abutters but also valued the landfill business, as it provided tax revenue and an important service to other citizens.

双方有着长期的敌对历史，彼此都指责对方动机不纯。缺乏信任阻碍了创造性地解决问题。镇政府官员夹在中间左右为难。他们同情邻近居民，但也重视垃圾填埋场业务，因为它能带来税收，并为其他居民提供重要的服务。

When other efforts at peacemaking failed, they hired an outside mediator, an environmental lawyer who had no prior ties to the community. He held a public session where people shot accusations back and forth, and then he met privately with individuals. His goal was to find a solution that would address everyone’s core concerns. The landfill wanted to grow; that was obvious. And its neighbors wanted their own properties to be cleaner—much cleaner. The mediator then called together key representatives. He told them that he had come up with a possible solution, but he wanted everyone to hear each of its elements before expressing opposition or support.

当其他调解努力失败后，他们聘请了一位外部调解员，一位此前与社区并无任何关联的环境律师。他主持了一场公开会议，人们在会上互相指责，之后他又与个别居民进行了私下会谈。他的目标是找到一个能够解决所有人核心诉求的方案。垃圾填埋场想要扩大规模，这一点显而易见。而附近的居民则希望自己的土地更加清洁——清洁得多。随后，调解员召集了各方代表。他告诉他们，他已经提出了一个可能的解决方案，但他希望每个人在表达反对或支持之前，都能仔细了解方案的每一个细节。

“Point one,” the mediator said. “At the start of each fiscal year, the landfill will advance one hundred thousand dollars to the town to cover cleanup costs.” The owner started to speak. This was more than he was prepared to pay.

“第一点，”调解员说，“每个财政年度开始时，垃圾填埋场将预付给镇政府十万美元，用于支付清理费用。” 业主刚要开口，这远远超出了他的预算。

But the mediator put up his hand. “Hold on,” he said. “Point two. Town officials will control that fund and put the cleanup work out to bid.” The neighbors looked at one another. This scenario wasn’t quite what they had in mind.

但调解员举起手说：“等等。第二点，镇政府官员将掌控这笔资金，并将清理工作公开招标。”邻居们面面相觑。这和他们预想的完全不一样。

“Point three,” the mediator continued. “At the end of the year, whatever’s left of the fund will be divided two ways. Half will go back to the landfill operator. The town can spend the other half any way it wants.”

“第三点，”调解员继续说道，“年底剩余的资金将分成两部分。一半将返还给垃圾填埋场运营商。镇政府可以随意支配另一半。”

A few people smiled. Others looked confused. “Run that last point by us again,” somebody said. The mediator explained that whatever was left of the $100,000 would be divided, with the landfill getting a refund, of sorts. The town could spend the other half on the library, a new Little League field, or anything else it needed. Some people looked skeptical, as they were catching up with the idea that the problem that had long confounded them might have a practical solution. It was as if they were looking for holes in the plan and were perplexed that there weren’t any.

有些人笑了，另一些人则一脸困惑。“再跟我们说一遍最后一点，”有人说道。调解员解释说，剩下的10万美元将进行分配，垃圾填埋场会得到某种形式的退款。镇上可以将另一半用于图书馆、新的少儿棒球场或其他任何需要的地方。有些人显得有些怀疑，因为他们还在努力理解这个困扰他们已久的问题或许真的有切实可行的解决方案。他们似乎在寻找方案中的漏洞，却惊讶地发现竟然没有任何漏洞。

The up-front guarantee of $100,000 addressed the concerns of even the most pessimistic opponents. In turn, the landfill operator was relieved to see that his exposure would be capped in the worst-case scenario and likely be much lower in the best. After all, the town would now have an incentive to control cleanup costs in order to enjoy a year-end bonus. As for the neighbors, after thinking about it, they actually liked that the landfill could earn back some of its money. Dangling that carrot could make it more careful about keeping trash from blowing off the site in the first place.

预先支付的10万美元保证金打消了最悲观的反对者的疑虑。反过来，垃圾填埋场运营商也松了一口气，因为这意味着即使在最坏的情况下，他们的损失也会被限制在一定范围内，而在最好的情况下，损失可能会更低。毕竟，现在镇政府有动力控制清理成本，以便获得年终奖金。至于邻居们，仔细考虑之后，他们其实也乐见垃圾填埋场能够收回一些成本。这笔诱饵或许能促使他们更加谨慎地防止垃圾被风吹离场地。

It was a simple and elegant solution, one that addressed past problems and created incentives for joint value creation going forward. The only regret was that someone hadn’t thought of it earlier. Maybe things had to get bad before they got better. Maybe people would listen only to an outsider with no local political baggage. But often we can’t count on a mediator riding in to solve our negotiation problems. Instead, we have to rely on our own creative vision and the capacity to explain it so that it is accepted.

这是一个简洁而巧妙的解决方案，它既解决了过去的问题，又激励了未来共同创造价值。唯一的遗憾是，为什么之前没有人想到过。或许事情必须先恶化才能好转。或许人们只会听取一个没有当地政治包袱的局外人的意见。但很多时候，我们不能指望调解人突然出现来解决我们的谈判难题。相反，我们必须依靠自身的创造性思维，以及将其清晰阐述并被他人接受的能力。

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Trade on differences to generate value.

■ 利用差异创造价值。

■ Be creative about process as well as substance.

■ 在过程和内容上都要有创意。

■ To open up your imagination, step back and see what you’d suggest to someone else in your situation.

■ 为了打开你的想象力，退后一步，想想如果你是处在你的位置，你会给别人提什么建议。

■ Think analogically. How does the problem at hand compare and contrast with other situations that you’ve resolved?

■ 运用类比思维。当前的问题与你曾经解决过的其他情况有何异同？

■ Expand your mental library of creative solutions.

■ 拓展你的创意解决方案知识库。

#↩

[ 12 ] Wicked Learning

[ 12 ] 邪恶学习

Margaret pushed the Down button a third time.

玛格丽特第三次按下了向下键。

“Go ahead,” said Richard with a sweep of his hand. “After you.” Margaret looked up, half startled that the elevator was already there. She was too deep in her own thoughts to be embarrassed. “Yes,” she said absently.

“请便，”理查德挥了挥手，“你先请。”玛格丽特抬起头，有些惊讶地发现电梯已经到了。她正沉浸在自己的思绪中，无暇顾及尴尬。“好的，”她心不在焉地应了一声。

This was the first time that Margaret and Richard had met, and those were the only words they spoke. This would also be the last time their paths ever crossed. Yet at that particular moment, their fates were intertwined.

这是玛格丽特和理查德的初次见面，也是他们唯一说的话。这也将是他们人生中最后一次交汇。然而就在那一刻，他们的命运却紧紧相连。

Unbeknownst to them, Richard and Margaret had been competing against each other for a lucrative contract with ComTX, a major telecommunications company. Each had survived a review process in which dozens of proposals had been winnowed down to two finalists. They each had worked nonstop this past week, trying to negotiate a winning deal.

理查德和玛格丽特浑然不知，他们一直在竞标一家大型电信公司ComTX的一份利润丰厚的合同。两人都从数十份提案中脱颖而出，经过层层筛选，最终只剩下他们两人。过去一周，他们都马不停蹄地工作，试图达成一项有利的协议。

And here they were, strangers bumping into each other late on a Friday afternoon, having just left different offices on the forty-fourth floor of ComTX’s imposing Midtown tower. One of them had just signed a contract with the communications giant. The other had been thanked politely by a company official but told that another bidder had been selected for the project.

就这样，两个素不相识的人在周五下午的傍晚，在ComTX位于曼哈顿中城的宏伟大厦44层的不同办公室里偶然相遇。其中一人刚刚与这家通信巨头签订了一份合同。另一人则被公司一位官员礼貌地道谢，但被告知该项目已选定了其他竞标者。

Richard rocked back and forth on the balls of his feet, a grin spreading across his face, as the elevator began its descent. He could feel his tension drain. It was all he could do to keep from whistling. Glancing over at Margaret, he was tempted to ask, “Is everything okay?”

电梯开始下降，理查德踮着脚尖前后摇晃着身体，脸上露出笑容。他感到紧张感逐渐消散。他竭力克制住自己，才没吹口哨。他瞥了一眼玛格丽特，很想问：“一切都好吗？”

Her brow was furrowed, and she was shaking her head no, as if she were lost in a difficult internal conversation. Margaret took a deep breath, but that didn’t seem to do much good. She was consumed by anxiety and self-doubt.

她眉头紧锁，不停地摇头，仿佛陷入了一场艰难的内心对话。玛格丽特深吸了一口气，但这似乎并没有什么用。她被焦虑和自我怀疑彻底吞噬了。

How, then, is it that Margaret carried the signed contract in her briefcase, while Richard had just been told that his deal was dead?

那么，为什么玛格丽特的公文包里装着签好的合同，而理查德却刚刚被告知他的交易告吹了呢？

LEARNING FROM EXPERIENCE

从经验中学习

What constitutes success in negotiation? And, for that matter, what is failure?

谈判成功的标准是什么？而失败的标准又是什么？

This story is a parable, though it’s surely been enacted countless times in the real world. (All the other examples in this book are based on actual negotiations.) Here Richard walked away empty-handed, yet his spirits were buoyant. He had fought the good fight, he told himself. Time after time, when negotiations with ComTX seemed to be at a dead end, he had found a creative way to keep the dialogue going. Sometimes that meant tweaking his proposal in response to what he’d learned about the client’s priorities. At another point, he encouraged someone across the table to become a de facto champion of his bid.

这个故事是个寓言，尽管它在现实世界中肯定已经上演过无数次。（本书中的其他所有例子都基于真实的谈判。）理查德最终空手而归，但他精神抖擞。他告诉自己，他已经尽力了。一次又一次，当与ComTX的谈判似乎陷入僵局时，他总能找到创造性的方法来维持对话。有时，这意味着根据他对客户优先事项的了解来调整自己的方案。还有一次，他鼓励谈判桌对面的人成为他投标的实际支持者。

Richard was pleased, in fact, that his proposal had gotten as far as it did. He was confident of his own abilities and those of the team he had assembled, yet this project had always been a stretch. Together they had worked hard on the plan, though their principal goal was getting their name out. Even if they had little prospect of winning the contract, they knew they’d learn a lot just by going through the process. Richard and his colleagues were a bit surprised that they survived the first cut. Later, when told they were one of two finalists, they were astonished.

事实上，理查德对自己的提案能走到这一步感到很满意。他对自己和团队的能力都很有信心，但这个项目对他来说始终是个挑战。他们一起努力制定计划，尽管他们的主要目标是提升知名度。即使中标的希望渺茫，他们也知道，即使只是经历这个过程，也能学到很多东西。理查德和他的同事们对能够通过第一轮筛选感到有些意外。后来，当他们得知自己是最终入围的两名候选人之一时，更是震惊不已。

As implausible as winning had first seemed, some of Richard’s partners started to believe that they’d be selected. “Don’t count your chickens,” he warned. Their presentation was strong, but his new team didn’t have much of a track record. And the truth was, he was a bit superstitious, too. The surest way to jinx the deal would be to assume that it was all locked up.

尽管一开始获胜似乎不太可能，但理查德的一些合伙人开始相信他们会被选中。“别高兴得太早，”他警告说。他们的方案确实不错，但他的新团队并没有太多成功经验。而且说实话，他自己也有点迷信。最容易搞砸这笔交易的方法就是认定一切都已成定局。

Maybe Richard even knew ComTX better than it knew itself. The company would be tempted by his team’s innovative approach, yet in the end, its conservative bureaucracy would feel safer going with a more established outfit. He was the runner-up, the silver medalist, but in his mind, there was little chance his bid would triumph.

或许理查德比ComTX自己更了解它。公司会被他团队的创新理念所吸引，但最终，保守的官僚作风还是会觉得选择一家更成熟的公司更稳妥。他是亚军，是银牌得主，但在他看来，他的竞标成功的可能性微乎其微。
