That’s not to say he didn’t try. On the contrary. If Richard was at peace with himself on the elevator, it was because he knew that he had done his best. He had been patient, inventive, and, yes, forceful, too, when necessary. Perhaps Richard could have clinched the deal if he had conceded on each and every point, but there were certain principles he didn’t want to compromise.

这并非说他没有努力。恰恰相反。如果理查德在电梯里感到心安，那是因为他知道自己已经尽力了。他耐心、足智多谋，而且，必要时也展现出了强硬的一面。或许，如果理查德在每个方面都做出让步，他就能拿下这笔交易，但他有一些原则不愿妥协。

For instance, he might have snared the contract with ComTX had he been willing to cut costs by squeezing out one of his teammates, but that just didn’t sit right with him. Forging a business relationship with ComTX would have been great, but not if that meant swallowing a financial loss or rupturing a relationship. It wasn’t as if Richard hadn’t gained anything. He had established important contacts and had learned a lot about a promising new market. Already he had ideas for potential projects that were closer to his expertise and might better meet ComTX’s needs.

例如，如果他愿意通过排挤一位队友来削减成本，他或许就能拿下与ComTX的合同，但他觉得这样做不太妥当。与ComTX建立业务关系固然很好，但如果这意味着蒙受经济损失或破坏合作关系，那就得不偿失了。并非理查德一无所获。他建立了重要的人脉，并对一个充满潜力的新市场有了深入的了解。他已经有一些想法，可以开展更符合自身专长、或许更能满足ComTX需求的潜在项目。

“Give it a rest,” Richard told himself. This would be the first weekend in more than a month that he wouldn’t be working the phone or redrafting memos. He deserved some time off. Rowing out to his vintage sloop would clear his mind. He could clean the winches, varnish the teak. Or why not go out for a long sail just the way the boat is? Leave the cosmetic work for some other time.

“休息一下吧，”理查德对自己说。这将是他一个多月以来第一个不用接电话、不用修改备忘录的周末。他理应好好放松一下。划船去他的老式单桅帆船上，可以让他彻底放松。他可以清理绞盘，给柚木上漆。或者，为什么不就让船保持原样，出海远航呢？把那些表面功夫留到以后再做吧。

As Richard was mentally casting off and hoisting the main, Margaret’s thoughts were still back in the conference room. All the ComTX people had seemed eager. Their enthusiasm was flattering, yes, but maybe their desire to nail down the deal signaled something. Were they desperate? Lots of small firms must have submitted proposals, but perhaps her chief competitors had dropped out at the last minute. Or maybe the ComTX team couldn’t agree on any other bidder. If that were the case, Margaret told herself, she should have been steadfast and held out for a better overhead rate.

当理查德在脑海中构思着解缆起航时，玛格丽特的思绪还停留在会议室里。ComTX公司的所有人都显得兴致勃勃。他们的热情固然令人受宠若惊，但他们急于拿下这笔交易或许也暗示着什么。他们是不是走投无路了？肯定有很多小公司提交了方案，但也许她的主要竞争对手在最后一刻退出了。又或许ComTX团队根本就找不到其他合适的竞标者。如果真是这样，玛格丽特心想，她当初就应该坚持立场，争取更低的管理费率。

The ComTX’s team clearly valued her work—otherwise it wouldn’t have awarded her the job—but Margaret was less convinced that she’d earned her new client’s respect as a negotiator. Sitting alone across the table from their team had been a little intimidating, particularly as the talks wore on. The numbers person would quibble about this or that, and then one of its marketing types would take the conversation in a different direction.

ComTX团队显然很重视她的工作——否则他们不会把这份工作交给她——但玛格丽特不太确定自己是否赢得了新客户作为谈判者的尊重。独自一人坐在桌子对面与他们的团队谈判让她有些紧张，尤其是在谈判进行到后期时。负责财务的会就这个那个问题斤斤计较，然后他们的市场营销人员又会把话题引向另一个方向。

ComTX’s senior vice president sat opposite Margaret with an inscrutable look on his face, not saying a word. Was this some new negotiation gambit, she wondered: good-cop, mime-cop? Did they practice their roles before each meeting? There was no way of knowing, of course, but Margaret was sure that after every session, they must have dissected everything she said and how she said it.

ComTX公司的高级副总裁坐在玛格丽特对面，脸上表情难以捉摸，一言不发。她心想，这难道是什么新的谈判策略？假扮红脸假扮警察？他们每次开会前都会排练一下吗？当然，我们无从得知，但玛格丽特确信，每次会议结束后，他们肯定都会仔细分析她说的每一句话，以及她说话的方式。

There were times she had wanted to be more aggressive—to say no forcefully—but she had bitten her tongue. As the only woman in the room, she feared that being tough might come off as being bitchy. Her younger brother could always be a wise guy, quick with a smart comment or put-down, and get away with it. But growing up, she had learned that if she said the same thing, she was accused of having an attitude. At the playground and in a business meeting, there was one code for men and another for women.

她有时也想更强硬一些——想果断地说“不”——但她最终还是忍住了。作为房间里唯一的女性，她害怕强硬会被人误解为刻薄。她的弟弟总是能耍些小聪明，妙语连珠，而且总能让人信服。但她从小就明白，如果她说同样的话，就会被指责态度不好。无论是在操场上还是在商务会议上，男女之间有着不同的规则。

“Stop obsessing,” she told herself as the elevator descended. “What’s done is done.” But now her mind turned to the hard work ahead. She’d have to make copies of the signed contract and lead her partners through what it meant, line by line. Margaret knew that she’d have some selling to do. She had promised ComTX a lot, including an ambitious delivery date. She and her colleagues would have to scramble to pull together all the pieces. Margaret expected one person in particular to be critical of commitments she had made on their behalf. “I’m not necessarily disagreeing with the terms,” Anne in marketing would say, “but I’m not very happy with the process.”

“别再纠结了，”电梯下降时，她对自己说，“事情已经发生了。”但现在，她的思绪又回到了即将到来的艰巨工作上。她得复印已签署的合同，然后逐条向合伙人解释合同内容。玛格丽特知道，她需要费一番口舌才能说服他们。她向ComTX公司承诺了很多，包括一个雄心勃勃的交付日期。她和同事们必须争分夺秒地把所有环节都整合起来。玛格丽特预料到，肯定会有一个人对她代表他们做出的承诺提出批评。“我倒不是反对这些条款，”市场部的安妮可能会说，“但我对整个流程不太满意。”

Margaret had tried to keep everyone informed, but she was the one who had to make the hard decisions. Now, of course, she’d have to listen to her colleagues tell her how they would have done things differently. The reward for negotiating the ComTX deal, she thought ruefully, was now having to negotiate with her own people to make it happen. With so much left to do, she probably should cancel dinner with her friend Kim tonight.

玛格丽特一直努力让每个人都了解情况，但最终做艰难决定的还是她自己。现在，她当然得听同事们说说他们会如何以不同的方式处理这件事。她懊恼地想，自己谈判达成ComTX交易的回报，竟然是现在要和自己的人谈判才能促成此事。还有那么多事要做，她或许应该取消今晚和朋友金的晚餐。

MAXIMIZERS AND SATISFICERS

完美主义者和满意主义者

Who would you rather be, Margaret or Richard?

你更想成为玛格丽特还是理查德？

That’s not an easy choice. If Margaret is tied up in knots, she’s also the one who got the contract. Richard may be mellow, but serenity doesn’t pay the rent. He’s walking out without a deal, after all. It would be bliss to have it both ways, of course—triumphing at the bargaining table while maintaining peace of mind—but it may be that Margaret’s temperament gave her an advantage over Richard.

这并非易事。玛格丽特虽然焦头烂额，但她毕竟是拿到合同的人。理查德或许性情温和，但平静并不能解决实际问题。毕竟，他最终还是空手而归。当然，如果能两全其美就好了——既能在谈判桌上胜出，又能保持内心的平静——但或许玛格丽特的性情反而让她比理查德更有优势。

Back in the “Prospecting” chapter, I mentioned psychologist Barry Schwartz, who adapted a short test that distinguishes people whom he calls maximizers from others who are satisficers. You can find the test in his stimulating book The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less . Maximizers fret over every decision. At a restaurant, they scrutinize the menu from top to bottom and then back again, weighing the appeal of each item. Even after giving the waiter their order, they wonder if they should have asked for something else. By contrast, satisficers just take a quick glance at the offerings, spot something they like, order it, and don’t worry about it further.

在“寻找潜在客户”那一章里，我提到过心理学家巴里·施瓦茨，他改编了一个简短的测试，用来区分他称之为“最大化者”和“满足者”的人。你可以在他那本引人入胜的著作《选择的悖论：为什么越多越少》中找到这个测试。最大化者会为每一个决定而焦虑。在餐厅里，他们会从头到尾仔细研究菜单，然后再从头到尾读一遍，权衡每道菜的吸引力。即使已经点完菜了，他们仍然会想自己是不是应该再点点别的。相比之下，满足者只是快速浏览一下菜单，看到喜欢的就点，然后就不再纠结了。

Margaret is a poster child for the first category, while Richard probably falls into the second. What’s interesting, though, is that these differences are more than mere personality quirks. How people feel about choices—specifically, how much they agonize over them—significantly influences what they achieve in negotiation. As mentioned earlier, there was a catch: maximizers are less happy with what they get.

玛格丽特是第一类人的典型代表，而理查德则可能属于第二类。不过，有趣的是，这些差异不仅仅是性格上的怪癖。人们对选择的感受——特别是他们为此纠结的程度——会显著影响他们在谈判中取得的成果。正如前文所述，这里有个问题：追求极致的人往往对最终的结果不太满意。

For Margaret, success and discontent may go hand in hand. All that brooding can’t be fun, but her relentless self-criticism may have yielded insights that eluded Richard. She doesn’t take things at face value. She always wonders what she has overlooked or misread. Those traits left her feeling less happy but may have impelled her to look harder—both at the situation and at herself. She worries about the right things too. After all, it is possible that she left value on the table. And she’s right in recognizing how social norms affect what a woman can say and do in negotiation (and elsewhere). She thinks hard about the substantive issues and how she relates to others.

对玛格丽特来说，成功与不满或许如影随形。长时间的沉思肯定不好受，但她不懈的自我批评或许让她获得了理查德未能领悟的洞见。她不会轻易相信表面现象，总是反思自己是否忽略或误读了什么。这些特质让她感到不那么快乐，但也促使她更加深入地审视自身——既审视所处的环境，也审视自己。她关注的也都是真正重要的事情。毕竟，她有可能错失了一些机会。而且，她敏锐地意识到社会规范如何影响女性在谈判（以及其他场合）中的言行，这一点也无可厚非。她认真思考实质性问题以及自己与他人的关系。

And what should we make of Richard? If an optimist is someone who sees the glass as half full, Richard looks like a guy who has just been handed an empty glass but somehow convinces himself that he isn’t really thirsty. He recognizes that negotiation is a learning experience, yet did he grasp the right lessons?

那么我们应该如何看待理查德呢？如果乐观主义者总是看到杯子半满，那么理查德看起来就像一个刚拿到空杯子却自欺欺人地认为自己并不渴的人。他意识到谈判是一次学习经历，但他真的吸取了正确的教训吗？

Richard has no regrets, but he may have been blind to opportunities to save the deal. For all he really knows, he may have been oblivious to signals that ComTX was sending. We just can’t know whether he was astute, obtuse, or somewhere in between—and neither can he. His positive spin may be exactly right. Then again, it might be only rationalization and self-delusion, exhibit A in a text on cognitive dissonance. If Margaret takes self-criticism to the extreme, perhaps Richard could use more of that trait.

理查德并不后悔，但他或许对挽救这笔交易的机会视而不见。就他自己而言，他可能根本没注意到ComTX发出的信号。我们无从得知他是精明、迟钝，还是介于两者之间——他自己也无从知晓。他乐观的解释或许完全正确。但话说回来，这也可能只是自我安慰和自欺欺人，正如认知失调理论中的典型例子。如果玛格丽特的自我批评到了极致，或许理查德可以借鉴一下这种特质。

THE FEEDBACK PROBLEM

反馈问题

It’s devilishly hard to judge success in negotiation. You may love an agreement you reach or feel lukewarm about it, but either way, results themselves are an imperfect test of how well you’ve done.

谈判的成功与否很难评判。你或许对达成的协议非常满意，或许感觉平平，但无论如何，结果本身并不能完美地检验你的谈判表现。

Let’s say that you just bought a car at the price you hoped. Isn’t that success? Yes, in a sense, but the fact that you achieved your goal doesn’t tell you whether with a little more persistence you could have kept another $600 or $700 in your pocket. Maybe your aspirations weren’t high enough. Then again, another time you might be disappointed that you paid more than expected. Is that failure? Maybe not, if the seller wouldn’t have gone a penny lower. The true, substantive test of negotiation success, then, is how well you do in light of what is possible. The problem, though, is that you never know what the other party might have accepted.

假设你刚以理想的价格买到了一辆车。这难道不是成功吗？某种程度上来说，的确如此。但达成目标并不能告诉你，如果再坚持一下，你是否还能省下600或700美元。也许你的期望值不够高。当然，有时候你也可能因为支付的价格高于预期而感到失望。这算是失败吗？如果卖家一分钱都不肯降，也许不算。因此，衡量谈判成功的真正标准在于，在各种可能性范围内，你的谈判表现如何。然而，问题在于，你永远无法预知对方的底线。

Throughout this book, we’ve seen how a shroud of fog obscures the negotiation landscape. Even after a deal is done, it presents a serious challenge to effective learning. Were you smart last time or merely lucky? Robin Hogarth, author of Educating Intuition , contrasts what he calls kind and wicked learning environments. A kind environment provides quick and accurate feedback on your actions. It shows you what works and what does not, so that you learn easily from experience and make adjustments.

本书通篇都在探讨谈判格局如何被迷雾笼罩。即便达成交易，它也对有效学习构成严峻挑战。你上次是靠智慧取胜，还是仅仅靠运气？《培养直觉》一书的作者罗宾·霍加斯对比了他所谓的“良性”和“恶性”学习环境。良性环境能够快速准确地反馈你的行动，让你了解哪些方法有效，哪些无效，从而轻松地从经验中学习并做出调整。

Imagine a basketball player practicing free throws at the foul line. If the ball goes in smoothly, he should keep on doing what he just did. And if it clanks off the rim, he should experiment—maybe next time trying more knee bend or more arc on the ball. Through trial and error, he’ll get reliable feedback: the ball either goes in or it doesn’t. He can learn and improve.

想象一下，一个篮球运动员在罚球线练习罚球。如果球顺利入网，他就应该继续保持刚才的动作。如果球砸在篮筐上，他就应该尝试一些新的方法——比如下次可以尝试更大的膝盖弯曲角度或者更大的投篮弧线。通过反复尝试，他就能获得可靠的反馈：球要么进，要么不进。他可以从中学习并不断进步。

Negotiation, on the other hand, is a quintessentially wicked learning environment. If you’re not careful, it can teach the wrong lessons. Let’s say that you’ve worked hard to close an important deal but ultimately were stalemated. What should you conclude?

另一方面，谈判则是一个极其棘手的学习环境。如果不谨慎，它可能会教给你错误的教训。假设你费尽心力促成了一笔重要的交易，但最终却陷入僵局。你应该得出什么结论呢？

There are lots of plausible explanations. Maybe you were deadlocked because there just wasn’t any room for agreement. Perhaps you overplayed your hand, expecting the other side to buckle when it wouldn’t. (Or maybe your counterparts misread your resolve.) Or it could have been a failure of creative insight on everyone’s part. Perhaps a lack of trust may have been the obstacle. Behind-the-scenes stakeholders may have scuttled the deal. Any and all of those factors could have been in play. You might have caused the impasse or had nothing to do with it.

有很多合理的解释。也许你们陷入僵局是因为根本没有达成共识的余地。也许你用力过猛，指望对方屈服，结果却并非如此。（或者你的对手误判了你的决心。）也可能是双方都缺乏创造性的洞察力。或许缺乏信任才是障碍。幕后利益相关者可能从中作梗，破坏了交易。所有这些因素都可能起作用。僵局可能是你造成的，也可能与你无关。

Explaining success is just as dicey. If we make a great deal, we like to think that it was due to our virtue, charm, and intelligence. In truth, though, it may simply be that we were in the right place at the right time.

解释成功同样棘手。如果我们做成了一笔大生意，我们喜欢认为这是因为我们自身品德高尚、魅力非凡、才智过人。但事实上，这可能仅仅是因为我们恰好出现在了正确的时间和地点。

How, then, can you tap your experience and improve as a negotiator if you can’t know for sure why you’ve succeeded in some cases and failed in others? Three precepts can sharpen your learning:

那么，如果你无法确切地知道自己为什么在某些谈判中成功，而在另一些谈判中失败，又该如何利用经验来提升谈判技巧呢？以下三条原则可以帮助你更好地学习：

1. Beware of mislearning. Admitting that you don’t know is better than operating from an erroneous conclusion.

1. 谨防误学。承认自己不懂总比基于错误结论行事要好。

2. Don’t confuse satisfaction with success.

2. 不要把满足感和成功混为一谈。

3. Remember: it’s not all about you.

3.记住：这不仅仅是关于你的事。

It’s natural to congratulate yourself when you succeed and second-guess your setbacks. Letting go of such judgments isn’t easy. But acknowledging uncertainty is far better than clinging to—and acting upon—mistaken assumptions. The most important thing is to avoid mislearning. Just because you were stalemated in a case where you held your ground on an important issue doesn’t necessarily mean that you should be more accommodating the next time around. The other side may have been responsible for the deadlock.

成功时自我祝贺，失败时自我怀疑，这都是人之常情。放下这些评判并不容易。但承认不确定性远胜于执着于错误的假设并据此行事。最重要的是避免误学。仅仅因为你在某个重要问题上坚持立场却陷入僵局，并不意味着下次就应该更加妥协。僵局的根源或许在于对方。

Self-assessments must be provisional, since the information on which they are based is necessarily incomplete. People learn from what they see, but not necessarily from what they don’t see. The fog of negotiation can’t be wished away, but you can guard yourself against being overconfident about what you discern.

自我评估必须是暂时的，因为其所依据的信息必然是不完整的。人们从所见所闻中学习，但未必能从所不见之事中学习。谈判中的迷雾无法被消除，但你可以避免对自己的判断过于自信。

A while back, it was time to replace my car, so I returned to a dealership I’d done business with for years. My old salesman had retired, so that evening I found myself talking with his tiresome replacement. He ran through a whole gamut of pressure tactics. If it hadn’t been so late and I wasn’t busy, it would have been entertaining, but I just wanted to buy a car and get on with my life.

前段时间，我的车该换了，于是我又去了一家我光顾多年的车行。我的老销售员退休了，所以那天晚上我跟他那个烦人的接班人聊了起来。他使出了一连串的推销手段。要不是时间太晚，我又不忙，这倒也挺有意思的，但我当时只想赶紧买辆车，好继续过我的生活。

We haggled down to a decent price, but I was so turned off, I said, “Let me think about it. I’ll call you in the morning.” At that moment, I just didn’t want to reward the salesman’s behavior. He glared at me and said, “Someone else could snap it up.” It was 8:27, and the showroom was closing in three minutes. “I’ll take my chances,” I replied, but I don’t think he caught my sarcasm.

我们讨价还价，最终成交价还算可以接受，但我实在提不起兴趣，便说：“我考虑一下，明天早上再给你打电话。” 当时，我实在不想助长销售员的这种行为。他瞪了我一眼，说：“说不定别人就买走了。” 当时是8点27分，展厅还有三分钟就要关门了。“我愿意碰碰运气，”我回答道，但我觉得他没听出我的讽刺。

I was planning to call back the next morning and do the deal, either at a little better price or at his number, if need be. But driving home, I mulled over how unpleasant the guy had been. Yes, I liked the car, and yes, the price was acceptable, but the more I thought about it, the less I wanted to do business with him. The next day, I bought the same model elsewhere for the same money. I haven’t been back to my old dealership since.

我原本打算第二天早上再打电话过去谈这笔交易，要么稍微降价，要么就按他之前的电话号码打。但开车回家的路上，我一直在想那个人有多不友好。没错，我喜欢那辆车，价格也合适，但我想得越多，就越不想跟他做生意。第二天，我在别的地方以同样的价钱买了同一款车。从那以后，我就再也没去过那家经销商。

What did this salesman learn from that experience?

这位销售员从那次经历中学到了什么？

My guess is, nothing. Instead, he remembers other times that his pressure tactics seemed to work with customers who paid a fat premium over his bottom line. Yet there’s nothing in his feedback system that teaches him about all the deals that he has lost with people like me. To him, I may have looked like just another tire kicker, not somebody who was ready to write him a check (as I actually was). From where I sit, it’s easy to recognize his mislearning, but anyone can fall into that trap.

我的猜测是，他什么也没学到。相反，他只会想起以前那些客户愿意支付远高于他底价的高价，而他施压的策略似乎奏效了。然而，他的反馈系统里却没有任何信息能让他意识到，像我这样的客户，他错失了多少笔生意。在他看来，我可能只是个随便看看的顾客，而不是一个准备给他开支票的人（而事实上，我的确是）。在我看来，很容易看出他的错误认知，但任何人都有可能掉进这个陷阱。

ENDS AND MEANS

目的与手段

We mislearn when we draw hard conclusions from incomplete and ambiguous evidence. We also mislearn when we confuse what we ultimately obtained in a negotiation with how we performed . As already noted, luck—good and bad—can influence what happens in the course of negotiation.

当我们根据不完整或含糊不清的证据得出武断的结论时，我们就是在误导自己。当我们把谈判中最终的结果与谈判过程中的表现混淆时，我们也是错误的。正如前文所述，运气——无论是好运还是厄运——都会影响谈判的走向。

In the movie The Verdict , a down-and-out lawyer played by Paul Newman rejects a settlement offer without even telling his clients. Instead, he takes his chances in court. That’s unethical, of course, but movies being movies, he wins dramatically thanks to a surprise witness at the end. Was he smart in refusing to negotiate or merely lucky?

在电影《大审判》中，保罗·纽曼饰演的落魄律师拒绝了和解提议，甚至没有告知他的客户。相反，他选择孤注一掷，诉诸法庭。这当然是不道德的，但电影总是如此，他最终凭借一位意想不到的证人的出现而戏剧性地胜诉。他拒绝谈判是明智之举，还是仅仅运气好？

Compare that story with a real-life case involving a blind college student who brought a medical malpractice suit. She accepted a $165,000 settlement, against the advice of her lawyer and family, while the jury was in its third hour of deliberations. It was on the verge of awarding her $900,000. Some of its members burst into tears when they learned that the settlement had rendered their verdict moot. Did the student make a grave mistake?

不妨将这个故事与一个真实的案例进行比较：一位失明的女大学生提起医疗事故诉讼。在陪审团审议的第三个小时，她不顾律师和家人的劝阻，接受了16.5万美元的和解金。当时陪审团几乎就要判给她90万美元的赔偿。当得知和解协议使之前的判决失去意义时，一些陪审员当场落泪。这位女大学生犯了一个严重的错误吗？

It might seem that way, but she was philosophical. “I think I made a wise decision,” she explained. “Everybody said, ‘You’ve got it won.’ But I wasn’t sure. They [the insurance company] said they definitely would have appealed and there’s a chance I would have lost it all.” The only practical test of the wisdom of an agreement depends on what was known and knowable at the time it was made. Subsequent events over which you have no control may make it look better or worse. At first we may love the house we bought and be pleased that we got it at a great price. A year later, when a guy who raises pit bulls moves in next door, we may wish that we had blown it. As the carnival barker says, you place your bet and take your chances.

或许看起来是这样，但她却很豁达。“我觉得我做了个明智的决定，”她解释道。“大家都说，‘你赢定了。’但我并不确定。保险公司说他们肯定会上诉，而且我很有可能会损失全部赔偿。” 检验一项协议是否明智的唯一实际标准，取决于协议签订时已知和可知的情况。之后发生的一些你无法控制的事件，可能会让协议看起来更好，也可能让协议看起来更糟。起初，我们可能很喜欢买的房子，也为能以优惠的价格买到它而感到高兴。一年后，当一个养比特犬的人搬到隔壁时，我们可能就会后悔当初没买。正如马戏团的叫卖者所说，你下了赌注，就得承担风险。

Even when circumstances turn out as we’d hoped, things we worked hard to get in negotiation can look different after we win them. Dan Gilbert, author of Stumbling on Happiness , has found that most of us aren’t that good at predicting how we’ll feel in the future. We know that positive things will make us happy and that negative ones will make us sad, of course, but we tend to overestimate both the magnitude and duration of our future feelings. We can be similarly myopic when we negotiate. Whatever satisfaction Margaret felt at signing the ComTX deal gave way to regret even as she was leaving the building.

即使事与愿违，我们辛辛苦苦谈判争取来的东西，在最终达成之后，其意义也可能截然不同。丹·吉尔伯特（Dan Gilbert）在其著作《撞上幸福》（Stumbling on Happiness）中发现，我们大多数人并不擅长预测未来的感受。我们当然知道，积极的事情会让我们快乐，消极的事情会让我们悲伤，但我们往往会高估未来感受的强度和持续时间。在谈判中，我们也可能犯类似的短视。玛格丽特在签署ComTX协议时所感受到的满足感，在她离开大楼的那一刻就被后悔所取代。

It’s healthy to remember that whatever you’re seeking to achieve (or avoid) during negotiation may not matter as much to you in the future. That’s not invariably true, of course, but the anxiety you feel in the moment often abates—and likewise for exuberance. If you keep that in mind, short-term and long-term considerations may come into sharper focus. The same attitude is important when you look back and try to draw lessons from past experience. You should ask yourself whether certain things you tend to fight for have lasting value. The pleasure of winning small ego battles may be fleeting.

记住这一点很重要：你在谈判中试图达成（或避免）的目标，未来可能对你来说不再那么重要。当然，这并非绝对如此，但你当下感受到的焦虑通常会消退——热情也是如此。如果你能牢记这一点，短期和长期的考量就会更加清晰。当你回顾过去，试图从经验中吸取教训时，这种态度同样重要。你应该扪心自问，你坚持争取的某些东西是否具有长远的价值。赢得一些无关痛痒的小小胜利所带来的快感，或许转瞬即逝。

ONE HAND CLAPPING?

单手鼓掌？

To learn from experience, we need a wide-angle lens. Too often we zoom in on details and miss the bigger picture. I see this tendency a lot in my MBA and executive education courses. When students do simulations, paired up as a buyer and a seller, every person is eager to see how he or she did. Results typically vary widely. Some people sell high, while others buy low, even though everyone was working with the same information. When we dig into analysis, most students tell self-centered stories. Those who snatched up bargains think it was all their own doing. Others who paid more than necessary beat themselves up for making stupid mistakes.

要想从经验中学习，我们需要广角镜头。我们常常过于关注细节，而忽略了全局。我在MBA和高管培训课程中经常看到这种倾向。当学生们进行模拟交易，两人一组扮演买家和卖家时，每个人都急于知道自己的表现如何。结果往往千差万别。有些人高价卖出，有些人低价买入，即使每个人都掌握着相同的信息。当我们深入分析时，大多数学生讲述的都是以自我为中心的故事。那些抢到便宜货的人认为这完全是他们自己的功劳。而那些支付了过高价格的人则自责自己犯了愚蠢的错误。

Self-centered comments miss the point, however. Wherever a student ends up is driven as much by what his counterpart did as by his own actions. After all, for every buyer scrutinizing an outcome for clues about what he did right or wrong, there is a seller trying to figure out the same thing for himself.

然而，以自我为中心的评论却不得要领。学生的最终成绩，与其自身努力相比，很大程度上取决于竞争对手的表现。毕竟，正如买家会仔细审视结果，从中寻找自己做对或做错的线索一样，卖家也会试图从中找出同样的问题。

Negotiation is never about us alone. What ultimately unfolds is a function of each party’s attitudes and decisions, not just our own. Asking ourselves, “How did I do?” is the wrong question. It’s a one-hand-clapping exercise. Instead, our starting point should be, where did we end up and how did we get there?

谈判从来都不是只关乎我们自身的问题。最终的结果取决于各方的态度和决策，而不仅仅是我们自己的。问自己“我做得怎么样？”是错误的问题，这无异于自鸣得意。相反，我们应该从以下问题出发：我们最终达成了什么结果？我们是如何走到这一步的？

Posing the question that way focuses attention on how you interacted with your counterpart. It leads you to review more closely how the process unfolded at each stage of the process:

这样提出问题能让你更关注与对方的互动方式，引导你更仔细地回顾流程每个阶段的进展情况：

• Recall how you and your counterpart engaged each other when the negotiation began. Was the opening friendly, hostile, or someplace in between? How did the both of you frame the task ahead?

• 回想一下谈判开始时你和对方是如何互动的。开场白是友好的、敌对的，还是介于两者之间？你们双方是如何看待即将面临的任务的？

• Likewise for critical moments. Were there transition points where the process could have taken a sharp turn? Were these rifts or breakthroughs? What provoked them, and how were they handled?

• 同样，对于关键时刻也是如此。是否存在一些转折点，导致进程发生急剧转变？这些是裂痕还是突破？是什么引发了这些转变，又是如何应对的？

• Finally, what brought the negotiation to a close? Is this what you anticipated? If not, could you have planned for it?

• 最后，是什么导致谈判破裂？这是否符合你的预期？如果不是，你是否可以提前做好规划？

It’s a matter of dispassionately reconstructing—not judging—what took place. You will do a better job and learn more if you’ve taken notes along the way. Only after getting the facts down should you turn to evaluating your performance.

关键在于冷静客观地重构——而非评判——所发生的事情。如果你在过程中做好笔记，就能做得更好，学到更多。只有在掌握了事实之后，才能着手评估自己的表现。

Some of my Program on Negotiation colleagues employ the acronyms WWW and WWYDD as debriefing reminders. The first one stands for what worked well. If you handled a prickly exchange deftly or came up with a clever solution, keep those techniques in mind for your next negotiation. Just as important, identify what allowed you to respond effectively. Perhaps it was good preparation, the right kind of emotional balance, or some combination of the two. Building that foundation for future negotiations will help you handle other challenges.

我的一些谈判项目同事会用 WWW 和 WWYDD 这两个缩写词来提醒自己谈判后的工作进展。WWW 代表“哪些方面做得好”。如果你巧妙地处理了棘手的交锋，或者想出了一个巧妙的解决方案，请记住这些技巧，以便在下次谈判中运用。同样重要的是，要找出是什么让你能够有效应对。也许是充分的准备，也许是恰到好处的情绪控制，或者两者兼而有之。为未来的谈判打下坚实的基础，将有助于你应对其他挑战。

WWYDD is short for what would you do differently. This is an important question, whether you feel snookered or successful. Margaret got halfway there in her ruminating. She worried about the right things, but she should take the further step of playing out what would have happened if she had acted differently. Not being as flippant as her wise-guy brother was smart, but negotiating solo against a formidable team may have been a mistake. Having another set of eyes and ears at the table would have allowed her to calibrate her own impressions.

WWYDD是What Would You Do Different（你会怎么做）的缩写。无论你感觉自己是失败还是成功，这都是一个重要的问题。玛格丽特的思考已经完成了一半。她担心的事情没错，但她应该更进一步，设想一下如果她采取不同的行动会发生什么。不像她那自作聪明的哥哥那样轻率固然明智，但独自一人对抗一支强大的团队或许是个错误。如果谈判桌上有其他人在场，她就能更好地审视自己的判断。

Don’t forget to similarly assess the person you just faced. You probably saw her up close. What did she do well, and what might she have done better? Consider the underlying factors that might explain her attitude and behavior, starting with her perceptions of you. And if you feel that you didn’t get a good outcome, there might be consolation in regarding the experience as an instructive demonstration of what effective negotiation entails.

别忘了同样地评估一下你刚才面对的那个人。你可能近距离观察过她。她哪些方面做得好？哪些方面可以做得更好？思考一下可能解释她态度和行为的潜在因素，首先要考虑她对你的看法。如果你觉得结果并不理想，不妨把这次经历看作是一次有益的谈判实践，从中学习有效的谈判技巧。

You can do this reflection on your own or as part of a team, if you were negotiating on behalf of your company or organization. People recognize the importance of preparing seriously for negotiation but too often neglect to analyze their experience afterward. It’s a lost opportunity for organizations and individuals alike. “After-action reviews” are a matter of course in the military; they should be common practice in negotiation as well.

你可以独自进行反思，也可以作为团队成员进行反思，尤其是在你代表公司或组织进行谈判时。人们认识到认真准备谈判的重要性，但却常常忽略了事后分析谈判经验。这对组织和个人来说都是一次错失良机。“事后回顾”在军队中是惯例；它也应该成为谈判中的常规做法。

Think about the car dealership I no longer patronize. Its salesman not only blew that particular deal but also cost the company a longtime customer. And if ComTX didn’t debrief after negotiating with Richard and Margaret, it certainly should have. The potential benefits for companies that take a systemic approach to their negotiations are huge, especially if it helps them identify their best negotiators and develop the skills of others. Built to Win: Creating a World-Class Negotiating Organization by Hal Movius and Larry Susskind lays out a practical blueprint for enhancing corporate negotiation competence.

想想我不再光顾的那家汽车经销店。他们的销售员不仅搞砸了那笔交易，还让公司失去了一位老客户。如果ComTX在与Richard和Margaret谈判后没有进行总结，那他们绝对应该这样做。对于那些采用系统性方法进行谈判的公司来说，潜在的收益是巨大的，尤其当这种方法能够帮助他们识别出最优秀的谈判者并提升其他谈判者的技能时。《制胜之道：打造世界一流的谈判组织》（Built to Win: Creating a World-Class Negotiating Organization）一书由Hal Movius和Larry Susskind合著，为提升企业谈判能力提供了一套切实可行的方案。

I recommend as a further step, conducting an annual review of your negotiation fitness. You likely undergo a regular physical from your doctor, after all. If you’re lucky enough to have a nest egg, you check on your investments with your financial advisor. Do the same with your negotiation portfolio: see if you’re getting a healthy return on your efforts.

我建议您更进一步，每年对您的谈判能力进行一次评估。毕竟，您很可能定期进行体检。如果您有一笔积蓄，您会定期咨询财务顾问，了解您的投资情况。同样，您也应该定期评估您的谈判能力：看看您的努力是否获得了丰厚的回报。

Keep a journal documenting transactions large and small. It should include projects that you’d considered but soon dropped, as well as others that you saw all the way through to agreement. From your planning notes, you might see how you could have better allowed for surprises. You could also compute a success rate. If you reach a deal most every time, you are being awfully agreeable. Have they all panned out? You may discover that you conceded too much in deals that didn’t work. Maybe you should get more comfortable with the idea of walking away from the table. Also look for patterns. Are you better at price-driven transactions or ones where it’s possible to create joint gain? Work on your weaker suit. That’s where you’ll have the biggest upside for improvement. And look at your own behavior. If you recognize your hot buttons, you’ll be less likely to lose your composure in a heated negotiation.

记日记，记录大大小小的交易。日记里应该包括你考虑过但很快放弃的项目，以及你坚持到最后达成协议的项目。从你的计划笔记中，你或许能发现如何更好地应对突发情况。你还可以计算一下成功率。如果你几乎每次都能达成协议，说明你太容易妥协了。这些交易真的都成功了吗？你可能会发现，在那些失败的交易中，你做出了太多让步。也许你应该更坦然地接受“中途退出”的想法。同时，也要寻找规律。你更擅长以价格为导向的交易，还是更擅长那些能够创造共同利益的交易？努力提升你的弱项。这才是你提升空间最大的地方。还要审视自己的行为。如果你能意识到自己的情绪敏感点，在激烈的谈判中就更不容易失去冷静。

If need be, you can do this annual exam on your own, though that means being both player and coach. Better still, recruit a friend or colleague for this exercise. It will help you be more discerning and objective. And in returning the favor, you can learn from his or her experience as well.

如有必要，你可以独自进行这项年度评估，但这需要你既扮演球员的角色，又扮演教练的角色。更好的办法是，邀请一位朋友或同事来协助你完成这项评估。这将有助于你更敏锐地洞察问题，保持客观。同时，作为回报，你也可以从他们的经验中学习。

ARROGANCE AND HUMILITY

傲慢与谦逊

Earlier in this book, I spoke of the importance of being modest about how much we can know in negotiation and not treating assumptions as hard facts. I also stressed the need to master paradox. To be effective, negotiators must be both calm and alert, patient and proactive, creative yet fully grounded.

本书前文我曾谈到，在谈判中，我们应该保持谦逊，不要把假设当作确凿的事实。我还强调了掌握悖论的重要性。要想高效谈判，谈判者必须既冷静又警觉，既耐心又积极主动，既富有创造力又脚踏实地。

UN diplomat Lakhdar Brahimi describes another, more fundamental duality. “You need, I think, to be at the same time arrogant, because you want to solve problems that look insolvable, but you also need to be very, very humble.” Brahimi insists that these two traits aren’t contradictory. By arrogance, he means determination, the belief that something “is doable, even if everybody says it isn’t.” Just as important, however, “You need to be modest; don’t play God.”

联合国外交官拉赫达尔·卜拉希米描述了另一种更为根本的二元性。“我认为，你既需要有点傲气，因为你想解决那些看似无解的问题，但你也需要非常非常谦逊。”卜拉希米坚持认为这两种特质并不矛盾。他所说的傲气，指的是决心，即相信某件事“即使所有人都说做不到，它也是可以做到的”。然而，同样重要的是，“你需要谦逊；不要扮演上帝。”

How could it be otherwise? Nobody is omniscient. Modesty about what will occur is essential. Yet you also need the will to act notwithstanding that uncertainty. Top negotiators such as Brahimi project a certain equanimity. Their comfort with paradox arises from a basic acceptance of what is ultimately within their power and what is not. “Accept failure like it is part of the job,” Brahimi says. “And see how much luck you can have and take along with you.”

还能有什么别的结果呢？没有人是全知全能的。对未来要发生的事情保持谦逊至关重要。然而，即便存在这种不确定性，你也需要有行动的决心。像布拉希米这样的顶级谈判者展现出一种沉着冷静的气质。他们能够坦然面对矛盾，源于他们从根本上接受了哪些事情最终在他们的掌控之中，哪些事情则不然。“把失败当作工作的一部分来接受，”布拉希米说，“看看你能拥有多少运气，又能从中汲取多少力量。”

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Be a maximizer as you negotiate, but consider how your actions will impact your counterpart’s decisions.

■ 在谈判中要争取最大利益，但也要考虑你的行为将如何影响对方的决定。

■ Be a satisficer when you’re finished, content with what you’ve achieved, and focused on the next transaction.

■ 完成任务后，要让自己感到满意，对自己的成就感到满足，并专注于下一笔交易。

■ Deal or no deal, conduct an after-action review. Focus on how you prepared for and managed the negotiation. Were there surprises that you should have seen coming?

■ 无论达成协议与否，都要进行事后回顾。重点回顾你如何准备和处理谈判。是否存在你本应预料到的意外情况？

■ Review your negotiation portfolio so that you can build on your strengths and shore up any weaknesses.

■ 审视你的谈判技巧，以便发挥你的优势并弥补任何弱点。

■ Accept the luck factor in negotiation. Your results—good or bad—aren’t all of your own doing.

■ 接受谈判中的运气因素。你的结果——无论好坏——并非完全由你掌控。

#↩

[ 13 ] Fair Enough

[ 13 ] 公平合理

Every time we sit down to negotiate, we implicitly decide what we owe other parties—if anything—in regard to fairness, honesty, or the use of pressure tactics. The hardest questions aren’t about right or wrong—rather, they force us to reconcile competing rights and obligations. Often we must deal with people whose values don’t match our own.

每次坐下来谈判，我们都在潜移默化地决定自己对其他方负有哪些义务——如果有的话——这涉及到公平、诚实以及是否应该采取施压手段。最棘手的问题并非关乎对错，而是迫使我们调和相互冲突的权利和义务。我们常常不得不与价值观与我们截然不同的人打交道。

SCENARIO 1: DIVIDING THE PIE

情景一：分饼

Imagine that you’ve saved some money and are at a stage in life where you want to buy a vacation home. You’re not looking for anything fancy, just a cabin in the woods, far from the city, where you can get away and relax. The real estate market in your area is soft, so you’re hopeful that you can find something reasonably priced. After thinking carefully about your baseline, you’re prepared to pay around $200,000, though exactly how much you’ll spend will depend on the particular place and how it compares with others.

想象一下，你攒了一些钱，现在到了想买度假屋的年纪。你并不追求奢华，只是想要一个远离城市喧嚣、隐匿于森林深处的小屋，让你能够远离尘嚣，放松身心。你所在地区的房地产市场行情不佳，所以你希望能够找到价格合理的房源。经过仔细考虑，你准备支付大约20万美元，但最终的花费将取决于具体房源的情况以及它与其他房源的比较。

On recent weekends, you’ve done some prospecting, meeting with real estate agents and looking at properties. These outings were enjoyable at first, but now you’re discouraged. Everything that you’ve liked costs at least $250,000, sometimes more. Even if you negotiate well, a decent place may be beyond your budget. You may have to put this plan on hold.

最近几个周末，你都忙着找房子，跟房产经纪人见面，也看了些房。一开始感觉还不错，但现在你有点泄气了。所有你喜欢的房子都至少要25万美元，有的甚至更高。就算你砍价砍得再好，一套像样的房子可能也超出了你的预算。看来你得暂时搁置这个计划了。

But on your latest excursion, you spot a hand-painted sign, For Sale by Owner—Inquire Within. You slow down and turn into a gravel driveway. There it is: a well-maintained cabin nestled among tall pines. Off to one side is a glistening pond.

但在你最近一次的郊游中，你发现了一块手绘的牌子：业主自售——店内咨询。你放慢车速，拐进一条碎石车道。眼前赫然出现：一座维护良好的小木屋，掩映在高大的松树林中。旁边是一个波光粼粼的池塘。

The elderly owner shows you around the place. You accept her invitation to sit down for tea and listen politely to the story of how her family built the cabin almost fifty years ago. You also talk about politics, the latest books, and even sports, yet there’s been no mention of price. You’re careful about spending money, but this place is by far the best you’ve seen. Maybe you should stretch your budget.

年迈的女主人热情地带你参观了小屋。你接受了她的邀请，坐下来喝茶，并礼貌地听她讲述近五十年前她家建造这座小屋的故事。你们还聊了聊政治、新书，甚至体育，但始终没有提及价格。你花钱一向谨慎，但这地方绝对是你见过的最好的。或许你应该稍微提高一下预算。

The owner finally broaches the topic and says, “It’s always awkward to talk about money, I know, so I hope you won’t be offended if I’m asking too much.” It turns out that she is moving back to the city to be closer to her grandchildren. The cost of living is higher there, so she’ll need to get every penny that she can garner from this sale. That’s why she’s not using a broker.

房主终于开口谈及此事，说道：“我知道谈钱总是让人尴尬，所以如果我要价过高，希望您不要介意。” 原来，她要搬回城里，离孙辈们更近一些。城里的生活成本更高，所以她需要从这次卖房中尽可能多地拿到钱。这也是她没有通过经纪人的原因。

You brace yourself for a number that’s way out of your price range. But then you’re shocked when she asks only $180,000. As you know from looking at other properties, this figure is way under market value. How do you respond?

你做好了心理准备，觉得她要价肯定会远远超出你的预算。但出乎意料的是，她只肯卖18万美元。你从其他房产的经验中得知，这个价格远低于市场价。你会如何回应？

I’ll sharpen the question. Whatever you decide, there’s no downside. You can draft a simple offer to purchase that gives you complete protection if there’s any problem with legal title to the property or its physical condition. Likewise, you can write a small, fully refundable check to secure the deal. Now, taking all that into account, how would you respond to the owner’s $180,000 price?

我把问题提炼得更具体一些。无论你做什么决定，都没有坏处。你可以拟定一份简单的购房要约，这样如果房产的产权或房屋状况出现任何问题，你都能得到全面的保障。同样，你也可以开一张金额较小的、可全额退还的支票来确保交易成功。现在，考虑到所有这些因素，你会如何回应房主提出的18万美元的价格？

A. Quickly accept the asking number.

A. 迅速接受对方索要的号码。

B. Counteroffer with a somewhat lower figure, knowing that you can always agree to the $180,000 if necessary.

B. 提出一个稍低的还价，因为你知道如果需要的话，你随时可以接受 180,000 美元。

C. Inform the owner that you want to buy the cabin, but you believe she has undervalued it.

C. 告知房主你想购买这间小木屋，但你认为她低估了它的价值。

Take a moment to think about the pros and cons of each of these options. You might do something different, but pick the one that comes closest to what you’d say. Also, note which of the responses seems least desirable. Why?

请花点时间思考一下每种选择的利弊。你可能会采取不同的做法，但请选择最接近你真实想法的选项。另外，也请注意哪个回复最不理想。为什么？

I’ve presented this scenario to executive program participants from all over the globe. Opinion on the right thing to do is always sharply divided. Forty-five percent say that they’d quickly agree to the owner’s asking price. But 29 percent say that they’d counteroffer. Almost as many (26 percent) say that they’d inform the seller that the price is below market value.

我曾向来自世界各地的企业高管培训学员介绍过这个情景。对于应该怎么做，大家的意见总是截然不同。45%的人表示会立即接受卖家的要价，但29%的人表示会还价，还有几乎同样多的人（26%）表示会告知卖家价格低于市场价。

I start case discussion by posting the tally and then ask those people who’d inform the owner that the price is too low to explain their choice. They typically speak in general terms. Taking advantage of an elderly person troubles them, they say. It just feels unfair. I push a bit to see how they define fairness. Would they feel any differently, I ask, if they were certain the person is mentally competent? I remind them that in the conversation over tea, she was well informed about current affairs.

我首先公布了统计结果，然后询问那些认为价格过低而劝阻业主的人，让他们解释一下自己的选择。他们通常会泛泛而谈。他们说，占老年人的便宜让他们感到不舒服，觉得不公平。我追问他们如何定义“公平”。我问，如果他们确定对方心智健全，他们的想法会不会有所不同？我提醒他们，在喝茶聊天时，对方对时事非常了解。

That’s not the problem, they reply. What bothers them is that they know the local real estate market much better than the seller does. Bargaining power is unfairly tilted in their favor. When pressed, they acknowledge that there isn’t a precise measure of fairness. They see it more as a reasonable range, not an exact number. While they’d be happy to buy at the lower end of that band, the asking price seems far below that here.

他们回答说，那不是问题所在。让他们困扰的是，他们比卖家更了解当地的房地产市场。议价能力明显偏向他们。被追问时，他们承认公平并没有一个精确的标准。他们认为公平更像是一个合理的范围，而不是一个确切的数字。虽然他们乐意以这个范围的下限价格购买，但这里的要价似乎远低于这个范围。

I next turn to the group that would make a counteroffer and ask them to respond to the arguments that they just heard about fairness. “Seller beware,” some say. For them, it’s a logical corollary of the caveat emptor principle. They assert that buyers and sellers both have the responsibility to know what something is worth. Others note that this owner chose to save money by not hiring an expert broker, so if there’s any blame, it falls on her shoulders.

接下来，我转向那些会提出还价的群体，请他们对刚才听到的关于公平性的论点作出回应。“卖家当心，”有人说道。对他们来说，这是“买者自负”原则的必然结果。他们认为，买卖双方都有责任了解物品的价值。另一些人则指出，这位业主为了省钱没有聘请专业经纪人，所以如果真要追究责任，那也应该由她自己承担。

People who take this position are on solid legal ground, at least in most Western countries. Courts sometimes invalidate agreements where there has been a mistake, but the misunderstanding must be mutual. If a customer walks into a jewelry store, pays $50 for a Timex watch, but an absent-minded clerk inadvertently hands her a much more valuable Rolex, that wouldn’t be what either party intended. There’d be no real meeting of the minds. Other than that, however, courts are leery about second-guessing mistakes about value, especially when the error is unilateral.

持这种观点的人至少在大多数西方国家有充分的法律依据。法院有时会因误解而宣告协议无效，但这种误解必须是双方共同的。例如，如果一位顾客走进一家珠宝店，花50美元买了一块天美时（Timex）手表，但粗心的店员却误给了她一块价值更高的劳力士（Rolex），这显然不是双方的本意。双方并未真正达成共识。然而，除此之外，法院对于事后质疑价值上的错误持谨慎态度，尤其是在错误是单方的情况下。

Meeting legal requirements is merely a threshold requirement, of course. Moral standards may be more stringent. I challenge the counterofferers by asking, What if this is your family’s cabin and the owner is your grandmother? Some stranger comes along and exploits her ignorance about property values. How would you feel then?

当然，满足法律要求仅仅是最低要求。道德标准可能更为严格。我向那些还价的人提出质疑：如果这是你家的度假小屋，而屋主是你的祖母呢？有个陌生人出现，利用她对房产价值的无知，你会作何感想？

A few people get the point. If we believe that an action is morally justified for us but not others, we’re applying a double standard. However, most people who’d counteroffer say that they wouldn’t criticize another buyer who took advantage, even if they happened to be on the wrong end of that deal. They regard negotiation as an arm’s-length process where each party is responsible only for his or her well-being. It’s up to others to take care of themselves. (“If I have any problem,” said one manager, “it’s with Grandma for not checking with me first.”)

有些人明白这一点。如果我们认为某种行为对我们自己来说是道德的，但对其他人来说却不是，那就是双重标准。然而，大多数会还价的人表示，即使自己在那笔交易中吃了亏，他们也不会批评占便宜的买家。他们认为谈判是一个公平的过程，每一方只对自己负责。其他人则应该照顾好自己。（一位经理说：“如果我有什么不满，那就是奶奶没有事先跟我商量。”）

Debate over this case is always spirited. Usually I can step back and let people challenge one another’s reasoning, but I make sure to get the third group into the discussion. These are the middle-ground people who’d simply snap up the owner’s asking price. If you don’t feel obliged to inform the seller that she has underpriced the property, I ask, why not counteroffer?

关于这个案子的争论总是很激烈。通常我会置身事外，让大家互相质疑对方的论点，但我也会确保让第三类人参与讨论。这些人是中间派，他们会毫不犹豫地接受房主的要价。如果你觉得没有义务告诉卖家她定价过低，我会问，为什么不还价呢？

It’s hard to pin down these people when they answer. Most start by saying that they don’t want to risk blowing a great deal. Fine, I say, but that’s a pragmatic argument, not a moral one. Moreover, the risk of countering here is low, especially if you do it gently. For example, one could say, “I might be able to make your $180,000 work, but I know I could do it for sure at $160,000.”

很难把握这些人回答的真正意图。大多数人一开始都会说他们不想冒着损失一大笔钱的风险。好吧，我说，但这只是出于务实的考虑，而非道德层面的考量。而且，反驳的风险很低，尤其是在你委婉表达的情况下。例如，你可以说：“我或许能让你的18万美元项目成功，但我肯定16万美元就能搞定。”

Even so, there’s something else that makes them squeamish about countering. “If the seller is happy,” they say, “then I’m happy.” They emphasize that it was the owner who put the low number on the table. As they see it, fairness is about process as much as it is about outcome. If the other side undervalues what it’s selling, then that wasn’t due to anything that the buyer did. By contrast, buyers who actively push for a lower price may share some responsibility for the result. For them, it’s the difference between sins of commission and sins of omission.

即便如此，还有另一件事让他们对还价感到不安。“如果卖家满意，”他们说，“那我也满意。”他们强调，是卖家主动报出了低价。在他们看来，公平不仅体现在结果上，也体现在过程中。如果对方低估了所售商品的价值，那并非买家的过错。相反，那些主动压价的买家可能要为最终结果承担部分责任。对他们来说，这关乎主动出击和被动疏忽之间的区别。

The three alternative courses of action represent contrasting views of right and wrong in negotiation. Bear in mind that whichever answer you chose was passed over by most people in my survey. Some of them rated it as the worst option (just as whichever alternative option you rated as worst was some people’s favorite).

这三种备选方案代表了谈判中对错截然不同的看法。请记住，在我的调查中，大多数人都忽略了你选择的那个方案。有些人甚至认为它是最糟糕的选择（正如你认为最糟糕的那个方案却是某些人最喜欢的一样）。

The core problem in this example is inherent in any negotiation. Need we worry about the overall fairness of an agreement? People don’t use fancy philosophical language to justify their choices in this scenario, though I’m struck by how firmly they state their conclusions. Minds don’t seem to change. Discussion doesn’t lead to consensus. If anything, people seem to become more entrenched in their particular views. Some see negotiation as a micromarket: a voluntary process where anyone who feels mistreated can say no and walk away. Others maintain that when we negotiate, we define ourselves in relationship to others. Are we isolated economic agents, they ask, or members of a larger community?

这个例子的核心问题是所有谈判都固有的。我们是否需要担心协议的整体公平性？在这种情况下，人们不会使用华丽的哲学辞藻来为自己的选择辩护，但我惊讶于他们如此坚定地陈述自己的结论。人们的想法似乎不会改变。讨论也无法达成共识。恰恰相反，人们似乎更加固执己见。有些人把谈判看作一个微型市场：一个自愿的过程，任何感到自己受到不公平对待的人都可以拒绝并退出。另一些人则认为，谈判时，我们是在与他人的关系中定义自己。他们问道，我们是孤立的经济个体，还是更大社群的成员？

It doesn’t have to be one or the other. Even if we have responsibilities for others, we also have the right to advance our own interests. “If we are not for ourselves,” asked Hillel the Elder, a Jewish religious leader of the first century, “who will be?” But then he added, “If we are only for ourselves, who are we?”

两者并非必须二选一。即便我们对他人负有责任，我们也同样有权追求自身利益。“如果我们不为自己着想，”公元一世纪的犹太教宗教领袖希勒尔长老问道，“谁会为我们着想呢？”但他接着又补充道，“如果我们只为自己着想，那我们又是谁呢？”

Being fair requires self-sacrifice. I’m not talking about being fair simply out of reputational concern. Believing that what goes around comes around is fine, but that’s just an enlightened view of self-interest. In the purest sense, fairness means leaving something on the table with no expectation that the favor will be returned or commended. It’s a matter of doing so because it feels right.

公平需要自我牺牲。我说的公平并非仅仅出于维护名誉的考量。相信善有善报固然没错，但这只是对自身利益的一种开明看法。从最纯粹的意义上讲，公平意味着付出而不求回报或赞扬。这样做是因为你觉得这样做是对的。

Before closing discussion of the case, I come back to the people who’d inform the owner that the property is underpriced. “Exactly how would that work?” I ask with a smile. “How does a buyer talk a seller up in negotiation?”

在结束对这个案例的讨论之前，我又问起了那些会告诉房主房产定价过低的人。“这具体该怎么操作呢？”我笑着问。“买家在谈判中该如何说服卖家呢？”

These people admit it could be risky. The owner might decide to retain a broker. Maybe the price of the cabin would get jacked way up. Still, most say they’d rather take that chance than feel guilty later. They also point out that the owner might appreciate the candor and reciprocate by sticking with the initial figure. (Remember how the owner of Bold Island in Maine overruled her lawyer’s instruction to increase the price?)

这些人承认这样做可能存在风险。业主可能会决定聘请经纪人。小木屋的价格或许会被大幅抬高。不过，大多数人表示，他们宁愿冒这个险，也不愿事后后悔。他们还指出，业主或许会欣赏他们的坦诚，并因此坚持最初的报价。（还记得缅因州博尔德岛的业主是如何否决律师提高价格的建议的吗？）

The two parties might determine jointly what’s fair—perhaps a number that’s higher than the asking price but less than full market value. Or they might find other ways to generate value. If the buyer wouldn’t be able to use the property all the time, for instance, maybe she could rent it to the owner’s family at a bargain rate. Or if her family could use it free of charge, the negotiators might end up back at the original asking price.

双方可以共同商定一个合理的价格——或许高于要价但低于市场价。或者，他们也可以找到其他增值方式。例如，如果买家无法一直使用房产，或许可以以优惠价格租给房主的家人。如果她的家人可以免费使用，那么谈判者最终可能会回到最初的要价。

Virtue isn’t always rewarded, and fairness may not always be a priority. In this case, though, informing the seller seems like the most promising avenue for expanding the deal space. Snapping up the owner’s offer would make the transaction into a zero-sum game. You’d get more. She’d get less. Likewise for countering with a lowball offer. Instead, shining a light on how both parties value what they are trading could reveal opportunity for mutual gain.

美德未必总能得到回报，公平也未必总是首要考虑因素。然而，就此案例而言，告知卖家似乎是扩大交易空间的最佳途径。如果接受卖家的报价，交易就会变成零和博弈。你会获得更多，而她会更少。同样，如果还价过低，也会如此。相反，如果双方都能了解彼此对交易标的的价值判断，或许就能找到互利共赢的机会。

SCENARIO 2: THE TRUTH, THE WHOLE TRUTH, OR SOMETHING LIKE THE TRUTH

情景二：真相，全部真相，或者类似真相的东西

Now flash forward a few years. Assume that you bought the rustic cabin for an acceptable price. You’ve enjoyed the place but have learned that a motorcycle track will be built nearby in just a few months. The new facility will meet all environmental and land-use regulations, but there is no doubt that you’ll hear the noise, especially on weekends. It’s time for you to move on.

现在时间快进几年。假设你以合适的价格买下了那间乡村小屋。你很喜欢这里，但得知几个月后附近将修建一条摩托车赛道。新的赛道将符合所有环境和土地使用法规，但毫无疑问，你会听到噪音，尤其是在周末。是时候搬走了。

You found the old For Sale sign that the prior owner had painted and nailed it to the same tree by the roadside. An eager young couple, driving an expensive car, has toured the property and appears ready to make an offer. One of them asks, “Why would you ever want to sell such a beautiful place?”

你找到了之前房主挂在路边同一棵树上的“出售”牌子。一对年轻夫妇开着豪车，兴致勃勃地来看过这处房产，似乎准备出价。其中一人问道：“这么漂亮的地方，你为什么要卖掉呢？”

Which of the following comes closest to how you’d answer that question? (Again note also which would be least desirable.)

以下哪个选项最接近您对这个问题的回答？（同时请注意哪个选项最不可取。）

A. “You know, ever since I put up the sign, I’ve been thinking the same thing myself.”

A：“你知道吗，自从我挂出那个牌子以来，我自己也一直在想同样的事情。”

B. “I’m worried that the noise from the new motorcycle track may be disturbing.”

B：“我担心新建摩托车赛道的噪音可能会令人烦恼。”

C. “Oh, I guess it just feels like time to try something new.”

C：“哦，我想是时候尝试一些新的东西了。”

Think about what you’d likely say on the spur of the moment. Is it the same answer you’d give if you had anticipated the question beforehand?

想想你临场可能会说什么。这和你事先预料到这个问题时给出的答案一样吗？

More than 60 percent of the people I’ve surveyed favor the third response: namely, saying that it just feels like the right time to move. Alternatives A and B each garners only 18 percent support. In class discussion, this time I start with the majority, asking them why their try-something-new answer is better than the other two. They zero in on the negative impact of telling the buyers about the motorcycle track. Disclosure could kill the deal or at least knock down the property’s value in the buyers’ eyes.

在我调查的人中，超过60%的人倾向于第三种回答：即感觉现在是搬家的最佳时机。选项A和B的支持率都只有18%。在课堂讨论中，这次我先从大多数人的回答入手，询问他们为什么觉得这种“尝试新方法”的答案比其他两种更好。他们集中讨论了告知买家摩托车赛道的负面影响。信息披露可能会导致交易失败，或者至少会降低买家对房产的估值。

This is a results-oriented view of the question. It considers how our actions affect us (see part one of Hillel’s aphorism about advocating for ourselves), but it disregards what that statement says about us in relationship to the other party (Hillel’s part two). The implicit rule seems to be one of convenience: apparently it’s fine to be honest if it doesn’t cost us anything (for instance, if we’re motivated to sell because we’re moving to another part of the country), but not if telling the truth hurts.

这是一种以结果为导向的观点。它考虑的是我们的行为如何影响我们自身（参见希勒尔关于为自己辩护的格言的第一部分），但却忽略了这一陈述对我们与对方关系的影响（希勒尔的第二部分）。其隐含的规则似乎是一种便利性原则：如果诚实不会给我们带来任何损失（例如，如果我们出售房产的动机是搬到国内其他地方），那么诚实显然是可以接受的；但如果说真话会伤害到我们，那就另当别论了。

The underlying reasoning may be more complex than that, however. When I ask these “try something new” people why they prefer that to feigning second thoughts about selling (as the first answer implies), they say that the latter is an outright lie, whereas their response is not. At first that may seem like hairsplitting. Yes, it is true that you want to go someplace else. But that response is deliberately misleading in that it omits the fact that their decision is triggered by upcoming noise in the area.

然而，其背后的原因可能比这更复杂。当我问这些“尝试新事物”的人，为什么他们宁愿这样做，而不是假装对出售房产犹豫不决（正如第一个回答所暗示的那样），他们说后者是彻头彻尾的谎言，而他们的回答并非如此。乍一看，这似乎是在吹毛求疵。没错，你的确想去别的地方。但这种回答故意误导人，因为它忽略了一个事实：他们的决定是由该地区即将出现的噪音所引发的。

Perhaps the distinction is just an alibi, a way that some people salve their conscience. But others might see it as a legitimate tactic for ducking the question; avoiding having to choose between self-interest and obligations to others, at least for the moment. Some people who choose this option maintain that they would never tell an overt lie, but they have no reservations about answering questions as narrowly as possible. If the prospective buyer asked a more direct question (“Are there any potential problems with the property that could give me a concern?”), they’d feel compelled to reveal more information.

或许这种区别只是个借口，是某些人用来安抚自己良心的方式。但另一些人则可能将其视为一种合理的回避策略，至少暂时避免在自身利益和对他人的责任之间做出选择。一些选择这种做法的人坚称自己绝不会公然撒谎，但他们却毫不犹豫地尽可能地含糊其辞地回答问题。如果潜在买家提出更直接的问题（例如“这处房产是否存在任何可能让我担忧的潜在问题？”），他们就会感到不得不透露更多信息。

There are two lessons here, one for each side of the transaction. For would-be buyers, it’s about asking questions the right way. Precision and persistence are essential. Asking general questions in negotiation invites vague answers. Be persistent pinning down details. In turn, sellers who don’t want to reveal any more than necessary should be ready for follow-ups. Saying “It’s time to try something new” might end the inquiry with some people, but others may continue by asking, “Why? Is there some problem?” Know ahead of time what you will feel obliged to disclose if you’re pressed. And remember that being evasive can cost you credibility.

这里有两个教训，交易双方各一个。对于潜在买家来说，关键在于如何正确地提问。精准和坚持至关重要。谈判中泛泛而谈只会得到含糊不清的答案。要坚持不懈地追问细节。反过来，那些不愿透露过多信息的卖家也应该做好被追问的准备。对某些人来说，一句“是时候尝试一些新方法了”或许就能结束询问，但其他人可能会继续追问：“为什么？是不是有什么问题？”事先要清楚，如果被追问，哪些信息你必须披露。记住，闪烁其词会让你失去信誉。

Going back to the second option, only 18 percent of the managers I’ve surveyed say that they’d mention the new motorcycle track the moment they were asked. (Most of the other respondents ranked this the worst choice.) Nevertheless, this approach may be wise. In fact, it would be legally required in some places.

回到第二个选项，在我调查过的经理中，只有18%的人表示，如果被问及，他们会立即提及新建的摩托车赛道。（其他大多数受访者认为这是最糟糕的选择。）尽管如此，这种做法或许是明智的。事实上，在某些地方，这甚至是法律强制要求的。

Specific laws vary from country to country—indeed, from state to state in the United States—but many courts disallow fraudulent transactions. Fraud is commonly defined as an intentional misrepresentation of fact on which someone reasonably relies to his or her detriment. Just because a statement is false doesn’t make it fraudulent. It must be deliberately misleading. Moreover, it has to be plausible, cause real harm, and pertain to facts, not subjective opinions. Thus, a salesperson’s puffery (“This is the finest automobile ever made”) doesn’t constitute fraud, even if the vehicle in question is a Yugo. And it’s all right, legally at least, to say “I’ll never pay a penny to settle this case,” even if you know that you could write a big check if you ultimately have to do so.

具体法律因国家而异——甚至在美国，各州之间也存在差异——但许多法院都禁止欺诈交易。欺诈通常被定义为故意歪曲事实，而他人合理地信赖该事实并因此遭受损失。仅仅因为陈述是虚假的，并不意味着它就是欺诈。它必须是故意误导的。此外，它还必须是合情合理的，造成实际损害，并且与事实相关，而非主观意见。因此，销售人员的夸大其词（“这是有史以来最好的汽车”）并不构成欺诈，即使所涉车辆是辆Yugo牌汽车。而且，至少在法律上，即使你知道最终不得不支付一大笔钱，你也可以说“我绝不会为这起案件支付一分钱”。

The elements of fraud are easy to state in the abstract. Applying them in specific cases gets tricky. Proving that a particular seller’s statement was intentional can be hard, for example. Likewise for showing reasonable reliance on the buyer’s part. Fraud is even harder to establish in negotiations where instead of saying something false, a seller remains silent. Legal rules set the bar low when it comes to truth telling. Most moral principles require a higher standard of conduct. In any event, it makes pragmatic sense to keep well away from any gray area. Lawsuits are costly. So is a reputation for sharp dealing.

欺诈的构成要件抽象地陈述起来很容易，但在具体案例中应用却很棘手。例如，要证明卖方的陈述是故意的就很难，同样，要证明买方有合理的信赖也很难。在谈判中，如果卖方没有说谎而是保持沉默，那么认定欺诈就更加困难。法律对诚实的要求很低，而大多数道德原则则要求更高的行为标准。无论如何，远离任何灰色地带都是明智之举。诉讼成本高昂，而精明交易的名声同样代价不菲。

It’s curious in this scenario that fewer people (18 percent) say that they’d disclose information about the new motorcycle track than the 26 percent in the first case who’d inform the owner that her property was underpriced. If you’re willing to tell someone that she’s shortchanging herself why not also share secondary information that may (or may not) influence how she values things?

在这种情况下，令人费解的是，只有18%的人表示会透露新建摩托车赛道的信息，而第一个案例中，有26%的人会告知房主她的房产定价过低。如果你愿意告诉别人她买贵了，为什么不也分享一些可能（也可能不会）影响她对房产估值的其他信息呢？

My guess is that context is at work here. At least some of the respondents may have adjusted their answers according to whom they think they are dealing with. They may feel more generous toward a charming older person in apparent need of money than they do toward a younger couple who just arrived in a fancy car. There’s nothing inherently wrong with making that distinction, but we should be aware of our biases, whether they lead us to be more or less generous.

我猜想，情境在这里起了作用。至少有些受访者可能根据他们认为的谈话对象调整了答案。他们或许会更慷慨地对待一位魅力十足、看似需要钱的老人，而不是一对刚开着豪车抵达的年轻夫妇。这种区分本身并没有错，但我们应该意识到自身的偏见，无论这些偏见是让我们更慷慨还是更吝啬。

When I present the first scenario in class, I take care not to mention gender. Instead, I refer consistently to the owner as the seller or the person. Yet almost invariably, people nevertheless assume that the owner is a woman. Essentially, they paint a mental picture, coloring it in with their own experience and values. We do that in real life as well. Dealing with others, even strangers, we don’t start with a blank canvas. We bring in old associations, be they positive or negative.

我在课堂上讲解第一个案例时，会刻意避免提及性别。相反，我会始终称店主为“卖家”或“本人”。然而，几乎无一例外，人们仍然会想当然地认为店主是女性。本质上，他们会在脑海中构建一幅画面，并用自己的经验和价值观去渲染它。我们在现实生活中也会这样做。与他人交往，即使是陌生人，我们也不会从一张白纸开始。我们会带入过去的联想，无论是积极的还是消极的。

It would be natural to assume that when we come upon a knotty problem, we analyze it from multiple perspectives and then arrive at a well-reasoned conclusion.

我们很自然地会认为，当我们遇到棘手的问题时，我们会从多个角度进行分析，然后得出合理的结论。

Recent scientific findings, however, indicate that many of our moral judgments really are visceral. NYU professor Jonathan Haidt puts it succinctly: “Moral reasoning, when it occurs, is usually a post-hoc process in which we search for evidence to support our initial intuitive reaction.”

然而，近期的科学研究表明，我们许多道德判断实际上是出于本能。纽约大学教授乔纳森·海特简洁地指出：“道德推理，即便发生，通常也是一个事后过程，在这个过程中，我们会寻找证据来支持我们最初的直觉反应。”

That’s a bold and unsettling claim. It tramples the notion that we are principled actors who reach moral conclusions through a deliberative process. That’s not what neuroscientists see, however, when they conduct fMRI scans of subjects being asked to make choices. When people are presented with ethical quandaries, the emotional parts of the brain that register fear, disgust, and empathy fire up before the conscious mind kicks in. Those first reactions color our subsequent thinking. We can concoct justifications for what are actually gut responses. If someone pokes a hole in our rationale, we can come up with another argument without realizing what’s actually driving our decisions.

这是一个大胆且令人不安的论断。它颠覆了我们作为有原则的行动者，通过深思熟虑的过程得出道德结论的传统观念。然而，神经科学家在对被要求做出选择的受试者进行功能磁共振成像（fMRI）扫描时，观察到的却并非如此。当人们面临道德困境时，大脑中负责感知恐惧、厌恶和同情的情感区域会在意识启动之前就被激活。这些最初的反应会影响我们随后的思考。我们可以为那些实际上源于本能的反应编造出各种理由。如果有人质疑我们的论证，我们可以在不知不觉中提出另一个论点，而没有意识到真正驱动我们决策的是什么。

Some emotional responses are sound and praiseworthy, of course. The fleeting thought of cheating somebody may trigger self-contempt or disgust. That’s good. So is the compassion we feel for someone who deserves a decent slice of the pie. But our first impressions deserve a second look.

当然，有些情绪反应是合理且值得称赞的。比如，一闪而过的欺骗他人的念头可能会引发自我厌恶或反感，这很好。我们对那些理应得到应有份额的人产生的同情心也很好。但我们的第一印象值得重新审视。

SCENARIO 3: CHOOSING BETWEEN RIGHT AND RIGHT

情景三：在左右为难

This time imagine that you’ve been negotiating the sale of some property owned by your company. After some discussion, the buyer made an attractive offer that you orally accepted and shook hands on. Your boss is pleased with the terms as they stand but has suggested that you tell the buyer that he or she has to improve the price to get the deal approved. “No harm in asking,” your boss says.

这次假设你正在洽谈出售公司名下的一处房产。经过一番讨论，买家提出了一个颇具吸引力的报价，你口头接受了并握手成交。你的老板对目前的条款很满意，但建议你告诉买家，他/她需要提高价格才能让交易获得批准。“问问也无妨，”你的老板说道。

Which of the following responses comes closest to what you would do? As before, note which option is the least desirable:

以下哪个选项最接近你的做法？和之前一样，请指出哪个选项最不可取：

A. Tell your boss that you’ve already given your word to the buyer and that you’re uncomfortable going back on it.

A. 告诉你的老板，你已经向买家做出了承诺，你不愿意反悔。

B. Do exactly what your boss says. It’s a common bargaining tactic, after all.

B. 完全听从老板的指示。毕竟，这是常见的谈判策略。

C. Meet with the buyer and ask if he or she can raise the offer, while making it clear that this isn’t a deal breaker.

C. 与买家见面，询问他/她是否可以提高报价，同时明确表示这并非交易的必要条件。

Our first scenario focused on distributional fairness. The second raised the question of what’s required in regard to honesty. This one poses a dilemma of divided loyalties: Do you stand up for your own values or compromise them if that seems to be in the best interest of your employer?

我们的第一个情景侧重于分配公平性。第二个情景则提出了关于诚实的要求。它提出了一个忠诚度冲突的困境：你是坚持自己的价值观，还是为了雇主的利益而妥协？

Of the people I’ve surveyed, 53 percent picked the first answer, choosing to tell their boss that they didn’t want to break their word to the buyer. Their answers may be sincere, though I wonder whether that many people would have the nerve to contradict their superior. Still, it’s significant that this is many people’s first impulse.

在我调查的人当中，53%的人选择了第一个答案，也就是告诉老板他们不想违背对买家的承诺。他们的回答或许是真诚的，但我怀疑是否真有这么多人有胆量去违抗上级。不过，这仍然是很多人的第一反应，这一点意义重大。

It would be nice to believe that you don’t have to leave behind your principles when you show up at work, but the problem is more complex than it might first appear. In the prior examples, you were acting on your own behalf. If you chose to be fair and honest, you bore the consequences, specifically the risk of paying more or losing the deal. In this scenario, by contrast, keeping your word could be at your employer’s expense.

我们当然希望上班时不必放弃原则，但实际情况远比表面看起来复杂。在之前的例子中，你都是在为自己着想。如果你选择公平诚实，就要承担相应的后果，比如支付更多费用或失去交易的风险。而在这个例子中，信守承诺可能会让你的雇主蒙受损失。

In the Citibank land assembly, as you may recall, the last piece of the puzzle was a corner property owned by an estate. Don Schnabel had agreed to a premium price to wrap up the project. When they closed the deal, however, he learned that the executrix had just extended the tenants’ leases and then sold them to a speculator. This last-minute bait and switch was legal, but it meant that Schnabel didn’t get the property free and clear. That move may seem slimy, but the profit from selling the leases went to the heirs’ pockets. The executrix could have been more upright in respect to Schnabel, but that would have meant less money for the beneficiaries. She might even argue that she had a fiduciary duty to violate her personal scruples. Of course, that doesn’t feel right either.

你可能还记得，在花旗银行的土地收购案中，最后一块拼图是一块位于街角、属于某遗产的地块。唐·施纳贝尔同意支付溢价以完成该项目。然而，交易完成后，他却发现遗嘱执行人刚刚延长了租户的租约，然后将其卖给了投机者。这种临阵脱逃的伎俩虽然合法，但意味着施纳贝尔并没有完全获得这块地。这种做法或许显得卑鄙，但出售租约的利润最终还是落入了继承人的口袋。遗嘱执行人本可以对施纳贝尔更加正直，但这会减少受益人的收益。她甚至可能会辩称，她有受托责任，所以不能违背自己的个人道德准则。当然，这种说法也让人感觉不太对劲。

The best way to avoid this dilemma is defining your scope of authority before negotiating on someone else’s behalf. One aspect of authority involves substance; getting clarity on what you can agree to. Sometimes your role may be to scout the landscape and let others reach a final agreement. Other times you may be empowered to commit to a deal within specified limits. But you also need to clarify authority regarding process. Your boss or client has the right to know what you’re willing to do on his or her behalf and where your ethical boundaries lie. If you’re lucky, your values may be well aligned. But if they want an attack dog, and that’s not your style, you owe it to them to resolve that up front.

避免这种困境的最佳方法是在代表他人谈判之前明确你的权限范围。权限的一个方面在于实质内容；你需要清楚地了解自己能够同意的内容。有时，你的角色可能是了解情况，然后让其他人达成最终协议。有时，你可能被授权在特定范围内做出承诺。但你也需要明确流程方面的权限。你的老板或客户有权知道你愿意代表他们做什么，以及你的道德底线在哪里。如果幸运的话，你们的价值观可能非常契合。但如果他们需要的是一个咄咄逼人的谈判者，而这并非你的风格，那么你有义务事先与他们沟通清楚。

In the survey, 18 percent of respondents said that they’d do what their boss asked. Perhaps some saw it as a matter of loyalty—or staying in the boss’s good graces. And others might have regarded the check-with-my-boss gambit as perfectly acceptable. It’s a common practice in auto showrooms, after all.

调查显示，18%的受访者表示会听从老板的安排。或许有些人认为这是出于忠诚，或是为了讨好老板。而另一些人则可能觉得“先跟老板确认”这种做法完全可以接受。毕竟，这在汽车展厅里很常见。

The third option—broadly hinting to the buyer that he really doesn’t have to increase the offer—was picked as the best by 29 percent of those surveyed. It’s an easy choice to understand but harder to justify. It would allow you to please your manager without reneging on your agreement with the seller. If your boss is hotheaded and doesn’t listen to other viewpoints, expressing disagreement could be dangerous.

第三种选择——委婉地暗示买家他其实不必提高报价——被29%的受访者选为最佳方案。这个选择容易理解，但难以令人信服。它能让你在不违背与卖家协议的前提下取悦你的经理。如果你的老板脾气暴躁，不听取他人意见，那么表达不同意见可能会很危险。

This approach is troubling, however. It leaves the boss believing that you’ll do what he told you, when in fact you won’t. Maybe the boss will never know. But you will. To rationalize the deception in your own mind, you have to believe that he doesn’t deserve to know the whole truth. And if he is deceitful and overbearing with you, perhaps he doesn’t. That’s a gloomy conclusion to reach, however. It would certainly affect your dealings going forward. You’ll have to keep your head down and your mouth shut. That’s not a great way to live.

然而，这种做法令人担忧。它会让老板误以为你会听从他的指示，而实际上你不会。也许老板永远不会知道真相，但你会知道。为了在自己心中合理化这种欺骗行为，你必须相信他不配知道全部真相。如果他对你虚伪专横，或许他的确不配知道。但这确实是一个令人沮丧的结论，它肯定会影响你今后的交往。你只能低调行事，闭口不言。这样的生活并不好过。

As an alternative, consider Mark Twain’s advice. “Always do right,” he said. Here that could mean having a forthright conversation with your boss, rather than circumventing his wishes. You could try to persuade him that it’s not in the company’s interest for it (or you) to get a reputation for being devious. Twain also said that doing right “will gratify some of the people and astonish the rest.”

另一种方法是考虑马克·吐温的建议。他说：“永远做正确的事。” 在这里，这可能意味着与你的老板坦诚沟通，而不是违背他的意愿。你可以试着说服他，公司（或你）如果落得个诡计多端的名声，对公司（或你本人）都没有好处。吐温还说过，做正确的事“会让一些人感到欣慰，也会让另一些人感到惊讶”。

In any case, there’s a moral to this story if you look at it from the boss’s perspective. It’s hard to judge another negotiator’s performance if you’re not sitting next to him or her. At best, you’ll know only half of the story. Maybe the negotiator isn’t pushing hard enough to advance your firm’s interest. Or perhaps he or she isn’t as scrupulous as you hope. That’s all the more reason for having clear and verifiable rules for what behavior is permissible and what is not.

总之，从老板的角度来看，这个故事蕴含着一个道理。如果你不坐在谈判者旁边，就很难评判他/她的表现。充其量，你只能了解事情的一半。也许这位谈判者没有尽全力去维护公司的利益。又或许，他/她并不像你希望的那样恪守职业道德。正因如此，制定清晰且可验证的规则来界定哪些行为是允许的，哪些行为是不允许的就显得尤为重要。

Finally, there’s a lesson for dealing with negotiators who represent others, which is often the case in business dealings. Knowing the extent of your counterpart’s authority is essential. It’s dangerous to make commitments to people who can’t reciprocate with binding promises of their own. If they can’t give you a yes or a no, the most you should give them is a maybe.

最后，对于与代表他人的谈判者打交道（这种情况在商业交易中很常见），我们还有一条经验教训：了解对方的权限范围至关重要。向那些无法做出具有约束力承诺的人做出承诺是危险的。如果他们无法明确地回答“是”或“否”，你最多只能给出“也许”的答复。

DRAWING A LINE

画一条线

Acting responsibly doesn’t require a doctorate in moral philosophy, but it does mean knowing your core values before negotiation begins. There are tried-and-true tests that can help you not cross the line separating right and wrong.

负责任的行为并不需要道德哲学博士学位，但确实意味着在谈判开始前要清楚自己的核心价值观。有一些行之有效的检验方法可以帮助你坚守是非对错的界限。

• Universality check. Could you recommend that everyone in your situation act this way?

• 普遍性检验。您是否可以建议所有与您情况类似的人都这样做？

• Reciprocity check. Would you want others to treat you this way?

• 互惠原则。你希望别人这样对待你吗？

• Publicity check. Would you be comfortable if your actions were fully and fairly described in a newspaper or online?

• 公开性考量。如果你的行为被报纸或网络媒体全面、公正地报道，你会感到自在吗？

• Trusted-friend check. Would you be comfortable telling your best friend, spouse, or children what you are doing?

• 向信任的朋友咨询。你会愿意告诉你的挚友、配偶或孩子你在做什么吗？

• Legacy check. Is this how you want to be known and remembered?

• 审视一下你的历史地位。你希望人们这样认识你、记住你吗？

If a flag goes up on one of these checks, it’s a warning that you may be compromising your principles. If more than one test makes you squirm, change your plans or risk shame and regret.

如果这些检查中的任何一项发出警告，则表明你可能正在违背自己的原则。如果不止一项检查让你感到不安，请改变计划，否则可能会蒙羞并后悔。

Good intentions aren’t enough. Research shows that powerful people who are convinced about their own rectitude may be more likely to transgress. Time and time again, we see self-righteous politicians from both sides of the aisle sermonize about other people’s behavior, only to end up in the tabloids themselves. People with more humility about their capacity to resist temptation take care to avoid situations where their willpower might be tested.

光有良好的意愿是不够的。研究表明，那些深信自己正直无私的权势人物，反而更容易越轨。我们一次又一次地看到，来自两党的自以为是的政客们对别人的行为指手画脚，最终却沦为八卦小报的头条新闻。而那些对自己抵御诱惑的能力更有信心的人，则会小心翼翼地避免那些可能考验自己意志力的场合。

Being mindful of the company that you keep is also important. Back in the scenario about buying the cabin from its elderly owner, I noted how the image of a kindly grandmother could elicit generosity. But don’t assume that applies to everyone. In fast-paced, high-pressure organizations, it’s easy for people to adopt an us-against-the-world attitude that justifies crushing outsiders without compunction.

注意你结交的朋友也很重要。回到之前提到的从年迈的屋主手中购买小木屋的例子，我提到慈祥祖母的形象可以激发慷慨之心。但不要以为这适用于所有人。在快节奏、高压力的组织中，人们很容易产生一种“我们与世界为敌”的心态，从而为肆意打压外人找到借口。

Remember the energy traders at Enron who were audiotaped gloating about profiting from the 2000–01 California power crisis? One of them asked about the state’s efforts to recover Enron’s excess charges, or as he termed it, “All the money you guys stole from those poor grandmothers.” They went on to describe “Grandma Millie” with profanity-laced contempt. For them, grandmothers had come to personify easy prey, ripe for exploiting. Maybe if these same people worked for a company with a different ethos, they would have had a more compassionate outlook.

还记得安然公司那些能源交易员吗？他们曾被录音，得意洋洋地炫耀自己从2000-2001年加州电力危机中牟利。其中一人质问加州政府如何追回安然公司多收的电费，或者用他的话说，“你们这些家伙从那些可怜的老奶奶身上偷走了那么多钱”。他们还用充满脏话的蔑视之词描述了“米莉奶奶”。在他们眼里，老奶奶们成了唾手可得的猎物，任人宰割。或许，如果这些人效力于一家理念不同的公司，他们就会拥有更富同情心的视角。

Our moral sensitivity may slacken over time as well. I have a colleague who served on Los Angeles County’s Regional Planning Commission. We’ll call him Norman. His agency has powerful influence over what gets developed in an area that spans hundreds of square miles.

随着时间的推移，我们的道德敏感度也可能下降。我有一位同事曾在洛杉矶县区域规划委员会任职，我们姑且称他为诺曼。他所在的机构对数百平方英里区域内的开发项目拥有强大的影响力。

A few months after his appointment, Norman received a fancy smoked ham from Forest Lawn, a company that operates cemeteries throughout the region. He asked his assistant, “What’s this about?” She told him that Forest Lawn had a tradition of sending hams to commissioners every Christmas season. “They like to stay on good terms with us, as they’re always looking for new sites to develop.” Norman told the assistant to send back the gift immediately.

诺曼上任几个月后，收到了一份来自森林草坪公司（Forest Lawn）的精美熏火腿。这家公司在该地区经营着多家墓地。他问助理：“这是怎么回事？”助理告诉他，森林草坪公司有个传统，每年圣诞节都会给专员们送火腿。“他们想和我们保持良好关系，因为他们一直在寻找新的墓地进行开发。”诺曼吩咐助理立刻把礼物寄回去。

Nevertheless, the following year, another ham appeared. Norman meant to return this one as well, but he was busy, and so was everyone else. When his assistant reminded him, Norman said, “Oh, just use it for our office party tomorrow night.” Norman sampled some of the ham himself. It was delicious.

然而，第二年又出现了一块火腿。诺曼本想把这块也退回去，但他很忙，其他人也都很忙。当他的助理提醒他时，诺曼说：“哦，就用它做我们明天晚上的办公室派对吧。”诺曼自己也尝了几口，味道真不错。

Another year passed. It was early December, and Norman caught himself thinking, “I wonder when my ham is going to arrive.” Good for Norman to recognize that he was starting down a slippery slope. What at first seemed to him like a clumsy bribe had become an entitlement. It’s a trap any of us can fall into.

又一年过去了。十二月初，诺曼突然想到：“我的火腿什么时候才能到啊？” 诺曼能意识到自己正在滑向深渊，这真是明智之举。起初在他看来只是笨拙的贿赂，如今却变成了理所当然的享受。我们每个人都可能掉进这个陷阱。

Learning also involves gauging what rules your counterparts play by. Studies show that most people rate themselves well above average when it comes to ethical behavior. In fact, a newsmagazine poll asked people whom they thought would get to heaven. Bill Clinton was a toss-up, getting 52 percent backing from respondents. Former basketball star Michael Jordan did better, at 62 percent. Mother Teresa topped the two American men with 79 percent. But she was not the highest. That honor went to “yourself,” with 87 percent.

学习也包括了解他人遵循的规则。研究表明，大多数人对自己在道德行为方面的评价都远高于平均水平。事实上，一家新闻杂志的民意调查询问人们认为谁能上天堂。比尔·克林顿的支持率不相上下，为52%。前篮球明星迈克尔·乔丹的支持率更高，为62%。特蕾莎修女以79%的支持率位居两位美国男性之首。但她并非最高。最高荣誉属于“你自己”，支持率高达87%。

If feeling morally superior were just self-flattery, it would be harmless. But if we tend to see people we negotiate with as having lower standards than we do, at best we become distrustful. At worst, we may feel that we have to be as ruthless as we suspect them to be. Impugning bad motives to others can also be a way of justifying shady practices on our part. But there are some people who treat negotiation as a winner-take-all battle. We don’t want to be naïve. After all, there is nothing fair about splitting the difference between our reasonable offer and someone else’s ridiculous demand. As Sean Connery’s Irish cop character in The Untouchables says, it’s folly to bring a knife to a gunfight.

如果道德优越感仅仅是自我吹捧，那倒也无伤大雅。但如果我们倾向于认为谈判对象比我们标准低，那么往好了说，我们会变得不信任对方；往坏了说，我们可能会觉得必须像怀疑对方那样冷酷无情。臆断他人动机不良也可能成为我们自身不正当行为的借口。但有些人把谈判当成一场赢家通吃的战斗。我们可不想天真。毕竟，在合理的报价和对方荒谬的要求之间折中，这根本不公平。正如肖恩·康纳利在《铁面无私》中饰演的爱尔兰警察所说，拿着刀去参加枪战是愚蠢的。

Don Schnabel and the team that fashioned the Citibank land assembly strove to be fair with owners but played tough when they had to. They were gracious to the elderly tenants who were reluctant to move. Likewise, after purchasing a restaurant, they kept it open so that the employees would continue to have paychecks. They honored their word to the church from which they bought air rights. But they also went toe-to-toe with professional holdouts who were angling for top dollar.

唐·施纳贝尔和花旗银行土地整合团队力求公平对待业主，但必要时也毫不妥协。他们对不愿搬迁的老年租户体谅有加。同样，在收购一家餐厅后，他们也坚持让餐厅继续营业，以确保员工的工资不受影响。他们信守承诺，从教堂购买了空中权。但他们也与那些一心想抬高价格的职业业主针锋相对。

CHARACTER

特点

When Getting to Yes was published three decades ago, it was rightly praised for making the case for collaborative, value-generating negotiation. The authors maintained that rather than being “a sermon on the morality of right and wrong, it is a book on how to do well in negotiation.” Nevertheless, some readers felt that it had a sanctimonious tone. A reviewer friendly to its overall thrust admitted to being put off by “a certain take-it-or-leave-it righteousness in the new religion.”

《谈判力》出版三十年前，因其倡导协作式、价值创造型谈判而备受赞誉。作者们坚持认为，这本书并非“对是非对错的道德说教，而是一本关于如何做好谈判的书”。然而，一些读者觉得这本书带有说教的意味。一位认同其整体主旨的评论家坦言，他对这种“新教派中某种非此即彼的自以为是”的态度感到反感。

In sharp contrast, Herb Cohen’s bestselling You Can Negotiate Anything (which appeared around the same time) was criticized from the opposite direction. Although Cohen tipped his hat to the win-win philosophy and extolled Jesus Christ and Socrates as “ethical negotiators,” his actual advice was, as one reviewer put it, “laced with enough manipulative ploys to make Niccolò Machiavelli nervous.” Even some of the stories that Cohen told about himself had a heartless edge.

与此形成鲜明对比的是，赫伯·科恩的畅销书《谈判无所不能》（出版时间与此书大致相同）却受到了截然相反的批评。尽管科恩对双赢理念表示赞赏，并称赞耶稣基督和苏格拉底是“道德谈判者”，但他实际提出的建议，正如一位评论家所说，“充满了足以让尼科洛·马基雅维利都感到不安的操纵手段”。甚至科恩讲述的一些关于他自己的故事也带有冷酷无情的色彩。

For instance, Cohen described an unsettling incident in front of a New York hotel. As he arrived in a cab, there was a crowd pressed around a police barricade and gaping upward. According to the doorman, someone on the eleventh floor was threatening to jump. “Gee, that’s too bad,” Cohen said. As he entered the lobby, he felt “upset at the thought of a fellow human being tumbling to the sidewalk.”

例如，科恩描述了在纽约一家酒店前发生的一件令人不安的事件。他乘出租车抵达时，看到一群人挤在警察设置的路障周围，抬头张望。据门卫说，有人在11楼扬言要跳楼。“哎呀，真可惜，”科恩说道。当他走进酒店大堂时，他感到“一想到有人可能会坠落到人行道上，就感到很不安”。

Then his story takes an unexpected turn. This isn’t a tale of how a gifted negotiator raced to the elevator and talked a desperate man off the ledge. Instead, Cohen strode directly to the front desk. His mood changed when the clerk told him that there weren’t any rooms available, even though he had a reservation. In Cohen’s own words, here’s what happened next:

然后，他的故事出现了意想不到的转折。这并非一个谈判高手冲到电梯前，劝说一个绝望的男人放弃自杀的故事。相反，科恩径直走向前台。当接待员告诉他没有空房时，他的情绪顿时跌落谷底，尽管他已经预订了房间。以下是科恩自己对接下来发生的事情的描述：

“ ‘Hold it!’ ” I snapped. “You do have a room! You know the guy on the eleventh floor? The one who’s causing all that commotion outside. He’s checking out!”

“等等！”我厉声说道，“你还有房间！你认识住在十一楼的那个人吗？就是在外面闹腾的那个。他正在退房！”

The windup? The guy didn’t jump. The police corralled him but checked him into a different facility for psychiatric examination. I got his vacant room.

事情的起因是？那家伙没跳。警察把他控制住，但把他送到另一家机构做精神鉴定。我住进了他空出来的房间。

It is true that Cohen had no role in pushing the stranger into despair, nor was he rooting for a suicide. And it’s true that somebody else would have eventually gotten that empty room, so why not him?

科恩的确没有参与将陌生人推入绝望的深渊，也没有希望他自杀。而且，最终那个空房间也会落到别人手里，为什么不能是他呢？

What’s missing in Cohen’s own account is compassion. His self-absorption led him to construe another person’s misery as his own good luck. It’s not the outcome that seems unseemly. Rather, it’s the haste with which he reached it. His behavior required a change of attitude, a narrowing of perspective. Within a few seconds, the “fellow human being” perched on the ledge became in Cohen’s eyes “the one who’s causing all that commotion.” That less sympathetic characterization suited his need for a room.

科恩的叙述中缺失的是同情心。他的自我中心让他将他人的不幸解读为自己的幸运。令人不齿的并非结果本身，而是他急于求成的态度。他的行为需要改变态度，需要缩小视野。短短几秒钟内，坐在窗台上的“同胞”在科恩眼中就变成了“制造骚乱的人”。这种缺乏同情心的描述正合他意，让他得以独处。

This incident took place many years ago. Cohen may feel differently about the situation now. And we all have weak moments and blind spots. The best protection against them is stepping back and reminding ourselves of who we aspire to be.

这件事发生在很多年前。科恩现在可能对这件事有不同的看法。我们每个人都会有软弱的时候和盲点。防止这些弱点出现的最好方法就是冷静下来，提醒自己我们想要成为什么样的人。

My friend Jim Golden is a personal injury defense lawyer with considerable experience in the trucking industry. One company he represents operates eighteen-wheelers that drive a combined million miles every day. Inevitably, there are collisions with smaller passenger vehicles. Deaths and horrible injuries result, sometimes followed by long and costly lawsuits. The conventional defense strategy in these kinds of cases is to stonewall and drag out the process. Victims’ families and injured survivors are often in a financial squeeze. Under pressure, they frequently settle cheaply.

我的朋友吉姆·戈尔登是一位人身伤害辩护律师，在卡车运输行业拥有丰富的经验。他代理的一家公司运营着十八轮卡车，每天行驶里程总计达一百万英里。这些卡车不可避免地会与小型乘用车发生碰撞。碰撞事故往往会导致人员伤亡和严重的人身伤害，有时还会引发旷日持久且费用高昂的诉讼。这类案件中，传统的辩护策略是拖延诉讼程序，阻挠赔偿。受害者家属和受伤的幸存者通常经济拮据，在压力之下，他们往往选择低价和解。

This was long Jim’s approach, though the thought of compounding other people’s suffering made him increasingly uncomfortable. He got to a point where he decided he couldn’t do it any longer. Right after the next fatal accident, Jim got his client’s permission to try a different tack. He telephoned the funeral home handling arrangements for the driver of the other car—a man with two young children—and asked if the family would like a representative of the trucking company to attend the service. He had no idea what the response would be, but a few hours later, he was told that the answer was yes.

吉姆长期以来一直沿用这种做法，但一想到会加剧他人的痛苦，他就越来越感到不安。最终，他决定不能再这样下去了。在下一次致命事故发生后，吉姆征得客户的同意，尝试了一种不同的方法。他打电话给负责另一辆车司机（一位带着两个年幼孩子的男人）丧葬事宜的殡仪馆，询问家属是否希望货运公司的代表出席葬礼。他不知道对方会作何反应，但几个小时后，他得到了肯定的答复。

Jim flew halfway across the country and stood in back of a packed church. When the service was over, he waited and then introduced himself to the victim’s widow. “We are very, very sorry,” he said, “for your loss.” Those were his only words, but his voice cracked as he spoke.

吉姆飞越半个美国，来到一座挤满了人的教堂后排。礼拜结束后，他稍等片刻，然后向遇难者的遗孀自我介绍。“我们对您的损失深感悲痛，”他说。他只说了这几个字，但声音哽咽了。

Two weeks later, he called the funeral home again to see if the family had a lawyer or some other representative he could talk to about the accident. He got the name of a local attorney, arranged a meeting, and flew out again, this time for a longer conversation. Jim explained that the company’s technical team had completed an investigation of the accident. It appeared that the truck driver was at least partially at fault. “We can negotiate a final settlement later,” he said, “or if that doesn’t work out, the case can go through the courts.” In the meantime, however, he worried about how the family was doing. He knew nothing could alleviate their emotional distress, but he didn’t want them to be struggling with financial problems on top of that.
