两周后，他再次致电殡仪馆，询问家属是否有律师或其他代表可以就事故进行沟通。他得知一位当地律师的姓名，安排了会面，并再次飞往殡仪馆，这次是为了进行更深入的交谈。吉姆解释说，公司的技术团队已经完成了对事故的调查。调查结果显示，卡车司机至少负有部分责任。“我们可以稍后协商最终赔偿方案，”他说，“如果协商不成，案件可以诉诸法庭。”与此同时，他很担心家属的处境。他知道任何事都无法减轻他们的精神痛苦，但他不希望他们雪上加霜，还要承受经济上的压力。

As he spoke, Jim reached into his pocket, pulled out an envelope, and slid it across the desk. “Here’s a check that may help—no strings attached,” he said. “I’m sure they’re going through a horrible time. We just don’t want to make it any worse.”

说话间，吉姆伸手进口袋，掏出一个信封，推到桌子上。“这是一张支票，或许能帮上忙——没有任何附加条件，”他说。“我知道他们现在处境艰难，我们只是不想雪上加霜。”

The other lawyer looked at Jim, stunned. “No strings?” he asked. “No obligations on our part? No releases or waivers?”

另一位律师震惊地看着吉姆。“没有任何附加条件？”他问道，“我们这边没有任何义务？没有任何免责声明或弃权书？”

“None at all,” Jim answered. “I’ll be glad to sign whatever document you’d like to draft in order to confirm that.”

“完全没有，”吉姆回答说。“我很乐意签署您希望起草的任何文件来确认这一点。”

The lawyer opened the envelope. His eyebrows rose. The check was for $25,000. “If you think the family needs more to get by,” Jim said, “let’s talk about it.” He also volunteered to share all the information that the company had already gathered about the accident. Less than two months later, the two lawyers reached a full settlement.

律师打开信封，挑了挑眉。支票金额是25000美元。“如果你觉得这家人还需要更多钱才能维持生计，”吉姆说，“我们再商量。”他还主动提出愿意分享公司已经收集到的所有关于事故的信息。不到两个月后，两位律师就达成了全面和解。

Now Jim begins all his negotiations this way. To his surprise, his offer to attend victims’ funerals is almost always accepted. It’s a heavy duty for him, but the gesture is appreciated. He’s not surprised that his approach often leads to early settlement. Jim thinks his own openness unfreezes other people, at least much of the time, and allows them to dispense with their emotional agendas. Experience has taught him that the “person who is the most aggressive, the most brazen, the most angry, is often, if you dig down underneath, the most fearful.”

现在吉姆每次谈判都以这种方式开始。令他惊讶的是，他主动提出参加受害者葬礼的提议几乎总是被接受。这对他来说是个沉重的负担，但他的举动却备受感激。他并不意外，他的方法往往能促成早期和解。吉姆认为，他的坦诚至少在大多数情况下能打破对方的僵局，让他们放下情感上的顾虑。经验告诉他，“那些最咄咄逼人、最厚颜无耻、最愤怒的人，如果你深入了解，往往会发现他们内心最恐惧。”

Dread of negotiation may be fear of being disrespected, exploited, or proven incompetent. Jim believes that when people mask their fear, they try to protect themselves by hitting first before getting bashed themselves. When both parties have that attitude, conflict escalates, whether it’s in the schoolyard or in negotiation. “I think if you can get past the fear,” he says, “the animosity, then maybe you don’t have to prove things to other people—or yourself.”

对谈判的恐惧可能源于害怕被轻视、被利用或被证明能力不足。吉姆认为，当人们掩饰恐惧时，他们会试图先发制人，以免遭到反击。如果双方都抱有这种态度，冲突就会升级，无论是在校园里还是在谈判桌上。“我认为，如果你能克服恐惧，”他说，“克服敌意，那么或许你就不必向他人——甚至向自己——证明什么了。”

Jim is a look-you-straight-in-the-eye kind of guy and an intense listener. When he walks into a settlement conference, he exhibits both compassion and confidence. By slashing litigation costs, he has reduced his company’s insurance premiums and put more money into victims’ pockets. Jim’s approach to negotiation isn’t a trick or gambit. Instead, it’s how Jim encourages the best in his negotiation counterparts by summoning the best in himself.

吉姆是个直视对方眼睛、认真倾听的人。每次参加和解会议，他都展现出既富有同情心又充满自信的一面。通过大幅削减诉讼成本，他降低了公司的保险费，也为受害者争取到了更多赔偿。吉姆的谈判方式并非花招或诡计，而是他通过激发自身潜能，从而激励谈判伙伴发挥出最佳水平。

My colleague Andy Wasynczuk has written a case study that examines Jim’s work. I use it in my own course, as it sparks spirited discussion for a full eighty-minute session. The buzz continues long afterward. Early one afternoon, as I gathered my notes and started back to my office, I overheard one student who’d boiled down Jim’s message to its essence. “To know the right thing to do,” she said, “you need to know who you want to be.”

我的同事安迪·瓦辛祖克（Andy Wasynczuk）撰写了一份案例研究，探讨了吉姆的工作。我在自己的课程中也使用这份案例研究，因为它能引发长达八十分钟的热烈讨论。讨论结束后，这种热度依然持续。一天下午早些时候，我整理笔记准备回办公室时，无意中听到一位学生把吉姆的观点提炼到了极致。“要想知道该做什么，”她说，“你首先需要知道自己想成为什么样的人。”

KEY POINTS

要点

■ Decide what you owe others in regard to fairness, candor, and the negotiation tactics you employ.

■ 决定你对他人应尽的公平、坦诚和谈判策略。

■ Recognize that your counterparts may have different expectations and principles than your own.

■ 要认识到你的对手可能与你有着不同的期望和原则。

■ Do what you can to encourage ethical behavior from others.

■ 尽你所能鼓励他人做出合乎道德的行为。

■ Be realistic, but take care not to rationalize questionable conduct just because you suspect your counterparts may not behave ethically.

■ 要务实，但要注意不要仅仅因为你怀疑对方的行为不道德就为可疑的行为辩解。

■ Remember that in the end, your actions define your character.

■ 记住，最终，你的行为定义了你的品格。

#↩

Appendix

附录

Twenty-five Reasons to Embrace Chaos in Negotiation—A Strategic Road Map

谈判中拥抱混乱的25个理由——战略路线图

PRECEPTS

原则

1. Negotiation is a dynamic, interactive process. Goals, interests, nonagreement alternatives, and, hence, potential solutions evolve as we negotiate. The changes are driven by our own actions, those of our counterparts, and external events. They can also be due to new ways that we (and others) construe the environment in which we operate.

1. 谈判是一个动态的、互动的过程。目标、利益、非协议替代方案以及潜在的解决方案都会随着谈判的进行而演变。这些变化是由我们自身的行动、对方的行动以及外部事件驱动的。它们也可能源于我们（以及其他人）对所处环境的理解方式的改变。

Changes in circumstances and perceptions may be significant or relatively small. They may be beneficial or to our detriment. Rarely are circumstances at the end of negotiation exactly as we anticipated at the beginning.

环境和认知的变化可能意义重大，也可能相对较小。这些变化可能对我们有利，也可能对我们不利。谈判结束时的情况很少会与我们最初的预期完全一致。

2. The better we manage and cope with the inherent uncertainty and unpredictability of negotiation, the more effective we will be. Even in seemingly simple situations, it’s hard to see the current landscape with perfect clarity. It’s harder still to predict exactly how things will unfold. Learning, adapting, and influencing are thus key elements of negotiation strategy and the tactics that implement it.

2. 我们越能有效应对谈判中固有的不确定性和不可预测性，谈判就越有效。即使在看似简单的情况下，也很难完全看清当前的形势。更难的是准确预测事态将如何发展。因此，学习、适应和影响是谈判策略及其执行战术的关键要素。

The actions we take and the statements we make to learn more about the negotiation environment, however, are also signals that are read (or misread) by our counterparts. Their perceptions will influence their actions and, hence, alter the world in which we must function. Thus, we must balance the strategic costs of how we endeavor to learn as well as the benefits.

然而，我们为了解谈判环境而采取的行动和发表的言论，同时也是对方会解读（或误读）的信号。他们的认知会影响他们的行动，进而改变我们所处的环境。因此，我们必须权衡学习过程中的战略成本和收益。

3. Omniscience about the present, let alone the future, isn’t possible. We must therefore act, often in real time, on incomplete and ambiguous information, even when the stakes are high. A bias for action is important, but we must prepare for surprises, pleasant and otherwise.

3. 我们不可能全知全能地了解现在，更遑论未来。因此，我们必须采取行动，而且往往是在信息不完整、模棱两可的情况下，实时采取行动，即便事关重大。积极行动固然重要，但我们也必须做好应对各种意外情况的准备，无论好坏。

4. The foregoing precepts all demand formulating robust strategy and executing nimble tactics.

4. 上述原则都要求制定强有力的战略并执行灵活的战术。

ASSERTIONS

断言

5. Conventional negotiation theory implicitly assumes a static environment by focusing on the individual decision maker instead of the interaction of the parties. It largely ignores problems (and opportunities) inherent in the dynamic nature of negotiation. Familiar concepts and techniques (such as working from interests and improving one’s BATNA) are important but do not in themselves prepare practitioners for the complexity of real-world negotiation.

5. 传统的谈判理论隐含地假设谈判环境是静态的，它关注的是个体决策者，而非谈判各方之间的互动。这种理论很大程度上忽略了谈判动态本质中固有的问题（和机遇）。一些熟悉的理念和技巧（例如从利益出发、完善自身的最佳替代方案）固然重要，但它们本身并不能使实践者为应对现实世界谈判的复杂性做好准备。

6. In negotiation, we don’t have complete control over our destiny. Exactly where we end up and how we get there are determined also by the needs, perceptions, and nature of our counterparts.

6. 在谈判中，我们无法完全掌控自己的命运。最终结果如何，也取决于对方的需求、看法和性格。

7. Striving for a degree of control that is beyond our reach is not in our interest.

7. 追求超出我们能力范围的控制程度，不符合我们的利益。

8. A fresh look at negotiation is required, one that focuses on the interaction between the parties (their dance, so to speak) rather than just the steps of a single party.

8. 我们需要重新审视谈判，关注各方之间的互动（可以说是他们的博弈），而不是仅仅关注某一方的步骤。

9. Our success in negotiation turns on both luck and skill: luck, in terms of our circumstances and whom we deal with; skill, in regard to our ability to analyze our situation and influence it positively.

9. 我们在谈判中的成功取决于运气和技巧：运气是指我们所处的环境以及我们所打交道的人；技巧是指我们分析自身处境并对其产生积极影响的能力。

Our counterparts are often as smart, determined, and fallible as we are. With potential partnerships and collaboration, encouraging counterparts to expand their vision and flexibility is usually to our advantage. By contrast, in some disputes, being at least a step ahead of others in respect to discernment and agility is beneficial.

我们的对手往往和我们一样聪明、意志坚定，但也难免犯错。在潜在的伙伴关系和合作中，鼓励对手拓展视野、提升灵活性通常对我们有利。相反，在某些争端中，在洞察力和敏捷性方面领先一步则更为有利。

10. We can learn to manage strategic complexity and interpersonal dynamics in two complementary ways. Illuminating the implicit practices of master negotiators is one avenue. Another is adapting principles and techniques from other domains in which people collaborate, create, or compete with one another (such as jazz, improv theater, psychotherapy, sports, and even warfare).

10. 我们可以通过两种互补的方式来学习如何应对战略复杂性和人际互动。一种方法是揭示谈判大师的隐性实践。另一种方法是借鉴其他领域（例如爵士乐、即兴戏剧、心理治疗、体育运动，甚至战争）中人们合作、创造或竞争的原则和技巧。

STRATEGIC PRINCIPLES

战略原则

11. Deliberate, ongoing learning is a critical element of effective negotiation strategy. It’s essential to recognize what we do—and don’t —know about what may develop. Rigid plans and untested assumptions hamper effective learning.

11. 有意识地持续学习是有效谈判策略的关键要素。我们必须认识到自己对未来发展趋势的了解程度，以及自身的知识盲区。僵化的计划和未经检验的假设会阻碍有效的学习。

12. Having clear objectives provides discipline and focus in negotiation, but that advantage must be weighed against openness to unexpected opportunities or obstacles that may warrant revising our strategy.

12. 明确的目标能够使谈判更有纪律性和专注力，但这种优势必须与对意外机遇或障碍的开放态度进行权衡，这些机遇或障碍可能需要我们修改策略。

13. Well-crafted strategies thus should contemplate not just likely outcomes but also best-case and worst-case scenarios. In some cases, that may require devising a plan B. In others, undertaking parallel negotiations with different potential partners may be wise. In all cases, it’s useful to set benchmarks and trip wires to activate alternative plans, including possible exits.

13. 因此，精心制定的战略不仅应考虑可能的结果，还应考虑最佳和最坏的情况。在某些情况下，这可能需要制定备选方案。在其他情况下，与不同的潜在合作伙伴进行平行谈判或许是明智之举。无论哪种情况，设定基准和触发机制来启动备选方案（包括可能的退出方案）都十分必要。

14. A strategic direction should be chosen that will seek vantage points and generate opportunities to test assumptions. Reconnaissance is especially important in the early stages of negotiation, when direction may be set. It is also important to optimize (as opposed to maximize) the number and nature of different paths to our ultimate goal. We must balance the option value of alternatives against the possible strategic advantage of commitment to a particular course of action.

14. 应选择一个能够寻找有利位置并创造机会检验假设的战略方向。侦察在谈判初期尤为重要，因为此时方向可能已经确定。此外，优化（而非最大化）通往最终目标的不同路径的数量和性质也至关重要。我们必须权衡各种方案的选择价值与坚持特定行动方案可能带来的战略优势。

15. Ongoing learning informs us how best to influence the actions and perceptions of our counterparts, where possible, and how best to adapt to their behavior where necessary.

15. 持续学习让我们知道如何最好地影响对手的行为和看法（如果可能的话），以及如何最好地适应他们的行为（在必要时）。

16. As negotiation unfolds, some options will close, while others emerge. Achievement of initial goals may still be possible, though perhaps through different means. New or unexpected conditions may call for a fundamental shift in strategy, including the execution of a plan B or ending the negotiation.

16. 随着谈判的进行，一些选项会消失，而另一些选项则会涌现。最初的目标或许仍有可能实现，但可能需要通过不同的方式。新的或意想不到的情况可能需要对战略进行根本性的调整，包括执行备选方案或终止谈判。

TACTICAL POINTS

战术要点

17. Many of the dynamic factors that inform broad strategy have microequivalents in moment-to-moment interactions. How parties generally engage each other and define the task is enacted by the specific things that they do and say.

17. 许多影响宏观战略的动态因素在瞬息万变的互动中都有相应的微观体现。各方如何相互协作以及如何定义任务，都是通过他们具体的言行来体现的。

18. Tactics and interactions must serve and be consistent with general strategy. Aggressive gambits seldom promote constructive relationships.

18. 战术和互动必须服务于总体战略并与之保持一致。咄咄逼人的策略很少能促进建设性的关系。

19. Negotiators must on the fly learn, adapt, and influence in both collaborative and competitive interactions.

19. 谈判者必须在合作和竞争的互动中随时学习、适应和施加影响。

20. Learning is an ongoing process of observing, orienting, deciding, and acting. We must begin negotiation with a clear set of expectations but be prepared to discard them when they do not match the situation at hand.

20. 学习是一个持续的过程，包括观察、判断、决策和行动。我们必须在谈判之初就设定明确的预期，但也要做好在预期与实际情况不符时放弃这些预期的准备。

21. Learning goes well beyond simply uncovering other parties’ substantive interests and perceived options (and the corresponding value of possible carrots and sticks). Specifically, it includes recognizing how best to engage others in regard to our demeanor, voice, and tempo. It also entails gauging if and how others can be influenced to act in a way that advances our interests.

21. 学习远不止于了解对方的实质性利益和潜在选择（以及相应的激励和惩罚措施的价值）。具体而言，它还包括了解如何通过举止、语调和节奏来更好地与他人互动。它还涉及评估是否以及如何影响他人，使其采取有利于我们利益的行动。

22. Maintaining situational awareness requires emotional balance and presence of mind. Paying heed involves more than merely processing the literal words that others speak. It also includes sensing their unspoken emotional nature and needs. Our own internal doubts and distractions can distort our perceptions.

22. 保持情境感知需要情绪稳定和头脑清醒。认真倾听不仅仅是理解他人所说的话，还包括感知他们未言明的情感和需求。我们自身的疑虑和分心也会扭曲我们的感知。

Emotional balance requires comfort with uncertainty and lack of total control. It also involves mastering paradoxes, such as being simultaneously calm and alert, patient and proactive, and creative and grounded.

情绪平衡需要坦然面对不确定性和缺乏完全掌控感。它还涉及掌握矛盾的应对之道，例如同时保持冷静和警觉、耐心和积极主动、富有创造力和脚踏实地。

NEGOTIATION SUCCESS

谈判成功

23. Measuring negotiation success is hard. We seldom know what our counterparts might have been willing to agree to, so we can’t access precisely how much value might be created and captured. Initial aspirations are an imperfect benchmark, as they may be unrealistically high or low.

23. 衡量谈判成功与否并非易事。我们很少知道对方真正愿意接受什么，因此无法准确评估可能创造和获取的价值。最初的期望值并非完美的衡量标准，因为它们可能过高或过低。

Impasse may occur for a variety of reasons: strategic behavior, interpersonal issues, or a failure of imagination. In some cases, there simply may be no room for agreement. Correspondingly, if we achieve an excellent outcome, it could be due to our skill and creativity, but maybe we were just lucky. Perhaps our counterpart was desperate for a deal or negotiated poorly.

僵局的出现可能由多种原因造成：策略性行为、人际关系问题或缺乏想象力。在某些情况下，可能根本就没有任何达成共识的余地。相应地，如果我们取得了令人满意的结果，这可能是由于我们的技巧和创造力，但也可能仅仅是运气好。或许对方急于达成交易，或者谈判技巧欠佳。

24. As a result, negotiation is a “wicked environment” for learning. Because negotiation is a complex process, isolating specific causes and effects is difficult. It is important to avoid mislearning from an outcome, good or bad, of a particular case. To learn from experience, we should focus on how we negotiated. Were we agile strategically and tactically?

24. 因此，谈判是一个“棘手的学习环境”。由于谈判是一个复杂的过程，很难将具体的原因和结果分离出来。重要的是避免从某个案例的结果（无论好坏）中得出错误的结论。为了从经验中学习，我们应该关注谈判的方式。我们在战略和战术上是否灵活？

25. Negotiation is an important, recurring process in our professional and personal lives. Even modest improvement in our skills can significantly improve our well-being. It can help us reach agreements that might otherwise slip through our fingers. It can enable us to create value through mutually beneficial trades. It can empower us to resolve small quarrels before they become major disputes. By negotiating well, we also benefit others—in our organizations, our homes, and our communities.

25. 谈判是我们职业和个人生活中一个重要且反复出现的过程。即使谈判技巧只有微小的提升，也能显著改善我们的幸福感。它能帮助我们达成那些原本可能从指缝间溜走的协议。它能让我们通过互惠互利的交易创造价值。它能让我们有能力在小争执演变成大纠纷之前就将其化解。通过有效的谈判，我们也能造福他人——无论是在我们的组织、家庭还是社区中。

#↩

Acknowledgments

致谢

As a graduate student, I took a negotiation seminar from Jim White, who happened to be visiting from the University of Michigan. In the first session, we did a simulation in which half of us played salespeople for a furniture manufacturer. The others were assigned to be buyers for a retail store. Each side received confidential instructions, and then we were paired up to negotiate a price for a mattress order. Even though each duo had been dealt the same cards, some buyers managed to get a bargain, while others paid much more than necessary. In the debriefing, we analyzed what tactics drove success and what explained failure. In simulations that followed, we tested our skill at settling lawsuits, handling family disputes, and resolving labor deadlocks. The fact that I remember these details decades later tells you that I was hooked from the start. I had found my calling.

读研究生时，我参加了吉姆·怀特（Jim White）的谈判研讨会，他当时正好从密歇根大学来访。第一节课，我们做了一个模拟练习：一半人扮演家具制造商的销售员，另一半人扮演零售店的采购员。双方都收到了保密指令，然后两两一组，就一份床垫订单的价格进行谈判。尽管每组人拿到的牌都一样，但有些采购员成功砍价，而有些采购员却支付了远超实际所需的价格。在课后总结中，我们分析了哪些策略促成了成功，哪些策略导致了失败。在接下来的模拟练习中，我们测试了自己处理诉讼、家庭纠纷和劳资僵局的能力。几十年后我还能记住这些细节，足以说明我从一开始就深深着迷。我找到了自己的使命。

Just as important—and just as fortuitous—that same year marked the launch of an interdisciplinary course on law and public policy taught by an all-star team of faculty. From the Harvard Law School, there was Phil Heymann, later deputy attorney general; Larry Tribe, the eminent constitutional scholar; and Stephen Breyer, who now sits on the United States Supreme Court. From Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government, we had economists Richard Zeckhauser and Edith Stokey; Howard Raiffa, a towering figure in decision science; and Tom Schelling, who later became a Nobel laureate. For a full year, we students sat back and enjoyed the ride as our teachers debated how to divide scarce resources, allocate risk, and promote efficiency. It was in this class that I first learned about game theory, decision trees, and linear programming. One didn’t have to be a genius to connect the conceptual dots, as many of those analytic tools mapped well to negotiation. (Just think of a personal injury claimant weighing the bird in the hand of a settlement offer against taking the chance of going to court and either winning more or losing everything.)

同样重要且恰逢其时的是，同年开设了一门由全明星教师团队执教的跨学科法律与公共政策课程。哈佛法学院的教师包括后来的副司法部长菲尔·海曼、杰出的宪法学者拉里·特里布以及现任美国最高法院大法官斯蒂芬·布雷耶。哈佛肯尼迪政府学院的教师则有经济学家理查德·泽克豪瑟和伊迪丝·斯托基、决策科学领域的泰斗霍华德·雷法以及后来的诺贝尔经济学奖得主汤姆·谢林。整整一年，我们这些学生都悠闲地聆听老师们探讨如何分配稀缺资源、分散风险以及提高效率。正是在这门课上，我第一次接触到了博弈论、决策树和线性规划。其实，要理解这些概念并不难，因为许多分析工具都与谈判密切相关。 （试想一下，一个人身伤害索赔人，在权衡和解方案的利弊，以及冒险上法庭可能赢得更多也可能输光一切的风险时，会作何感想。）

And so my professional career began. Using the basics that I had just learned, I first taught negotiation at New England Law School in Boston. At the time, it was one of only a handful of schools to offer such a course. Now negotiation is a standard part of the curriculum in professional programs throughout the United States and, increasingly, in universities throughout the world.

我的职业生涯由此开始。凭借刚刚学到的基础知识，我首先在波士顿的新英格兰法学院教授谈判技巧。当时，开设这门课程的院校屈指可数。如今，谈判技巧已成为美国各地专业课程的标配，并且在世界各地的大学中也越来越受欢迎。

Later I moved to MIT, where I joined a research team studying contentious environmental disputes that involved dozens of parties, huge costs, and complex technical issues. These real-world cases didn’t really fit the analytic boxes I had been taught. Other perspectives were needed to understand how such controversies arose and how, on occasion, they were constructively resolved.

后来我去了麻省理工学院，加入了一个研究团队，专门研究涉及数十方、耗资巨大且技术问题复杂的棘手环境纠纷。这些真实案例与我之前所学的分析方法截然不同。我们需要从其他视角来理解这类争议是如何产生的，以及在某些情况下，它们是如何得到建设性解决的。

Once again I was doubly lucky, for this was also when the Program on Negotiation was created. PON is an interuniversity consortium of Harvard, MIT, and Tufts faculty who share an interest in negotiation but who work in a wide variety of disciplines and fields. In those early years, we hosted regular “devising seminars” at which practitioners would dump real-world challenges in our laps. One month our guest might be an FBI hostage negotiator. The next month, it could be a federal official trying to site a repository for radioactive waste from nuclear power plants. After a guest would describe his or her particular case, our band of psychologists, anthropologists, urban planners, organizational theorists, and legal types would jump in with ideas from our various perspectives.

我再次感到双喜临门，因为就在那时，谈判项目（Program on Negotiation，简称PON）也成立了。PON是一个由哈佛大学、麻省理工学院和塔夫茨大学的教职人员组成的跨大学联盟，他们都对谈判感兴趣，但研究领域却十分广泛。在成立初期，我们定期举办“方案设计研讨会”，邀请实践者们提出各种现实挑战。这个月我们的嘉宾可能是联邦调查局的人质谈判专家，下个月则可能是一位联邦官员，他正在为核电站的放射性废料寻找合适的处置库。嘉宾描述完具体案例后，我们这群由心理学家、人类学家、城市规划师、组织理论家和法律专家组成的团队就会从各自的角度提出见解。

All of which is to say that I’ve had the good fortune to have great negotiation teachers and colleagues right from the start. I am deeply grateful to each one of them. I only wish that I had the wit to compose a rhyming tribute in the spirit of the New Yorker ’s annual Christmas poem, “Greetings, Friends!,” into which I could drop each of their names. And there are so many of them, I can thank only a relative few in the space here.

总而言之，我非常幸运，从一开始就遇到了许多优秀的谈判导师和同事。我对他们每一个人都深表感激。我真希望自己有足够的才华，能像《纽约客》每年圣诞诗歌《问候，朋友们！》那样，写一首押韵的赞歌，把他们的名字都写进去。他们人数众多，我在这里只能简单感谢其中几位。

Certain colleagues contributed significantly to the ideas in this book. Most of what I know about improvisation I learned from Frank Barrett, an organizational theorist and gifted jazz pianist. Kim Leary has taught me about psychodynamics and emotion. Debbie Kolb opened my eyes to how power is transacted in the shadow of explicit negotiation. Larry Susskind and Jim Sebenius have continually challenged my thinking in enormously helpful ways.

本书中的一些观点得到了几位同事的大力支持。我所了解的即兴演奏知识大多来自弗兰克·巴雷特，他是一位组织理论家，也是一位才华横溢的爵士钢琴家。金·利里教会了我心理动力学和情感方面的知识。黛比·科尔布让我意识到，权力是在公开谈判的阴影下运作的。拉里·萨斯金德和吉姆·塞贝纽斯不断地以极具启发性的方式挑战我的思维。

Many other colleagues and friends have generously shared their knowledge, support, and good company. These include Larry Bacow, Susan Carpenter, Amy Cuddy, Clark Freshman, Ran Kuttner, Carrie Menkel-Meadow, Richard Paisner, Barbara Pizer, Frank Sander, Sandra Sucher, Noah Susskind, Gerry Williams, and Gerry Zaltman. Bob Mnookin is on the list as well, though he warrants a special bow, as he introduced me to my agent, Jim Levine, who understood the core of my book even when it was in rough form. Jim helped shape the proposal, sharpened the writing, and found the right home for the book.

许多其他同事和朋友也慷慨地分享了他们的知识、支持和陪伴。他们包括 Larry Bacow、Susan Carpenter、Amy Cuddy、Clark Freshman、Ran Kuttner、Carrie Menkel-Meadow、Richard Paisner、Barbara Pizer、Frank Sander、Sandra Sucher、Noah Susskind、Gerry Williams 和 Gerry Zaltman。Bob Mnookin 也在其中，但他尤其值得特别感谢，因为是他介绍我认识了我的经纪人 Jim Levine。Jim 在我书稿还很粗糙的时候就理解了它的核心。Jim 帮助我完善了提案，润色了文笔，并找到了合适的出版商。

Thanks to the support of the Harvard Business School, where I’ve been these past twenty years, I’ve had a succession of smart and creative research associates. They have really been more like collaborators. Those whose research is reflected in this book include Lakshmi Balachandra, Captain David Dixon, Jill Morris Green, Jane Juliano, Jenny Illes, Georgia Levenson Keohane, Ellen Knebel, Dana Nelson, and Julianna Pillemer. It was a privilege to work with them, and it is a continuing delight to watch them make their way in the world.

感谢哈佛商学院的支持，过去二十年来我一直在这里工作，也因此结识了一批又一批才华横溢、富有创造力的研究伙伴。他们更像是我的合作伙伴。本书收录了他们的研究成果，其中包括拉克希米·巴拉钱德拉、大卫·迪克森上尉、吉尔·莫里斯·格林、简·朱利亚诺、珍妮·伊莱斯、乔治亚·莱文森·基欧汉、艾伦·克内贝尔、达娜·纳尔逊和朱莉安娜·皮勒默。与他们共事是我的荣幸，而看到他们在各自的领域取得成就，也让我倍感欣慰。

I’m grateful as well to my MBA and executive students—thousands of them, at this point—who were patient with me as I tested ideas in the classroom and searched for ways to express them effectively. Jazz teacher and horn player Ed Sarath taught me that in order to be creative, improvisers need to be 80 percent in their comfort zone but 20 percent beyond it. I live by that principle in the classroom, though that has meant that some of my pedagogical experiments failed. I’m sorry for any collateral damage and hope that my stumbling didn’t discourage students from taking risks themselves.

我还要感谢我的MBA和高管培训学员——目前为止，人数已达数千——他们在我课堂上尝试各种想法、探索有效表达方式的过程中，始终保持耐心。爵士乐老师兼号手埃德·萨拉斯（Ed Sarath）曾教导我，为了保持创造力，即兴演奏者需要80%处于舒适区，而20%则要跳出舒适区。我在课堂上奉行这一原则，尽管这意味着我的一些教学实验失败了。对于由此造成的任何损失，我深表歉意，并希望我的失误不会让学生们不敢冒险尝试。

Students provided many of the examples I describe in this book, sometimes long after having been in my course. Other friends have told me great negotiation stories as well. I’m especially grateful to Jeff Ansell, Courtney Cowart, Tim Crouse, Charlie Davidson, Erin Egan, Jim Golden, David Hoffman, Lt. Colonel Leonard Lira, Jack Parker, Sandy Ritchie, Derek Sanderson, and Colin Smith.

本书中我描述的许多案例都来自学生，有些甚至是在我课程结束后很久才提供的。其他朋友也跟我分享过很多精彩的谈判故事。我尤其感谢 Jeff Ansell、Courtney Cowart、Tim Crouse、Charlie Davidson、Erin Egan、Jim Golden、David Hoffman、Leonard Lira 中校、Jack Parker、Sandy Ritchie、Derek Sanderson 和 Colin Smith。

A half dozen people I’ve named to this point also read earlier drafts of the book. I am deeply grateful for their encouragement and their candid criticism. Thanks to them, I was able to clarify and provide support for some of my conclusions. They also helped me see what had to be scrapped. Rather than implicate those readers, I’ll simply bow to them deeply, grant them deniability, and take sole responsibility for the finished product.

到目前为止，我提到的六位读者也阅读过本书的早期草稿。我由衷感谢他们的鼓励和坦诚的批评。正因为有了他们的帮助，我才能澄清并佐证我的一些结论。他们也帮助我认识到哪些内容必须舍弃。我不会牵连这些读者，而是向他们致以深深的谢意，尊重他们的意见，并独自承担最终成书的全部责任。

Turning ideas in one’s head into words on a page is a physical act. So is turning those pages into a book. For many years, my assistant MaryAlice Wood was my partner in that enterprise, as drafts were revised and chapters were shuffled around. I am deeply grateful for MaryAlice’s patience, dedication, and friendship. Three years ago, Christina Lau took over the daunting task of managing me. The care, insight, and good humor that she brought to this work will serve her well as she embarks on her legal career.

将脑海中的想法转化为纸上的文字是一项实际操作。将这些文字汇集成书也是如此。多年来，我的助手玛丽爱丽丝·伍德一直是我在这项工作中的伙伴，我们一起修改草稿，调整章节顺序。我由衷地感谢玛丽爱丽丝的耐心、奉献和友谊。三年前，克里斯蒂娜·刘接手了管理我的艰巨任务。她为这项工作带来的细致、洞察力和幽默感，将对她未来的法律职业生涯大有裨益。

I also thank Kim Ducharme, working in collaboration with Chris Pullman, for creating the illustrations in this book. Using words alone to describe the dynamic, nonlinear nature of negotiation is a challenge. Kim’s freehand drawings have helped bring improvisation to life. And in conjunction with the book, thanks also go to Jesse McDougall and Cally Wheeler for designing and developing my website ( www.michaelwheeler.com ). Readers can find research updates, analysis of current negotiations in the news, and instructive videos on the site.

我还要感谢金·杜沙姆（Kim Ducharme）与克里斯·普尔曼（Chris Pullman）合作，为本书创作插图。仅凭文字来描述谈判的动态性和非线性本质是一项挑战。金的手绘插图生动地展现了谈判的即兴性。此外，我还要感谢杰西·麦克杜格尔（Jesse McDougall）和卡莉·惠勒（Cally Wheeler）设计并开发了我的网站（www.michaelwheeler.com）。读者可以在该网站上找到最新的研究成果、对新闻中当前谈判的分析以及教学视频。

Hearty thanks to the talented crew at Simon & Schuster. Emily Loose, who was my editor initially, pushed me to reorganize the book and add important new material—specifically, the chapters on critical moments, closing, and negotiation ethics. Ben Loehnen, who saw the book home, pared my prose so as to make it more compelling. He reminded me that good writing, like jazz, is about the notes that you don’t play. Brit Hvide masterfully managed the production process and Jonathan Evans is the best production editor I’ve ever had the good fortune to work with. (And I apologize for ending that sentence with a preposition.) I’m most grateful, as well, to Akasha Archer for her work on the interior design.

衷心感谢西蒙与舒斯特出版社才华横溢的团队。我的初稿编辑艾米丽·卢斯(Emily Loose)敦促我重新组织书稿，并添加重要的全新内容——特别是关于关键时刻、成交技巧和谈判伦理的章节。负责本书最终出版的本·洛恩(Ben Loehnen)精简了我的文字，使其更具吸引力。他提醒我，好的写作就像爵士乐，在于那些你没有演奏的音符。布里特·赫维德(Brit Hvide)出色地管理了整个制作流程，而乔纳森·埃文斯(Jonathan Evans)是我有幸合作过的最优秀的制作编辑。（很抱歉，我这句话以介词结尾。）此外，我还要特别感谢阿卡莎·阿彻(Akasha Archer)为本书所做的内页设计工作。

Finally, profound thanks to Candace, Kate, and Cally for their love and support. Their patience, optimism, and humor have seen me through.

最后，衷心感谢坎迪斯、凯特和卡莉的爱与支持。她们的耐心、乐观和幽默一直陪伴我走过这段艰难的时期。

#↩

Award-winning Harvard Business School professor MICHAEL WHEELER has taught negotiation to thousands of MBA students, executives, managers, and public officials from companies and organizations around the world. Wheeler is editor of the Negotiation Journal, published by the Program on Negotiation at Harvard Law School, and co-chairs the board of the nonprofit Consensus Building Institute. He lives in historic Gloucester, Massachusetts, his hometown.

屡获殊荣的哈佛商学院教授迈克尔·惠勒（Michael Wheeler）曾为来自世界各地企业和机构的数千名MBA学生、高管、经理和政府官员讲授谈判技巧。惠勒是哈佛法学院谈判项目出版的《谈判期刊》（Negotiation Journal）的编辑，也是非营利组织共识构建研究所（Consensus Building Institute）的联合主席。他居住在他的家乡——历史悠久的马萨诸塞州格洛斯特市。
